reviewText: The gymnastic chase scenes of the new James Bond film, 'Casino Royale' are so stunning, we find ourselves needing a break from the whole game.  With breathtaking camera angles and surprises at every turn, we get a whole new Bond.  Not to mention Daniel Craig who is easily one of the best Bonds since Sean Connery.  He isn't as suave as the former or Pierce Brosnan, but his cool, steely demeanor make him easily as confident and more to be reckoned with.  As one might expect, there are some sweaty hands dealt at an exotic gambling resort, but the urgency of terrorism meated out with card sharks for jihad funds and bomb threats give us a new urgency.  Certainly the tension ups the ante quite a bit.  Bond's new female sidekick, Vesper Lynd (Eva Green) has a mysterious allure, and the new Bond demonstrates a love interest--for a  sensitive side--to go with the lust of lush bikinis and evening gowns.  The softer side seems natural enough to provide a needed slow down to the plot and an increased interest from the female audience, but it's not enough to destroy the suave and witty nuances uttered from the coolest private eye ever conceived.  Co-written by Paul Haggis ('Million Dollar Baby' and 'Crash') the script is sharp and funny enough to increase the venue's hand and raise it quite a bit.  Satisfying to the last deal, 'Casino Royale' is a sure bet for moviegoers.

reviewText: When it comes to follow-ups to a Bond movie, one must understand the needed presence of some certain unalienable elements. One always makes use of the capacity to build upon the achievements of the previous film. With Casino Royale, a film that sets itself apart from the others due to the very nature of it being the first mission for James Bond, a Bond who is still green in the field and happens from time to time to be a bit sloppy, the creators managed to not only keep the preset elements, but give them some substance as to what they mean as well.Since the inception of the Bond film and its release back in 1962, the movie always began with a pair of tracing white dots following each other from left to right across a black screen. Once they reached the edge, the view through a gun barrel would pan in from the right following a well-dressed man walking in a plain white room. At the middle of the screen, the man in view turns and shoots straight ahead. Down pours a puddle of red blood, and the gun barrel wavers left and right.The gun barrel scene is iconic. It sets apart the entire canon of Bond films from the botched rehash attempts made. It was the brain child of an incredibly talented visual designer named Maurice Binder, and has been lovingly adopted and modified over the last 44 years.James Bond creator Ian Fleming made the impulsive mistake early on in his career to sell the rights to his first novel Casino Royale whereas he held onto the other novels until the arrival of Albert R. Broccoli and Harry Saltzman. The result was both an agitation and a hidden blessing.For years it was presumed that the movie Dr. No was Bond's first mission. It premiered in 1962 and portrayed a hardened Connery with a roguish panache and a smarmy self confidence that the world over has known to accept as the epitomic portrayal of James Bond. All fans of the novels know that Bond was not always perfectly in control though, and that flaw in temperament is evident in Casino Royale.A few years ago when Sony Pictures bought out MGM Studios, suddenly all the cards fell into place as it were. The long pined-for rights to Casino Royale had finally come back into focus along with the companies that owned the rest of James Bond, and so began a tiresome heated production of one of the greatest gambles in James Bond history.For starters, Sony Pictures is a giant in Hollywood that very much wants to make as much money as possible from anything it does. Therefore it felt that by milking the Bond machine for everything it had, they wanted to go nuts-to-the-door spectacular. Bond had become famous for its use of incredible gadgets, statuesque women and a fairly untarnished hero. Eon Productions, the company now in the hands of Broccoli's daughter Barbara and step-son Michael G. Wilson, wanted to take the less popular approach and show the hero in his early days . . . without the toys and the posh exterior.As for how the proceedings between Sony and Eon transpired, I don't know truly other than that Eon got what they wanted in the long haul. And by doing so, one of the most fan-shaking decisions came about. They needed a new Bond. Pierce Brosnan carried the mantle for seven years. He had played James Bond - 007 in four very-well received movies. He was by every means still popular in the eyes of the fans of the films, but mostly in the eyes of the young fans who only knew the franchise led by him. Letting Brosnan go was a decision that brought about wide-spread panic and endless speculation about "The New Bond."Then the name game began. Ewan MacGregor? Hugh Jackman? Clive Owen? Adrian Paul? Christian Bale? Web sites popped up like mushrooms after a hard rain. In particular was the rash of sites dedicated to the return of Pierce Brosnan. Many a fan, in my opinion, never took into account the notion that in Brosnan's last picture Die Another Day he was in his fifties and clearly showing signs of age in his face and in his hair. I'm just as much a fan of keeping along a talented actor, but the face needs to match the requirements of an ageless hero who moves with time itself.Production on the next Bond movie was quickly becoming the largest gap between films since the wait between Licence to Kill and GoldenEye. Two and a half years passed before Eon Productions came forward and finally announced that Casino Royale would indeed be the film to be made. It was then six months following that the company made it public to the world who the next man would be. And his name was Craig . . . Daniel Craig.Daniel Craig is an actor who bears little familiarity in the States. His greatest claims to fame were crime dramas in Britain. Only such pictures as Lara Croft: Tomb Raider and Layer Cake presented him to a small portion of film audiences in the USA, so his great reveal was understandably less than warmly received. But I prefer to remember history rather than let it fall to the wayside. Some 40 years ago when Cary Grant was an option to play Bond, the producers favored rather an unknown actor by the name of Sean Connery. It was a choice that even Bond creator Ian Fleming had serious doubts about. Just look how wrong everyone was.And now, 44 years later, just look how wrong everyone was again. Having the man who directed GoldenEye at the helm, Casino Royale was the first Bond film in history to both redefine and reinforce the strengths of the franchise. The world will realize that Daniel Craig is James Bond, no matter how rugged, untamed, temperamental, inexperienced and brash he comes off.And so we come back to the beginning. How does one reinforce the norms of such an old franchise while at the same time keeping it new? It goes into Fleming's description of what it takes for Bond to become 007. He needs two kills to his name. And so instead of starting the movie with the usual (and expected) gun barrel sequence, we instead get to see a black and white noir-ish scene interlaced with grainy black and white footage of a brutal conflict in a lavatory. We understand that these are to be Bond's first two kills. In a clever work of editing, we get to see the second kill before the first. Why? Because the first one ends with the view through a gun barrel of Bond standing against a white wall, he turns to face his opponent and fires one shot straight ahead. Crimson blood pours down the screen, and then we are treated to the opening titles.Elation comes in so many forms, but none so much as being gratified so much by something that has kept you bated for four years. The gun barrel is a mere sequence that hardly lasts more than 15 seconds at the most. Casino Royale's decision to make the audience work for it is one of the best decisions that I could ever hope for.The title sequence by Daniel Kleinman features psychedelic representations of silhouetted spies running amok amid lethal playing card and casino motifs. All is loosely matched to a subtle rock theme by Chris Cornell entitled "You Know My Name." It's a song that has the capacity to grow on someone after each listening. The titles also sustain and depart from the established norm. They contain silhouettes, which have become unanimous with the style of Maurice Binder. However a lack of any representation of the female form is seen, which lends it to more reminiscent of the opening title for Dr. No while also looking somewhat like the titles for Licence to Kill.The silhouettes are of Bond and several nameless assailants in various forms of combat while at the same time being pitted at the mercy of lethal playing card accents. We are also treated to a teaser image of the Bond girl when a gun sight crosses over a queen's face revealing Eva Green who plays Vesper Llynd. At first she is revealed from the queen of hearts, but the other end of her motif is that of the queen of spades, a clever method of foreshadowing a nuance to her character. The titles conclude with a slowly on-walking silhouette that transforms into Daniel Craig giving a cold stare, very much a serious and fierce take on his ageless character.The movie opens up onto a military camp in Uganda where we are first treated to the introduction of the film's villain Le Chiffre. He's a tall gaunt man bearing a familiar look to that of Peter Lorre (who played Le Chiffre in the 1954 inception of Casino Royale presented by the show Climax!) and a little bit of an evil Macaulay Culkin mixed in. This Le Chiffre has a few more tweaks though, a positive step toward making him look a bit more sinister. He has a scar over his left eye, he has a tear duct that cries blood and he habitually uses an inhaler. This man is the mathematically inclined banker and investor for several terrorist factions around the world.In the same locale, we find Bond on his first mission as a double-0. He's commanded by MI6 to capture a suspicious, and horribly burn-scarred, suspect named Mollaka. Things go awry when Bond's aide blows their cover causing the incredibly agile target to tear off into a construction site with Bond in hot pursuit. The target is chased up scaffolding, over a couple of cranes and back down again through a Nambutan embassy where 007 finally get his man. Upon seeking his escape, Bond uses his prisoner as a wrecking ball until he ends up in a courtyard surrounded by armed guards. With everything to lose, Bond takes the risk of swiping his prisoner's backpack, shooting him dead and blowing up a series of gas tanks allowing for his escape; all of which is caught on surveillance camera.It's a great achievement on the part of the film makers to let us believe completely that James Bond could die at any second despite us already knowing that he carries on to fulfill other missions. It's expert writing and directing, because I was constantly on edge wondering if this will be the one that finally ends the life of 007. But it's also more than that. There are instances of other movies with spies in them that look to copy what James Bond has done, coming never so close as to the grandeur and originality of what Fleming and Eon came up with.The resulting mayhem causes 007 to make headlines as a murdering spy, turning MI6 into the laughing stock of London. M, played once again by Judi Dench, throws a considerable fit when she learns about Bond's failure and code violations. She becomes even more surprised to find that he's broken into her home to find him casually browsing through a suspect database on her laptop.Film consistency continues with this remarkably hilarious scene. It shows that an untamed Bond is even more prone to insubordination that he would be as a tenured member of the secret service. The only reason he ever gets away with anything he does is because he's so good at his job, which his superiors constantly find themselves conflicted over. Bond's free thinking and unconventionality rob the straight-laced affiliates of prestige and success. Anyone else who violates a direct order or international code would face serious consequences. The apex of Bond's punishment though is nothing more than a terse reprimand.Following the suggestion of M, Bond looks to keep himself out of the public eye (if only for a brief moment). He travels to Nassau based on a lead found from the material he swiped from the bomb maker he assassinated. His nonchalant meandering allows him the opportunity to fake his identity as a valet driver, and create a tremendous ruckus in the parking lot sending the entire security staff of a high-end hotel to investigate, thus leaving the surveillance office vacant and open for Bond's perusing leisure.What makes me the most jealous of James Bond is his immaculate skill and grace in wandering about in places he doesn't belong. Not only does he do it with such stealth, but he's cocky about it too. Every environment becomes his playground the instant he steps into it.While placing occupancy for a room in the hotel, he cleverly manufactures a charismatic lie to gain knowledge of the subject he witnessed in the surveillance office. His charm of course is placed on that of a lovely blonde woman, the easiest target for 007 to interrogate without making his efforts seem like an interrogation. After he finds out what he needs, he manages to successfully track the man, Dimitrious, down, beat him on a whim at a game of Texas Hold'em, win his gorgeous Aston Martin and seduce his smoldering Latin wife Solange.In a surprising turn of events though, Solange is abandoned with only a bottle of Bollinger to keep her company as Bond whisks away to a Miami airport in an attempt to find what her husband is up to. They meet up in a crowded terminal where they share wicked stares and a fierce yet silent knife fight. Bond comes out the winner, and the loser of the battle waits out the rest of his time on screen unnoticed.In the scuffle though, Bond loses track of the materials that he saw the man place in the terminal for the next contact to take up and carry out the terror plot. But with skillful use of ingenuity, 007 uses his last victim's phone to call up the next target in a crowd. Bond finds his guy and continues pursuit. The situation escalates when the man being followed puts himself behind a locked door. Bond calls up MI6 seeking assistance only to be met with smarmy bureaucracy. His quickly detailed explanation soon puts them into motive panic however just in time for Bond to realize he didn't need their help at all.As is common with 007 films of the past, ridiculously exciting action set pieces materialize in unlikely places. This one shows no weakness or fatigue. Bond and an the intimidating terrorist play fisticuffs in the front seat of a fuel truck rocketing across the tarmac toward a prototype jetliner that our main villain Le Chiffre is counting on going up in flames so that he can make a killing on the stock market. Unbeknownst to him though, our man Bond comes through in a clench, putting him at a serious financial disadvantage.Thus the first act concludes with M not so much apologizing to Bond for having a higher sense of what he was up to than anyone thought, but rather a commendation for strength of character. After all, if M were to ever thank 007, it would only be spoken in sarcasm.Le Chiffre organizes a high stakes poker game at the title location in Montenegro to win back everything that he lost on the non-disaster. With great reluctance, James Bond is staked in the game by M, only because he's the best card player in the service.For grand entrances of the famed Bond girls of old, this film seems to shift that stock to the lesser of the two. Solange was introduced riding a valiant steed across the beach. In the case of Bond's biggest crush though, treasury executive Vesper Llynd just sort of shows up and drops into a seat in front of James and announces, "I'm the money."Bond retorts, "Every penny of it." (That's the only hint of Moneypenny in this movie; maybe in Bond 22 we'll see the real deal.)What is surprising about this film (apart from other new things) is that Vesper's character is much more rounded out and multidimensional than the usual heroine. This is a woman that laughs, cries, sulks, seethes, screams and seduces. She has the same amount of dynamic that Diana Rigg did when she played the woman to be James' wife in On Her Majesty's Secret Service.Perhaps in the process of getting caught up on the reverie of finally seeing my favorite film hero on the screen again I neglected to mention that the scenery and cinematography of this movie surpass even the greatest of installments in the anthology. The vistas are absolutely breathtaking. It qualifies as being one of the films in which the places that James goes are places I would desperately like to visit some day.Casino Royale then steam rolls into the segment of the film which I refer to as the Fleming section. It's the content that was ultimately pried from the pages of Ian Fleming's first Bond novel. With the timely adjustments to fit the modern age, it plays out like an impressive cat and mouse game of high stakes gambling.A sudden shift in the momentum is a dangerous calculation, but I'm slightly biased in this endeavor. I like Bond more for the subtleties in his character and the fancy quirks he uses to really upend others. One charming example is his disruption of the game to have a waiter bring what becomes his infamous Vodka Martini, shaken not stirred.The director is wise though to not simply hash out a half-hour long poker game on the screen. Select cuts and recesses are installed to keep tempo moving. We have instances where Bond is actually forced to look after the villain and make sure he doesn't get ousted before the end of the game. A number of terrorists show up unannounced and voice their concern over Le Chiffre's ability to return their money that he lost.Bond exercises his savage brutality as Vesper looks on in complete disbelief. A chilling shower scene later on builds credit to her character's inexperience in the film. We also get to see Bond for the first time in a great while in a truly perilous situation having much to do with his famous beverage. For a movie to make you believe that James Bond could die on his first mission is phenomenal storytelling.The climactic scene at the poker table is heavily rewarding after all the drama that ensued with Bond going for broke, losing everything then being graciously reentered through the help of a long time (first time met) friend Felix Leiter. Aficionados of the game with balk at his highly improbable finish, but to them I give the middle finger and a smug, "Good day to you." It's a Bond movie. Stuff like that is supposed to happen.To celebrate his grand victory, Bond and Vesper have dinner alone in Casino Royale's dining room. The elation is short lived with she steps away briefly only to be kidnapped. In pursuit of his lovely, Bond manages to accomplish one of the most heartbreaking of exploits . . . he murders his Aston Martin. To make matters worse, he gets kidnapped afterwards too.What follows next is the scene that I feared to see because of the contextual nature of it. Like never before seen, Bond is brutally tortured. But like I had never seen before in my life, it became one of the most visceral and yet hilarious things I had ever witnessed. To merely explain it would do such great injustice.Beyond the climactic turnout of that scene, we come to the slow-roving finale in which the story twists when you don't expect it to. Bond falls in love with Vesper but soon finds himself once again caught off guard. And like no Bond before, it actually sets itself up for a sequel.Now what was that name again? Ian Fleming took the name James Bond from a book called Birds of the West Indies. It just so happened to be the name of the author. He chose the name because it had no great importance or attitude about it. It was just a name. Yet from mediocrity came something internationally famous.It all began in a casino in London in the movie Dr. No. A non-descript man sits at a table playing baccarat. His face goes unseen. Across from him is a dark haired woman in a red dress. As the hand proceeds, he ends up beating her. She has an understandable look of irritation on her face. The man says to her as she's writing out her check for more money to stay in the game, "I admire your courage, Miss . . .""Trench," she replies. She looks up at him and adds, "Sylvia Trench." She then says to him, "I admire your luck, Mr. . ."We then finally get to see his face as he slowly lights a cigarette in his mouth and replies, "Bond," and then mockingly adds, "James Bond."In its inception, Bond, James Bond was meant only as a joke. When Guy Hamilton directed Goldfinger, the film that is commonly referred to as the one that set the Bond formula, the introduction was used again. The film to follow was Thunderball, the highest adjusted grossing Bond movie of all time. It was both an expansion on the Bond formula as well as a fist against all the critics who never liked Goldfinger, and the fist takes its form in the guise of a femme fatale who ridicules Bond for his playboy nature. She is the one to call him by the name "Mr. Bond, James Bond." And so from then on, in every film following the character of Bond always introduced himself that way at least once.So what has become a tradition is surprisingly the greatest pay off in Casino Royale. With all the remarkable set pieces, action sequences, dramatic diversions and dreamy locales we get the famous introduction as the very last piece of dialogue in the movie.Following through the end credits the words "James Bond Will Return" roll up from the bottom. A great sense of apprehension and relief consumes me. It means that I will get to see a great actor return to play Bond again . . . in two year's time.I know exactly what I'll be doing on November 7th, 2008.
summary: The longest review of Casino Royale you're likely to see

reviewText: Like many other Bond fans, I genuinely enjoyed the Brosnan films...up until the second half of Die Another Day.  Goldeneye and it's slick, underrated follow-up Tomorrow Never Dies are modern Bond classics in my opinion, and The World Is Not Enough is consistently interesting when things aren't randomly exploding.  However, an invincible Bond was getting tiresome, and in these more cynical days, Bond fans needed a return to Ian Fleming's dark, somewhat sociopathic protagonist.Although the realistic but generally dull Jason Bourne and the silly, over-the-top Jack Bauer managed to steal some of Bond's thunder in the past few years, the makers of Casino Royale stopped these rather temporary franchises dead in their tracks.Martin Campbell, Paul Haggis, and the Purvis-Wade combo have created a flim that is both new and old.  It's new in that it shows us the edgier, harder side of Bond that fans haven't seen since Dalton's performance in Licence to Kill.  It also gives fans a taste of the nihilism and narcissism that surrounded Bond's character in Ian Fleming's novels.  It's old because the film harkens back to the classic Connery films, with lush cinematography, a bold musical score, and some truly spectacular action sequences.Then there's Daniel Craig himself.  While it may not be the most familiar or accessible Bond performance (that honor goes to Connery in From Russia With Love), it is in my opinion the overall best.  Physically and psychologically, Craig transforms himself into the iconic British agent and brilliantly handles both the action sequences and the quieter moments of contemplation and dialogue.Overall, Casino Royale achieved the impossible and reinvigorated a franchise that's nearly half a century old.  I just hope that the follow-up is as inspired and competently-handled as this was.

reviewText: This film starts in monochrome to suggest the distant past. James Bond is on an assignment to eliminate a traitor in a very dramatic way. [No doubling considered?] In Uganda we see suitcases filled with money - for a safe investment. In Madagascar a man is chased to a construction site, and ends in an embassy. Will such actions be repeated? The code word is "Ellipsis". Bond uses high-tech methods to gain information from a cellular phone. Can `M' trust Bond? He needs a vacation. [Note the informal dress compared to earlier decades.] Bond uses a ruse to get the name of a car owner. Who is Mr. Demetrious? Bond wins big at cards. A telephone call sends Bond to Miami. A bag is switched, and this leads to more action with a fuel truck. Bond prevents a disaster at the airport. Shorting stocks after 9/11 made a fortune for a few.On the train to Montenegro Bond gets his cash. Vesper Lynd brings the message, and they match their wits. Later there is a high stakes card game. During a break there is a lot of action. Back at the table Le Chiffre wins big. Did Bond lose because of his ego? An ally advances fund to Bond. But another drink is too much. A phone call brings help. Vesper arrives in time. Bond is back in the game. Fortune smiles on Bond - a straight flush! Le Chiffre has lost all. There is a car chase in the night, and a crash. Bond is captured and tortured in a gross scene. Wil he give up the password? Will Bond be saved? Who will be next? Then Bond and Vesper spend time on the beach. How long will that last? Is there a problem with the funds on deposit? There is exciting action that causes a house to collapse into the waters of Venice. The last scenes wrap up the loose ends. Is there a last message for Bond?The film was changed a lot from the original novel, which was simpler and better. The old theme song is repeated when they roll the credits. There was a lot of product placement. This film has the most acrobatic James Bond; was it CGI? The script seems slower than the classic films from the 1960s. I think this film has an over-complicated plot with too many scenes. It has one educational part when it shows how a "heart attack" can be created. [Remind you of "The Parallax View"?] The exotic locales continue to entertain.

reviewText: Talk about beating the odds.  Twenty-one films and some forty-four years into cinema's longest-running franchise, the Bond filmmakers have managed to redefine the character with resounding success.  In fact, as of this writing, Casino Royale is the highest-grossing 007 adventure ever.I've seen them all, and I've always held onto the belief that Connery IS and ALWAYS WILL BE James Bond.  But Daniel Craig almost made me forget Connery completely!  Oh sure, the early Connery films are still great fun, and the sheer nostalgia of his era can't really be ignored.  But THIS is Ian Fleming's James Bond the way he was meant to be: Cold as ice, infused with lethal cunning and nerves of steel.The real fun (and the real payoff for longtime fans) is watching how the writers, and Craig, slowly "create" Bond for the audience.  [SPOILERS AHEAD] There's no Q branch, no Miss Moneypenny, almost no gadgets and precious few glib one-liners.  But all the things that fans would come to love about the character are subtely laid out in the course of nearly 2 1/2 hours.  And if that sounds like a long time, you obviously haven't seen the movie yet.  Second-time director Martin Campbell (of Goldeneye, in which Bond was recreated in the person of Pierce Brosnan) piles on the action from the outset.  The construction-scene chase alone packs in more mind-blowing action in 10 minutes most movies manage in two hours.  And the scene that could have, in lesser hands, brought the action to a grinding halt (the poker game) actually provides some of the film's greatest thrills.Two minor quibbles that probably won't matter to casual fans: Considering this is a 2-disc set with many extras, why is there no trailer for the film?  We get trailers for Spider-man 3, Rocky Balboa, The Pursuit of Happyness and others, but not Casino Royale?  And I wish MGM/Columbia would have maintained the same package design as the previous Bond films, just so this one won't look kinda odd on the shelf next to my 20 other 007 adventures.  But again, minor complaints.Even if you're not a James Bond fan, give this one a try.  It's easily the best action film of 2006.  And [looks around to make sure no one is listening]. . .Daniel Craig IS Bond!
summary: Everything old is new again (and that's a GOOD thing)

reviewText: There were moments... I admit some jokes were very good (I thought Bond's comment on vodka/martini in the bar was hilarious) and practically every scene with Judy Dench was great.Madds Mikkelsen as Le Chiffre was not bad, though personally I think he had tonns of quiet menace as Tristan in King Arthur - where he looked much more dangerous than in this movie.Craig was slightly better than initially expected but he lacks charm, charisma, humour and wit that is traditionally linked with Bond's role. I remember watching the movie and having a funny thought that it was quite obvious why Lara Croft dropped her boyfriend (Craig played Lara's former boyfriend in the first Croft movie - and she had to save the looser at the end).I hated the absence of logic in actions and characters. The best example is the first chase where Bond shouts to his associate not to shoot the guy running away as he needs him alive. He them proceeds to chase him all over the place, creates a major diplomatic incident and then shoots the guy himself. If he needed to pick up some items from the dead man (as it is shown) it would have been considerably more logical to shoot him in the very beginning and same himself some heavy running.Same with characters. The best way for the girl in the movie would have been to tell Bond everything and get his cooperation. But that would have been out of the type for a femme fatale (who does not have much use for brains, obviously).What I definitely did not like was all the teary-bleary love story that clogged the plot so much that at moments all action stopped to permit another soul-wrenching conversation with Eva Green's heroine. Being a woman myself, I suppose I should have loved the soppy interludes but they were way too pathetic. When the heroine looks tragic all the time in all circumstances, it is really difficult to feel anything for her when the tragedy finally happens.In fact all the sentimentality and wooden acting is the reason I give the movie no more than 3 stars. Have been watching Bond movies for years and I simply do not feel like a "New Age" sensitive Bond with a broken heart or a Bond without humor and charisma.I shudder at the thought that I now have to wait 10 (20?) years for Craig to be replaced with somebody more "bondish". What a pity.
summary: should have stayed in the toilet where it belongs

reviewText: CASINO ROYAL (new version) was a in my opinion a far from the standard James Bond picture and not particularly good.  The original was a campy comedy, outdated for today standards, but this one borders with a tragedy.BLU-RAY quality is the best thing for this picture. Images are crisp and clear; sound outstanding. You can almost feel in those exotic places excluded Miami which is a fake. I still cannot understand why not even the exterior of the real Miami Airport was used.Obviously CASINO ROYALE was made for the new USA generation where fantasy does not exist; sex is bad, killing is good and drinking is in between.  This James Bond is a tortured fiend, more resembling Jason Bourne than the character portrait by Sean Connery.If you are interested in good filmed action, PG-13 violence and exotic (albeit not 100% real ) locations this  is your movie.  If you are looking for fun look elsewhere
summary: EXCELLENT QUALITY NOT SO FUNNY PICTURE

reviewText: I admit I was smitten by Ian Fleming's James Bond epic Cold War spy notion back when we used to see such adventure film fare on the big screen at the local drive-in theater (for those who do know of that 1950s and early 1960s institution check Wikipedia) when we were more interested in some "hot" date more than in the movie. I think the first one in the Bond series was Doctor No with Sean Connery in the Bond role. There have been some twenty-odd Bond films since (and many copy-cat films) and a succession of Bond replacements. Frankly, despite the good performance here by Daniel Craig as Bond (and as almost always by Judi Dench in anything she does) this Bond notion I think has gotten stale. The virtue of Connery's Bond was that while he was a wily and steadfast advocate of the "free world" he brought something of a slapstick air about the whole thing. This one, premised on fighting the "war on terrorism" by foiling a poker-loving "banker," made me long for a cheeky Cold War spy night performance by Connery done with far less physical and technical whiz-bang action and more guile.
summary: When James Bond Re-Tread The World

reviewText: By adding my own review ofCasino Royaleto all these others -- making mine the 1,268th -- I expect to accomplish nothing more than to conjoin my voice to the chorus of praise for the best James Bond movie in years.  Until this came along, I had written the franchise off.  But I enjoyed this so much, I didn't mind buying it twice, first on DVD, then later upgrading toCasino Royale [Blu-ray].  The hi-def picture was absolutely phenomenal, and whenever I want to impress upon someone the difference Blu-ray makes, I pull this one out as the demo.  From the retro grainy black-&-white introduction, thru sunny tropical locations, to the darker European countryside and luxurious interiors, a full range of textures and tones is sampled, making this engrossing story beautiful to look at, something to savor over multiple viewings.  Daniel Craig's powerful performance makes it all the sweeter.Selecting the actor to play Fleming's iconic character is Hollywood's equivalent to the Vatican picking a new pope.  In the limbo between films, the people gather and wait.  When the studio finally announced amidst the usual éclat that Craig had been chosen to fill the tuxedo, the surprising selection was a signal that something major was going down.  It was a ballsy break with tradition, and it paid off.  Craig owned that part, and his Bond will be what future generations will compare his successors to. Of course it helped that he had a topnotch script, which hews closer to the novel than any Bond film since aroundFrom Russia with Love, after which they became increasingly distracted with silly gadgets (exceptingOn Her Majesty's Secret Service).  The stuff about the footrace and the tanker at the airport were added, along with the stuff on the boat with Vesper in the epilogue.  But the salient points of the rest of the story have some basis in the novel.  It distinguishes itself further with its emotional detail, beginning with a pre-credit sequence marked with a psychological gamesmanship that was maintained on some level throughout the rest of the film.  It's tightly crafted, wasting nothing, slamming into Chris Cornell's "You Know My Name" through the barrel of the trademark gunshot and swirl, then moving through the locales, hewn seamlessly through great editing and strong musical cues of variations of the theme.  The pacing gives the story enough time to breath, but never lingers.  It flows.  Even the card game itself to me was exciting, and I don't play cards.I was prompted to write this review today because I ordered the Blu-ray edition ofQuantum of Solace, and anticipating its arrival has got me appreciating all over again just how goodCasino Royalewas.  At first disappointed thatQuantum of Solacedidn't have the same subtleties asCasino Royale, I've since come to see it as part two of this one great story.  It should be here Saturday.  In the meantime, I'll refresh the continuity by watching this one again.________________________________________________________
summary: By the current count, the 1,268th review for Casino Royale

reviewText: This is the first James Bond movie I've seen from beginning to end,and I have to say,I'm impressed.It's engrossing,even if the casino scenes are overly long.Daniel Craig plays 007 as simultaneously intelligent (he does know about computers&his; numerous cellphones),tough,tender,and ruthless.He's rougher around the edges than the debonair Pierce Brosnan in the campy "Die Another Day"...and a diamond in the rough.In "Casino Royale",James Bond has more depth of character than a womanizer&superspy.He; gets betrayed,he falls in love,he suffers,and one wonders if his suffering at the hands of Le Chiffre is a nod to Mel Gibson's "Passion."Eva Green as Vesper Lynd is a complicated love interest.She enjoys Bond's intellectual thrusts and parries...and seems trustworthy.(After all,her first name means "prayer.")Le Chiffre is a bland Bond villain.He has asthma attacks and a homoerotic interest in 007 (despite a scantily clad ladyfriend),but beyond that,his villainy isn't understandable,or all that threatening."Casino Royale" is a perfect combination of intrigue,action,and romance.It's A New Hope for the James Bond series.

reviewText: I am not a Bond fan. And, after Pierce Brosnan did a horrible job (in my opinion) at being Bond, I didn't ever think I would be one.But, then here come Daniel Craig. Pretty much being the best Bond, in my opinion. Yes, there was Sean Connery, but for my generation, Craig = Bond.In this re-telling of Bond's beginnings as a 00 agent, we get a naive, daring, and egocentric Bond that will stop at nothing to get the bad guy, and the girl. I loved the storyline, how it unfolded, and how it was expertly told. Craig, along with Eva Green, do an excellent job of selling the plot and reeling you in. The action is top-notch and Craig looks like he's been Bond all along.My only rant is the sequence when Bond and Vesper go off on vacation. I understand that it sets up the last scenes of the movie, bu they were a bit pretentious to me.However, if you are a Bond fan, this will definately get you into the series again. If you aren't a Bond fan, this will make you one. And, if Pierce Brosnan's snotty Bond made you sick, then Daniel Craig's attitude driven Bond will make you forget Brosnan even existed. An overall 5/5 stars.

reviewText: The Good Things*Excellent action scenes, stunts, and special effects.*Excellent picture quality and cameramanship. Very different style.*Excellent portrayal of James Bond; the best since Sean Connery. Daniel Craig best captures a roughness and attitude that the other Bond films lacked (and the original novels actually had).*It's largely accurate to the original novel. Numerous liberties with the story serve to make it updated for modern times.*Good portrayal of other characters.*Good music.The Bad Things*It's kind of long.*Strange continuity; it's a prequil, but takes place after all the other Bond movies (it's probably better to think of this as a whole new saga).As an adaptation of Ian Flemming's novel "Casino Royale," this definately the best, since previous adaptations have been pretty bad. As a Bond film, it's also one of the best, because it's very exciting, stylistically different, and sheds new light on Bond's character. The franchise has finally broken free of the usual James Bond corniness, and told a strong, original story with a strong central character. I hope that the trend continues, for this is the way Bond was meant to be.

reviewText: ***Spoiler Alert***In the same lane as Batman Begins, where a franchise that has sucked starts prequeling to rejuvenate itself, I didn't expect much from Casino Royale but a rolicking action flick not really worth much more than an action flick.Casino Royale blew me away, and I think it is the greatest Bond movie since the likes of Goldeneye, Goldfinger, Moonraker, Dr No, etc.The best thing about this Bond that I loved, was that Bond was HUMAN.  As opposed to the super sophisticated suave man with only two emotional settings---uptightly angry and erotically romantic---or as M so elegantly labeled him in Goldeneye "...a sexist, misogynist dinosaur. A relic of the Cold War, who's boyish charms, though wasted on me, obviously appealed to the young lady I sent out to evaluate you."  This Bond was HUMAN.  He got very angry, and lost his temper, and as a result failed his mission and nearly lost his job.  He fell in love, and quit his job to stay with the girl.  He comforted the girl when she freaked out at seeing him kill two men.  He cried when the girl died.  He was smug when the man he was chasing finally got his due.Daniel Craig isn't the most good-looking Bond (he's quite grotesquely rugged in my opinion), but he strikes a perfect balance between rough-and-tumble and suave and sophisticated.  He's much more sophisticated from the old one-dimensional Bond we've seen in the likes of Die Another Day.  Even the villain, Le Chiffre, has more depth than just "Before I kill you, Meestur Bond, I will tell you exactly how I plan on executing my evil plan..."Le Chiffre's diabolical schemes go beyond the typical "hold someone hostage, make lots of money, take over the world".  This time, the villain is in trouble: he's been taking African warlords' money and holding on to it and using it in gambling, and stock market investings against a prototype airplane's success.  He even hires a man to make sure the plane fails by planting an explosive on it.  After Bond foils this plot, he's in big trouble, and stakes it all on a high-stakes Texas Hold-em poker game at Casino Royale.  Imagine seeing Bond's top villain fearing for his life as African agents threaten to cut his girlfriend's arm off if he doesn't get them their money.While there's plenty of action and violence, including a spellbinding scene in Africa with Bond chasing an African agent through a construction site, hundreds of feet in the air atop a crane, and into an embassy building, the core of the drama actually resides in the great poker game at Casino Royale.  If Bond wins, he wins 150 million dollars and foils the Le Chiffre's plans.  If he loses, his 10 to 15 million dollar investment goes to help fund terrorism.The dialogue is surprisingly ripe as opposed to the endless string of stale and childish sexual innuendos polluting the last movie's dialogue, and there are plenty of witty lines ("That last hand... nearly killed me" after having to leave the poker game when Le Chiffre poisons his drink, or "Do I look like I give a damn?" when asked if he'd like his martini shaken or stirred.)While there's a confusing moment where Bond is betrayed by his contact at Casino Royale, Mathis, and then he ends up in a hospital where Mathis is then betrayed, it all makes sense eventually, and the ends are even neatly tied up when the girl Bond's fallen in love with dies and he returns to his work, much colder now, and leaving the door open for some sequels.  While I know this isn't the first movie Bond's fallen in love in (GoldenEye is one I know of), this is the first one where you felt the chemistry was there.All in all, it was a great new beginning for the franchise, and nicely gritty and sophisticated all at once.
summary: Bond is back, and this time, he's human...

reviewText: At the outset, I must admit that I am not a keen follower of the cult of James Bond.  I have only ever seen one James Bond movie prior to "Casino Royale" and have only vague recollections of reading "Thunderball" in my teens.Overall, I was probably underwhelmed by this film.  Lots of action, much of it very spectacular, and little in the way of dialogue.  Typical Hollywood style stuff that has been done a thousand times before.  If action is your turn on then see this film.Daniel Craig in the lead role is probably a good choice.  I remember seeing Craig in "Layer Cake" a few years ago and he stole the show.  I must admit that Craig is a far more realistic action figure than Roger Moore.  Does he surpass Sean Connery?  Well, that is a choice that I will leave to the aficionados.On a lazy Sunday afternoon, "Casino Royale" is a pleasant way to spend a few hours.  Don't see it to be challenged.

reviewText: I can't say that I was surprised at how good this was.  I saw the trailer and I just knew that this movie was going to blow me away.  From the opening gritty black and white introduction to the climax I was in cinematic heaven.  It's funny because when a film receives so much attention prior to its opening it is usually a bad thing, but when the only attention the film is receiving is the mixed words over the color of the lead actors hair, well then you have to take into consideration that know one knows anything yet.  Daniel Craig is blond, yes, but he is also the best Bond in the series, seriously.  He's dark, mysterious, charming, handsome, buff, bright and just about the best thing that has ever happened to the spy thriller.In `Casino Royale' we meet Bond for the first time.  In the opening scenes he's earning his 00 status which means he has to make two kills, which he does in a very violent and gritty fashion.  What `Casino Royale' was able to do, by starting at the beginning, was establish Bond all over again, recreate his character to be more palatable.  We are able to reexamine his charm and his pride.  The Bond represented here is a bit softer, not as callused as those in the previous films because it is this film that defines Bond, that molds him into the man he is today.The film was smart in the way it handled the adaptation from the Ian Fleming novel by building up to the poker scenes as apposed to consisting mainly of them.  The novel read a little slow but the film is so fast paced and intense it's brutally good.  Aside from the action sequences (which are all phenomenal) it works very hard to make each and every character real to the audience, most notably Bond and his partner Vesper Lynd.  This is due to the brilliant performances by both Daniel Craig and Eva Green.  Daniel reinvents Bond beautifully and I'm sure will continue to develop him as the franchise takes off.  Eva Green is just utterly flawless here, breathing so much life in Vesper.  She is by far the most mature and well rounded Bond-Girl to ever grace the screen and she deserves major credit for giving the film a sense of warmth and reality.  The other performances are also well placed, especially that of Judi Dench who reprises her role as M.What I admire about this film is its ability to prove superior to the rest in its genre.  There are so many action/thriller type films but rarely do they ever reach this magnitude, this level of perfection.  The action scenes are flawless, the acting is award worthy, the script is tight and coherent, the set pieces are brilliant designed and the direction is astonishing.  In fact I can't pick out a single flaw.  Even my wife, who I literally had to drag to the theater, loved this movie.  In fact she made me take her back to see it a second time and insisted we purchase it the minute it was released on DVD.As far as the DVD is concerned, the extras are worth the price of the disc.  The behind the scenes featurette with Daniel Craig discussing his training for the film and such is a great extra, one that is entertaining and worth watching.  It's funny because it's rare that the extras on these DVD's ever really interest me, but I must say that I watched these and enjoyed them immensely.So, bottom line is that `Casino Royale' quite frankly may be the best Bond movie yet.  It's certainly the most polished and entertaining since the days when Sean Connery carried the title.  Many were skeptical of Craig's ability to pull this off but I'm here to say that Daniel Craig is better than any Bond so far in his ability to not only carry out the amazing stunts involved but also make this character real to us for the first time, making Bond someone we understand and admire.
summary: Surpasses all expectations and succeeds in blowing the audience away...

reviewText: First of all, I want to say that I would give this more of a 3.5 star rating, but Amazon doesn't allow half-stars.  It seems strange that a Bond fan like myself felt a little disappointed coming out of this film.  Myself and the two people I saw this with felt like something was missing from the film, but everyone else I know who has seen the film has loved it, claiming that it is the herald of a revitalized Bond franchise.  Looking back on the film, it is better than I first remembered, but I still feel like something was lacking.Casino Royale serves as a reboot of the James Bond franchise; it isn't a prequel to the other films in the series despite the fact that it is the story of James Bond's first mission as a 00-agent.  It starts the series over, taking Bond back to his roots as a spy without super-gadgets and self-parody.  Bond (Daniel Craig) has recently been promoted to 00-status, becoming 007.  His first mission involves Le Chiffre (Mads Mikkelsen), a terrorist financier.  After a botched capture in Madagascar, Bond is led to Le Chiffre by one of his constituents.  As it turns out, Le Chiffre lost a lot of his clients' money (due to Bond), and he intends to win it back in a high stakes poker game.  M (Judi Dench), who pretty much despises Bond due to his brash nature and relative lack of experience, orders Bond to join the game and make sure Le Chiffre doesn't win.The film follows Bond as he learns how to perform as a 00.  M's assesment of Bond is not wrong, and he has a lot to learn before he becomes the suave agent that we are most familiar with.The problems I had with the film had to do with the film's pacing.  It seemed like there would be action scenes that would go on way too long.  As a Bond film, action sequences are fun and expected, but in this film, some seemed to just be over the top and unending.  Towards the end, the scenes with Bond and Vesper Lynd (Eva Green) grew very tiresome and I honestly thought that they were part of a dream sequence.Still, despite the problems that I had with the movie, it still had many enjoyable aspects, and I would reccomend seeing it.  It seems that after speaking to others who have seen the film, I am definitely in the minority, and I merely advocate that you be prepared for some pacing issues.

reviewText: My wife and I literally high-fived when we heard Daniel Craig had been selected as the new Bond.  We've been fans for years, most notably of his work in 'The Mother' and 'Layer Cake.'  Besides flat-out looking like a movie star, the guy is simply a great actor...and one not afraid to take chances.  Check out 'The Mother' if you doubt that.So, to hear doubters and naysayers pooh-pooh the Craig selection smacked to us as coming from people who'd simply never seen Daniel Craig in...anything.  Now that the movie is out, all those negative opinions have disappeared.  Hats off, for example, to CNN's Jeanne Moos, who typifies the type and went on air to apologize.  Craig had simply bowled her over...as he has everyone.Craig's selection was but one part of an effort to strip-down and re-tool the Bond series from the bloated buffoonery of the last Brosnan-era releases.  Everyone seems to be in agreement that they'd turned ridiculous.  Producer Barbara Broccoli has done a masterful job protecting and re-inventing the franchise managed for so long by her late Dad, Cubby.
summary: Daniel Craig lays waste to the doubters and naysayers

reviewText: It has been 30 years since a decent Bond film (The Spy Who Loves Me). It has been nearly 40 years since the last great one (On Her Majesty's Secret Service). But I kept going to each new release, with less and less enthusiasm. Until now. Craig has brought back the rough and tumble style of Connery and Lazenby. No more ratatattat machine guns with no recoil! No invisible cars! No "witticisms" that could have been recyled from Austin Powers! Nope. Just hardcore action, great acting and a fantastic story and dialogue. Wow!!! Bond is really back. As for the lack of special features that several have mentioned, I predict that a special edition for hardcore fans will be on the way by the end of '07.

reviewText: I don't know how general audiences will take to a re-imagined, back-to-the-source, colder and harder James Bond as brought to the screen by a thoroughly believable Daniel Craig, but for my money, the team behind Casino Royale has shot some juice back into what had become a lackluster, farcical, and moribund series, reinvigorating the characters while dispensing with much of the nonsense and clutter that had accumulated over the years.I haven't gone to a theatre to see a James Bond movie in decades, the last memorable outing probably On Her Majesty's Secret Service (one of the better efforts: good movie, bad Bond (Lazenby).  I had seen the various Bonds over the years on cable or DVD and the movies were always somewhat amusing,  well-produced with some great stunts, but they had become so comic-booky and increasingly self-parodying that I found them hopelessly silly and overblown.  I found the Roger Moore era especially egregious and dismal while the attempt in the Timothy Dalton phase to sort-of get back to a grittier Bond was a nice try, but no cigar.  Pierce Brosnan's films were good, but by now so cluttered with nonsense that his last, with the invisible car and the villain's Ice Palace (nee Fortress of Solitude) only served to demonstrate that Bond had become Spiderman.I had read with relish Ian Fleming's series as a kid and loved the first 3 or 4 Bond movies, with From Russia with Love and Goldfinger favorites, and closest to the novels.  Thunderball was okay, but I started to lose it with You Only Live Twice and the volcano fortress and rocket gobbling, Donald Pleasence doing Blofeld as Dr. Evil, and all the rest of the tripe they began piling onto the series.So we come back to the first book in the series, Casino Royale, and the producers have shrewdly gambled on taking Bond Back to Basics.  I think they have succeeded admirably, and hope they will find an audience for the newer, harsher Bond.  Judging by some of the reviews from Bond loyalists I read here, many of them also welcome a new breath of life in what was becoming a stale and outdated franchise.You have terrific stunts with some really exceptional physical stunt work.  Fights that are nasty and brutal with pain that appears to be painful, and a double-O assassin who looks and acts like an assassin. Judy Dench is a marvelous M.  We have dispensed with Q and all the fantastical and silly gadgets for less but more appropriate equipment.  There aren't a bevy of Bond girls, but when you have the gorgeous Eva Green, you really don't need anyone else.  By and large the cliched quips are gone in favor of some dialogue that is actually kind of adult and often pretty snappy (thank you Paul Haggis).  You have villains that actually inhabit this planet and not Marvel Comics land.  There is a story with some twists and a beginning for Bond that lays the groundwork for some intriguing possibilities as to where they want to take him.  And you have Daniel Craig doing his damndest to re-define the role and make it his own.Take away the Bond name and legacy, and you would still have a hell of a  good movie here.  It looks great.  It is richly produced with care, and is smartly directed.  It goes places Bond movies in later years seem to have feared to tread.  I enjoyed it immensely, and yes, I would pay to go see the next one in the theatre.  By bringing Bond back closer to Fleming's creation, and by bringing in an actor without the expected, traditional look but who is a bloody good actor, and by dispensing with great heaps of the rubbish, they've hooked me back into it.  I hope others find it as entertaining as I did.

reviewText: I have been a Bond fan from the beginning, and must agree with several other reviewers that Craig is the best Bond since Connery. He brings a toughness and believability to the role which has been missing for a long time. Real secret service operatives who do what Bond does are often ex-military special forces types, not dandies who worry about whether their martinis are shaken or stirred. This hard edge comes through in many of Ian Fleming's books: Casino Royale captures that tone, as did the early  Bond films with Connery. Many of the other films with Moore, Dalton, and Brosnan seem almost cartoonish by comparison.

reviewText: OK. Let me first state that my favorite Bond was Sean Connery. To that point let me advise you to take Casino Royale as its own entity. This is not a Bond movie in the tradition of the tongue-in-cheek quips, sexual romping or suave machismo of the Bonds of the past. It's a rough and gritty film where this Bond character makes more than one mistake, gets in over his head and is a mystifyingly "burnt-out" after just making the prestigious "00" status.Alright, here's where things get confusing if you take this as another James Bond film. It's out of order in the sequence of time with the other films. This is Bond's first adventure the viewer, or reader if you read the books, has with the character. Cool, but this takes place in present day and not in the past. This is why I advise you to discount all other Bond movies. Don't waste your time with the little insights that, I believe, are suppose to "flesh-out" the character of the other films. It will only add to you unsuccessfully trying to logically fit all the other Bond movies in context. This will get in the way of enjoying what the movie does have to offer the viewer.I've got to say here that, Caterina Murino, was a knock-out in the truest of Bond girl traditions. We needed more of that in this story. From the, now infamous opening Bond movie credits, we can see there isn't going to be much fun in the sack with this show. By the way, the opening credit graphics are fantastic and don't disappoint from a visual aspect. As stated, the movie takes place contemporarily which accounts for the brutality depicted in the portrayal of the action? The old Bond almost never got his hands dirty. Daniel Craig wallows in one bloody confrontation after another and still manages to tidy up with hardly a cut on him. No bruising or scrapes even though he's just come back from either getting the poop kicked out of him or visa versa. If we all could heel so miraculously!!!What is there that makes this film worth watching? The action scenes. They are very good, especially the "Jackie Chan"-style feats at the beginning of the movie. The amazing places where we travel with Bond. A story that shows it's not as easy as the old James Bond's character portrayed being in a job that really sucks. There's not much glamour getting the [...] kicked out of you all the time. And . . . I guess Daniel Craig's performance. I begrudging give credit here because there are times when I can feel some empathy for him and then there are times when there doesn't seem to be much substance to his character. But, he definitely seems like a guy who's rather new at the "00" job. From my perspective Daniel is not a suave, debonair or even a slightly mistakable smooth operator. Rather he is more the civil savage. Brooding, rugged and definitely VERY rough around the edges. I suppose this is the "insight" as to how James Bond became the character to come? Like I said, don't try and figure it out in context. The sudden switch in his character from cool killer to love lost schoolboy at the end is also a bit disjointed. You just want to smack him up side the head so he comes back to reality. But, hey, maybe that's why he's a little confused by the end of the movie; too many cracks up side the head?!?!?!?What's not to like about this picture? The repeated unrealistic physical comebacks of Craig's character. Also, there's not much "fun" in this film so you're hit with endless struggles. "In the old days" James Bond had a little pleasure with his business and you dreamed of being "James Bond". If you dream of being this character you must be a masochist. Eva Green's portrayal of the character Vesper left me rather flat. Mads Mikkelsen's acting of the villain, Le Chiffre, was great but at times you couldn't hear what the heck he was saying. Poor sound?!?!? And lastly, the storyline got a bit foggy at times. It probably could have been streamlined more and it would have made the plot so much more entertaining instead of an on-the-fly self-editing task.If I took the film as a stand-alone I would say it was a good adult, no sex, adventure. Full of amazing photography and settings. And, with enough of a plot, use your own editing filter when watching, to be an enjoyable viewing.

reviewText: Every ten years or so, the producers behind the James Bond movies get an itch to re-invent the entire genre; and `yes' the Bond films are far beyond a mere film franchise - they are, in fact, a genre onto themselves. This genre, which by now includes The Bourne films, Mission Impossible, and stuff like Alias and Austin Powers, is complete with a clear set of tropes and clichés that can be referenced, tweaked, and altered to create a new-yet-familiar effect that every genre thrives upon.Up to this point the Bond pictures have generally kept their re-inventions fairly conservative; adjusting the tone to fit the strengths of their changing leading men, while keeping the Bond character basically still. Unlike most other film series, the Bond films each exist individually, not really following or even referencing the previous installments (with just a few exceptions). Bond, an established and self-contained character, simply enters each film, kills the bad guys, bangs the ladies, and saves the day. By their very nature, every Bond film is the first and the last Bond film.That's probably why Casino Royale, (Bond 21) feels so different. After more than 40 years since Sean Connery uttered the immortal words "Bond, James Bond" - and changed our perception of screen masculinity - 007 gets an origin story. Does it work?  Well frankly, Casino Royale left me a bit puzzled. I loved some aspects of the plot and the conceit itself is intriguing, but the film is unevenly paced, and its structure and tone is all over the place.Daniel Craig has been given the most leeway since Connery, to create an original character; he doesn't just step into the role of Bond, he gets to build it from scratch. His Bond doesn't start as the Bond we know, but he's supposed to be the Bond we know, by the end. And this is the film's biggest problem; we go to see a 007 film, but instead we get a film about a guy who's trying to become 007. By the end, I was basically ready to see the next film, the one in which Bond is Bond, but I really wasn't itching to have more of Casino Royale. Craig is a good actor, but he's not the most charismatic Bond (I'd put him behind Bronsnan) and his physical appearance is so un-Bond-like, he constantly has to overcome his own lack of suave. Blonde, short, and noticeably Cockney, Craig is the most miscast Bond ever. But what he lacks in looks, he makes up for in sheer physicality; this guy can probably beat up Moore, Dalton, and Brosnan all at the same time. And the action scenes, most being fairly organic fights and chases, really cook. This is where Casino Royale is at its best. There's a foot chase early in the film that's one of the best action sequences ever in a Bond film; and that's saying something. There's also a scene that's very reminiscent of Raiders Of the Lost Ark (to the point of rip-off really) that still manages to be quite satisfying. Through all this, Craig bleeds and sweats more than all the previous Bonds combined; this guy is physical to the max. And it's during these action scenes that his Bond is most effective.But by the middle of act two, the film settles into the casino showdown with villain Le Chiffre (Madds Mikkelsen), and things get a bit stiff. There's a crucial romance with fellow agent, Vesper Lynd (Eva Green) that should have felt stronger; the chemistry between these two is fairly mild. The poker showdown is nothing groundbreaking, though I do understand why they substituted Texas Hold-Em for the Baccarat of the novel; poker is more confrontational. But the competition is presented in separate `rounds' (in an apparent homage to Cincinatti Kid) and it creates a jarring stop-and-go affect that doesn't serve the film's pacing. Then things get downright gruesome as Bond gets tortured (not threatened, but really tortured), then recuperates (seriously... there's several hospital scenes) and then ... Casino Royale just kind of fizzles out. Sure, there's a sort of afterthought action finale, but it's both unspectacular and bizarrely referential to Moonraker, one of the worst Bond films ever. Then there's a coda that finally gives us the Bond we know and love for literally a second and... roll end credits. This left me with the burning question: couldn't they have given us what we came for just a bit earlier? I mean, the film is well over two hours long! Can't we have both a radical re-invention and a satisfying comfort food that one expects from a Bond film? Or at least how about a movie that has a consistent tone from beginning to end. I know it's a tough mission, but certainly not an impossible one. Maybe next time.
summary: CASINO ROYALE - A Bit Too Dry For Me

reviewText: "Casino Royale" lives up to the Bond legacy and is a stellar edition to the movie series. Okay, first up: Daniel Craig is an excellent James Bond. I love that he can give his all in grueling action scenes and still look dapper in a fitted tuxedo. I was overjoyed with Craig's performance. Next up is the plot which is supposed to be Bond's first case so don't be too alarmed to see Bond make some abysmal errors here and there. It's his first day on the job so we gotta cut him some slack. Who woulda thought that a casino game could be so intriguing? I sure didn't but it's in here. The action sequences are beautiful from Bond's non-stop chase after a suspect to another harrowing chase on an airport runway. I also liked the stripped down tone of the film. There were less inuendos and more realistic character performances. No schtick, just a pure action film. Overall, "Casino Royale" is an incredible film from the slick opening sequence to the end credits. Bond is soooo back.

reviewText: I have always been a huge fan of the James Bond movies, and have all the DVDs in my collection.  This will be the first "James Bond" film that I will never own. If you're a traditional 007 fan like me you will hate it.They have destroyed everything that made James Bond the popular movie hero that he was. Daniel Craig is James Bond with a license to bore.  Instead of the tall, dark, and handsome, suave and debonair naval officer who became a secret agent we have what appears to be a short blonde homely arrogant thug that would have been better cast as a villain's dumb bodyguard.Everything that made James Bond the popular movie hero is gone. Gone are the cool gadgets, the super villains, the charisma and charm, the clever one liners that convey character,the awesome music themes, the great seducer of all those Bond girls, the brilliant secret agent that hadextensive knowledge on nearly everything, and who was always cool and unflappable in the face of danger.  That James Bond is dead. The James Bond films that were great fun escapism, are now replaced with a somber, depressing, brooding and dark version.No Miss Moneypenny, no Q, the only person they kept is the one they should have gotten rid of, Judi Dench as that obnoxious feminist, M, who somehow must have traveled through time to go back to what is supposed to be Bond's first mission.Martini shaken, not stirred?  When a barman asks the new Bond whether he'll take his martini shaken or stirred, Craig snaps "Do I look like I give a da*n?"  Apparently the producers, Broccoli & Wilson, feel the sameway, because they have killed the James Bond loved by millions and replaced him with what comes across as a classless, bumbling, sadistic psycho, who goes by the same name.

reviewText: I have seen every Bond film that was ever made and to this day, Sean Connery has been the only actor I have enjoyed playing Bond...until now.After all the controversy and comments on Daniel Craig's potential as an actor and doubts over him playing Bond...I'd say forget it and be enthralled by the new BOND! He's here to stay.Casino Royale has a strong plot for once and makes it even stronger by showing us where Bond came from and how he smoothed away some of the rough edges. And the edges are brutally rough here. The killings are nasty and the aftermath has to be dealt with in a way Bonds have never done before.  The real ace in the hand is Craig. He doesn't have Connery's raw star quality, but he's easily the best actor to have played the part. I don't know if the film was shot in sequence but for the only time since OHMSS you get a sense of Bond changing throughout the film as his cockiness becomes confidence and his brutality becomes cold efficiency. He starts off unlikeable but human and gradually picks up the Bond traits we know until he becomes more likable but just a little less human. It's an interesting journey and Craig is up to it. It's not just his delivery, it's also his body language. Even his fighting style changes as he adapts.  Physically he's the most in your face Bond and the action scenes look brutal for once.  Even the not very likely free running chase is spectacular but believable because you get the idea that this really is kill or be killed stuff. It's got a real feel of danger to it that hasn't been seen in the series in years. Only the torture scene feels like it's holding back (it's almost as tastefully done as the old TV version) but that's probably fear of the censors.You'll come out of this one not just thinking that Daniel Craig IS James Bond, but that no-one has ever played him before.  And he does fill out those teeny-tiny blue swim trunks very, very well.  I need a cold shower now.
summary: One of the best Bond movies in years

reviewText: I think it's a bit interesting that Casino Royale was the first James Bond book written and, while there have been other adaptations, it's one of the newest 'official' movies released. The powers that be attempt to cover their tracks by having Bond gain his 00 status at the begninning, and the writing in general was pretty decent, but Bond is not an action hero and his style of espionage simply would not work in a post-Cold War era, or probably not even then. I have enjoyed Daniel Craig as Bond throughout his three movies so far but I would be hard-pressed to say which I like best between this movie and Skyfall. The pacing of Casino Royale is not seamless, with some scenes moving too fast and others dragging, and there are a few plot threads that didn't make much sense, which are comically discussed in How It Should Have Ended, but overall I felt it was a very entertaining movie and would recommend it to followers of Bond as well as to action/spy movie fans.

reviewText: I've been reading Ian Fleming's James Bond stories since my teen years (we won't discuss the offerings of subsequent authors), and I've repeatedly seen all of the movies, most of which mangle the Fleming books to a greater or less degree. That's unfortunate, for the real genius of Bond lies in Fleming's stories, and now the filmmakers at last seems to have realized that. In my experience, NOTHING the studios have ever done until now comes close to capturing the spirit of Fleming's Bond. Casino Royale does. (Ironic, since the novel on which it's based isn't one of Fleming's strongest.)This movie strips away decades of celluloid layers of convoluted plots, stylized humor, overblown and even stupidly-conceived villains, and fetishistic devotion to gadgetry, and at last returns to the basics: A fast-paced plot that follows Fleming's original novel pretty closely, and Daniel Craig's portrayal of a Bond exactly as Fleming wrote him. This is a Bond who is, at one level, passionate for life and somewhat reckless, while simultaneously (and paradoxically) cold, calculating, and professional. Fleming's narrative style allowed us to listen in on Bond's thoughts, giving us a three-dimensional character (despite Blofeld's description of him in the book You Only Live Twice), and for the first time ever in the films, Craig manages to portray that complexity. He's totally unforced. Dalton and Bosnan give us glimmers, selected dimensions, of the true Bond (Dalton's darkness, Brosnan's "I never grew up"), but Craig nails it. He IS James Bond. There is, somewhat regrettably, still more than a touch of the "rogue agent" element here that's a creature of the films rather than the books, but this time, unlike the other films, it doesn't come across as quirky but instead underscores how ruthless and dangerous Bond really is. A "decent" person doesn't break into a lady's home, especially when the lady in question is his boss. A "decent" man doesn't make a practice of bedding a string of married women, but Fleming's Bond does, and so, pointedly, does Craig. He has just the right amount of understated humor (as opposed to silliness a la Roger Moore et al.) as well, also typical of Fleming's Bond. In short, he takes the role seriously and plays it just as Fleming wrote it, and the producer, director, and writer all let him, much to their credit.As to the rest, it largely measures up to Craig. Judi Dench is the best M ever, just as dangerous and ruthless in her own way as Bond is, highly faithful to Fleming's M despite the sex change. Mads Mikkelsen is an excellent Le Chiffre, very human as opposed to the years of set-piece supervillians we got from the films from the '60's until the early '80s. (When he begins to lose his temper while torturing Bond, it's perhaps the most humanizing moment for any cinema Bond villain. It's nice to have a villain show some emotion for a change instead of sitting around in a zany Stalinesque uniform oozing affectation and plotting world destruction, although that stereotype does admittedly trace its roots to the Fleming books.) Eva Green is closely faithful to Fleming's Vesper and even looks like her.  The film downplays Felix Leiter and does get Rene Mathis wrong--in the books Mathis is Bond's old and unquestionably loyal friend--but compared to the stellar job the producer does with the rest of the film, these are minor qualms. The score is lush and understated, and the theme song may possibly be the best one ever: edgy, high-energy, with lyrics that evoke a combination of danger, recklessness, and cynicism, PERFECTLY reflecting Bond's character. It works seamlessly with what is also the best opening sequence ever in the Bond film series.By now you get the idea. This film deserves nothing but superlatives and has set a very high bar for the next outing. To paraphrase a review of one of Fleming's books, the movie is escapism, of course, but what escapism! This one's a keeper.

reviewText: Going against the harshest of critics and fans, Daniel Craig becomes the 6th James Bond, and passes with flying colors. Many people have had to eat their words. This Bond is tougher, leaner, and can be deadlier when need be. Some people complain(among many other hilarious things if you look at other reviews) that the charm and swagger isn't there. Not in abundance with Bonds past, no nor does it absolutely need to be, but it is there. The film, and Craig, breathe new life into the franchise, which was already doing just fine with Brosnan(who I still like better). It's a little grittier, and there is some old school Bond involved here. The story?. Pretty good. Starting from the beginning when Bond became a double O agent, he goes against evil villain Le Chiffre(Mads Mikkelsen), in a high stakes poker game, to thwart him from funding more terrorist acts. Fun premise. A big part of the Bond films is the villain. Mads Mikkelsen is unique and interesting looking. He has the presence, and has the right, classic evil Bond guy look. He weeps blood from his disfigured eye. The villain is handled a bit differently in the end than in most other Bond films. One of the better Bond villains in a good long while. The female is Vesper Lynd(Eva Green), and the ensuing romance, while good for showing Bond in a more human, relatable light, does bog the film down towards the end. It feels like it could of been done away with. The character is appealing, but it adds up to just being another Bond girl, really. Eva, however, is exceptionally lovely. Judi Dench is back as M, and the film just works. The first half is exceptionally good, with Bond being set up as an agent, and his relationship with M. The first big action/chase scene is quite something, as is the airport scene. Things slow down a bit in the second half from the first half, but the locations, Craig's Bond, and overall tone of the film save it. The end action climax is thrilling. The film also boasts a great tune. Chris Cornell's "You Know My Name" is rocking and modern, with a touch of old school Bond theme signatures. Makes you forget all about Madonna's uninspired Bond theme. It all comes back to Craig, though. He doesn't seem like Bond at first, but he definitley does as the film rolls along. He has a strong, undeniable presence, and you believe him in everything that he does in the film. The filmmakers are also aware of Craig's more buff physique, as it is on display a number of times throughtout the movie. In the end, Casino Royale is a wonderfully put together and directed Bond film. It has classic-retro Bond touches here and there, and really sets up a sparkling new life on the 44 year old series. As for extras, it's a bit slight, compared to DAD and other Bond films. The Bond Girl featurette is the best of the bunch. The film does feel to be a tad bit too long and goes on another 20 minutes or so when it feels like it should of already been over. Craig is not Connery, but he doesn't need to be. He is the Bond of today. Nobody still does it better than Bond.
