reviewText: I love all of the odies from Sean Connery to Roger Moore to Timothy Dalton, but I'm sorry Daniel Craig was amazing.1. First he had a better script than most of his predicessors which of course makes things must more intresting for the actor. If Tim or Sean had a script this good they would have been Oscar worthy.2. Perice Brosan didn't want to play James Bond anymore anyway ok. I'm sorry he says it on the Die Another Day DVD. So for all you so called true fans out there saying bring him back he didn't want the job. Only other guy that honestly may have done half as good a job and fits is Clive Owens, not Peirce Brosan ok.3. Daniel Craig acually played Bond the way it would work in real life. Think about every single movie, every single magazine article, newspaper story, book, and tv show you have every seen about real life assissains. Now stop and think about it..."Did any of those guys sound like happy go lucky people who just pranced around being swave and smooth and just be your best darn buddy all the time? No." Daniel Craig played the charcter like a real person not like "oh jeez I'm James Bond so I have to be super cool." That is not how people act in real life espically not if their life was on the line. Think about it...if you were being posined, shot at, stabbed, beat up, tortured, being paid worse than a teacher, and not always being told by your employers(the goverenment) good job or even the full story of why you have to go on these missions...hey you would be pretty crazy and angry and whenever you got the chance you would take it out on someone. Thats how Dainel Craig captures...if James Bond were real...would he be happy...how would he treat his boss...how would he treat his coworkers...how would he feel about himself. There is a certain underlying self loathing that someone would have if they killed people for money, Roger was way to happy...Timothy almost had it...Sean had it but there was no way they would write a script back then where someone gets pyhsically tortured on screen.

reviewText: I am a big Bond fanatic and had huge reservations about Daniel Craig taking over the 007 role.  Casino Royale is my favorite of the Flemming novels [edging out Thunderball], so I have been waiting anxiously for a proper film treatment of the introductory story in the Bond canon, which made me all the more nervous about seeing the blonde Bond take the licence from Pierce Brosnan.  Well, mission accomplished.  Craig turns out to be the perfect blend of rough around the edges in the movie's opening third and then grows perfectly into the sort of Bond that we're used to seeing as the character is promoted and eases into his new slate as a 'double-o'.  The story is similar to the original novel, with Bond having to outwit LeChifre at a casino, though character names and some details of the actual characters are updated and shuffled to account for modern political situations.  The action sequences that begin and end the movie are spectacular, whereas the middle portion is where the character does the most developing as an espionage agent  This is a very long film by Bond standards, but it only drags a little near the end before picking back up again.  My trepidations were unfounded as Craig and company pull off the story and add to the fledgling franchise quite nicely.  The omages and nods to the series' long past are especially well done [variations on the vodka martini, Bond's preference to married women and his favored choice of vehicle].  The title sequence and accompaning song are superb [regrettably the main title does not appear on the movie soundtrack].Add note; the second viewing was even more enjoyable as I was able to catch more the second time around.

reviewText: Like many movie fans who loved Sean Connery as 007, I wasn't sure the new actor Daniel Craig would pull this off. Boy was I wrong.He is great because among other things he looks British in a nice blue eyed blond hair, WASP way, is buffed, aloof enough, and has just enough chauvinism to make 007 authentic.  But I also liked seeing the human side, like when he misreads gamblers and alas looses at the table.Anyone who knows much about either the CIA, Special Forces be it the United States or RAF, know that the men have to know not to get to attached to those they have to work with.  Craig brings this off to a 'T'.  The action is smooth and steady.  And fun!And the physical action or 'stunt work' that Craig has to do, comes off believable because he is so buffed.  Makes for a much nore realistic presentation.Judi Dench plays 'M' like a great iron lady, take no nonsense or  take no prisoners should.Vesper Lynd, played by Eva Green is interesting if one listens to the dialogue and catches the devout Catholic girl remark, because in past Bond movies the women were intentionally sexual and not at all hesitant.  Was rather nice to see the suggestion that this Bond woman, wasn't so easy.  Made the romantic/sex aspect of the movie interesting and alas refreshing for me.Am really looking forward to more 007 with Daniel Craig as Bond.

reviewText: I started out being a not-so-big 007 fan. I knew who Sean Connery was(because of Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade) and Pierce Brosman (I still barely remember seing him in Goldeneye at the theatres), but had no idea who George Lazenby or even Roger Moore was. All I knew about the James Bond character was that it was a series of films about a secret agent who used his overly suave style to overpower women and his sometimes-failed wits to overcome some outragouse, unbelievable villain. Heck I didn't even know they were based on novels by Ian Flemming! I simply didn't watch much James Bond 007. One day, a year after "just another James movie", Die Another Day, I noticed those movies starrin Brosman were no longer showing. They just stopped...Skip forward about 2 years later, I read somewhere that another James Bond movie called "Casino Royale" was to be released in 2006. First of all, not knowing much about the plot or what it was based on, I thought the title was pretty stupid (he has all these mysterious and dramatic titles like Die Another Day, From Russia with Love, Goldeneye, and Live and Let Die. Then he has this dead-obvious title, Casino Royale, which, in my opinion, made the plot pretty predictable.). Secondly, I noticed what the new actor looked like: blonde hair, EXTREMELY blue eyes, and didn't look near as muscular (at least with a shirt on) as previouse Bonds. I found out other details involving this actor: his name was Daniel Craig and he is against the use of guns! AGAINST THE USE OF GUNS!!!! I knew then that the series was pretty much doomed to end.Early reviews show up on the internet, and the ratings were, surprisingly, positive. Now interested in the fact that the movie tells of Bond's first ever mission for MI-6 as 007, I rented several earlier James Bond movies, which were Dr. No, Goldeneye, Live and Let Die, and Die Another Day, and was very impressed with all of them. James Bond had just gained a new fan. Opening night of Casino Royale came, and I was there. I was hooked all the end:The movie opens with James Bond talking about gaining 00 status to a man he kills a few minutes later while showing flashbacks of Bond fighting and killing another person who worked for the man who Bond was discussing 00 status with, all in black and white. This leads to James Bond's famous spin-around-and-shoot-through-a-barrel openning sequence. The theme music, "You Know My Name", is a nice change from the usual music you might hear in a nightclub, being much more fast-paced than the other films.When I walked out of the theater, I realized that each of the previouse Bonds each had a share of fatal flaws: Sean Connery was too hairy, Roger Moore was too comical and messed up alot, and Pierce Brosman seemed a little caught up in himself and got beat up alot. Daniel Craig portrayed a much-more-realistic agent who was still a flawed human, knew how to get the job done, and only made out with girls when he absolutely needed to, while still having the same ego and style as the original Bonds. Simply put it, this is the best James Bond film I have ever seen.

reviewText: If you've seen all the previous Bond movies, if you've read any of the bond novels by Ian Fleming, then this is just another action movie by our 21st century standards. Our "NEW" Bond (in my opinion) does NOT, I repeat does NOT capture the true flavor of the Bond personality. He's a fast shooter, but other than that, he didn't act like the bond we know. For example, he allowed himself to be poisened by a drink at the Casino (not careful enough for 007!). He over trusted his lady partner with millions of dollars. He's too serious and even harsh, no Bond usual charm. For the new generation that has not seen Sean Connery's best and Roger Moore's best and even Brosnan's best, this maybe a good action movie. reviewText: Casino Royale stars a new Bond, played by Daniel Craig. Forget what your opinion is after viewing the commercials or reading the press, Craig is Bond through and through. Also, you'll view him as Bond, but you'll be able to separate him from the other actors. This movie is a reboot of the series. It takes you back to before Bond became the Bond we know and love. This movie shows his formation. The movie doesn't show Bond after Brosnan, it shows him before Connery. Starting with Goldeneye, I told myself that, "man, that movie was awesome," because it was a Bond movie, and they just HAD to be awesome didn't they? Well, some of the recent ones were good. Some weren't (I haven't seen Die Another Day completely since the theaters.  It seems so cartoonish). Craig's Bond is different. He makes mistakes. He doesn't think things through. It's fun to see his mistakes and know the experienced Bond wouldn't do those things. At one moment, when it looks like Bond has failed, Bond is ready to strike back and kill, when common sense says he should do something else. Only other, more experienced spies can stop him, and they do.So, with the movie fresh on my mind, I think this is one of the best, and I think that opinion will hold up through time. For starters, this movie isn't about a laser pulse that can destroy electricity, an atomic bomb that will blow up Hong Kong or the oil supply, or a machine that can harness the sun. This movie is about a man who finances the world's terrorists and in order to raise money, he's hosting a poker game. It's a simple spy story. As said before, Craig is awesome. The one-liners and puns aren't as blatant as earlier movies, but Bond is still witty. He also cares a lot, is more human, and suffers some remorse at the actions his jobs call him to do. This Bond is on the verge. At times, he shows heart and compassion, and at times he can be cold blooded. The person that can draw him out is the beautiful Vesper Lynd, played by Eva Green. Eva Green is beautiful, as a scene shown where she stands in front of the mirror without makeup will prove, her face is perfect. (I caught a glimpse of her in the movie Dreamers on the Independent Film Channel, and the rest of her isn't bad either.) She is tough, yet vulnerable, and her character will leave a mark on you for awhile.Now, what makes this a great "Bond" movie, and not just a great action movie. As far as the action goes, it is great stuff. There are fights on cranes, in stairwells, in collapsing buildings and at airports. Bond fans will want to know, does the movie have the stuff that makes Bond movies great?Considering the music, and specifically the Bond theme, many people say Goldeneye is one of the best Bond movies. I specifically remember that movie as being one that went away from the traditional Bond theme. They didn't use it once! So while it might have been a good movie, it was a poor Bond movie. In this film, the Bond music is there, though not as much as usual. But you can expect that, because Bond doesn't become "Bond" until the end. The traditional "gun-barrel" opening is also a bond staple, something that usually opens every Bond film. This movie opens without it, and I was disappointed, but then it is showcased in a different way, and that makes it even better. As mentioned above, the wit is there, just not focused upon as much.This is an intense PG-13, movie. There is not any nudity, despite what the MPAA says. The language is fine, the violence is plentiful, but not gory. I echo other reviews I've read when I say I'm ready for a sequel. This is the kind of movie that could start a series, even if it was the first, not the 21st. I hope this movie makes gobs of money because it is that much better than Die Another Day.
summary: One of the best Bond movies ever, a great movie, Awesome!

reviewText: I can't fathom the reviews that proclaim this as the best Bond ever?!?! I am a life long Bond fan, having seen and own, the movies and read books to accompany them. This doesn't make me any better than any other Bond fan, but I have an unflattering opinion of this train-wreck of a movie. I was disappointed when Pierce Brosnan stepped down as Bond, but I was willing to give Daniel Craig a shot at it. After all, I didn't think anyone could butcher the job the way Timothy Dalton did. Boy, oh boy. This movie could kill the franchise. Reinventing Bond is ludicrous. Taking out his calm, cool assuredness and replacing it with hot headed response, I shed a tear. Then the writers had Bond leave a beautiful woman in the middle of a passionate moment to chase her terrorist male counterpart. James Bond WOULD NEVER do that. A real Bond would spend the night with the lovely lady and give her a gentle kiss before giving chase. Taking Bond back to the rank of normal "O" status had me shaking my head. Bond playing Hold 'Em poker (a nod to a current fad)instead of his game of choice baccaratte. In fact, if you read the book, Bond is playing baccaratte... the movie guys changed it, obviously figuring that they knew Bond better than Ian Fleming. What idiots.Another thing. What was one of the best points of Bond movies? For me it is the "over the top" bad guys that Bond fights. They never showed up in this flick. Instead we got a bad guy who was a weeping sissy. He owed money to other bad guys and was playing poker to try and win the cash. Those bad guys probably should have been Bond's prey. The guy Bond chases is no super villian. He's all to human. He has asthma, shakes in the company of real bad guys and begs for mercy when caught.Does anyone remember Bond movies with real hokey contraptions that the meanies would put Bond into when they wanted him dispatched? This movie replaces those contraptions with a chair and a naked Bond getting hit in the genitals by a heavy rope?!?! (say what) Bond gets hit in those family jewels by none other than the weeping bad guy himself. No henchmen, no fortress, no Q, no fancy gadgets... No Bond Movie!The lone high point of the movie, and the reason I gave it 2 stars was the chase scene early on in the movie. Incredible. Probably the best chase scene I have ever seen! And it was ON FOOT!!!

reviewText: I didn't see it in the theater because the trailer didn't impress me. I read many a glowing review of this film and thought perhaps it would be worth my time. Every James Bond film that Pierce Brosnan was involved with was crap, so I was extremely skeptical. Well, this...reinvention of the series...is no different. It's not Daniel Craig's fault though. He has potential, if they would give him a character to play instead of a cardboard cut-out. I could tell from the very first moments of this film that it sucked, and it never got any better. Did the whole world suddenly accept B-movies as the standard? Martin Campbell has never directed a good movie in his life and this is no exception. Why let him on? He sucks! He ruined a good script! Who thought he could do it in the first place?!As far as I'm concerned, this is no James Bond movie. It feels more like one of those opening skits of an MTV movie awards, but instead of trying to be humorous, it is without trying. I feel sorry for anyone who thinks this is good. It's far from it. Ian Fleming would be pissed.

reviewText: ***CONTAINS SPOILERS***How did James Bond become a "00" agent? What makes him so good at his job and so distant to the beautiful women he often encounters? Wrap your mind around those questions and then go and see director Martin Campbell's latest Bond flick, CASINO ROYALE. That someone could pull off such a fantastic film whilst giving us the Bond-background is something of a marvel. Leave aside (for the moment) that Daniel Craig isn't as debonair as previous Bonds, and you just may enjoy Casino Royale on a level never before seen.It's simply a fact that Craig isn't the dashing, clean-cut, and uppity Bond audiences have come to expect. He's rougher, tougher, and a bit naive. He loves instead of lusts. He learns to kill with a conscious (in the beginning), but still delivers pithy lines ("That last hand nearly killed me.")The question of James Bond's beginnings have always been in question and Casino Royale gives them to us while also delivering the action, a few gadgets, a kick-butt automobile, and the curvaceous women we expect.Director Martin Campbell first cut his teeth on a Bond film with GOLDEN EYE in 1995, so he knows the lay of the land. He also went on to direct the stylish THE MASK OF ZORRO in 1998. From there his repertoire stammers with several duds, but came back in glaringly fine fashion with this year's Casino Royale.From the opening credits with its flashy and somewhat retro poker card graphics, to the black-and-white film stock beginning, audiences immediately realize they're in for something special. We quickly watch Bond make his first two kills, granting him access to his 007 status. Then we get to see him nearly ruin his career by causing an international crisis. From here he's sent on hiatus by M (Judi Dench, MRS. HENDERSON PRESENTS) to get his head together. But of course Bond never lets go of an assignment until it's finished. Continuing his international crisis across borders, he travels to a tropical island where he meets up with terrorists who are trying to advance their causes by selling bomb-making material. He meets up with one of the racketeers' wives in true Bond fashion. But the British Secret Service have their eyes on him and quickly find out what he's up to. They are forced to go along with Bond's plans to enter into a high-stakes poker game with the evil Le Chiffre (Mads Mikkelsen, EXIT), a facially scarred and blood weeping villain who recently lost a ton of money because of Bond's interference in his "business". If Le Chiffre wins the $120 million game, he'll have enough money to get back into supporting bombers and bomb-makers.Bond also happens to be The Service's best card player, but he has to convince the penny pinchers of the British government that he's got a good chance of winning or they'll refuse to back him (if Bond loses the British will, in effect, be sponsoring terrorism). Enter Vesper Lynd (Eva Green, KINGDOM OF HEAVEN), a government finance agent who agrees to give James Bond the money to enter the tournament. As the cards fall, so does Bond's chances. As all appears hopeless, Bond wins the tournament, thus crushing Le Chiffre's chances at re-entering terrorist haven, and threatening his very existence because he's lost all of his financing given to him by the dark forces of the world (they'll obviously want their money back at some point and now Le Chiffre is broke). Obviously Le Chiffre is none to happy about Bond winning and kidnaps him and Vesper.By now Bond has grown very fond of Vesper and they form a relationship unheard of in terms of Bondom. He confesses his love for her and eventually (after a dizzying and testicularly funny escape from the clutches of death), agrees to leave the Queen's Service in order to live a life of love and happiness with her. But all Bond fans know this cannot be. A sense of terrible foreboding grips the film as Bond learns the true nature of Vesper.It's wonderful to see how all of this effects James Bond and how it coalesces to help form the Ian Fleming character we've all grown up with. Vesper, through Bond's love of her and her betrayal of him, helps turn James into the tough-loving, womanizer we all know. This betrayal also lets us see why James Bond doesn't trust anyone and prefers to work solo.So Daniel Craig being a bit rougher around the edges in appearance actually fit the script nicely. He IS rougher. He IS tougher. And he IS the Bond we've come to enjoy.(Note: Caution to all those who get this when it comes out on DVD. There is another comedy film entitled CASINO ROYALE starring Peter Sellers, so make sure you're aware of which is which.)

reviewText: This is one good Bond film. I must admit, that I, like so many others, did not believe that Daniel Craig would make a good James Bond. Oh, how wrong I was. Craig plays Bond with confidence and gives him exactly the rigth mixture of elegance and brutishness. We must keep in mind that Craigs Bond is new to the game, rough, tough, adventurous and most importantly, human. He is not yet the suave ladykiller we all know and love. He's still learning his trade.I think the producers were very clever in distancing themselves from the smooth Bond from the past. We're not only dealing with a new Bond actor, but an entirely different kind of movies alltogether. The last few Bond films have been nothing more than flat (and really not funny) one liners and loads upon loads of gadgets. Too far fetched really. This new film is delightfully gadget-free and delivers clever dialogue, funny as well as impressive and dramatic moments and most importantly: it has a more realistic feeling to it than the latest of the Bond movies. You believe it could happen.This is partially acomplished by making the fightscenes very rough and tough (and beautifully choreographed) instead of the usual "judo chop". Also making Bond a proper soldier and a proper gentleman instead of the super suave super agent gives credibility. He is not afraid of getting dirty and leans on his physique rather than savvy when encontering problems.Daniel Craig plays the role to perfection and the supporting cast also delivers beautiful performances, especially Dame Judy Dench as M is very good. This movie is spot on.Highest possible recommendation.

reviewText: If the James Bond franchise had to be rebooted, this was the way to do it.Daniel Craig gives the character a sense of deadliness not sensed since the Timothy Dalton days. As much as I liked Connery, Moore, and Brosnan, and all delivered good performances, none of them seemed like sudden death with a bad attitude. For a government assassin, such an attitude would be helpful.Daniel Craig sells that attitude convincingly. From the very start where he coolly terminates a traitor, to the very end where shoots a foe through the leg when it is clear he didn't have to, you know this Bond is cool about the job of dealing death.The movie itself? I think of it as three movies in one. It starts as an action flick, segues into a cool spy mode with a very relaxed and long lasting poker tournament, and then gets back to the action again.Although this movie does have scenes that remind you of the book, it is not a close cover of the book in the way the first few Connery movies were.Altogether quite enjoyable, and closer to the way I perceived Bond as I read the books than most of the other Bond actors managed.The DVD presentation meets current standards well. The picture is bright and sharp, and the sound quality is outstanding. If you liked this film in the theater, you won't be disappointed with the DVD.

reviewText: "Casino Royale" is a re-imagining of James Bond, a reboot of a tired old franchise.  James Bond has been a cartoon for decades, epitomized by Roger Moore and to some extent Timothy Dalton.  In its place, Craig's Bond is part Jason Bourne, part Terminator.  (Just watch him run like Robert Patrick at the beginning!)  "Casino Royale" is grittier, less cartoony and still big and action-oriented.Craig is a decent if not great Bond, but the fault of Bond in this movie lies not with him but with poor writing.  The viewer will note that this Bond screws everything up and does nothing right, and even has to be rescued at times.  This is not the supremely confident, always-prepared Bond we are used to.  Nonetheless, the first part of the movie is serviceable and competent, and at least watchable.But "Casino Royale" completely derails on the train to Montenegro, where Bond meets his Bond girl and the movie hits a brick wall.  Action transforms into a lot of pseudo-romantic chatter between the two.  Eva Green turns in a truly legendary performance as a Bond girl.  Legendary, in the sense that the acting bar for Bond girls is set pretty low, and she doesn't even make it that high.  Due in part to poor writing and in greater part to exceptionally poor Bond girl acting, her last scene in the movie is laugh-out-loud funny rather than dramatic.I will not spoil the ending, such as it is, but its open-ended lack of closure caused me to knock off a star.  Come on, this movie is 2 and a half hours long, and they couldn't have cleared out 45 minutes of look-at-my-watch yapping in order to give us 5 minutes worth of closure?I noted to my wife that Montenegro sure looked a lot like Italy, and that maybe we should visit someday.  However, do not use "Casino Royale" for travel planning purposes, as the credits reveal that Lake Como, Italy stood in for Montenegro.  In one sense, I guess I was right!

reviewText: Grammatically idiotic though it may be, the initial catchphrase for Casino Royale "James becomes Bond" is a pretty accurate descriptor for the movie. The film works as a reboot button, similar to Batman Begins, taking the character of James Bond back to his very first mission as MI6 agent 007. There's been a lot of hype surrounding this movie promising that this gritty, modern interpretation of Ian Fleming's classic secret agent will give a second wind to a series that has been struggling for years. Thankfully, Casino Royale doesn't disappoint. Daniel Craig does an excellent job of portraying Bond and he infuses the character with the rough edges that one would expect a novice "double O" to have. Bond's ego and arrogant recklessness provide many of the close calls that he very narrowly avoids; these scenes add a human element that has been missing in many of the Bond films. Bond's humanity is even more apparent in the ruthless manner he uses to get the job done, especially when compared to the typical, cold-blooded killing that he exercises later in his career. This new side of Bond hints at many layers of unexplored depth that make his character something far more interesting than the walking punch-line machine that he had become in previous installments. The villain, Le Chiffre (played by Mads Mikkelsen), is a more reined-in version of the madmen that Bond usually encounters thanks to the wise decision of skipping on the more camp elements for which the series' villains had become notorious. The battle that Le Chiffre and Bond have over a game of high-stakes poker provides the most tense moments of the movie, a scene that is sure to be loved by all Bond fans eager to see James back in playboy mode. Eva Green, though nothing out of the ordinary for a Bond girl, is just interesting enough as Vesper Lynd to make the audience care for her; her character is one of a handful of people that play a vital role in making Bond the gentleman spy that people know and love. The overall picture is wonderful but it's the smaller moments, such as Bond's birth as 007 and how he earns his first Aston Martin, that help make this installation, and Daniel Craig, the best Bond since Connery.

reviewText: Until this movie, when I thought of James Bond I pictured Sean Connery.  I'm 60, and I remember standing in lines that spread around a city block to seeGoldfinger, and I never thought there could be anybody else who could play Bond.Since then the chain of Bond films became synonymous with stunt-oriented, fantastical tales full of whimsy, exotic locales, and girls, girls, girls.  Bond himself became defined only by the particular villain he chased down, and there was a certain mass-produced feel to each of the post-Goldfinger era.Though still a popular and cash-worthy entity, Bond had become a franchise; the films became increasingly silly, and the only really interesting patter about them became who was going to be the new Bond this year.Then along came Daniel Craig, and 007 came alive once again.The most remarkable and successful aspect of "Casino Royale" is that, after twenty films in the Eon line its producers decided to use it to reboot of the Bond legend.  Like the newStar Trek (2009)(minus the temporal window, of course), this movie is the beginning of the next phase of the secret agent's legend. Another likeable quality is that, for the first time in years, a Bond movie plot can be followed in one viewing.  Certainly there are twists and turns, but this is no serpentine movie defying the viewer to follow it.And, as there is no mention made of the previous films or characters within them--save M (his boss) and Felix Leiter (his American CIA counterpart)--our Bond is free to kick start the mythology anew--in fact, one of the most amusing segments of this film occurs when the spy becomes eager to find an alcoholic drink he likes.  After several false starts he quickly orders a vodka martini, but the bartender has no idea Bond is at that moment under great stress, and when the server asks if he would prefer it shaken or stirred, our spy snaps, "Do I look like a man who gives a damn?"That this is a remaking of the 007 legend becomes clear at the precise moment the movie starts: shot in black-and-white, the first scenes depicts Bond's attainment of his double-0 status through the removal of a traitorous double-agent.  It is made clear immediately that this Bond is a no-nonsense creation; a thug being polished into a highly trained spy.When the film returns to color we find 007 assigned to Madagascar, where has to chase down a spy who has been accidentally alerted by another agent's foolish mistake, and a thrilling parkour chase once again confirms that this Bond means business.  While their target colorfully and gracefully runs like a gazelle, wending his way through a building by ballet-like leaps and agile maneuvers, Craig's Bond smashes through boards and wire fences like the Hulk.It is this aspect which Daniel Craig portrays so well.  He is a lean, hungry Bond, quick-witted and clever, yes...but he has the persona actors like Steve McQueen conveyed so well: a quality that quite clearly said that he is not to be intimidated or outdone.  He is, indeed, a brute who can wear a fitted suit and pass for a sophisticate, but just as the excellent opening theme song (by Chris Cornell of Soundgarden and Audioslave) informs anyone opposing him: "the coldest blood runs through (his) veins."Bond has always had a contentious quality about him toward any of those who would be seen as "above" him, but it was almost always playful and non-threatening.  Craig's Bond goes a little further: he is a man whose anti-authoritarian chip-on-the-shoulder smugness runs quite definitely in opposition to those who are attempting to control his actions.  In fact, this will be a quality that will fuel the new trio of movies made at the time of this review.  M (played by Dame Judi Dench, the only remnant from the films preceding this movie) is in fact quite ruffled by his presence, and constantly seeks to upbraid him for insubordination.  Yet, even when he breaks into her apartment and hacks into her computer, she does little other to him than give him a tongue lashing. She has her eye on this agent, to be sure, but it is clear the thought has occurred to her that they might just have created a loose cannon.There is scarcely a "down" moment in the movie, and some scenes are truly spectacular.  Bond's saving of a new airplane prototype is as physical and rough and tumble as they come, featuring not only his prowess with his fists, but also other athletic feats as rough and tumble as, say, Harrison Ford's Indiana Jones.  There is some price to be paid, however, in the new films: after the airplane escapade Bond is debriefed by M in the Bahamas, and his body is riddled with wounds, scrapes, cuts and bruises...and this is NOTHING compared to what he will go through soon.There are many terrific battles, but the one for which the film is titled is a high stakes card game that involves Bond and LeChiffre, a criminal financier who is trying a last-ditch effort to avoid bankruptcy by backing a winner-take-all poker game.  Our side's plan? To bankroll Bond and have him destroy LeChiffre, at which point his creditors come after him and he's left with only one option: our protection.Of course, the game is exciting, and there are several scenes that let us know how vital these games are.  Suffice it to say that there are several deaths...and one of them is Bond (watch the film!).Yet there is more than one climax in this film, and our Bond is not done--not even when an anguished LeChiffre has broken loose and decides to torture a naked Bond in a manner that, well...  Let's say his voice will never reach the low notes again.But, as one might guess, Bond wins the day, and to continue speaking about the plot would be to tell too much, only that what happens is important enough to supply the next film with its driving force.My main bullet point, therefore, is that "Casino Royale" is a terrific and intelligent movie.  If you have ever seen a disappointing Bond film, be reassured: he is back in form again.  James Bond is no longer a silly, quipping fop whose main sources of derring do are doing things that warrant words like "derring do."And I, for one, am glad.

reviewText: Not since the glory days of "Goldfinger" and "Thunderball" has a 007 film received the kind of sterling reviews that greeted 2006's "Casino Royale." Roger Ebert gave it a whopping four stars, and Entertainment Weekly recently included it in a countdown of the best movies of the past 25 years.Is it that good?Although it was produced by EON productions, the same company founded by Albert R. Broccoli and Harry Saltzman in 1961 to produce the Bond films and now in the hands of Broccoli's daughter Barbara and stepson Michael Wilson, "Casino Royale" is what's known as a "rebooting" in the same vein as Warner Bros.' "Batman Begins." Based on Ian Fleming's first Bond novel published in 1953, it begins with Bond earning his double agent status then embarking on his first mission. However, the film has a contemporary setting with Bond and his cohorts using laptop computers and cell phones. In other words, 007's previous adventures against such adversaries as Dr. No, Goldfinger, and Ernst Stavro Blofeld have yet to take place. Does this mean that remakes are in the offing?Daniel Craig, the sixth Bond of the official series, also represents a break with the past. He brings to mind Steve McQueen more than Sean Connery. You get the impression that Craig's Bond could hold his own in a fight with Connery but feel less confident, intimidated by Connery's cooler, more sophisticated manner. On the other hand, he would probably mock Roger Moore's gentlemanly agent and regard Pierce Brosnan as more playboy than killer. Craig's Bond is more of an alley cat, more at home in the gutter than the casino at which he stares down the villainous LeChiffre. He may be heroic, but he's far from fearless. He perspires and faces death with genuine terror. When he tosses off a witticism, as he rarely does, it's not with the nonchalance we have come to expect but with a sigh of relief, a means of breaking the tension. When this Bond's car flips over multiple times, he's bloody and barely conscious as his enemies drag him from the vehicle for a hair raising session of torture. Roger Moore would have calmly climbed out of the car, tightened the knot in his tie, and moved on.The critical acclaim accorded this new Bond is justified. It's an all-together excellent show, but I can't help but detect a certain amount of condescension toward the earlier films, as if to suggest this one is superior and more innovative than the more fantasy oriented adventures that, with few exceptions, preceded it. It is nothing of the sort. While the earlier Bond films with their megalomaniacal madmen plotting the takeover of the world did grow stale after a time, they were innovative when first released and grew tired only after being endlessly recycled in later chapters in the series and by the imitations that sprang up in the wake of "Bondmania."In the `60s, when Bond reigned supreme as the world's biggest box-office draw, his only competition came from the lesser spies given life to cash in on 007's success. Now, of course, we have Star Wars, Indiana Jones, Batman, Superman, Spider Man, et al, special effects heavy films that never would have made it to the big screen had Bond not arrived there first. But unlike them, Bond doesn't need the gimmicks and the fancy hardware and can stand apart from them. He has a secret weapon more effective than anything that Q could provide. He has Ian Fleming whose original conception of Bond has only rarely made it to the screen intact. Now he has. This isn't a better Bond, though, only a different one, as interesting in his own way as the previous 007s were in theirs.Brian W. Fairbanks

reviewText: I never cared for James Bond flicks. The megalomaniac adversaries who have billions of dollars and hundreds of private soldiers in silver lame` but not the common sense to simply have Bond shot on sight, the flying/floating/submersible Bond car that's tricked out with an assortment of the highest of hi-tech gadgets, etc. always seemed silly and shallow to me. I think one of the reasons Michael Myers' Austin Powers character was such a success was because he did an excellent job satirizing the implausibilities and tacky nonsense of Bond movies.Now, with that being said, let me tell you that CASINO ROYALE is a great movie that I very much enjoyed. I don't know but I've been told that this movie and Daniel Craig's Bond is the closest ever to the character in Ian Fleming's books. It was interesting how this movie offered some explanation on the origins of a few things surrounding the Bond myth, like 007's predilection for Aston Martins and his trademark martini - shaken, not stirred. Most importantly, however, it also delved into Bond's disposable treatment of women. Early on, an alluring Mediterranean woman, who could easily have become the next "Oh James!" cooing 'Bond Girl,' gets  killed, to be replaced with a more mature and independent female lead character.Craig's Bond is a complex character; stylish yet gritty, brutal but human. Not since Sean Connery has the franchise had such a believable 007. Bond's target too is more realistic this time around. CASINO ROYALE has no Dr. Evils living in underwater fortresses surrounded by legions of mercenaries. Instead, the adversary here is a much more menacing figure in today's world: a man who offers his investment and holding services for terrorist money.The ending assures us that James Bond will be back. If he's played by Daniel Craig so will I.
summary: A 5-Star Review From Someone Who Never Liked A Bond Movie:

reviewText: With its death defying leaps, amazing stunts, and action-packed action, I deemed Casino Royale one of the best James Bond movies ever. Add Judi Dench as M and a few Bond girls like Ivana Milicevic as Valenka, Eva Green as Vesper Lynd, and some typical Bond bad guys like Mads Mikkelsen as Le Chiffre and here is a Bond classic. Daniel Craig came across brilliantly and then some, and he was handsome. He was more like Sean Connery than the last Bonds but more high-tech which makes the movie awesome. With all the hype about Mister Craig taking over as 007, I had my doubts that he would fit the bill. But then, he appeared on screen and almost immediately I thought: "Here is the new 007."He has Sean Sean Connery's blessing, and he has mine too. Being a die-hard Bond fan, I can't wait to see Mister Craig in the next Bond film.This review pertains to the theatrical cut, which kept me at the edge of my seat. What a thrill-ride, to say the least. I give this movie 1,000,000 STARS for being a great film. But, mind you, it's not for the kiddies, only 13+

reviewText: Move over Pierce Brosnan and Timothy Dalton. Daniel Craig is the best Bond in 20 years and has resurrected the franchise that was on life support.The first thing you notice about Casino Royale is that it is absent of all of the cheesy gimmickery of the old Bond movies. The stunts and effects are believable. The acting is understated and real. The plot is fresh and new.Daniel Craig's performance gives a hint of Sean Connery. But it's not an imitation of Connery. Craig makes the role his own. This is a whole new Bond. The cliche is that this movie is Bond for the 21st century (the terrorist angle), when it actually just brings Bond back to his roots. He is cunning more than he is charming. (unlike Roger Moore) He is different, he is new, he reinvents what you think a secret agent in her Majesty's secret service should be.If you are looking for the trademark Bond staples such as the Martini (shaken, not stirred) - the easy women, the endless supply of Aston Martins etc... this movie may disappoint. Craig is rough around the edges but just smooth enough to make you believe that he deserves to be the newest "double-oh".I suggest buying this DVD in 1080p Blu-Ray because of the spectacular cinematography, shot on location in Prague. It won't disappoint.The best part about the movie, without giving too much away, is that the ending leaves you wanting more. Isn't that the goal of any great series?I give it 5 stars.

reviewText: The 007 series has been the most successful and longest running series in history. What began as a series of books by Ian Fleming, has lasted for fifty years. It has been immortalized by Sean Connery & Roger Moore. It has been kept current by Pierce Brosnan, but as time goes by, the old stale formula can't continue to draw interest or box office returns.So, what do you do? You give the world of Bond a curveball. You keep the spirit of Bond; the ladies man, the gadgets, the high risk stunts, the adrenaline pumping action, the bow tie, the suit and the cars, but you give the man a new personality. This is the genius of CASINO ROYALE, and the very thing that is gonna keep the spirit and the series alive for lord knows how much longer.The one thing that all the Bond movies have done in the past is give James Bond the same personality. We have numerous changes in the actor, but the personality of the character is always the same. CASINO ROYALE kept most of the character of Bond, but with Daniel Craig, they've given the series an adrenaline jolt with an unlikely Bond and a slightly skewed Bond.The first twenty minutes takes you into the fast paced, well-thought out thrill ride and introduces you to a character who isn't as clean cut as the suit may suggest. The world has changed around us. We live in an age of danger, terrorism and war and knowing that, the BOND series required a man to fit the part.James Bond is in tact and I can't wait to see what more they're gonna throw at us. The series continues to be the most energetic successful gotta see more series in history, thanks to a knife toting Daniel Craig.This is one of the best action movies to come along in a long time. I'm a tough nut to crack, and I was sitting wide-eyed and bushy-tailed, popping popcorn, eager for more and disappointed when the credits rolled.

reviewText: James Bond has always been a shallow figure, so super suave and so heavily stylized, yet completely lacking in substance. At last, we have a film that gives Agent 007 some depth and complexity; it's called "Casino Royale," and while it isn't a perfect film, it's still a far cry from some of the overly ambitious early attempts in the franchise. It's an action film, yet the story isn't drowned out in wall-to-wall stunts. It's a mystery, yet the twists and turns aren't piled on top of each other. It's even a love story, yet it isn't sappy or melodramatic. This is the James Bond movie I've been waiting for: a pleasing blend of classic intrigue, danger, suspense, and sexuality in a plot that--true to the Spy Film genre--isn't even remotely plausible. What a fun, fun movie this was.This is the first Bond film in many years that's actually based on an Ian Fleming novel. I can't say whether or not that made it worth seeing; I've never read anything he's written, and I can't compare them to the other twenty Bond films. But I can say that this story hit all the right notes, both as an action film and as a character analysis. I could describe in detail what the film is about, but does it really matter? All you need to know is that it's a prequel, and it covers Bond's very first mission. The long and short of it is that he has to prevent a banker from winning at a casino tournament in Montenagro; the prize money will only go towards funding terrorist activities. Specifically what activities are never alluded to, but that's irrelevant. We all know that terrorism, in any form, should be stopped.Early on in the film, Bond says, "I understand double-ohs have a very short life expectancy." How true: the character is now played by Daniel Craig, the sixth actor to assume the role (following a long and fairly mediocre run with Pierce Brosnan). This new portrayal gives Bond a different dimension, one that helps to define him more as a person and less as a debonair drone. Craig definitely gives him a suave demeanor, and to say he isn't physically attractive would be a bold-faced lie. Yet there's an underlying ruggedness to this new James Bond, one that replaces some of the more pristine Bonds of the past. His face shows some wear, as if to say that he's seen plenty of action. He's even capable of making mistakes, as seen during the casino tournament when he incorrectly assumes the tactics of his opponent.Noticeably absent from "Casino Royale" are the wealth of over the top gadgets and gizmos; the best we're given are a couple of guns and a few miscellaneous items in the glove compartment of a sports car (including a defibrillator, which will eventually come in handy). I liked this; for once, Bond will have to use his wits and physical strength as opposed to ridiculous science fiction-grade props to gain the upper hand. There are no watches with built in lasers or pens that fire tiny darts. There's no eject button for his car's driver's side seat. There's no hidden radio in his cufflinks. Of course, such a change also required the absence of Q (first played by Desmond Llewelyn, then played by John Cleese). He could always be counted on for a bit of comedy relief.But I see this as a good thing; this time around, comedy relief wasn't needed. Small doses of appropriately timed humor were scattered all throughout the film, and not just from one character. It was an especially welcome change for Judi Dench to be given a couple funny lines; M was always such a serious character, and she definitely needed to lighten up. In "Casino Royale," she's initially portrayed as being very hesitant around Bond, especially since his ego caused him to mess up a few very important missions. He even breaks into her apartment, not to steal anything, but simply to speak to her face to face. She finds such an act untrustworthy, and she's understandably worried about his success at the casino tournament.Interestingly enough, those moments in the casino are the best the film has to offer, despite being relatively quiet and low key. Bond plays against Le Chiffre (Mads Mikkelsen), the film's lead villain. Despite the fact that he says and does little, he's probably one of the coldest villains ever seen in a Bond film. He sits across from 007 with an expression that you'd swear would turn you to stone (if it weren't for the fact that his left eye has an injured tear duct, resulting in tears of blood). He fiddles with his poker chips intensely yet carefully. He makes grandiose bets that he knows Bond will attempt to outdo. There's calculation going through this man's mind, and it was fascinating to watch him at that table (it was also fascinating to watch him during an especially uncomfortable torture scene). If it weren't for the fact that he doesn't fit the usual profile of a Bond villain, that he doesn't have a secret lair rigged with electronic booby traps, and that he doesn't have an exotic pet, then I'd say he would appeal to those looking for a classic bad guy.And then there's Vesper Lynd (Eva Green), an accoutant and the inevitable love interest. She and Bond play off each other perfectly, with one initially finding the other's personality flaws irritating. Yet there's a definite attraction, made stronger by the mission they're to complete together. She eventually awakens within Bond a desire, one that allows him to see her as a person as opposed to a sexual object (and we all know that James Bond is notoriously sexual). After a while, she, too, beings to see him in a different light. At that point, we can't help but wonder what would happen if the world's greatest secret agent were to settle down, marry, and possibly have a family. Can anyone picture such a circumstance? Of course they can't; James Bond is a man of action, dedicated to service but attached to no one.This is the kind of complexity I've always wanted to see, and I'm glad the filmmakers of "Casino Royale" decided to make use of it. I'm also glad that it was balanced with a couple of good action sequences; yes, each one is over the top and completely unrealistic, but they're so entertaining that the little details aren't even noticed. Of course no one can jump off of a hundred-foot crane and live to tell the tale. Of course you can't shoot at someone while leaping in mid air. Of course such bodily harm would result in debilitating injuries. No one thought about such things while watching the other James Bond movies, so why start now? This is a worthy addition to the 007 franchise; I can only hope that future additions will be as good.
Title: N/A

reviewText: For once James Bond appears to be modern. A character who has spent most of his existence with a wooden, Ken doll personality finally, in the hands of Daniel Craig, has joined the rest of us in the year 2007. Of course Bond can never be as edgy as say, XXXX, Craig's character from "Layer Cake" the film that won him this most prestigious role. This is, after all, a franchise built upon a foundation of bling so anything the least bit offensive most be removed. And yet still they found a way to flesh this Bond out with humor and bravado. "Shaken not stirred" may have won them over many moons ago, but today our audiences demand more, they demand sexual innuendo with their ostentatious action set pieces. And Craig delivers, creating a Bond we can believe in, even when he is stealing cars and fornicating other people's girlfriends on the floor.At the center of this good, but not great, film is a poker game in Montenegro. We are back at the beginning of Bond's career (although the setting is modern day) and he is one of those shameless self-promoters who is looking to move up the ladder as quickly as possible. After an awe inspiring opening chase scene Bond is sent into the high stakes poker game (because he is the best, duh) with hopes of shutting down La Chiffre, a known terrorist. If he loses he has to live with himself knowing that he helped finance terrorism to the hefty tune of $10 million. Now poker isn't really my game so there is a chance that some of the nuisances of the game itself were lost on me. Stopping short of having an ESPN announce team in the house, Bond's co-conspirator Vesper works as the Greek Chorus filling in the poker simpletons (such as myself) and letting them know what is transpiring. "Rounders" made poker actually look exciting, but this film has no such trick up its sleeve. More than anything the central game works best as a way to slow down the pace of the film and in the process keeps it afloat.To watch this film back to back with the one that preceded it, "Die Another Day", would be to not believe that the came from the same genre much less the same series. Pierce Brosnan looked the park, especially when driving cars and acting cool, but I'm pretty sure I could beat him up. Daniel Craig would wipe the floor with me and that represents a major upgrade in that department. "Casino Royale" has its feet planted firmly on the ground and is helped along greatly by director Martin Campbell who can actually direct action sequences. "Die Another Day", with its embarrassment of a climax, was nothing more than special effects and fantasy lands, where somehow Bond ends up driving this uncrashable car through an ice palace. Oh, it is so bad. The old complaints about Bond refuse to go away however: plots are predictable, it doesn't have a thought in its head, and it represents commercialism above all. And still, for once, I am going to recommend a Bond film. It didn't give me whiplash and I am secure in the notion that Bond can once again clean my clock. What else does a man need? ***1/4
summary: Bond's Eternal Quest for a Good Movie Ends

reviewerName: Chris Swanson "I'm just this guy, you know?"
reviewText: So somewhat to my surprise, it turns out that, in general, I actually like James Bond films. This comes as something a shock to me, because normally I tend to prefer more highbrow cinema. But there's something about Bond...When the Bond movies are at their best (Goldfinger,Licence To Kill,On Her Majesty's Secret Service - 2-Disc Ultimate Edition,Thunderball), they are among the best films ever made. Roger Ebert even put "Goldfinger" on his list of Great Films. When they're bad, however, they can really stink up the joint.Moonrakeranyone? Yeah, I thought not.Given the way the franchise had been leaning in the last few films (invisible car, anyone?), rebooting it was, perhaps, the only really course of action. Thank goodness when they rebooted it, they did a great job!This is a VERY good film. Excellent action sequences, a tight plot, good acting and beautiful scenery (even though it wasn't filmed in Montenegro, which is a pity). The villain, while certainly unpleasant and weird, isn't nearly as unrealistic as some of the other Bond bad guys, and his plans are much more interesting than, say, world domination.Daniel Craig makes for an excellent Bond. I would say, just on this one movie, that he is, thus far, almost as good, if not actually as good, as Connery. He's got great intensity, a good sense of timing and, well, frankly, he IS Bond.I very much look forward to the next Bond film and in the meantime highly recommend this one.

reviewText: Casino Royale surprised me.  I was expecting not to like it after someone I trusted gave it less than favorable marks.  But more and more people said it was good, so I bought it on DVD.  What a great film: action packed, thrilling and well written.This Bond film reboots the franchise, and one of the most signifigant changes is the women in the movie are more than scenery.  No more appalling acting just for some eye candy, Eva Green delivers a fine performance in spite of being perhaps the most beautiful of any of 007's costars to date.  She's really something; exotic and confident!Finally, the movie despenses with all of the foolish gadgets, substituting realistic action and violence in its place. Bond is bashed and battered in Casino Royale, and it refocuses the character in reality after years of the over-the-top Roger Moore style camp.
summary: Casino Royale: the women can act this time

reviewText: What fun.  From the theme song to the hero, everything has been revamped - and it rocks!  I hadn't bothered to watch an 007 movie for years.  They had become so plastic, forgettable and trite.  All those boring gadgets and villains.  Plus a variety of unconvincing, way too suave 007s, who were nothing like Ian Fleming's hero.  Except for Timothy Dalton, none of them had the gritty edge I expect in a James Bond - and that we got with the first and greatest of them all, Sean Connery.  This guy has it.  I have to say I was a little doubtful because he's a blonde, and somehow blondes don't do it for me as tough guys.  But he is perfect in the part, and believably tough and violent - think human tank....  If he does another 007 movie, I won't wait till the DVD is available to see it.  And that's a high recommendation from me!  (hate crowded movie houses)

reviewText: Despite the fact it's almost unanimous that Sean Connery is everyone's favorite Bond, for some there's just the case of the era you happened to catch. Some are old enough to remember the Connery era while others were introduced to Bond thanks to Roger Moore. For me it was Pierce Brosnan in Goldeneye, which is still one of my favorite Bond films, that brought me into the 007 world. However, the series needed a serious revamp when it was filled with awful one-liners, over-the-top action scenes and a campiness that was hard to shake off. Taking a cue from the Batman restart, Casino Royale also restarts the series by showing not only a more serious agent, but a better approach.Just getting his "00" status, James Bond is a bit arrogant and has a case for letting his ego letting the best of him. His mission is to stop the man, Le Chiffre, a poker fanatic who helps finance world terrorists. Instead of blowing things up left and right, Bond instead goes into a high-stakes poker game and make Le Chiffre lose all his money and make him easier to apprehend. Sent to look after Bond and finance him in the poker game is Vesper Lynd, who Bond starts to fall for and drop his guard. He'll find the world of espionage a difficult life, especially when it comes to separating emotion from the mission.First of all, I have 2 knocks against the film: I'm not the greatest fan of the theme song "You Know My Name", performed by Chris Cornell. Then again I didn't like the last 3 songs anyway but even though it fits with the darker atmosphere the film has, I just don't like it as a song. The other is the actual poker game itself: it's just too slow. It takes a good half an hour when it starts and when we find out the winner and while it does have some action in-between, he just feels like a good 15 minute scene stretched twice as long. It's not enough to completely knock the film down a point and it is important to the overall story, it just should've been better edited.Now the big question: how's the new Bond? Like Christian Bale taking over the Dark Knight, Craig just seems like a perfect choice. While he's arguably the less pleasing Bond aesthetically, he's got that wit and charm that he should have, while also having that action hero we expect. He seems more intense and withdrawn than any of them have had. That isn't a knock against the more charming Connery, or the actor-y Timothy Dalton but Craig just has a more loose cannon feel he should've been all along. As for the action, it's quite exciting because it's grounded in reality. Outrunning a satellite beam in a car that can turn invisible just feels too silly while Bond hanging on for life on a speeding airport vehicle set to blow up is more exciting. Also the big opening set-piece, a physics-defying foot chase looks awesome but it also looks slightly comical since you keep thinking that guy should've broken his bones already.Like the Departed, this is probably the skinniest "2 Disc special edition" I've ever seen. It's basically got 3 featurettes: a look at Daniel Craig's announcement and start as the new Bond, a surprisingly entertaining look at the Bond girls with Maryam D'Abo being our main host and a look at the stunts being more real rather than using CG. You can obviously tell that a bigger release is coming since there just seems to be a lot missing. A commentary would've been nice, or a breakdown of the action scenes; something, anything. But at least the stuff we have is interesting and worth a look but all of a sudden, it just stops and you feel there's more to explore.Bet a lot of naysayers sure felt sheepish when this came out. More serious, brutal and just all around better, it's great to see Bond as the agent men wanted to be and women wanted to be with...and do.
summary: Bond as he was meant to be: exciting and awesome

reviewText: I have to admit that when I heard Daniel Craig was going to replace Pierce Brosnan, an actor who has done a fine job, one almost as good as Sean Connery, I was incredibly apprehensive and even thought of boycotting the film. I must say that I'm glad I didn't. As other reviewers have written, this movie is Bond the way he was meant to be seen (it's too bad that Brosnan was not the beneficiary of such a solid script because almost all of his movies were overly far-fetched and to a certain extent, campy). The story, based on the first Bond novel is perfect for Craig because he provides the physical force necessary to play the role.And what kind of Bond do we have? He doesn't have the suave and sophisticated carriage of the previous actors, but Craig does not need it since this is Bond when he just gains double O status. What this movie does is bring us back to the basics, especially in terms of the action sequences. Even if the movie were not a Bond film, it would be highly entertaining, the fact that it fits into this franchise makes it all the more rewarding.Without going into the actual plot, I would like to say that this movie is a success, one not to be missed.

reviewText: I have sat silent here for 4 months awaiting the best time to sum up my thoughts on Casino Royale. My friends know how I have felt, that this was the most serious entry in the Bond series ever. And the 84 reviews that preceed me is like the Bond line "Your reputation preceeds you Mr. Bond" (Moonraker). All in all, this was not only a Bond movie, it should have been considered for the Oscars more seriously. At least Best Direction, Best Set Design and yes, even Best Song. Oh well, maybe next time.But really, Daniel Craig captured what should have been captured long ago, but could not with the actors who preceeded him. Yes, Brosnan was cool, yes Moore was funny and yes Dalton tried to be serious, and even Connery tried to be Bond. Lazenby was perhaps even better than Connery in some ways. But if you know the Bond lore at all, Daniel Craig got it right, the producers got it right, Martin Campbell got it right. BOND IS BACK is more than a slogan for a poster, it is the truth of the series.Admittedly, this is the first Bond movie I ever shed a tear from, and that was at the end when Vesper slipped from Bond's fingers and was gone just inches from him. As much as she may have turned on the British Treasury by luring the money from Bond, it was a sad moment much like when Tracy was shot at the end of OHMSS. Bond truly loved both women and you can't help but feel his pain. He was lured into love and love was lost. It was real life on the big screen.The action...well, what can you say, top notch. The one thing I have seen absent in all of these reviews and online articles however, is any curiosity who the man in M's bed was when she was called in the middle of the night. Never since Judi Dench took over as M have we been aware of a husband or lover. And also, the woman at the table on LeChiffre's yacht during the private card game turns up at Casino Roayle and the table there. Who is she? Was she the mustache player's on the yacht wife or friend of LeChiffre? I am aching to find out.Simply the story was compelling and the length was actually just right. It gave room for the character development to come out. While 144 minutes may be too long for some people, I found it to be ideal to allow a Bond film to breathe, grow and tell a story. I would not have cut another minute.All in all, the producers and writers have much to accomplish in Bond 22. And I am confident they will. But we must wait for 20 months to find out. In the meantime, I will be wearing out the upcoming DVD between now and then realizing that in 49 years of life, I have grown dependent on Bond to give me an outlet from the pains of real life and take me to places I will never go. Bond is my escape, but he is also as real now as ever.
summary: BOND-CRAIG=BEST BOND AND BOND MOVIE EVER!

reviewText: The best Bond film in quite some time (we're talking years here - possibly decades). The production values are top notch - great locations, handsome cinematography, a solid score - in other words, the hefty budget is clearly displayed on the screen. But then that's not really the surprise (high production values have been pretty consistent ever since Pierce Brosnan's first picture), nor is it the primary reason that this film works.The real reasons are twofold: producers cast Daniel Craig, and they managed to produce a script that nailed the better elements of a traditional Bond film (plenty of action and wit) while stripping the series of any camp and injecting it with a level of genuine emotion usually absent from the series. In this one, I actually cared about Bond as a human being. But credit Craig, at least in part. He brings a physicality and magnetic charisma that have been long absent from the role. Look, I liked Brosnan, but when Craig goes after a bad guy, he makes it believable and unpredictable. And it's been a long time since I could say that about the franchise and its hero.Added bonuses: Judi Dench returns as M, and Eva Greene plays the smartest, most literate heroine outside of Diana Rigg forty years ago. Very good stuff.

reviewText: The rugged looking Daniel Craig gives a fresh approach to the James Bond character since Sean Connery relinquished the role.  With an ambivalent attitude to danger and no hesitation to immerse himself into peril, Craig plays a seminal version of Bond, recently bestowed with a license to kill.Not fully trusted by his superior M played by the stern Judi Dench, he globe trots in a mission to upend the organization of the villain Le Chiffre played by Danish actor Mads Mikkelson.  Le Chiffre is the banker to a worldwide network of terrorists.  Craig thwarts a Chiffre sponsored act of terrorism costing him millions.  This leads to Craig's inclusion in a super high stakes game of Texas Hold Em in Montenegro's Casino Royale as Le Chiffre tries to recoup his losses with the $150 million first prize.  Craig is fronted the money under the supervision of MI6 sponsored accountant Vesper Lynd played by Eva Green, who will become his love interest."Casino Royale" typically has an abundance of death defying action sequences replete with dangerous and acrophilic stunts.  Filmed in many exotic locations the film is a worthy representative of the James Bond series.  Unlike his pretty boy predecessors Roger Moore and Pierce Brosnan, Craig creates a more appealing character who not only takes his lumps but unthinkably actually falls in love.

reviewText: Just as "Batman Begins" was a restart for the Batman franchise, so is "Casino Royale" a reboot for James Bond.  Not only do we have a new Bond in Daniel Craig, but we go back to the first of Ian Fleming's spy novels, long inaccessible because of a copyright issue with the makers of a TV movie.  Like Batman Begins and other reboots of successful franchises, the film is all the more enjoyable: it is familiar yet different, not "more of the same" which tends to happen in upper sequels.Just as each actor has re-invented Bond to his own liking, so too does Craig bring a new twist.  Both his and Dalton's Bonds are more edgy and prone to violence (as opposed to the smoothness and womanising of the Moore and Brosnan incarnations).  The story: the young Bond is vying for "double-O" status (and therefore a license to kill).  He foolishly chases his terrorist quarry into an embassy and gets involved in an international incident.  This leads to my favourite line in the movie, uttered by Judy Dench's M: "In the old days, when an agent did something that stupid he had the sense to defect.  Ch**** I miss the Cold War!"  One senses that the writers of the Bond films would echo that sentiment....Having failed to bring in that terrorist, Bond gets to work trying a different tack to track down the mysterious "Le Chiffre" - banker to the world's terrorists and banana-republic dictators.  Foolishly, Le Chiffre loses a huge sum of these people's money, and decides to host a high-stakes poker game in an attempt to win the money back.  Unfortunately, there is the usual silliness involved in the poker (in one hand the 4 players have a flush, two full houses, and a straight flush, the odds of which are astronomical, even in Texas Hold-em rules).But that is one of the few complaints that can be made of the film.  The scriptwriters (including the multi-Oscar nominated Paul Haggis) have a clear vision in mind and execute it well.  Most of the modern Bonds (going back to Moonraker) have been special effect and stunt extravaganzas where the plot often seems to be simply a thread holding together the action sequences.  This film makes the action serve the story.  As such, you're never quite sure what to expect - for example, once Bond finally gets into his Aston Martin for a car chase, it leads to a very unexpected result (if only in its duration).Granted, the end of the film drags out and introduces a confusing array of extra villians.  But countering that is Craig's performance (and Dench's, for that matter - some of the best moments are M trying to rein in Bond's impulsiveness and violence while trying not to blunt his effectiveness).  I don't know what the most vociferous of Craig's detractors think of his performance, but the final word goes to Rotten Tomatoes, which rated Casino Royale in its top 10 films of the year, based on the number of positive reviews it received.

reviewText: With all the negative pre-publicity this movie received, I was not much interested in seeing it.  However, I heard from some who saw it that it was quite good.  So, I gave it a look.  It is terrific.  Now, if you want Sean Connery, or Roger Moore, or Pierce Brosnan or any other Bond, you will certainly be frustrated.  This is an entirely fresh take on Bond and I enjoyed it a great deal.This is Bond at the beginning of his 007 career.  He is laconic rather than full of quips.  While he can be charming and even dress elegantly, we never forget he is a killer.  Bond hasn't developed his signature martini yet and is actually conflicted about what all the violence is doing to whomever it is he is underneath.Unlike most of the Bond films, there isn't a single super-villain here.  Instead there are several bad guys and we are not quite sure what is actually going on until near the end and even then there is still something more than we realize.  The technology, conflicts, and fashions of the film is present day rather than 1950s - 60s Cold War.The fighting and action of the film is also very up to date.  While not horribly graphic, it does seem more real and in some ways beyond reality.  I am thinking of the chase scene on foot early in the film.  Who can move like that?  But it does come off as thrilling.The Bond Girls are beautiful, but are not mere decorations.  They have things they do in the plot.  Certainly, some are more capable than others.  But the emotional depth of what they go through is deeper than in any other Bond film that I can recall.Is Daniel Craig a good Bond?  Of course, you have to decide for yourself.  My wife deos wish that his face were more elegant, but I like him.  He has the kind of anger and animal energy one would expect in a killer who lasts against steep odds.  I look forward to his next film as Bond.If you like Bond, I say give this film a chance and enjoy it for what it is rather than wishing it were something it never intended to be.There is a second disk with some good features about this film and its context in the Bond tradition that are pretty good.
summary: Much better than I expected, but certainly a fresh take on Bond

reviewText: James Bond seemed dead, but along came Daniel Craig who brought the best in the business back, but giving us a lean, mean 007 that blows previous Bonds away. As well as giving the performance of his career in the process. Daniel Craig gives a galvanizing performance as the freshly minted double-0 agent. Suave, reckless, and possessed with an ego that compromises his judgment during his first mission to root out the mastermind behind an operation that funds international terrorists. There is also one of the best villains in recent years with Mads Mikkelsen as the cold blooded Le Chiffre. He heads an international cartel not so much bent on world destruction as on taking advantage of the chaos in which we live.For longtime fans of the franchise, Casino Royale offers some retro kicks. Bond wins his iconic Astin-Martin at the gaming table, and when a bartender asks if he wants his martini "shaken or stirred," he disdainfully replies, "Do I look like I give a damn?" There's no Moneypenny or "Q," but Dame Judi Dench is back as the exasperated M, who one senses, admires Bond's "bloody cheek." It is also refreshing to see Bond have a real love interest in Eva Green, not the usual banter that rings hollow. Bond is not afraid to expose himself in this movie, revealing a much more vulnerable figure than we have seen before.From its punishing violence and virtuoso action sequences to its romance, Casino Royale is a Bond film that, in the words of one character, makes you feel it, particularly during an excruciating torture sequence. Double-0s, Bond observes early on, "have a short life expectancy." But with Craig, there is new life in the old franchise yet, as well as genuine anticipation for the next one when, at last, the signature James Bond theme kicks in following the best last line ever in any Bond film.
summary: The most brutal and viscerally exciting James Bond film yet!

reviewText: Daniel Craig stars as the new, re-imagined James Bond in the 2006 (non-spoof) version of Casino Royale.After Bond foils the plans of the banker Le Chiffre (Mads Mikkelsen), who provides funding for the world's terrorists, Le Chiffre sets up a last ditch effort to win his money back in a high-stakes poker tournament at Casino Royale. James Bond enters the game in order to destroy Le Chiffre for good. Bond teams up with Vesper Lynd (Eva Green) who is assigned to keep an eye on him and how he handles the large amount of government money needed to enter the tournament. But as Bond gets more involved in the game, he becomes tangled in a web of lies, deceit, and betrayal.Casino Royale is partially based on Ian Fleming's first James Bond novel. About the first third of the film is added to provide a background for Le Chiffre, but the poker game stays very close to the book. Although the film may not sound as action-packed as some of the others, trust me, the action is intense! This film has a deeper storyline than most Bond movies. Daniel Craig plays a colder James Bond that has a chip on his shoulder. The film definitely takes a darker and more serious tone to match. Casino Royale also lacks the humor of other Bond films (don't expect Sean Connery style one-liners or Roger Moore slapstick here). The film has a noticeable absence of gadgets, which I thought were becoming over-the-top after Die Another Day.This stylistic re-boot to the Bond franchise is very well done! Daniel Craig is an excellent James Bond in his own unique way. Highly Recommended!
summary: Darker Bond...but still just as good!

reviewText: I don't care much for cards and seldom enjoy movies that revolve around card games. About all I know is that it's usually good to hold aces and always good to have a huge pile of chips in front of you.  Yet, I certainly enjoyed Casino Royale which features a giant-stakes game.Daniel Craig plays a more "human" James Bond than those I have seen before. Craig seems more fallible and, therefore, more believable than the other Bonds. As other reviewers have pointed out, Craig is also more of a "working class" Bond. For example, he says he doesn't give a damn whether his martini is shaken or stirred, thus mocking a trademark line of the former more sophisticated and plastic James Bonds. This is not to imply that Craig portrays a soft Bond. His Bond is a master marksman, street fighter extraordinaire, and brutal assassin.There's plenty of excitement. Fantastic stunts. The foot chase through the skyscraper construction site is spectacular. The poisoning of Bond is one of the most dramatic sequences ever.Other Bonds are noted for their seduction of beautiful women. But this Bond convinces us that he's really smitten with the vivacious Vesper Lynd, who was so very effectively portrayed by Eva Green.  There's a touching love story here.There are elements found in all the 007 films. M is here, but now M is a woman, deftly portrayed by Judi Dench. There's the heartless villain, Le Chiffre (Mads Mikkelsen), the man who cries blood. There are vintage and high performance cars. Like earlier Bonds, this one uses advanced technology. Beautiful people in the background. Exotic locations.I earlier saw Quantum of Solace, in which Craig also starred. Quantum is very good, but I think Casino Royale is much better. I have seen perhaps five other Bond movies, and can hardly remember anything about them. They really can't approach the excellence of Casino Royale.

reviewText: When a formula works, you really should stick with it.  The team behind Casino Royale obviously decided to move in a new direction, abandoning key elements of the formula: debonair Bonds, drop dead gorgeous vixens, and incomparable special effects.  Let's start with Daniel Craig.  He just doesn't have it.  He looks too old (this story is supposed to occur early in Bond's career).  His stockiness kills any hope for a fashion sense.  Still, a great actor can overcome these shortcomings to look like a hero (like Tobey Maquire did with Spiderman).  Not Craig.  This man cannot act.  He has a total of two looks in the movie:  a poker face and a constipated canary face.  The later he uses to woo women and to stare down villains.  Apparently, that looked took a lot of work since even it disappeared in the second half of the movie leaving us with a blank poker face.I guess to keep with a somewhat ugly Bond (whose most notable feature are his satellite dish ears), the producers decided to cast more down to earth females.  I never imagined seeing ladies like this in a Bond movie.  I thought I was watching The Facts of Life.  As for the special effects...they started off good, but just faded into ordinary low budget action thriller effects.In short, it was disappointing.  BTW, I won't delve into the lack of continuity of the movie (when compared to other Bond films) as this seems to be a common problem with these movies.
