reviewText: From the moment the film opens, with it's gritty black and white (so gritty in fact that it had me wishing they'd made the whole film black and white) to the moment the Bond theme closes out the film, `Casino Royale' is probably the most intoxicating and rewarding film to come out this year. With all the pre-release criticism and speculation put to rest, Daniel Craig proves that blondes do have more fun, much more fun, for his James Bond is the most real, the most intense and the most enjoyable of the lot of them.With a plot that makes sense and is easy to follow, `Casino Royale' delivers on every level that a film can, providing entertainment for everyone. My wife, who is not a fan of Bond movies or even action movies utterly loved this film, so much so that she insisted we see it again the following night. With action sequences that look so painstakingly real, to emotions that look so painstakingly real, Daniel Craig and the rest of the cast hit every note just right.Starting us off with Bond earning his `00' status, the film gives us a great development of the man. `Casino Royale' is what Bale and Nolan did for Batman with last years `Batman Begins' for Craig and Campbell breathed life into a dying genre. Sure, everyone who loves Bond will love Bond, but even his fans will admit that the latest in the long line of Bond films was growing tired, but now, with `Casino Royale' under his belt, Bond has a new reason to breathe.I want to also make mention of Eva Green, an actress I feel is only a few short roles away from an Oscar, for her turn as Bond girl Vesper Lynd was brilliant. For the first time in the history of Bond films has a Bond girl been more than a piece of tail. Vesper is smart, seductive and essential to the development, of not just the story but of James Bond himself, for her character and performance add so much weight to his growth as a man.`Casino Royale' will go down as the greatest Bond film in history (that is until Craig and Campbell top it) and will be a reminder to all that just because Bond looks different doesn't mean it's a bad thing, for Daniel Craig has done things with this franchise that us Bond fans have only dreamed of. He made Bond cool again, and made him someone even my wife can watch again and again!
summary: Daniel Craig does Bond bolder, buffer, blonder and um...better than ever before!

reviewText: I've always been a marginal admirer of the James Bond series. Sean Connery was obviously the man to beat for the role of 007, but boy, the other actors, in my opinion, really fell far short of his mark. Roger Moore? The guy had so many stunt doubles you have to wonder how he justified his paycheck. Pierce Brosnan? OK, but as an actor, he doesn't have much range. (And, like Moore, he provided plenty of work for stunt doubles.)"Casino Royale" completely blew me away. Not only was it a great, fresh, vital, exciting Bond picture, I thought it was one of the best of 2006. It's just a cool movie! And Daniel Craig? HERE is James Bond unleashed. Craig does excellent work. Not only did he do many of his own stunts, in some of the most thrilling and well-filmed action sequences in many a year, he also made Bond an intriguing, scary, likable character. Who knew there could be so many facets to 007? Judging from Roger Moore's work, it was definitely hard to tell.Craig carries this sleek, often brutal, exceptionally well-produced movie on his capable shoulders. He's got great charisma (think Harrison Ford crossed with Steve McQueen), a wit as dry as one of Sean Connery's martinis, and looks just as comfortable with blood on his face as in a tuxedo. Even if the film itself had been average, or even sub-par, Craig's swaggering, low-key presence makes it something special.Thankfully, the movie is anything but sub-par. Martin Campbell handles action scenes and poker table intrigue with equal brilliance. The writing impressed me the most. "Casino Royale" seems long because it takes time to develop the characters and story, a rarity these days. The dialogue is razor sharp, and the actors clearly relish their lines. This may be the first Bond movie that DIDN'T put me to sleep in between chase scenes.Can't wait to see the next Bond pic, as long as the producers are smart and keep Daniel Craig on board.

reviewText: Batman Begins was the movie that started the whole franchise reboot craze. Like The Pink Panther, James Bond was soon to follow. Daniel Craig is good but in my opinion he lacks the suave sophistication that Connery, Moore and Brosnan had. He's a fine actor though, able to handle the action (especially Le Chiffre's torture), dramatic and romance scenes. Eva Green was a brilliant choice as Vesper. Unlike previous Bond girls where they had to be a government agent or nuclear physicist in order to be an equal with Bond, Vesper is able to make jabs at Bond and hold her own against his sexist ways but her character is not action oriented and emotionally vulnerable, which makes her more feminine than some of her predecessors. The shower and final scenes are the best examples I can give on how, other than Tracy from OHMSS, Vesper is the only woman Bond has ever fallen in love with. Le Chiffre, while not one of the more memorable villains in the Bond canon, is big step up from the bratty Gustav Graves. He is cold, calculating and not afraid to cut Bond down to size if he doesn't tell him what he wants to know. Judi Dench, the only connection to the previous films, returns as M, who is shown more in this film but some of her scenes just seem unnecesary to the storyline. The plot is good, though the only parts that are adapted from the original novel are the casino and torture scenes. I do hate that they made it seem that Le Chiffre had a hand in 9/11. In this and the following Bond film, I hate how they're striving too hard for realism, in the past, the politcal points of the films were always subtle (the Cold War, detante and the fall of Communnism) and sometimes actually relevant to the story. The reference to 9/11, to me anyways, just seemed pointless as it adds nothing to Le Chiffre's character or the plot. There are too many action sequences in this film, which hurts it a little bit. They make Bond seem like Superman, jumping around on top of construction sites and bursting through walls (I could hear the George Reeves Superman theme in my head when he did that). And the way Bond heals from all of his wounds is so astounding, he'd put Wolverine to shame. David Arnold provides probably his best Bond score, though his music, especially for the action sequences, are loud and obnoxious. And I know that this is Bond's first mission, but that doesn't mean he should just barely use the Bond Theme. I think it was Arnold himself on a special feature on the Bond music who said "Don't be afraid to use the Bond Theme. If it's not in the film, its just a regular action film." Or something of that nature anyway (and I hope they stop making the Bond films look and feel like a regular action film. The Bonds have always been different from the rest and the direction the producers are going in are practically disgracing Broccoli's hard work). reviewText: CASINO ROYALE**** Out of 5Release Date- November 17th, 2006Running Time- 144-MinutesRating- PG-13Screenplay- Neal Purvis, Robert Wade & Paul HaggisDirector- Martin CampbellStarring- Daniel Craig, Eva Green, Mads Mikkelsen, Giancarlo Giannini, Jeffrey Wright, Jesper Christensen and Judi Dench as MI'll be the first to admit I'm not the biggest fan of the Bond series, while I do enjoy the movies when a new Bond movie is released I'm not in a rush to go see it. I'll watch it whenever I get around to it. So my opinion on Casino Royale may not hold as much weight as the hardcore fans, but I'll give it a go.After the Die Another Day, which was the 20th Bond movie Pierce Brosnan was out as James Bond and Daniel Craig was in. While Daniel Craig has been around for a while he wasn't very well known. A lot of fans were upset that Brosnan was out. When it comes to the best James Bond that title is between Sean Connery, Roger Moore and Pierce Brosnan and it seems many lean towards Brosnan; Daniel Craig was getting some heat when he was announced, but after the release of Casino Royale many were now hailing Daniel Craig as the best James Bond. I think it's still too early to declare Craig has the best Bond, but he's on his way to earning that title; I'll get back to that later.The one amazing thing about this franchise is how it went from decade to decade starting in the 60s and is still going strong today. How many franchises can go on that long and change with the times? It's quite rare, but I'll give the filmmakers of the series credit for keeping the Bond flicks going strong.I'm not sure which of the series would be my favorite, but Casino Royale is a frontrunner, but the movie isn't without it's flaws. Casino Royale starts off quite explosive and while it stays strong through out I do think it could have been slightly better. The biggest problem I had was the 144-minute running time. While I wouldn't say Casino Royale ever dragged at all and each scene does move the movie forward I do think it could have used a bit of editing. I personally don't think the movie needed to be as long as it was, but with that said despite the running time Casino Royale never drags.The screenplay by Neal Purvis, Robert Wade & Paul Haggis is well written and the characters are solid, but I have to say I wasn't too into the villains. In my opinion they were sort of forgettable. The Bond series has almost always had great villains, but this time around I never really cared too much about them. Besides that the script is quite strong with some excellent dialogue and excellent set ups. The Bond movies are often over the top, but not in a bad way, but the script here seemed a bit more real in my opinion.Director Martin Campbell previously directed the Bond movie GoldenEye, which happened to be the first time Brosnan played the role and here he is returning to the series and directing the part, which happens to be Daniel Craig's debut in the series. Casino Royale in my opinion might feature the best and most exciting action sequences of the series. The action is quite well done and strays from the typical Hollywood action movie put out these days and due to that they work even better. With 144-minutes it can be tough to keep the pace going and Martin Campbell is able to sustain a strong pacing and always keeps the movie interesting. I'm not really into poker and those scenes are the only time I started to lose a little bit of interest, but Campbell is able to keep the tension high and was able to keep my interest just when I would start to lose it.The Bond Girl is one of the most important things about any Bond movie outside of whose playing James Bond, the Bon Girl is the next big thing. Eva Green is the latest and while I did like the character she wasn't the best of the Bond Girls, but easily one of the sexiest of them all. Eva Green was good in her role, but I don't think she would be one of the elite, but she does work amazingly well with Daniel Craig and that in part helped elevate her a bit.I'm not sure who would take my top spot for James Bond, but Daniel Craig just might take that spot. His Bond was a little darker and a little more bad a** (almost reminds of Jack Bauer a little bit). From an acting stand point, Daniel Craig delivers a solid performance, but I don't think he's the best actor to play the role in line delivery, don't get take that wrong. I think Daniel Craig is an excellent actor, but I don't think he was the best in terms of delivering his lines, but from a psychical stand point I think he was by far the best.Daniel Craig also does really well with emotion without any lines. I don't wanna spoil anything, but a certain scene with Craig and Green towards the end is one of the best moments of the series and without any lines Daniel Craig was quite powerful. I still think it's too early to say Daniel Craig is the best, but he's well on his way. I haven't seen Quantum of Solace yet, so maybe that will put him over the top for me.Overall Casino Royale was an excellent entry in the series and Daniel Craig proved all the naysayers wrong and delivers a top notch performance. Fans of the series should enjoy and casual fans like me could also enjoy this. While Casino Royale stays true to the series it also takes a slightly different direction and possibly even non-fans might like this one.

reviewText: What film new Bond film did everyone else see that they are raving about it?  I own every other Bond film with the exception of this one(and boy, am I glad I rented it and didn't buy it).  Folks are noting that this is a realistic Bond -- where?  Was it during the Spiderman sequence as two man are scaling a construction site?  Oh, and the chase through a construction site (popping in and out of shafts and construction holes) apparently so perfectly choreographed that it may as well be "A Chorus Line."  No one runs at top speed through a major construction site unscathed or unblocked shooting and skipping through unknown crevices, without slamming into some dangerous obstacle on the other side -- ABSOLUTELY RIDICULOUS!!!  I would rather suspend belief and embrace an Alligator Submarine, an invisible car, a human jet-pack, or a mini-jet that exits from a Horse Carrier.  And, the gas tanker sequence, it may as well have been a Hook and Ladder chase through the streets of San Francisco (oh, that's right, that chase actually had me riveted!).  How convenient that Bond realized that the tanker windshield had been fully taken out, while his action sequence was in the back of the tanker -- in real life he would not have know that if he propelled himself from the top of the cab that he would land squarely next to the driver instead of banging off the front of the cab, unto the ground, and under the tires.  Bye bye Daniel Craig!  The film was about an hour too long.  Gimme Jaws and the good old days anytime because if this is the new Bond, it's time to find a new film icon.  Oh, that's right, Spiderman 3 is coming this summer and we'll see even more high-rise scaling displays.  At least I can believe that I superhero CAN DO THAT!  This Bond was realistic, realistically BAD!

reviewText: In a reboot of the venerable spy franchise, James Bond (Daniel Craig), newly invested with his license to kill, goes after Le Chiffre (Mads Mikkelson), an international financier with very shady connections, and falls in love with a Bond girl (Eva Green) that we can actually care about.With this film, Craig becomes the second best Bond after Sean Connery and, given time, he may take the number one spot.  Like Connery, he has some rough edges and a believable physicality.  He is much more of a rogue agent in this one, supported by M (Judy Densch) but never sure of whom he can trust.  The script (by Neal Purvis, Robert Wade, and Paul Haggis) replaces the usual (and, I admit, frequently entertaining) glib double entendres of previous outings with real dialogue in a well-written script that builds character.  The sequel, "Quantum of Solace," showed that going too far down the dark, gritty road to a greater realism can remove some of the magic from this classic character, but here they get it just right.

reviewText: Bond is back and that is a good thing, just not a great thing. Sadly, although I too like the new Bond, the script doesn't quite hold up the fort.The usual suspects put in their appearances and we are pleased, but I for one didn't get a lot out of the supporting cast of disposable villains. They didn't quite seem up to the challenge. The fights between the professional that Bond is and the miscellaneous thugs seemed prolonged. How is it that every gun-carrying lout can defend himself like a master? Many seemed to get the best of Bond, including the sprinting messenger in the opening sequence, which was far too long and entirely improbable. I kept thinking, well, you know, they can jump and fly better and farther than Spiderman. Bond's new playmate seemed more bitchy than sexy. She was constantly giving him the feminist line but failed to deliver the goods. She hardly seemed worth resigning over, and I never believed for a minute that he would fall in love with her. All of this is the fault of the script. Now that we've got a new Bond, let's get a new screenwriter.

reviewText: I'm no stranger to product placement, nor am I against it, but when I saw this movie, I couldn't help but feel the experience was cheapened by all the close-ups on Sony products.  When the camera purposely zooms in to show Blu-ray on a disc, PSP on the back of a videogame system, or Cybershot on a camera, it gets a little annoying.  It's no surprise that Sony placed all those products, it is a Sony Pictures film, but the purposely placed shots of Sony products was too much for me to handle.There wouldn't have been an issue if there were a Pepsi sign in the background, or if a character used a Cybershot camera; but when a shot zooms in to show the brand, model, or format, I call commercial.  If this is what all James Bond movies are going to be like, I might as well just stay home and watch TV.  I don't pay to go to a theater to be bereted by a two-hour long Sony commmercial, and I won't pay to do it again.

reviewText: Casino Royale was the kick up the backside that the Bond series needed if it wished to carry on forward and compete with the younger pretenders such as the Bourne series or even the Jack Ryan series. With the absurd invisible car in Die Another Day, things were getting too cartoonish and despite good box-office receipts it will only be a matter of time before fans had enough.In steps Daniel Craig, a new Bond taking on a familiar story, Fleming's first foray of James Bond, Casino Royale. Craig's chance at Bond was met with mixed feelings, some even setting up websites in protest. This, before even filming took place, was unfair and misguided. However, it worked in the film's favour anyway as the publicity helped the film shoot through the box-office roof and without much help of PR and advertising either.Craig is a tougher Bond, steely like Connery and without the comedy routine that Roger Moore brought to the role. He is a brilliant Bond, a man who is at war with his own morality as well as his enemies, a theme that hasn't really explored in previous Bond films.Eva Green is sexy AND intelligent as Vesper Lynd, and it is by no means just another bit of crumpet for Bond. It is through her fate that Bond becomes the cold-hearted ruthless killing machine that we have come to know.Mads Mikkelsen plays the chilling - though not the main villain as we find out near the end - Le Chiffre. Unlike other Bond villains he has no clear quirks (ala Dr. evil) but he does weep tears of blood when in stressful situations.In fact on the whole CASINO ROYALE loses most of the gimmicks and familiar base-situated-in-a-volcano that has grown over the years in Bond movies(to the absurd point in Moonraker). The gadgets are near non-existent, CGI is minimal, and so the stunts are amazing as always (especially the crane jump near the beginning). Even the famous, iconic Bond tune is only heard at the end.The only critism that can befall CASINO ROYALE is the avoidance of today's terrorist climate. The film does involve terrorism but avoids it front on (the bad guys here are arms dealers). This still seems like a world where 9/11 hasn't happened, and that MI6 are still trudging after arms dealers and misfits rather than terror groups. The Soviets were fair game for Bond when the Cold War was on, so how about Iran or North Korea?

reviewText: I was never a big James Bond fan.  The first one I ever saw at the cinema was GOLDENEYE.  Though many people who saw it with me and many people now say it was the best, I thought it wasn't worth the money or the time.  And since it was supposed to be the "best Bond" I didn't see much reason to watch any of the others.But I was told that the remake of CASINO ROYALE was a new and different James Bond picture.  So, I gave it a chance, and I loved it.  I think what separates Daniel Craig's Bond from all the others is that he brings a more human element to the role.  His Bond can get tired.  He can get hurt.  He can be vulnerable.  He can make mistakes.  He can be nervous and scared.  He can even die!  That's an action hero that I can watch again and again.  I can't relate to someone who sweeps the beautiful dame off her feet immediately after death-defying stunts as if nothing had ever happened.  But I can relate to someone who after a tough foot-chase or a battering brawl has to stop and catch his breath.I have heard that this new era of Bond does not have many of the critics or many of the hard-core fans happy.  But it leaves me satisfied enough.  Not only satisfied enough to watch CASINO ROYALE tonight but also to go see QUANTUM OF SOLACE tomorrow.

reviewText: All kidding aside,Casino Royale is hands down one of the greatest Bond films of all time.Anyone spoiled by gadgets,cheesy quips, and his "three women per film" quota will be a bit disappointed (even the gun barrel sequence doesn't start off the movie),but Casino Royale makes up for it in giving us the Bond that Ian Fleming creates half a century ago.Daniel Craig would silence anyone on who frowned on his being cast as Bond.He ranks with Connery and Dalton on staying true to the Bond in Fleming's novels.And even the updated screenplay is exceptional for keeping the story grounded, centering on a high stakes poker game to prevent funding of terrorism, as opposed to World Domination which goes all the way back to Dr. No(1962).The main villian LeChiffe isn't a larger than life evil genius with a hallowed out volcano layer, but a banker that funds terrorist activities who must replenish the money he stole, before his clients get to him.Even the main "Bond Girl" Vespa Lynde (Eva Green) is the most multi faceted since Diana Rigg from On Her Majesties Secret Servive(1969).Casino Royale is a total reboot of a nearly half century franchise that ranges from great (From Russia With Love,Goldfinger,On Her Majesties Secret Service,The Spy Who Loved Me) to far-fetched (Diamonds Are Forever,Moonraker, The World Is Not Enough),and will take it's righful place in the former category.

reviewText: Without a doubt, this would have been a five-star action movie for me if it didn't lose focus briefly at the beginning of the final act, but it remains one of the finer Bond films.  Craig's Bond is grittier than that of his predecessors, with some unresolved issues that make him dangerous, even to himself.  Perhaps because this film is set at the beginning of Bond's career, he is neither as suave nor as at ease as the other Bonds, although he is every bit as likable.The storyline is straightforward, at least in overview:  in tracking down a bombmaker, Bond uncovers a broader terrorist presence that leads to a French financier, Le Chiffre, who literally weeps blood and who promises off-shore safe haven for terrorist funds.  What the terrorists don't know is that Le Chiffre (Mads Mikkelsen) is using their funds for his own enrichment  When Bond thwarts Le Chiffre's plan, all bets are off except at the casino, where Le Chiffre attempts to win back the sum before the terrorists get to him.  As usual, Bond has no intention of letting Le Chiffre succeed.  And also as usual, there is a Bond girl, Vesper Lynd (Eva Green).All the actors, including Judi Dench as the authoritative M, fit their roles admirably.  But since most people watch the Bond movies for the blow-'em-up, adrendaline-saturated scenes, the real question is whether it is an exciting movie.  The answer is yes, except for the flabbiness mentioned in the first paragraph.-- Debbie Lee Wesselmann
summary: I love Craig's gritty Bond (4+ stars)

reviewText: To me and numerous Fleming (book Bond)fans the best Bond was Timothy Dalton. His reign was tragically cut short due to legal wrangles in the early 90's.Although some people enjoyed his successor Pearce Brosnan as 007, i found him a lightweight, wooden pastiche of all the previous Bonds. In addition his films got progressively worse culminating in the truly dire Die Another Day.Needless to say i was overjoyed when Brosnan got the boot and Daniel Craig was signed on. Bond was going back to Fleming and back to basics for the first time since Timothy Dalton.Casino Royale was simply stunning, better than anything i could have ever hoped for in a Bond film. Easily the best Bond perfomance and film since "Living Daylights" or "Licence to Kill".Although Dalton has remained my favourite Bond, Casino Royale has become my fave film surpassing "Daylights".Mr Craig deserves all the praise he can get but i do encourage people to check out Timothy Dalton as Bond in order to reappraise his efforts. You may be surprised as to how good Dalton really was as Fleming's Bond.
summary: The best Bond since Timothy Dalton.

reviewerName: Desert Gypsy "A Brooklyn Girl Out West"
reviewText: In my humble opinion Daniel Craig is the perfect new-incarnation of Bond. Like a streamlined new millennium version of Steve McQueen he brings a harsh grittiness to the role that to me fits the original written works. There are enough reviews on here that hash and rehash the contents of the film but I think this kind of thing generally boils down to personal preference.So, why did *I* like this film? Well, as far as what to expect from Bond, right from the opening scene you *definitely* get the idea that "Dorothy, you're NOT in Kansas anymore"!!! Without "spoiling it" I can tell you that Craig as Bond is serious as a heart attack from minute one and has no time to waste with the sometimes silly one liners that have peppered Bond movies of the past. He shows a range and depth of raw yet reigned in emotion unlike ANY of his Bond predecessors. He also gives new meaning to "edgy" - in a particularly wince-worthy scene you begin to question if he is uncompromisingly hard as nails or more than just a bit crazy.The action sequences are some of the best I have ever seen; better than those of the Bourne series if you're looking for something to compare it to.Since the story/script had the daunting task of being true to THIS film yet still had to tie the ones to follow together, I think it did a great job of connecting the dots.This DVD set includes a second disk which has the "making of" Casino Royale.The best I can do is say that whether or not you are a fan of the Bond legacy, this is definitely a film worth watching.
summary: bond fan or not, this is a fantastic movie

reviewText: There was a huge amount of controversy in fandom surrounding Daniel Craig as the new James Bond, most of it negative, and mostly centered around his appearance. I've mentioned before that I'm really not a visually-oriented person, so maybe that's why such objections never made any sense to me. It's vastly more important to me that the actor is convincing in the role, and Daniel Craig fit this role in this film very well.Of course, Casino Royale is a different sort of Bond film from the most recent ones, and substituting Daniel Craig's James Bond for Pierce Brosnan's really wouldn't have worked. Nor would Pierce Brosnan's James Bond have worked in Casino Royale.As for those who complain that Casino Royale is mucking around with the tradition--yes, this is vastly different from Die Another Day. But this is not the first time the franchise has shifted direction. It's happened pretty much every time there's a new Bond, though it seems to have been a more gradual shift from Moore to Dalton to Brosnan. What makes it more acceptable is that Casino Royale takes place at the very beginning of the Bond mythos, so even if one doesn't view the movies as disparate entities, it's believable that when he first became 007, he was rougher around the edges than he was later.Casino Royale shows the very beginning of James Bond--how he becomes 007. The start of the film was a dizzying blur, partially in black and white, depicting his earning that 00 status (two kills required--the first one's the hardest). It was brutal and stark, and only the distance created by the film techniques kept it from being too graphic.There's a requisite busy action scene, with a chase scene that was so long and involved such Jackie-Chan-worthy stunts that I started laughing, earning a glare from my older son. Whoops. No, I wasn't loud. I'm not one of those people.But then we get to the meat of the movie, with Bond against Le Chiffre, a terrorist financier who's also an inveterate gambler. Bond's mission is to join the high-stakes game and win--or rather, keep Le Chiffre from winning, bankrupting him, and forcing him to accept the government's offer. Enter Vesper Lynd, the treasury agent who comes along to ensure that Bond isn't wasting the government's money.You can tell it's been a long time since I read the books, because I kept hearing her name as "Vespa", which made some of the jokes a little nonsensical.It's not a spoiler to say that Bond falls in love with her and she eventually betrays him--after all, James Bond cannot have a HEA romantic ending, particularly not at this juncture, because we know from earlier films that he's single. Don't try to sort out the timelines--it'll give you a headache, particularly if you try to reconcile Judi Dench's M with Goldeneye.All in all, an exciting film. A change in direction for the franchise, to be sure, but one that was necessary, I think, to re-energize the series. I'm looking forward to Bond-22, whatever it is.

reviewText: Toughness and physicality stand out more than anything in the 22nd James Bond movie, thanks to the new Bond character played by Daniel Craig.  His physical appearance is tougher than any previous Bond, and that adds to the terrific and exciting action in Casino Royale.  His on screen presence, action or not, is always solid and he has a way of easily drawing in the interest of the audience.  His acting is just great, and I don't think you could find another Bond replacement anywhere else.  I have no doubt that the Bond franchise will continue because of this man, and Casino Royale has become one of the most popular of all the Bond movies ever made.While Daniel Craig is the strongest element that made this movie work, Casino Royale is actually a wonderful film in its own.  The story and plot are very well told and very interesting, told in the Bond tradition with the refreshness of a modern film rolled in.  The action is simply amazing.  Only 2 big action scenes but they are intense and again, more physical than any previous Bond film.  I don't mean fights, but more like stunts and quickness you would see in a Jackie Chan movie.  The other characters are wonderful too, especially the villain, Le Cheffre.  The man is not a physical challenge for Bond, but an intelligent one.  He carries a nasty scar over his fake left eye that speaks villain for itself.  The Bond girl in this movie is different than one would expect from previous Bond movies.  There is actually an emotional attachment between her and Bond, and we get to see what becomes of Bond's trust towards women after Casino Royale.The run time felt a bit long, nearly 2-1/2 hours.  The intensity slows way down at the end, but picks up with an ending I admit I did not see coming, and very important story for the future of Bond.  I loved the beginning of the film, which creates a unique beginning for the famous "Bond walk, stop, aim and shoot - seen through the eye of the enemy's gun" you see before every Bond movie.  The title credits and theme song "You Know My Name" were unique yet fit very well.  Bond locations have come back in Casino Royale, where as in some of the latter Brosnan movies, exotic locations were become nothing more than the inside of a studio.  Casino Royale takes place in Madagascar, Bahamas, Miami, and Montenegro.Bond fan or not, you will love this film.  It is everything a good classic Bond film has and what a film for today needs.  Yes, Bond seems to be coming back to its roots in this one.  Casino Royale is arguably one of the best Bond movies made and Daniel Craig might just give the original Sean Connery some competition.Acting - 4.5Action - 4.5Charcaters - 4.5Story - 4.5Overall - 4.5

reviewText: Bond's essential 21st century reboot is expertly orchestrated and potently thrilling, although I wonder if it may have pressed itself a bit too far in an effort to feel contemporary. The parkour and hold'em scenes in particular already feel out-of-touch, with both fads freshly occupying the rear-view mirror, but that's hardly a fresh hurdle for the series to clear. Daniel Craig makes for a far better Bond than I'd hoped, especially during the nail-biting action scenes or the prerequisite mingling with the high-cultured elite. He isn't the quip-slinging lady killer that Connery or Brosnan were, at least not yet, but he's twice as convincing when the time comes to flex a little muscle (or leap from one precariously-perched construction crane to another, as it were). This isn't a perfect effort - the poker climax is recklessly telegraphed, and the final forty minutes feel like a weepy, long-winded epilogue - but it is an action joyride, stuffed with clever winks and nods at the character's past, and one of the best Bonds ever made.
summary: Craig's First Mission with MI-6 is a Tough, Expectation-Shattering Endeavor

reviewText: NOTE: I'm rating the DVD itself, not the movie on it. The movie is incredible - easily the best, most realistic, most believable 007 ever. The movie gets a 5 out of 5 in all areas.But the DVD... ugh. I suspect Sony, in trying to push yet another proprietary format - Blu-Ray in this case - purposely degraded the picture and sound quality of this standard-definition DVD. The picture is grainy and slightly out-of-focus throughout. The sound is muffled, as if the sound engineer cranked up the mid-bass and turned down the treble, making vocals nearly unintelligible.When I first played this on my system (Westinghouse HDTV, Sony SD DVD player, Denon 5/6/7-channel receiver, Bose speaker system), I thought I was losing my mind. As a sanity check, I watched "The Full Monty," a 10-year-old low-budget independent film: it looked good and sounded great. I then tried the previous Bond film from 4 years ago, "Die Another Day" (which was *not* a Sony picture). The result: AMAZING picture and sound!So beware - this DVD is, in my observation and opinion, INTENTIONALLY FLAWED. I now hope HD DVD wipes the floor with Blu-Ray, and that this amazing film is re-released - without sour grapes - in that high-def format.
summary: Sony must have sabatoged this DVD to force more Blu-Ray sales

reviewText: The James Bond franchise periodically changes lead actor, as fan favorites age out of the role and a new actor runs the gauntlet of high expectations.  Thus for Daniel Craig's debut as Agent 007 in 2006's "Casino Royale."  Not only is this a new Bond, it is a reboot of the series, taking Bond back to his roots as an agent licensed to kill.The movie opens with a stunningly gritty retrospective showing Bond earning his 007 rating with two very ugly, messy kills.  This Bond is a relentless thug with only the thinnest veneer of the wit and charm associated with the role.  Licensed to kill, Bond is off in pursuit of a mysterious financier of terrorists named Le Chiffre.  The long chase ends at a casino in Montengro and a high stakes poker game.  Le Chiffre has speculated with other people's money; Bond, backed by M's (Judi Dench) money and by a treasury agent named Vesper Lynd, intends to bankrupt his opponent at the table.  The poker game turns into a fight to the death, at the table and outside the casino.  Bond's job will be complicated by betrayal and by his feelings for his partner.  A messy conclusion will lead directly to the next movie.Daniel Craig takes some getting used as Bond, but he ultimately owns the role (and has improved through two sequels).  "Casino Royale" is recommended as a successful reboot of an entertaining franchise.

reviewText: There have been several reboots of the James Bond series but this one is by far the most dramatic and succesful. In `License to Kill' the producers decided to send Bond back to his roots with the grittiest, most realistic Bond movie ever. Unfortunately they produced arguably the worst official Bond movie ever. Besides `From Russia with Love', `Casino Royale' is perhaps the most faithful adaptation of a Bond novel. The first third of the movie sets up the story and the rest of the movie picks up where the book begins. There was a complete reworking of the ending to add excitement but it actually served to make things rather confusing.So is it a success? I am a lifelong Bond fan who owns nearly every Bond film on DVD and I would measure this film as one of the best ever. Like Batman Begins, this as a textbook example of how a venerable series can be reworked a correctly. Unlike many Bond fans I was pleased with the choice of Daniel Craig as the new Bond and he exceeded my best expectations. Gone are the asinine Bond one liners. Gone are the crazy gadgets and say farewell to Q and Moneypenny. The core of guns, gorgeous woman and opulent settings remain intact, in fact this may be the most beautiful Bond movie ever created. The only complaint I have is that the music wasn't up to par. For some reason the producers of this generation of Bond films don't seem to be able to capture the fantastic music accompaniments of films like Goldfinger, You Only Die Twice and even Moonraker.Die Another Day made piles of cash but the series was becoming increasingly painful. The absurd stunts, the headache inducing double entendres, the bad dialogue and the silly characters would have eventually done the series in. After Moonraker the producers pulled way back and released For Your Eyes Only. Personally I found Moonraker the more enjoyable of the two. Casino Royale is the best reboot yet and ranks as the best Bond since at least the Roger Moore era. The story is smaller, the characters more believable and the dialogue is VASTLY improved. Sorry Pierce but Daniel Craig is a big improvement. Good Job EON.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The newest entry into the James Bond series probably has the least in terms of cheeky, double-entendre humor and voluptuous femme fatales, but it has the series' trademark action jacked up to current blockbuster standards and a Bond that goes deeper into the iconic character's psyche. Although director Martin Campbell steers the 2006 movie with often breathless pacing and popcorn-level aplomb, it does feel too long at 144 minutes, especially in the last half-hour or so. Some set sequences, while mainly thrilling, feel downright endless like the construction site chase and the collapsing Venetian villa.Fortunately, as the latest 007, craggy-faced Daniel Craig is a charismatic enough actor to sustain interest over the running time. Physically, he cuts a convincing figure as a roughneck agent, though the camera seems overly preoccupied with showcasing his chiseled physique. Not since the young Sean Connery in the role's first incarnation has an actor so successfully redefined the role within the contours of his own screen persona. His natural intelligence and piercing blue eyes bring a surprising soulfulness to the more dramatic scenes, and his roughhewn manner resuscitates a Bond more befitting of Ian Fleming's original vision of a hungry agent intent on proving his mettle.As usual, the plot is impossible to describe without going into detail, but suffice it to say it involves an underground banker named LeChiffre who engineers terrorist attacks on companies in order to short sell their stock. It culminates into a high-stakes poker game (the driest sequence in the movie) and a few necessary deceptions. Written by Neil Purvis, Robert Wade and Paul Haggis, the story feels more substantive this time and less reliant on pyrotechnics in place of character development, probably because the filmmakers were intent on remaining true to Ian Fleming's source novel (Casino Royale).Judi Dench shows up again as the authoritative M, and her role has surprising heft within the story. The other surprise is that the main Bond girl, Vesper Lynd, is also more substantive and complex than usual, although Eva Green plays her in a relatively pallid manner despite the advance. For once, the Bond villains seem as persecuted as Bond himself with Mads Mikkelsen playing close to the vest as the creepily scarred LeChiffre. The two-disc 2007 DVD set unfortunately has no commentary track on the first disc, though the print condition and audio quality are pristine. There are three featurettes on the second disc, including a thoughtful profile on the Bond girls.
summary: A Solid Return for Bond with Craig a Blessedly More Roughhewn Variation

reviewText: Last night we watched Casino Royale in the company of our friends Don and Virginia McDonald. This James Bond movie introduces a new identify for Bond, one that is closer to how Ian Fleming wrote about our action hero.Daniel Craig provides a powerful performance as the novice spy who finally becomes part of those who belong to Her Majesty's Secret Service. Some of the scenes are brutal, the action is non-stop, and the opening of the film is so incredible, that we found ourselves glued to the TV.Daniel Craig is handsome in a rugged way, reckless and egotistical, but suave, endearing, and believable. The dialogue between James Bond and his leading lady, while in the train, shall go down in history as one of the most psychologically thrilling give-and take exchanges that serve as an introduction we have ever watched.Not following the right sequence, Judi Dench is "Q" in this film, something that given that it is the introduction of Bond, does not follow the time line, but she is magnificent as the exasperated M, who says... "Bond should have the decency to defect... How I miss the cold war."The plot is just as the book ordered, and it sends our hero into his first mission, which is to surface the mastermind behind an operation that funds international terrorists. As usual with Bond movies, this film takes us from Uganda to Madagascar, then to the Bahamas, and ends in Montenegro, where James Bond finds himself confronting the enemy during a poker game where millions of dollars are at stake.The leading lady by the name of Vesper is played by Eva Green, and she delivers a superb performance as the woman who captures Bond's heart, only to place a dagger right through it... leaving Bond so hurt that he becomes numb to emotions.As for the gadgets, James Bond receives an Austin Martin that shall become the dream of every fan... a glove compartment filled with all the toys ever dreamed... and prepared to become the perfect emergency room.One of the best lines of all times by James Bond is that he likes his martinis... shaken not stirred, but here we get a twist, for when asked by a bartender how he wants his famous drink prepared... he replies.. "Do I look like I give a damn?"When this movie was released we watched it at a local theatre, but as soon as we received the DVD from Amazon.com, as we do with all films we own in our collection, we incorporated English sub-titles for the hearing impaired and watched the film with the assurance that we would not miss a single line.Finally, when Bond is tortured, 007 provides another line that shall go down in movie history. Let's hope you can spot it. With a terrifying climax, this movie leaves us with James Bond at his best, and the clamor for... more... more... Bond... James Bond!

reviewText: Daniel Craig is Bond.  The character is different from the sauve sophistication of the early years, the laughing of the middle years, or the more recent days of Pierce Brosnan.  Craig is about action, and lots of it.  Craig can also share the screen well.  Yes, this Bond film has a love story in its midst, but one cannot come to expect that in future fears (whether that is good or bad, I leave to you).  The chase scene in the construction yard is among the best I've seen; M's character is played brilliantly by Dame Judi Dench - a dramatically powerful actress; and Eva Green greatly exceeds the intellect and romance of past Bond girls while holding her own in a role competing with 007.  While the technological wiz-bang stuff of past films make an occasional appearance, its absence is refreshing.  This Bond is about muscle, force, and measured calculations of employing both to effect an end.  Kill a traitor?  No problem.  Eliminate a bomber?  Piece of cake.  On the other hand, if you're looking for a kindler, gentler Bond now that the cold war is over, look again.  There is no cold war in this movie, not in the least bit, and the movie couldn't be hotter because of it.  Go see it, and enjoy.

reviewText: My decision to see this film was based primarily on the rave reviews it had gotten, plus the fact that one of the best screenwriters in the business (Paul Haggis) was attached.The best Bond movie ever? The best Bond ever? I suppose that depends on your point of view. If you've been looking for a more "Americanized" version of the series, and you prefer your 007 to be more in the mold of  Jason Statham (Transporter 1-2) than the classic Bond types - Connery, Brosnan and Moore - then this one's for you. Speaking of Statham, I couldn't help but think Craig had Statham in mind when he was deciding how he would play one of film's classic roles. However, although I did enjoy Craig's performance in "Casino," I do think he's got a ways to go before he'll be ready for "Transporter 3."As for the movie itself, I found it hard to keep track of all the individual pieces and characters, and where they fit into the main theme of the film. The movie was long, and stretched out a bit too thin; I found the story hard to follow, and it seemed, at times, to drift away from the central theme. Some viewers may find this movie confusing and hard to digest if they have a short attention span.The best part of "Casino" is the action sequence that takes place in the beginning. (I can see now why Craig was getting hurt so often during the filming). From that point on, the movie drifts along like a barge cut loose from its morings. Toward the end of the film, it began to appear as though the writers had a hard time figuring out where to call it quits; just when you think the end is near (at times I hoped it was), off it goes again in an entirely different direction.Bottom line: give me the old 007 that we've known and loved in the past. And more of that familiar soundtrack, too. Ah, Sean, Pierce and Roger -  where are you guys when we need you?
summary: Where's Sean, Pierce and Roger when you need them?

reviewText: The DVD release of "Casino Royale" looks so good, Q must have personally supervised the transfer. Here's another case where MGM's home-video connection with Sony (and its A/V wizards) pays off big time. From the high-grain b&w; intro to the scenes in the Bahamas and old Europe, the visuals are all stunning -- reference-quality work. The audio starts off strong but distinctly front-biased, but once the big footrace scene starts the 6-D soundstage roars into action.The extras don't follow the template MGM has been using for 007 titles (as on the "Ultimate Edition"box sets), so look for a collector's edition down the double-dip road. The main docu follows actor Daniel Craig as he becomes Bond -- including footage of the gloomy day when he first met the press -- shaken and stirred by his jet-ski ride across the Thames. Instead of a goofy life preserver, Craig says, he'll use water wings next time. The actor says he was prepared for Bond fan backlash, but when the Internet campaign against him kicked in, "It did shake me up." (Apparently the fanboys hadn't checked out the excellent "Layer Cake.")The second docu is the usual stunt-work chronicle. The third rounds up most of the Bond girls. There's also a lame music video, one of those where the singer wanders around in the movie like he belongs there.The movie comes nicely letterboxed (a cinematic 2.40:1), but there's also a full-screenversion for those who must. Q must have been fresh out of DTS audio, unfortunately. The Blu-ray version no doubt sparkles.Put this title straight onto the year's top 10 list. Well done, indeed.

reviewText: Kill it and start at the beginning.The Casino Royale team have finally done it, pulled me out of my Bond boredom with a fresh new script and a fresh new face. Gone is the smirky, smart alecky bugs bunny in a butler suit that was making me roll my eyes in frustration. Instead of campy, toungue in cheek, cast off one liners, we get intelligent dialogue and subtext between Bond and his new leading lady. No large insidious criminal installations blowing up at the end and stupidly baroque torture scenes. We get a bare bones interrogation with wicked humor and a journey that turns a cold man colder.Not perfect, but I was quite surprised and Daniel Craig has a fascinating face and presence.
summary: How to Revitalize an old horse?

reviewText: Daniel Craig did a fantastic job as the new 007, and in no way did he disappoint by trying to change the original James Bond persona.  Hard edge, direct, interestingly cool, and sexy as hell- yes, Bond is back! I enjoyed his love-hate relationship with M (a welcome return by superb Judi Dench), and thought the scene where Bond breaks into M's house (to search her computer for some valuable information) and is caught by M, who reprimands Bond as he's about to leave with, "Don't ever break into my house again," a very nice touch. This scene is a primary example of the love-hate relationship between Bond and his superior, M.  "Casino Royale" opens with a great scene of Craig doing the famous "gun barrel" shot which phases into an artistic title sequence while the "theme song" plays.  Bond fans will appreciate the chase scenes with Bond and terrorist plotters, both at a high rise construction sight and at an airport. Thrilling jumps and leaps from the high rise are awesome and the fight between Bond and a terrorist attempting to blow up a plane with a fuel truck is excitingly played out.  And let's not forget about the Bond girls!  Exotic beauty Caterina Murino who first captivates Bond with her beauty, and later pays for her involvement with him with her life.  The movie locales are sumptuous and give the film that "Bond" movie look and feel that Bond fans have grown to know and expect.Giving the fine performance that Pierce Brosnan gave as the ultimate suave and debonair Bond, it was difficult to imagine anyone else taking on the role.  When Daniel Craig was named as the "new James Bond," many fans felt as I did- "who is this guy?"  I'm glad to be able to say that Craig not only succeeded in the role, but also took it to new heights!  I'm eager now to see what the next "James Bond" movie will comprise of.  Will there be a "new" Moneypenny?  And will we see a new "Q" introducing all kinds of high-tech gadgets for Bond to use while on Her Majesty's Secret Service?  After having just seen "Casino Royale," it makes me want to return to the very beginning of the Bond films and start with "Dr. No" and watch each of the "Bond" films, one per night, until I have seen them all.  The "Casino Royale" 2-disc Special Edition DVD is a total blast and is highly recommended for unabashed high rise thrills, airport chases, and attempted murders at Casino tables. And I believe all my fellow James Bond fans will join me in joyously proclaiming BOND IS BACK!!

reviewText: I've watched Bond films since I was a wee child, and have always enjoyed the mix of action, romance and exotic locales.  But the movies of late have become so formulaic and staid that the franchise was in danger of a giant leap over the shark.So, the producers of this latest film did exactly what those who made "Batman Begins" last year did.  They went back to the beginning, stripped away all the fancy gadgets, pithy one liners and unbelievable plots and got back to the simple idea of a British agent who is a cool, calculating killing machine.There could have been no better choice for this sort of Bond that Daniel Craig.  The man comes aross as coldly single-minded when on a mission.  His affect is calm, well composed and steely throughout the movie.  Watching this guy you can really believe he could wipe someone out without batting an eye.Playing against him is the lovely Eva Green, as different from the stereotypical Bond girl as any woman could be.  The two start off as reluctant team members, with Green's character loathfully dismissive of Bond as a murderous womanizer.  Needless to say, her attitude does a 180 degree turn as the movie unfolds.There are many of the classic Bond accessories, including high tech gadgets and fancy roadsters.  But these serve as spice to liven up an already excellent story, not as the main dish in themselves.  Throw in international intrigue and some fantastic action sequences, and you have a refreshingly original film that stays true to the best of the series.  Very highly recommended.

reviewText: This film features Judi Dench and I love her. She is one of those British actors who conceal their enormous skill (clarity of speech, mimic, postures) under a deceptive ease. When acting Shakespeare they can be operatic but when they play "normal" characters they appear real, everyday. But try and ask a lesser professional to play an everyday part and you shall see the difference.Daniel Craig is not such a novelty. I loved Timothy Dalton and he was a very physical Bond as well. I am not saying that Mr Craig is a miscast: he seems an excellent actor (I know no other movie of his), he has a beautiful muscular body that the authors display throughout the film, an eastern European (Polish or Russian I should say) look that is peculiar and easy to remember.The authors tried to offer the public an updated 007, very physical, gory, even crude but casting Mr Craig has been useless because they left the rest unchanged. The famous opening scene, Bond and the bomber jumping from a crane to the other is just as improbable as similar scenes in the past Roger Moore movies were.The situations are trite, the villains are mono dimensional, the women are just beautiful and meaningless.And please, the dialogues?These movies are intended for the general public, allright, but do the lines have to be idiotic? Do they have to convey the usual "Me Tarzan, you Jane" content and ethics? The only really good exchange? That of Bond tortured by Le Chiffre, but perhaps I was distracted by the sight of Mr Craig's naked body.There are a lot of beautiful actors in this film but the rest is unchanged.

reviewText: "Casino Royale" (2006) directed by Martin Campbell is different from the Bond movies I've seen but it is very good. Based on the first novel in the Bond series, it shows James Bond (Daniel Craig) in the beginning of his career. His mission is to destroy a corrupt banker LeChiffre (Mads Mikkelsen} at the poker tables where he never loses and wins a lot of money to supply the various terrorists' organizations. To accomplish this extremely dangerous task, Bond has to rely mostly on himself; there are no fancy gadgets that Q would provide him with. There is no Q either. I think it is the only Bond movie that lets us look rather briefly behind the Super-agent facade to see more human side of Bond. I don't remember any other Bond movie where he would be tortured in the way that made me truly uncomfortable. I also believe that it is the only (or one of very few) movie where Bond fell in love and as the result of that affair, he would never fell in love again. I have only seen Daniel Craig in two movies before "Casino Royale", "The Mother" (2003) and  "Munich" (2005) but he was memorable in both. As new James Bond, he is fabulous - a marvel to look at, he has unbelievably blue eyes, he is in a great shape (remember, he has to rely only on himself while chasing, fighting, shooting, and killing bad guys) and he delivers a very convincing James Bond, sharp, tough but vulnerable - the Bond for a new millennium.8.5/10

reviewText: Casino Royale proves that there is still a lot of life in this series and shows no signs of slowing down any time soon, which is great news for long time fans such as myself. There couldn't have been a better choice to play Bond than Daniel Craig, he brings a realness to the character of Bond, the likes of which hasn't really been seen since the Dalton films. Not saying that the Brosnan films are bad, no way, but it's back to basic Bond in this movie and it is like a fresh breath of air. This movie, being the first story in the series, gets rid of all of the gadgets that movies have relied on for so many films and goes back to emotion and excellent action sequences. It seemed that the Bond movies always tried to out-do the others by having fancier weapons from Q branch, so it is good to see something different.The story itself is full of emotion, comedy and action. Overall, this is exactly what I want out of my James Bond movies. I have seen this movie four times, twice in one day once, and it still isn't old. It is a movie that you learn more about the more you watch it. Everyone just fit, and what better way than to have the same guy who directed Goldeneye direct this?! This being based on the writings of Ian Flemming doesn't hurt either. This is a great movie that you have to see, I can't wait to see the next film!
summary: Daniel Craig Has Proven Himself As Bond

reviewText: This has a few of the reference points that assure you that you're watching a Bond film: the Aston Martin, 'M', the exotic locations and the girls. But as others have said, there's no Moneypenny or Q, and not many gadgets besides a mobile phone obsession -- Sony Ericsson must have paid a fortune for the repeated product placement.But it's in the changing pace of the movie that it feels least like a Bond film: e.g. the mundane toilet killing that kicks the film off, the rather slow recovery sequence leading up to the building collapse in Venice.The worst aspect of this film is the way it tries to ape '24' -- far too much torture, and little sexual content. The theme song sung by Chris Cornell is also bitterly disappointing. (It must now be more than 10 years since a Bond song zoomed up the UK pop charts.)The best aspects of this film are the opening credits (there's even a witty Mandelbrot reference), Daniel Craig throughout, and the staccato end. The movie also a serious, realistic tone lacking in the Roger Moore and Brosnan eras; you finish watching the movie feeling that not all ends have been neatly tied up. It's more like real life.Craig deserved his Bafta nomination. I strongly suspect that the movie largely got its Bafta nomination because the year is 2 007. The movie/DVD is recommended, but not outstanding.
summary: A new JB, but is this more Jack Bauer than James Bond?,

reviewText: I've never cared for Bond films.  Truth be told, my exposure has not been overwhelming, mostly in the form of various hyper-campy 70's versions and the dreadful Pierce Brosnan installments which I've caught in bits and pieces over the years despite my best efforts to avoid them.  No doubt there are films in the series that I would enjoy, but the bad impressions have always left me with little inclination to give them another look  The problem has been, well there have been various problems, but the key one is Bond himself, at least as portrayed by Brosnan and Moore.  He's always supposed to be witty and suave or whatever, but always comes off as completely lame.  I was plenty skeptical about "Casino Royale", but the almost universally positive reviews began rolling in, proclaiming it a darker and less campy entry, with a great, intense turn from Daniel Craig.  The reviews were right: Craig is great as Bond, providing one of the finest troubled action heroes in recent memory and washing away the bitter taste of Brosnan's groan-inducing performances.  Equally significant, "Casino Royale" has nicely varied, well-constructed and often suprisingly intense action scenes.  As many others have pointed out, "Casino Royale" is definitely a bit overlong, but when it's on it's really on, and proves to be more than worth the wait through the slower sections."Casino Royale" brings us back to Bond's beginnings, opening with the dual executions that earned him his 00 status.  This black and white, uber-noir opening sequence is simply as cool as all hell.  So damn cool, in fact, that the film has little hope of topping it, and never does.  This points to one of the flaws in the film which is intertwined with the film's excessive length:  "Casino Royale" tends to get weaker as it moves along.  The first hour or so is pretty much flat-out awesome, with the great opening being followed by a severely cool free-running style chase through a construction site and into an embassy, and later by an intense, over-the-top encounter in an airport.  Once we really start to get involved in the gambling tournament, however, the film loses some steam.  Turns out that Texas Hold 'Em isn't as thrilling as killing people/explosions/whatever.  Now, there's still some killing at this point, the tournament itself is not without interest, and we've got Eva Green to leer at, but the second act is, nevertheless, unquestionably weaker than the first.  This downward trend culminates in the overlong false ending, though this is partially redeemed by a rather sweet final shootout.  "Casino Royale" never loses momentum entirely, not by a long shot, but it definitely could've stood to have the tournament tightened up a bit, and the false ending trimmed by at least a few minutes.  The first hour would've still been the best part, and the first scene the best scene, but the overall difference wouldn't be as glaring.The action-packed first hour proves to be exposition, for the most part, culminating in Bond's foiling of a plot on the part of the film's main villain, Le Chiffre, to destroy a new airplane and reap grand financial rewards via the plummeting stocks.  Bond's intervention costs La Chiffre many  millions of dollars, and, more troubling for Le Chiffre, he is a sort of terrorist banker abd wasn't playing with his own money.  If Le Chiffre can't recoup 100 mil quickly he's a dead man, so he comes up with a peculiar plan: In order to get this cash fast he decides to host an ultrahigh stakes poker tournament at the Casino Royale in Montenegro.  Bond is sent to Montenegro to enter in the tournament and ensure that Le Chiffre loses and then must flee into British custody to save his own life and, as a natural extension, provide valuable on his various clients.Though "Casino Royale" is certainly darker than any other Bond film I've seen, it's still very clearly identifiable as one.  It still has some corny humor and a rather outlandish plot, but this is offset by the cold, dangerous Craig and the harsher violence.  Le Chiffre is also a bit toned down as far as Bond villains are concerned.  He's not exactly the most terrifying or intriguing figure around, but he's serviceable enough.  (This is Craig's film, anyway.)  Eva Green plays Vesper Lynn, an accountant sent along to make sure Bond doesn't screw things up too bad.  She's quite credible and grounds the oft-outlandish film a bit, on top of being as hot as hell.Unsurprisingly, the film doesn't end with the tournament in Montenegro, though I won't give away further specifics.  The final act is, again, a bit overlong, but it allows the film to have a bit more emotional impact than it would've had otherwise.  That, and, watching the film a second time, the false ending doesn't take quite as long as it seemed to the first time around, now that you know it's coming, and the final action scene is, again, quite cool.Yeah, that's it.  Cool stuff, enough so that I'm actually looking forward to the next Bond film, whenever it may come out.  I'd not have anticipated that that would ever happen.Grade: B+
summary: A Bond film I like?  Yep.

reviewText: Set prior to the previous Bond movies, James Bond (Daniel Craig) is sent on a mission to partake in a high-stakes poker game with the aim of bankrupting Le Chiffre (Mads Mikkelsen), the banker to a major terrorist organization.There are two ways that you can look at "Casino Royale": as an entry in the James Bond series of movies or as an adaptation of Ian Fleming's novel of the same name. As a Bond movie, "Casino Royale" is in many ways a far cry from its predecessors. Gone are the clever quips and the gadgets, yet the makers of this film were smart enough to retain the action sequences (and lots of them), Bond girls (although Eva Green is by no means great) and Judi Dench as M, so there are enough parallels between "Casino Royale" and the earlier films to keep fans happy.As an adaptation of the novel, on the other hand, the success of "Casino Royale" is less clear. "Casino Royale" is far more faithful to its source than any of the Roger Moore Bond films, but not as faithful as the earlier Sean Connery films (in particular, "Dr No" - probably the most faithful of all of the Bond movies to its origins). The central elements of the story are taken from the novel, but a lot of extra scenes are added in around them. Almost the entire first hour of the film comprises original material. These extra scenes, however, are, more or less, in the spirit of the novel. The biggest departure from the novel is in the character of Bond himself. The Bond of this movie is an immature, disrespectful loose cannon, while Fleming's Bond is the exact opposite. Several scenes have Bond acting against the direct orders of M, which the Bond of the books would never do.As for whether Daniel Craig makes a good James Bond or not, that will largely depend on your personal tastes. In my opinion, Craig is not a bad actor, but he is nowhere near as effective a Bond as Sean Connery or even Pierce Brosnan.Overall, "Casino Royale" is worth watching, and I am glad that someone has finally made a proper film version of this novel (the earlier, David Niven film of the same name bears little resemblance to the book and is one of the worst films I have ever seen), but it doesn't quite live up to the high standards set by some of the earlier Bond films, in particular "Dr No" and "Goldfinger".
summary: Not the old movie Bond, but not the book Bond either

reviewText: When this Bond film opens, it's evident that this is NOT going to be like any of the Bond films since Connery. There is NO opening snow skiing sequence...instead we get a riveting (and I mean riveting) action sequence that takes us high above an African city, into the construction cranes of an under construction building.Then, it's a bit of Bizarro world....If we accept that Dame Judi Dench is the M we're familiar with from the past couple of outings, then we have a bit of a jolt when we realize that Daniel Craig's James Bond is not yet a double O. He has yet to earn that (he quickly does). So based on Judi Dench's presence as M, we're warping backward in time to see Bond reinvented.It's a small price to pay. Dench is great as M and Craig....well, Craig completely reinvents the character. He's bold, brash, callous and reckless. He doesn't play at all the same things Roger Moore (way too foppish), Timothy Dalton (too jaded - but up until now far better than Moore or Brosnan), and Pierce Brosnan (a bit to flippant for me) did.This film also holds the distinction of having the most cohesive and believable of plotlines of any Bond film in recent memory. There are no satellites with death rays. There are no super sci fi plastic surgeries or silly villains (Jaws). This plot has Bond searching for a man who is financing terrorists by very plausible means, who ultimately must risk everything to secure money he lost in an ill fated attempt to sabotage a publicly traded company's newest product. It works. It works absolutely. Is our villain wicked and weird? Oh yeah. But he's also suave, quiet and handsome. Then there's a very underplayed medical condition that causes one tear duct to weep blood. But it's subtle and yet creepy.There's no Q. Bond wins the very famous Astin Martin in a card game. He doesn't care how his martini is made.Connery invented the character as a playboy who was suave, subtle and deadly. He was stealth embodied. Craig is only slightly suave, not the least subtle, and recklessly deadly. It's our old James Bond amped up for the modern era.Connery's Bond was comfortable with the Rat Pack set (and still to me), but with all the societal changes that have taken place since then, Craig's Bond is a welcome change - one who, I suspect we will see, will evolve into a more refined spy than we witness in this first outing.It's an evolution I'm looking forward to seeing.

reviewText: I think most people have agreed by now that Casino Royale is one of the best Bond films ever made.  But why do people think this way?  Let me analyze.  Casino Royale has the best aspects that the old Bond films had; good action sequences, a good opening sequence, a cool car, and, of course, the man himself; James Bond.  Except this movie has more than the old films; it has more emotion to it which makes Bond seem more believable as a character, it doesn't get caught up in gadgets, which is good to a certain point, but I know that's one of the reasons I like Bond films in the first place, and it doesn't have any crappy cliches, which, out of respect to Sean Connery, sounded good coming from him.All of these factors make this film worthy of modern day cinema and make the Bond series worth continuing.  But, then I asked myself, does it?  The original Ian Fleming novels were based on Bond saving the world from a sadistic organization called SPECTRE, featured in most of the Sean Connery films.  The awesomeness of the original Sean Connery movies were based on the original Ian Fleming books with SPECTRE, so naturally, if the Bond series is to be restarted, SPECTRE must play a part.  But, SPECTRE's main purpose was to play off of the cold war and benefit from the quarrels that would break out between the U.S., Britain, and the U.S.S.R.  So I began to think, how can they bring back SPECTRE if there's no cold war?The simple answer to this question is, they can't.  The rules of war in modern society have begun to change so that it's no longer quarrels between superpowers where terrorist organizations can get away with stuff.  Now it's countries fighting terrorists directly, so how can they bring back a terrorist organization who benefited from a conflict that's no longer there?From this conclusion, the future of the Bond series looks somewhat different from the memorable series that I remember watching.  And to clarify, people also think that Daniel Craig beats any other Bond.  Not that I don't like Daniel Craig as Bond, in fact he's probably the second best Bond there ever was.  But seriously, Sean Connery you guys, Sean Connery.
summary: Bond is Back - From the Beginning

reviewText: Not being a James Bond addict this viewer approached CASINO ROYALE in the quiet of the home with the DVD form of the film.  For the first time the unique appeal of this 007 character makes sense under Daniel Craig's interpretation.  Prior Bond films with the varied actors who have portrayed him have gone for the slick, tricky, smart killing machine whose eyes seemed  always on the outlook for the next gorgeous babe he treated with little respect except for physical favors.  The various villainous characters seemed to blend and the stories appeared to be more interested in that tired musical soundtrack theme and carnage than they were in character development.Enter Daniel Craig, all buff and uber-masculine, and the beginnings of James Bond's character are explained in a touching manner, making this machine-like concept a deeper being.  Of course, credit must go to director Martin Campbell working with an intelligent script by Neal Purvis and Robert Wade which travels Craig's Bond from Uganda, to the Bahamas, Miami, Montenegro and Venice.  The chief bad guy this round is Le Chiffre (Mads Mikkelsen) who complete with scarred blind eye and cruel gaze is Bond's nemesis.  Judi Dench turns in another strong performance as the ubiquitous 'M' on charge of 007's ventures and along the way Bond meets such good/bad characters as Giancarlo Giannini, Jeffrey Wright, and the very elegant and stylish French actress Eva Green whose complex character provides all the information we needed to know about James Bond's view of women.CASINO ROYALE is a strong 2 1/2 hour film that for this viewer makes James Bond an interesting character in addition to being a suave stunt/lady-killer man.  Daniel Craig is in fine form (literally) and proves his mettle here.  This viewer will see the next Bond/Craig film in the theaters!  Grady Harp, April 07

reviewText: When Sean Connery (arguably the "best" Bond) quit in the 1960's - the franchise dug deep into the plot line of Ian Fleming's book "On Her Majesty's Secret Service" and produced a movie that many Bond aficionados recognize as one of the best - while introducing George Lazenby in the role. George - sadly - didn't last and the franchise rumbled through some dreadful Roger Moore years propped up by outrageous stunts and sharply pressed dinner jackets. Pierce Brosnan rescued Bond from the dark and foreboding Timothy Dalton - so many were dismayed when he decided to hang up his Walther PPK and leave the producers looking for someone new.So on the day after Thanksgiving - the outlaws and I headed over to the local multiplex where 4 of the 20 screens were showing Daniel Craig's debut in Casino Royale. Glad we dropped by in the morning and bought our tickets early! If you haven't read the books -this was Bond's "first" mission for Ian Fleming and the producers have dropped a lot of the "givens" and started afresh with the franchise here too. Gone are Eon Productions, many of the "characters" who propped the previous movies and "in" are financial help from the Government of the Bahamas to place part of the movie there and some pretty overt product placement from Sony and Ford. Thank goodness it was a temporary aberration that had Bond drive a Ford rental, the Aston Martin (albeit Ford owned these days) gets more than a look-in with Bond winning a 1964 DB5 in a card game and later driving (and real world totaling) a DB9 later in the movie. But these little commercialization's in the movie don't detract from Daniel Craig's hard edged killer which harks back to Connery in Dr No when he kills in cold blood - because that is his job.Without spoiling the ending - this movie faithfully follows the twists, turns and doubts of the original 1953 novel. Some scenes are lifted straight from it - notably when Le Chiffre tortures Bond. Of course the movie has been brought up to date in terms of locations, bad guys and the world 53 years after the book was written. But the gadgets are believable PDA's and computers that we all use in the real world - only a little better, the stunts are exceptionally good - and they are believable (well - just!) and the violence is not necessarily gratuitous - though people meet violent deaths when they get in the way.Craig portrays Bond's dilemmas as real spy world, not necessarily black and white but varying shades of grey. Not just in his conscience but in who got disposed of along the way - and should they have been. M has her doubts - Bond has to remind himself that to survive he cannot afford to have doubts. The character forms and introduces himself at the very end of the movie in the very last line - "The name is Bond, James Bond".Of course we really are now out of original Fleming novels so it will be interesting to see how we move on from here - but this Bond IS one of the best since the 1960's. Perhaps reusing them realistically - as here and in OHMSS will keep the franchise strong.

reviewText: Although I'm not one of those people who line up and go see every James Bond movie, I generally find the films in the franchise to be fun and exciting. With fabulous locations (Lake Como looks breathtaking), and a fantastic supporting cast (Eva Green is gorgeous, and Judi Dench is brilliant as always) Casino Royale delivers two hours of glamour, excitement and so much fun.

reviewText: Contrary to what some reviews have said, both on Amazon and other sites like [...], there is a difference in the picture quality between the original Blu-Ray release and the 2 Disc Special Edition Blu-Ray release. The picture on the newer 2 Disc Special Edition has had some sort of re-digitizing and smoothing out. The difference is subtle, but definitely there. Some of the more noticeably grainy shots, like when Bond shoots the "one bombmaker", have been affected, although still a little grainy, but the cost of this has been to somewhat mute the colors and tones in the movie. Again, the difference is subtle, and to some, subjectively speaking, it may look better, especially if your HDTV and Blu-Ray player tend to really pump the colors. I personally like the original Blu-Ray release, with the strong colors and tones, and that "edgy" look, albeit, with several grainy spots. There is of course no denying the value of the Bonus disc in the 2 disc set, as well as the improved sound, although again, I personally like the more "edgier" sound on the original release, but to each his own. This is a great First Bond outing for Daniel Craig. A movie with depth, character development, and plenty of well shot action scenes. It is definitely a new direction for the Bond franchise, and a great way to start that transition, with a smart, "edgy" film that leaves you craving more.

reviewText: I first watched the 2006 release Casino Royale in the theater.  I was very impressed.  The movie was unlike any Bond film I had seen before.  In fact, the movie is gritty in a way that resembles the very well made Bourne movies.  I recently watched the movie again, and found that it was even more enjoyable the second time around.  The changes, in my opinion are for the better.  I was a fan of Pierce Brosnan in the role of James Bond.  I thought that he had been the best Bond since Sean Connery.  I thought Roger Moore was okay, while timothy Dalton did nothing for me.  Craig made for a very compelling and very human Bond.The visuals in this film are stunning.  The usual opening scenes are - true to form - pretty spectacular.  Bond shows little mercy when it comes to resorting to violence.  He also gets hurt and bleeds on numerous occasions.  He seems ill at ease in a tuxedo, but seems to adapt to the role.  The primary setting for the movie is an incredibly picturesque Venice.  The film features really stunning scenes with some excellent stunt work.  The Blu-ray version is without a dount the version to watch. Clocking in at 144 minutes, the movie seems to fly by with its fast paced story.  The only downside to the film is that the villain came across as pretty tame for the most part.  There probably could have been a bit more done to make him really evil and dislikable.Overall this is a strong 4 star movie that is well-worth the price of the movie.
summary: Blu-ray is the way to watch this great film!
