reviewText: Martin Campbell has reinvented the Bond franchise with an extremely convincing and intense Daniel Craig. The way Christopher Nolan reinvented the BATMAN franchise Campbell has done the same with Bond. Campbell and writer Paul Haggis have made an entertaining, serious John Le Carre spy story with some of the greatest, masterful action set-pieces ever seen. Instead of Soviet Cold-War villians we get the free-market, bankers and western corporations as the stand-out villians. Corporations that are willing to deal with the Right or Left, dictators or liberators as long as these corporations get their end. This is a more complex Bond dealing with more complex motivations then the camp and cartoon elements of previous Bonds. If only the disappointing MISSION:IMPOSSIBLE movies had been this good and ambitious.

reviewText: Yes, I miss Pierce Brosnan as James Bond...just to get that out of the way. But, even with Brosnan gone, I wasn't really too concerned that they were gonna bollocks the 007 franchise up too badly. I'd just seen LAYER CAKE and had been quite impressed with Daniel Craig's dynamic performance. So I knew I was in for a good time with CASINO ROYALE. This version - not to be confused with the wacky 1967 version with David Niven and Peter Sellers - is James Bond as Ian Fleming had written him in the novels, stripped bare of those cute cinematic touches. James Bond here is a cold and arrogant killer who hasn't yet perfected that veneer of wit and sophistication.Here come the crazy SPOILERS: CASINO ROYALE tells of the genesis of James Bond as Daniel Craig takes 007 back to his early days of having just been elevated to 007 status. Instead of the suave operator we're used to, what we glimpse is a raw, thuggish secret agent, whose clumsy modus operandi is "let's poke the bear and see what happens." This is never more typified than in two sequences in the film: during a thrilling, expanded chase thru a construction site where the grace and athleticism of Bond's target is contrasted with Bond's bull-in-a-china-shop methods of pursuit and, much later, in the casino, wherein Bond, fearing that he'd run out of options, prepares to crudely knife down his victim. Now, even in his later film exploits, Bond never really strays too far from his penchant for "poking the bear," but he does become more refined about it. It's interesting to note that, at that time of his career, even though he was already a cold-blooded killer, one particularly brutal, life-or-death struggle on a flight of stairs still was able to unnerve him, post-encounter.It's also worth mentioning that James Bond doesn't toss out a lot of one-liners here, although he does offer up a memorable barb after a failed attempt to give him a cardiac arrest. But, mostly, Bond keeps his mouth shut and his eyes open as he...learns to mold himself into his later, more dashing incarnation. In this movie, you could practically see the wheels of origin inexorably turn. We witness the evolution of various 007 fixtures, ie: his experimentation with the martini drink, his presumably first run-in with an Aston-Martin, his first meeting with CIA agent Felix Leiter (Jeffrey Wright), his first utterance of "Bond...James Bond," and his seemingly debonair but ultimately callous handling of women. Alas, we have no Q present and a bare minimum of cool gadgets, but Dame Judi Dench is here as M, which actually sets up a paradox because, in later films, Judi Dench now has to replace herself as the new M (in GOLDENEYE, chronologically). But that's just quibbling.Daniel Craig is a great and virile James Bond. He's got a presence that is very physical, intense, and commanding. The charm of Bond here doesn't come from urbane elegance and clever wordplay as much as from a wellspring of animalistic vitality. And, as ably proven in LAYER CAKE, the guy can act. Throughout the film, there's a sense of pent-up energy emanating from Craig, as if, at any moment, he could explode in a miasma of action. Also, his craggy face and his icy blue eyes lend him credibility as a straight-up killer. In a negative way, Pierce Brosnan and Roger Moore's pretty, good looks placed them too high up in  fantasy world, their exploits admired from afar but difficult to relate with. Craig, who's blessed with a rugged, blunt handsomeness but isn't too good-looking to piss a guy off, has a better chance here to come across as more "real." In the self-assuredness that he wears like a cloak, Craig borrows from Sean Connery. In muscular physique and physicality, he's closer to former male model turned actor George Lazenby (ON HER MAJESTY'S SECRET SERVICE). In fact, CASINO ROYALE and ON HER MAJESTY'S SECRET SERVICE also share one other thing in common besides the two leads' pumped up brawn: they are the only two films where Commander Bond has truly fallen in love.The plot of the movie, if looked into too closely, is boring. Roughly, it involves Bond, as his first 007 mission, having to beat a terrorist broker at cards in a high stakes casino tournament so that the prize money isn't used to fund terrorist activities. The film benefits from a slam-bang opening sequence, then the opening credits, followed immediately by another excellent action sequence. Afterwards, the pace  becomes leisurely and, with the advent of the casino scenes, decidedly  becomes even more leisurely. But, don't fret; here and there, the movie throws enough cinematic bones to keep the viewer contentedly glued to the screen. Eva Green as Vesper Lynd is smoking hot but seems to lack the same sensuality she showcased in DREAMERS. But there's decent chemistry between her and Craig. Mads Mikkelsen is perfectly adequte, if routine, as Le Chiffre, the main baddie who weeps in blood and has a gambling jones. But, naturally, Daniel Craig is head and shoulders and biceps and pecs above everyone else. And, as a sidenote, he really sells that torture scene. Ouchie.With only his first outing, Craig seems to have already cemented his place in the 007 pantheon. I hate to say this but Craig just might be the 2nd best Bond ever, after Sean Connery, of course. Unfortunately, this drops Brosnan, who I really like as an actor, to third place. Hopefully, Craig will keep up the quality with the inevitable sequels. But, for now, so long, Pierce Brosnan. And, welcome, Craig...Daniel Craig.

reviewText: When I first heard that Daniel Craig was going to play the next James Bond I was a bit suspicious.....a blond Bond??? But the more I heard about it the more I wanted to see it. I actually waited until it was released on dvd to see it. I can say, hands down, Craig is the best and the coolest Bond since Connery and Moore. Pierce Brosnan and Dalton have nothing on this guy!! Daniel Craig is really the ultimate. Superb acting, the action scenes are fantastic - it's been a long time since I've seen such a great and entertaining movie. Craig just melted into the Bond role so easy, and I don't think there's ever been a sexier guy playing Bond. I think Pierce Brosnan, even if he was pretty good, was a bit too proper and seemed to think about the way he looked too much. Craig doesn't seem to think about the way he looks so much, or so it seems....that's what makes him so good also. He seems to take it as a bit of a joke. He's not full of himself. I hope he stays that way. There's a lot more action in this movie (better action scenes) than in the other Bond movies. In a way it is a bit difficult to compare this one with the older movies from 1960's and 70's of course. I really hope he makes a few more Bond movies - apparently he's filming the next one now! Gotta love him!
summary: Best Bond since Sean Connery and Roger Moore

reviewText: Very difficult to review this. The critics herein have spoken from bad to better than ever. I must say I agree with them all. Take it in perspective and realize that the baby boomers, who were initially aroused by Dr No, will probably be the most critical. Give some consideration to the necessary editorial license that requires contemporary themes and ideology.So. If this is a legitimate prequel to past Bond adventures it's quite good. He has not yet achieved a 00 status. He's rough and tough but has not yet matured into the Bond style and charisma that we have grown to expect. The "bull in the china closet" has a lot to learn.True Bondians require that insane campy villain. They require it "shaken not stirred". The bevy of Bond girls devouring the screen. The wry sophisticated humor. That comic book effect that transposes the viewer into a dream world of excitement and adventure.The cinematography and action sequences are top notch. The plot...a bit complicated but OK. The cast...OK. Giancarlo Giannini and Judy Dench exceptional.The score is eloquently done in pre-007 style. A brilliant piece of cinematic magic takes place at the end. Or is it the beginning?Daniel Craig as James? Time will tell. After all....Bond is back.Carry on..... Commander.

reviewText: A confession: back in late 2006 before the opening of "Casino Royale", I was one of the clamoring pack of doubters.  Could blond indie thug Daniel Craig REALLY step into the rarified shoes of Connery, Moore, Brosnan, et al to portray one of the most beloved and long-running icons of cinema?  Though I respected Mr. Craig's acting ability in gritty British drama, at first blush his fit for the role of Bond was not apparent.  I attended a screening with very low expectations, prepared to hate a movie that had booted my beloved Pierce Brosnan out of the franchise.  Well.  To say that Mr. Craig blew me away would be an understatement.  He totally owns the part now and we have to stretch all the way back to Sean Connery to find a Bond with such confident physicality married to a dangerous edge.  Mr. Craig is not "handsome" in the classic sense.  But he's compelling, virile and relentlessly watchable--a potent combination that's way better than mere "handsome".  Though I submit that those blue eyes are one of the wonders of the cinematic world, and when Mr. Craig smiles (not often enough as Bond, alas), it's like the sun breaking out over the Aegean, and he is handsome, indeed.  His physicality is unsurpassed, even by Connery; his rising up out of the surf is an iconic moment in the Bond canon--Ursula Andress as beefcake.  The reviewer who labelled Mr. Craig 'effete' must have had a long doze, because the man drips masculinity from every pore.  The stunts, locations and set pieces are all spectacular, but the overriding reason to purchase this on DVD is to appreciate, with repeat viewings, the nuances of Craig's performance.  I have found reason to be fond of all the previous Bonds, but Craig is hands-down the most skilled actor to ever take the role.  Bond is by definition, 'larger than life', but in Craig's hands, we are not watching a caricature of a superman in a tuxedo, but a real man in a dangerous occupation who sweats and bleeds and suffers, who makes mistakes and learns from them.  He moves Bond beyond the one-note sexism and gadgetry and actually creates a fully-fleshed person who seems almost real.  Mr. Craig has definitively silenced his critics, and has become a Bond for the ages.  Whether his sophomore effort can maintain the high bar he set here remains to be seen, but "Casino Royale" has captured his Bond at the height of his considerable powers, and is a must-own.

reviewText: In these times of innovation and reengineering, the modern myth of James Bond simply could not stand apart. And the final result has been a certain lack of good taste, accustomed refinement and a set of traditional issues we use to watch; the absence of a striking soundtrack that nourishes the action, the absence of the traditional opening with the figure of Bond looking us through a virtual eye, the presence of Money Penny, the new technological devices with the used spices of double sense occurences and  the accustomed black humor.The new Bond lacks of European flavor and persuasive seduction spirit. All the previous characters (with the only exception of Georges Lazenby of Australian origin and Pierce Brosnan from Ireland), were from U.K., even the handle of the elements of tension which introduced us to the main plot, were marvelous shot, with a mesmerizing kinetic energy.But this time, it seems the globalization has knocked at the door of this character, and well you know, a change has to come and turn around the state of things. Bond doesn't make use of his Aston Martin with all the lot of unthinkable special effects and hidden weapons we used to expect, the fabulous chases, with that so well elaborated dynamics.The forces of evil even have lost that arrogance and cynical behavior to become simple gangsters. There's an impressive lot of moving sequences, as the first human chase,for instance or the attempts of making Bond a viction of the violence, and lack of luminosity around the sinisters enemies who must conspire against the world peace are absent.Casino Royale has always been a turning point, a cordial and pleasant stop on the road, a divertimento, but taking into account this was the debut role of Daniel Craig, maybe this dare attempt to make to exploit the screen didn't result as sophisticated as one expected.  Although we must admit the solvency of the final sequence of the crumbling building.Perhaps in another opportunity,with a major emphasis on a more realistic script, (beacuse to my mind there are a lot of issues to explore) we'll keep in touch for the new entry.

reviewText: I was quite surprised how good this series reboot was. Daniel Craig has convinced me that the 40+ year old franchise will be in good hands for years to come. While I don't believe that there has ever  been a bad actor to portray Ian Flemings creation I feel that each one has brought a different dimension to the role geared towards his strengths. But let's be honest, Connery is still the best because he has that right balance of charm and wit that'll make you smile one moment and then beat you to a bloody pulp the next. But overall I like Craig because he approaches the character closer to the Fleming books and that's not a bad thing although that may turn some people off.What I really love about this movie is the way we get to see how James Bond becomes "James Bond" and I think its quite refreshing and fun. I also think Vesper Lynn is quite possibly the most fully realized and best developed Bond girl since Tracy Draco in "On Her Majesty's Secret Service." It's also nice to see a more realistic villian in LeChiffre for a change instead of the take over the world types we ushally see. I also think the ending is one of the best ever in the series.Director Martin Cambell does a fine job and it's no coincidence he also directed the best Pierce Brosnan Bond in "Goldeneye".The only gripe I have with Casino Royale is the Title song by Chris Cornell . It's probably the weakest in the series. But overall this is a great Bond film and I think I may see it at the theater again.
summary: Easily one of the best Bond films ever.

reviewText: I can't yet say Craig is better than Connery, but he definitely holds his own with this movie.  I was taking my time on seeing this movie, but word of mouth eventually led me to get it and boy was I wrong about waiting! The first 10 minutes alone will have you on the edge of your seat! This was easily one of the best action movies I have watched in a long time.  My wife, who generally falls asleep watching movies and doesn't care much for action movies loved it.  There was more of a love story than you would expect from a Bond movie as another reviewer noticed, and it is a departure from what a Bond lover would expect, but I liked the storyline and it isn't "chick flick"ish, so it's no big deal.  Whoever were the writers did an excellent job - it did not seem put together just to make money from a big franchise name that is James Bond.  The thing I found hilarious was some of the British sexual humor.  It was at times so in you face, I was dying laughing!This bond is a little different than previous Bonds, though.  He has just became a "double O", so the movie shows the bond character more raw and less refined than other bond movies (as I guess you would expect for someone who's new to being a double O), but it is very convincing in this movie and I don't think it would have been as entertaining had he been more "Bondish".  I watched the movie twice I liked it so much, and my wife wanted to as well (which is really saying something considering all she likes almost are "chick flicks").If you are the type that rents many movies, but only buys the best ones you would watch more than once, then you will NOT be dissapointed if you add this one to your keeper list.
summary: The Best Bond Next to Connery.  A Definite Keeper.

reviewText: No matter who portrayed James Bond in past movies, he was always sexy, sophisticated, smooth, and fun, while deadly efficient.  Handsome, yes.  Able to take care of himself, yes.  Women liked him and men wanted to be him.  Sean Connery, the quintessential Bond, is difficult to match.  No, we don't expect anyone else to have the same appeal on screen, but we don't really want to lose sight of the original, either.Daniel Craig was not the actor many people expected, and some were disappointed, all before the movie was released.  It seemed an interesting choice to me and I was curious about how he would come across.  I'm glad to say he wasn't bad.  Buff, oh my yes.  Ruggedly handsome, yes.  Even tender once.  But there was no sense of fun.  No rascal.  Mostly just deadly.As for the screenplay -- well, too much of nearly everything.  The first action scene, which everyone always looks forward to, went on forever.  I actually went out of the room twice during it, and still got to see the end.  Other action scenes could have been shortened.  And the brutal scene where Bond is naked -- too much for me; I don't know how a man could stand watching it.  A half hour could have been cut easily overall, maybe more, making the story more immediate and more about the characters.  Younger movie goers might have thought the brutality was all right, but us older folks can do without it.  There are also a few times when something is missing in the story line, and the scene or sequence doesn't make sense.Judi Dench as always was wonderful.  Mikkelson was not the campy villain we're used to, he's just plain psychotic.  Green is a believable, and lovely, love interest.  And the scenery takes one's breath away.  I'm not sorry I saw this movie.  Just a little sorry that the filmmakers seem to have lost sight of how much fun Bond can be.

reviewText: CASINO ROYALE is the best James Bond film since ON HER MAJESTY'S SECRET SERVICE. ON HER MAJESTY'S SECRET SERVICE was the last film that was truly based on Ian Fleming's novel. Now comes CASINO ROYALE. This is an outstanding adaptation of Ian Fleming's book. Daniel Craig returns Bond to the no nonsense character that we last saw in ON HER MAJESTY'S SECRET SERVICE. CASINO ROYALE along with ON HER MAJESTY'S SECRET SERVICE and DR. NO are the best Bond films of the series.
summary: Daniel Craig is the Best James Bond since George Lazenby

reviewText: Casino Royale definitely leaves a mark in the mind of all those who watch it, whether you're a Bond fan or not. Personally, Casino Royale has made it into my Bond top 5 with the likes of Goldfinger and From Russia with Love.This is a James Bond reset, putting the audience in the view of Bond as a brand new double-0. To see Bond develop in Casino Royale was quite a spectacle since James Bond may be one of the least developed long-time Hollywood characters. The most emotion anyone may have ever had for Bond would have been back in On Her Majesty's Secret Service.In addition to great development of both character and plot (plot is always the key to a good Bond film), Daniel Craig absolutely blew my socks off with his performance! Next to Sean Connery, Daniel Craig may perhaps be the best Bond yet. I am an avid fan of all the Bond actors (yes, even Roger Moore when I'm not considering Moonraker), and Daniel Craig really stands out. Hopefully, Craig will go on to make a few more excellent and noteworthy Bond films to add to this fun series.And for those who could care less about Bond, Casino Royale is, put simply, the best action film of 2006. Great bad guys, amazing stunts, exciting story, high tension, etc. It's all one could ever ask for. The story entails a VERY high stakes Texas Hold 'em tournament (although we all know poker was not Bond's game of choice, it is an appropriate update for the new generation Bond), deceit, greed, politics, and of course a little bit of old-fashioned Bond romance.And lastly, a very important note, the Bond girls in Casino Royale are absolutely unforgettable. Eva Green gives a memorable performance, and was perfect playing opposite Daniel Craig. Having seen her in Kingdom of Heaven prior to this, I was very excited (for good reason) to see her in Casino Royale. If I haven't given you enough reasons to purchase this, I don't know what else to tell you.

reviewText: Obviously, this is just one of those films that by its very nature gets very different reactions running to the extremes. Any time you make some major changes to a long-running series (20 films!), some people are going to be happy and some people will be upset. So, if you are trying to gauge from the widely divergent things reported about this film what you're going to think, you are probably in for a hard time. Honestly, if you haven't seen it, you should probably just get it over with and judge for yourself. I think perhaps that the changes have been exaggerated and that, underneath it all, there's more continuity than the uproar would indicate. As everyone should agree, the facts are this: they hired a new blonde actor, reduced the reliance on implausible gadgets and outsized special effects, cut down on one-liners and outright comedy, and gave you a plot that didn't involve saving the world from destruction but rather focuses on trying to win at cards so as to bankrupt a financial backer of terrorism. The movie shows us Bond's two first kills and has him as newly promoted to double-0 status but is set in the present, which seems to cause some people continuity headaches (no Q, no Moneypenny in this one). The use of traditional Bond theme music is unusually minimized here but for a good reason, since this movie is sort of about Bond becoming Bond. There are fewer big action set pieces in this one than usual; some people seem not to like the opening chase sequence through a construction site, finding some of the stunts and choreography un-Bond like. Some have griped that the style of the action scenes would feel more at home in a film about Jason Bourne or John McClane than James Bond. While I enjoyed the action quite a lot myself, I can't say either criticism is off base: the airport sequence does feel quite Die Hard-like and the opening chase had tons of trendy parkour elements (a la B13 but more over the top). The movie runs almost 2 1/2 hours and has several quiet stretches which seem to have triggered impatience in some viewers.But of course, the really major complaint goes: Daniel Craig is no (insert your favorite Bond actor or Clive Owen or whoever). (Just for the record, I am a Connery guy (favorite Thunderball) and thought Clive would be a fabulous Bond.) This is no small matter: If you just don't like Daniel Craig for some reason, you are just not going to like this film, since who plays Bond is pretty much everything. After all, had Connery been in On Her Majesty's Secret Service, I suspect a lot of people would say that was the best Bond ever made. Similarly, Dalton, a relatively decent actor, simply didn't cut it for me as Bond, lacking the necessary magnetism and charisma that Connery had established for the character, so those films are not among my favorites. Moore and Brosnan seem to be the preferred Bonds of viewers who prefer to use words like "suave" or "charming" to describe Bond: neither actor projected real physical prowess or a dangerous quality and their films tended therefore to accentuate the quips, the technology, and the unflappable sophistication of Bond as globe-trotting superspy. Craig has been characterized by a lot of reviewers as a return to the physicality that Connery brought and this is true. I think Craig successfully projects physical confidence and manly prowess in carrying himself similar to the way that Steve McQueen used to pull it off. And Craig's Bond gets sweaty, looks to be almost in tears from pain, gets bloodied and bruised, and seems genuinely capable of pounding someone in a fistfight. I think this is all to the better: these films are action adventure films after all and having a lead who is convincing on this score is a pretty good idea.But I think not enough has been made of the use Casino Royale makes of Craig's acting ability. Having seen Layer Cake, I felt pretty optimistic about Craig's ability to carry a movie like this but I was surprised at how much I liked him in the part. Too often, Bond has been rather bland and dull because he has been, frankly, too good at what he does. But I was impressed in this film at how, by zeroing Bond out, by making Bond a relatively untested younger agent, DRAMA has returned to this series.  Craig's Bond is impetuous, arrogant, and occasionally foolish. It is remarkable how many poor decisions, how many unnecessary risks, how many misreads he makes in the course of this narrative if you look closely at how the action unfolds. And Craig is given the chance to display a far wider range of emotions and intensities than Bond has generally been allowed. In fact, Casino Royale, it seems to me, is really the first Bond FILM in quite some time; the character of Bond the person and the small particulars of the story matter, rather than what you are watching being merely a series of big budget stunts strung together.Whereas some seem to feel the movie drags late or becomes boring after they move to Casino Royale, I thought the opposite; when the movie got smaller and began to focus on the character interactions, the movie got better. Many people have complained specifically about the poker scenes as being too long. I disagree: they show you only hands that actually establish something important for the storyline, and the fact that nothing blows up to me does not equate to dull. There is plenty of intrigue going on in the Casino during and between the cardplaying to keep it from getting boring. Mads Mikkelsen is much more subtle here that the typical lead Bond villain is asked to play it (see Pusher 2 for more of him) and I think his casting indicates that the makers of this film want to you watch the human interactions in this film more carefully, that the characters here were not intended to be simple caricatures. And the two Bond women in this film, while both pleasurable to the eye in typical fashion, project a human quality which strikes me as rarely achieved in the series; Eva Green's Vesper is much more successfully developed than the typical Bond girl. To be clear, a Bond film is and should probably continue to be a male fantasy throwback and this film, despite the repeat presence of Judi Dench as the boss M, is no p.c. creation simply for having somewhat more realistic women characters than usual. It's notable that unlike many contemporary action films, violence is in this film a completely male domain: there's no woman beating up or shooting a bunch of guys demonstrating equality through brutality. It's just that one-dimensional bad guys and one-dimensional gorgeous shapely women alike generally make for more boring movies than multi-dimensional bad guys and gorgeous shapely women.I'm sure this film's detractors would simply disagree that the things I describe were successful for them and would say they still didn't like the movie, whatever it was trying to do, add drama and character or not. Despite my rating it 5 stars, I readily admit that the movie is not in any way flawless and I focus here only on the positives. And anyone who loved all the Brosnan films and has kept up their interest all these years could rightfully question why there was a need for the series to take a different approach. Which does sort of lead to the objection all the little objections add up to, which is, this movie doesn't really feel like a JAMES BOND movie to the people who dislike it. And those people certainly have every right to feel that way. But for me, this series has for a long time flirted with self-parody and camp, and I didn't feel much reason to see another installment in what was seeming increasingly routine and uninspired formulaic stuff; most of the recent Bonds didn't strike me as "fun" at all and I couldn't sustain enough interest to make it all the way through Die Another Day. I know several people, similarly burned out, who have seen this movie and been surprised at how much they liked it and these are, I think, the people the franchise is trying to win back. So for me, I haven't really felt like the movies in this series have been authentically "Bond" for quite some time, and I feel that this one is the most worthwhile one in ages. I worry a bit that the next one will start to move in the wrong direction without an original Fleming novel to ground it, with the pressure to restore some of the elements they stripped out of this one to please everyone. It might not work out. But for the meantime, this one has restored my faith in the series.
summary: you can't please all of the people all of the time

reviewText: ... and it's not only the Bond of this film which is shaken, but the entire franchise.Fans of the James Bond films have reacted with vituperative insults, slamming the film and (as Daniel Craig mentions in the special effects DVD of the 2-DVD set) sending scathing and vicious hate-mail to the new Bond. I can see why - many watchers of the James Bond films have a very specific idea of what they want in a Bond film, and it's often NOT a case of knowing the books and wanting the films to be faithful to that. How could it be, after all? From Roger Moore onwards, there does seem to have been quite a noticeable swing towards the concept of making James Bond almost a spoof of himself.This film is actually truer to the books than the earlier films were.The "traditional" James Bond (by which I mean the Bond many viewers today expect, based on the Bond films, especially on the more recent ones) is then not really the "real" Bond whom Ian Fleming created.I can't pretend to be an avid Bond fan - I'm not. But I've enjoyed pretty much anything that Sean Connery has done, and I feel that Connery did a superb job of creating a ruthless, hard character who was in many ways a sexual predator, a dysfunctional being, but one who was brilliantly unstoppable as a secret agent, and blazing with intelligence, sexual power and suave charm. Roger Moore's Bond was too reminiscent (in my opinion) of Simon Templar, the Saint (a role which I think suited him much better than Bond). And so on... I felt the recent Bonds had wonderful potential, but were hampered by increasingly silly plots and overwhelmed by gadgets. Yes, we all love the spoofiness of all of those gadgets, but they were already too much over the top - they could no longer be taken seriously. Ditto for the villains - they were caricatures rather than serious characters, and because of that, they failed (in my opinion) to present a real source of tension in the films.I'd heard that this film - Casino Royale - was a break in the tradition. I'd admired Daniel Craig's acting in Munich, and thought that this was a Bond film worth watching...... and in my opinion this is a very interesting film, well acted, well scripted, well directed. The film achieved what those involved wanted to achieve - this Bond is a harder, quite brutal Bond without the experience of the later Bonds (because he only gains his double-oh status in the beginning of this film), but still self-aware and with a disarming self-knowledge that has him able to laugh about himself. I found myself believing in this Bond, and that is not something I can say of previous Bonds (except for Sean Connery, but then... Sean Connery, after all... what more need I say?).I think those who want Bond films to have a spoof-like quality with amazing gadgets and unbelievable and over-the-top villains will probably not like this film. For those who want an intelligent and intricate action/thriller, the film will probably please. Daniel Craig is of course an extremely good actor, and he has the right face for this sort of hard-edged role. He is able to express so much just with the look of his eyes and the tiny movement of muscles around the mouth - he does most of his acting with his face. But his physicality comes in very useful here too, in some of the most realistic fight scenes (and a taxing torture scene) that have made it to the screen.The various villains are believably played, and Le Chiffre is particularly well done. Le Chiffre is the sort of villain that previous Bond films would have overplayed.The women are of course all ravishing, and as Vesper Lynd, Eva Green does a good job of creating an initially armoured woman with her own secrets.Unlike many, I very much enjoyed the intricacy of the card game - it's a hard thing to shoot, and it worked for me.There are several quite breathtaking extended chase scenes or fight scenes, and I don't think I'll forget the fight scene on the steel girder, the car chase where Bond's car rolls seven times, and (ouch) the scene in a cellar where Le Chiffre uses a rope on Bond to illustrate how elaborate gadgetry for torture is completely unnecessary.I give this film 5 stars for being successful in its genre. I don't think it's a film without flaws, but the successful tension, exciting look and good acting throughout make it work.
summary: Not the Bond of recent films - definitely shaken

reviewText: I choose this rating because the movie is good. What I like about the movie is that in Casino Royale introduces James Bond before he holds his license to kill. But Bond is no less dangerous, and with two professional assassinations in quick succession, he is elevated to “00” status. “M”, head of the British Secret Service, sends the newly-promoted 007 on his first mission that takes him to Madagascar, the Bahamas and eventually leads him to Montenegro to face Le Chiffre, a ruthless financier under threat from his terrorist clientele, who is attempting to restore his funds in a high-stakes poker game at the Casino Royale. “M” places Bond under the watchful eye of the Treasury official Vesper Lynd. At first skeptical of what value Vesper can provide, Bond's interest in her deepens as they brave danger together. Le Chiffre's cunning and cruelty come to bear on them both in a way Bond could never imagine, and he learns his most important lesson: Trust no one.  What I dislike about the movie is that I wanted to see more of it. I would recommend this movie to other people.

reviewText: When was the last time you were wowed by a Bond film?Mine was the first Bond film I watched when I was 7 and it was The Spy Who Loved Me. Since then, I have watched all the Bond films, and none seem to have the depth nor character development usually required in a real film.This Bond movie is different. This is a different kind of Bond and a different kind of a Bond film.Daniel Craig plays a Bond with a actual psyche. Yes, Bond has feelings now! He even has psychological vulnerabilities!Vesper Lynd, played so skillfully by Eva Green, pokes at Bond's vulnerabilities by guessing, presumably correctly, "you are an orphan!....you did not come from money and your friends at Oxford NEVER let you forget it!".The fight sequences has Bond getting hurt and even getting a few scratches on his face. Yes, Bond gets hit and gets hurt too. Whoever thought that was possible? Bond is far from mythical, he is all too human. And that makes him far more interesting than ever.Daniel Craig portrays Bond as an angry, almost psychotic, man willing to do anything to achieve his mission. Sometimes, he lets his anger get the better of his judgment and he even unravels.Did I also mention this is the best casino gambling film I have ever seen?Overall, this is a masterpiece that will be remembered by Bond fans for a long time to come. It will be hard to beat this one.
summary: Different kind of Bond and different kind of Bond film.

reviewText: You already know the movie is one of the best Bond's ever, and that Daniel Craig stands next to Sean Connery, so I will just review the image quality, which is one of the best blu ray transfers you can buy. Avatar looks stunning, but the story is nothing special, and the acting only OK, but this gives you all the marbles. Some say the best in the series (or darn close) and to make it even sweeter, one of the best looking blu rays out there. If you are looking for some films to revel in both visually, and substance wise, this should be near the top of your list. A few others that are worth looking for are 2001: A Space Odyssey, LOTR trilogy, Alien & Aliens, Casablanca, any Pixar title, Chinatown, and of course The Godfather collection, which retains all the beauty of the original transfers with added clarity. Don't miss this one.

reviewText: I was beginning to wonder if James Bond was dead, but along comes Daniel Craig to breathe new life into the role, giving us a lean, mean 007 that blows previous Bonds away.  Martin Campbell went back to the basics, retooling Bond and giving him a much more physical presence, reminiscent of Sean Connery.  From the opening sequence we see we are in for a real treat, as Campbell takes nothing for granted.  He knows he has to earn the audience's respect, and he does with a thrilling chase scene in the chaotic urban center of an African republic.Bond really comes across as a rogue agent in Casino Royale, stealing his way into M's apartment to leave her coded messages, taking risks that threaten painstaking operations and getting himself into jams that require MI6 to bail him out.  This is a young impetuous Bond, overanxious and thrilling to watch as Craig fills his role with the energy of a stage actor.There is also one of the best villains in recent years with Mads Mikkelsen as the cold blooded Le Chiffre.  He heads an international cartel not so much bent on world destruction as on taking advantage of the chaos in which we live.  He is a much more believable villain than Spectre and relies on much simpler methods of getting his piece of flesh from someone.It is also refreshing to see Bond have a real love interest in Eva Green, not the usual banter that rings hollow.  Bond is not afraid to expose himself in this movie, revealing a much more vulnerable figure than we have seen before.MI6 also finds itself as a much more porous organization, capable of being infiltrated so that Bond doesn't know who to trust in key moments.  All he has is the support of M, played to deadpan perfection by Judi Dench.Everything about this movie is fresh and clean, including the opening credits.  Bond hasn't looked this good since the early films in the series with Sean Connery.  There is even an amusing scene where Bond wins a 1964 Aston Martin in a poker game, a tip of the hat to Goldfinger.

reviewText: To my mind, the last great Bond movie was "You Only Live Twice." Admittedly, it paled somewhat in comparison to its predecessors-- "Dr. No," "From Russia with Love," "Goldfinger" and "Thunderball"-- but given much of followed it, it truly was the last great Bond movie.Of course, some of the credit for what powered those first five movies has to go to Sean Connery. Connery was Bond, as far as the public was concerned, and he spent years shaking that image off.True, he did appear as Bond again in "Diamonds Are Forever" and "Never Say Never Again," but both of those were mediocre efforts. In fact, if rumors are true, and they probably are in this case, the only reason he made "Diamonds" was for a very sizable paycheck.Connery's successors just couldn't get it right; sometimes because of the tepid to idiotic scripts they saddled with, and sometimes because they just didn't fit the role.George Lazenby, a complete unknown, gave a good effort in "On Her Majesty's Secret Service," which was sandwiched in between "Twice" and "diamonds," but the storyline wasn't that great and he also faced the considerable challenge of being the guy who immediately followed Connery into the role. He was largely derided and pretty much disappeared, appearing in an occasional movie role.Roger Moore seemed like a logical choice, after all, he was Ian Fleming's original choice. Moore, however, ushered in the error of goofiness and occasional slapstick.And he himself never took the role seriously. A fact which carried over onto the screen. He did have two decent efforts with "The Spy Who Loved Me" and "For Your Eyes Only," but those films were average at best. He also had the distinction on making "Octopussy," the worst Bond film to come from Cubby Broccoli line of Bond films.Timothy Dalton brought acting cred to the role, but never seemed comfortable with it. And many of us, including me, just didn't buy him as Bond, despite his reputation as a good actor.Pierce Brosnan came along, and he actually seemed like a good choice. He had actively campaigned for the role when Dalton got it, but was prevented from getting it because of his "Remington Steele" TV contract.Brosnan was an acceptable Bond, but his physical appearance (the guy was pretty much rail thin and lacked any muscularity), kept many of us from believing he was capable of actually engaging in the physical tasks Bond constantly faces.He does have the distinction of appearing in the best of the non-Connery Bonds, at least pre-"Casino Royale," with "tomorrow Never Dies." But, thankfully, either he grew tired of the role, or the producers decided he was getting too old.Which brings us to Daniel Craig. A worthy successor to Connery, and a guy who might even surpass Connery in the role someday.Before "Royale" was released, Craig was the subject of campaign determined to deem him totally unacceptable as Bond. Websites took glee in pointing out he appeared to short, his hair was the wrong color, and a whole host of other real or imaged offenses they believed him guilty of.I was originally sorta in this camp. But after seeing him in "Holocaust," I was suddenly convinced he could pull it off.And he did.Of course, Craig benefited from a "back-to-basics' approach to the franchise. "Royale" was the book that introduced Bond and, coincidentally, the only one not made into a film by the Broccoli family, who owned the rights to all the Bond books except "Royale."Well, luckily they gained the rights and decided to start the franchise over. And Craig proves to be a great choice for the role of Bond. Blonde hair or not (it seems like they colored it darker in some parts of the film, and not in others), you come to believe he is Bond. In fact, given the opening sequence, and an intense chase seen that follows the opening credits, he's probably the most physical Bond ever.Like Connery, he brings a certain cool detachedness to the part. something you'd expect from a guy who is in many ways an assassin on the British payroll.He's also taking on a believable bad guy, which helps tremendously. Let's face it, the bad guys can make or break these films. Just think how Auric Goldfinger still looms as the standard against all other bad guys must be judged in the film series.And "La Chiffre," like Goldfinger, is a guy who is quietly sinister.La Chiffre is the banker to rich bad guys of the world. Only he makes the mistake of putting all of the money he's entrusted with into an airline stock, and shorting it. "Shorting" a stock amounts to betting that the stock will lose value and, well, you don't want a lesson in stock trading here do you? Let's just say, La Chiffre loses his arse on the stock market and his clients aren't too happy.So he sets up a high stakes poker game in Montenegro, figuring that because he's a bit of a mathematical and probability expert, he can't lose and he'll win back all the money he lost on the stock market.Enter Bond, freshly minted as "007," and sent into the game only because he happens to be the best card player in MI6. M doesn't yet trust him, but she knows he's their best bet to win, causing La Chiffre, and all his dirty little secrets, to come running to MI6 and the Americans for protection from his clients.Naturally, things don't go quite as planned, and Bond is double crossed more than once. He also is subjected to a torture scene that actually tells us a lot about the new Bond--he's tough, a bit sadistic in his own right and maybe even a little masochistic.The film is the most satisfying Bond film since "Twice," which was released in 1967. So, nearly 40 years later, they finally get it right. Again.It's not perfect. They take their time telling the story, and it does seem to drag a little toward the end when Bond is recuperating from injuries. It also never quite convincing explains the motives of one of the characters who double crosses Bond. But you might disagree. See it. It's well worth buying for multiple viewings.
summary: Almost 40 Years Later, They Finally Get it Right Again

reviewText: While there seems to be a lot of rallying support for "the new Bond", I can't say that I'm with that group at all.  Casino Royale was "ok" and certainly 1000% better than the Woody Allen/Peter Sellers sham, but compared with more traditional Bond movies, I felt it left a great deal to be desired.First there was the tragic demise of a well established timeline.  This could have been easily avoided by simply adding that the "previous" Bond had retired (or been killed) and that the new agent was simply replacing his predecessor, the way "M" and "Q" had been replaced as the actors portraying them aged and/or passed away. To "re-envision" such a well established franchise completely without paying tribute to that which has come before was simply a mistake.Then there is Daniel Craig's less than impressive portrayal of one of the most well known "action heros" of all time.  Let's face it here...whether you are a fan of the books or the movies, when someone mentions the name "James Bond", it provokes a certain mental image.  Regardless of who has portrayed Bond in the past, there is an image of a suave, sophisticated individual usually wearing a tux, drinking a vodka martini (shaken, not stirred).  The image certainly includes having a beautiful woman on his arm, fancy gadgets to help him out of a tight spot and that attitude that "laughs in the face of danger"...usually accompanied by a "pithy come back".  With the introduction of Daniel Craig in Casino Royal, gone is the tongue in cheek humor that typically accompanies the James Bond persona.  To me this was a tragic mistake as it is simply a part of who James Bond is.  In the Bond movie "Golden Eye" for example, there is a scene where Bond (portrayed excellently by Piece Brosnan) crashes a tank he is driving in a chase scene (wonderful in it's own right!).  The camera zoom's in on Bond as he pauses, straightens his tie then continues with the chase.  Truly a wonderful moment of humor to say the least!  There are no such "moments" with this new Bond...he is simply a man with a bad attitude and "a chip on his shoulder" who's out to prove himself against the world.  With Craig's portrayal, the character of James Bond could have just as easily been a disgruntled shoe salesman who's forced to smell stinky, fat feet day in and day out.  I'm sorry to say but Craig does a very poor job of "filling the shoes" of his predecessors.To use a food analogy, if you make spaghetti sauce without any spices what so ever, all you end up with is tomato soup.  Daniel Craig's portrayal of Bond is watery tomato soup at best.  While Sean Connery, Roger Moore and Pierce Brosnan (and even Dalton and Lazenby) all brought something new and unique to the role, they all managed to maintain the principle character that is "Bond".  Here particularly, Craig falls abominably. While it is a ok action film with a fairly average plot (save the world...yawn), there is nothing in Craig's portrayal that really says "James Bond" in any way.  The character names could have been easily changed and very simply, it would not have effected this movie at all (and probably would have been for the better).Gone too are the wonderful gadgets that are so iconic of James Bond movies.  While a good story line is certainly the greatest success of any film let alone "Bond", high tech gadgetry is something that most loyal fans have come to expect (for example the submarine Lotus in "The Spy Who Loved Me"...priceless!).  When watching James Bond using many of these devices, one can easily hear Q's words of wisdom saying "Grow up 007!".  Such things are now apparently a part of the distant past.  Apparently all a modern secret agent needs any more to defend himself against the evils of the world is his ever loyal and faithful cell phone.For the sake of fairness, I will add that there have certainly been other Bond "flops".  Connery's "Diamonds Are Forever", Moore's "Man With The Golden Gun" and "Moonraker" and Brosnan's "Die Another Day".  I guess even the best of Bonds are entitled to having a bad run.  That said, it appears that this may not be a one time event due to the fact that the producers seem to want to take Bond in a new (and horrifying) direction.  We loyal Bond fans can certainly hope but none of us should hold our breath for too long either.Final Thoughts...For those who are looking for an average action film with the proverbial explosions and car chases and an otherwise average plot, you will probably be satisfied with "Casino Royal".  However for those like me who are long time fans of the James Bond franchise and all that it represents, you will probably be sorely disappointed.  In and of itself it was an "ok" movie but it certainly wasn't "Bond" by any stretch of the imagination.  It would have been better to simply change the character names and call this film something else and just let the Bond franchise rest until something better and more appropriate came along.
summary: Casino leaves something to be desired...

reviewText: Ian Fleming wrote the original book, and he got credit on the film, but this was completely re-written. But, it wasn't James Bond.

reviewText: I was not expecting a great deal from this and I was pleasantly impressed. Amazed even. Easily (easily) the best Bond movie since From Russia with Love; frankly, it is the best Bond movie ever. The reason is that it is the first of the films that manages to be even faintly realistic, that is character as much as plot driven. The plot in fact is nothing special, but the handling of the scenes is refreshingly raw and gritty (not quite Bourne Identity, but close enough); for the first time ever, James Bond seems like a real personality and not just a fantasy figure, capable of suffering and other human emotions. Special praises go to Craig, who is a revelation. Eva Green doesn't do badly either: tho she weirdly fluctuates between divinely pretty and almost mannish (she looks way better without make-up), Green is extremely affecting as the first flesh and blood Bond girl. What really distinguishes this movie from other Bonds, however, is the touch of a real writer - Paul Haggis, whose hand is evident throughout the proceedings. There is actually something going on beneath the scenes now, psychological undercurrents, character dynamics, tensions; at least half the time, this is not just a good Bond movie: it's a good movie. I didn't even notice that the Bond theme wasn't being used until moments before the end when it finally appears - I had almost forgotten I was watching a Bond movie at all (yes, that's a compliment). These last few moments, after all that has gone before, made me very nearly euphoric. Never mind the fact that they celebrate Bond's acceptance of his fundamental soullessness and embracing his dubious destiny as a cold-blooded killer fantasy hero! This is cracking entertainment and final, unexpected proof that there is life in the old dodo yet.

reviewText: **Warning: Possible Spoilers**Maybe it's because I'm so used to the portrayals of Bond by Sean Connery, Roger Moore, and Pierce Brosnan, that I couldn't connect with Daniel Craig's Bond as easily.  Personally, I was expecting Bond to be a far more suave character in this movie, but Craig's Bond was a lot darker and harsh than previous Bond incarnations.  Frankly, I thought that Casino Royale was a pretty good movie, but not as good as I thought it was going to be, especially after hearing all the critical praise it was getting.The plot of this movie revolves around Bond trying to stop a man named Le Chiffre, who is a member of an organization that funds terrorists worldwide.  Bond is sent to play against him in a high stakes poker game that would cause the collapse of Le Chiffre's organization should Bond win.  One thing I enjoyed about Casino Royale was that it was full of great twists and double-crosses, many of which were completely unexpected.  This is something you don't often see in a Bond movie.The action scenes in this movie are definitely top notch.  My favourite scene involved Bond chasing down a man in Madagascar.  In this scene, the man that Bond was chasing moved almost as he were Spider-Man, while Bond himself was struggling to catch up, and had to come up with innovative ways to get to him.  This chase was a perfect way to emphasize the fact that he is new to the double 0 spy game.  Also, the scene where Bond tries to stop a man from blowing up an airliner in Miami may be derivative at first glance, but it was fun nonetheless.So now you must be wondering why I didn't give Casino Royale a higher score.  Well, first off, the relationship between Bond and Vesper Lynd (played by Eva Green) felt a little too forced, almost as if it was simply put in there to forward the plot, and not much more.  Also, the pacing in the movie was a little uneven, especially towards the end of the movie, where it looked like the movie was going to end at several points, but just kept on going.  Lastly, this movie just felt that it was about 20 minutes longer than it should be.  Personally, if I were the editor I would have cut out a lot of the unnecessary scenes between Bond and Lynd, as they did little to add to the overall movie.As I previously mentioned, Craig's Bond is not the type of Bond that I am used to.  The character was just way too brooding for my tastes.  However, this is not necessarily a knock against Daniel Craig's acting ability.  I have seen him in a few other movies in the past, and he is perfectly suited to play a rougher Bond, as clearly shown in Casino Royale.  I appreciate the fact that the creators of this movie wanted to try something different to shake up the franchise's formula, but I'll wait on the next movie to say whether they've succeeded or not.In the end, Casino Royale is a pretty good action movie, but it just wasn't as good as I hoped it would be.  However, I am more than willing to give Daniel Craig's Bond another chance, and as such, I will hold judgment on this new take on Bond until the next movie comes out.My final score: 7/10 (a mild thumbs-up)
summary: A pretty good action flick, but not as good as I hoped

reviewText: This is the worst example ever of the Bond series. Craig just doesn't live up to the character played by Connery for 20 years (few do). Connery's Bond was always on the offensive with women; in the scene with Caterina Murino, she's in charge and the two seem almost self-conscious; at least things liven up when Eva Green arrives on the set. The movie has too many uninteresting characters and what else can they do but flip an occasional evil eye. There's too many gambling scenes that look too serious and too many close-ups of players hands, as if trying to show that damn, this game really means something. That can happen when the story is weak. There's too many close-ups of cell phones, showing messages that supposedly add to the meaningless script. It seemed that the combo of Judy Dench as "M", who should have stayed in the background more, and Craig as Bond did not really work. I was surprised this turned out to be such a poor effort since the director, Martin Campbell, also did Golen Eye (1995) which I liked. One star to qualify, one for Eva Green.
summary: Not now, M, I'm playing cards.

reviewText: Which one is the best James Bond, right?  I can't pick one, because each one of them actually pretty well reflect the particular times, and for that, I can even forgive and enjoy Roger Moore.  Of course, the least appreciated today probably is Timothy Dalton, which is not really fair in my opinion, especially considering he had the best "gun barrel" sequence (I'm talking about the shooting stance). Anyway, Daniel Craig is a very good Bond -- mean, ugly, ruthless, remorseless, even slightly humorless, too -- a bit like what you would imagine 007 would look like if you read the novels instead of watch movies first.  Hence, he makes pretty good Bond movie.

reviewText: Yeah, I know. Sean Connery is the best James Bond. If that's true then Daniel Craig is a very close second in this remake of Casino Royale. This "remake" is much better (a thousand times better) than the silly original done in the mid 1960s. This time, Daniel Craig (who plays Bond) is a young 00 agent earning his title. He then finds himself involved in a complex situation with a wealthy weapons dealer and the stakes are high.The movie is better than any Bond movie I have seen since Connery's early stuff. The silly/impossible gadgets are no more (i.e. the silly invisible car in the last Bond movie) and Bond is now realistic and real. He has his own psychological issues he has to deal with and the plot, the plot twists and the action are outstanding.I've watched the DVD twice and I think it's the best Bond movie ever. The plot, the dialogue, the acting have finally returned James Bond to top notch entertainment.

reviewText: Director Martin Campbell and lead Daniel Craig have done for the Bond genre with "Casino Royale" what Clint Eastwood did for the Western genre with "Unforgiven."  The cartoonishness has been stripped away for a powerfully visceral experience.  I used to think that there could never be another Sean Connery in the part of Bond, but Daniel Craig has now defined the role and is elevated to the status as the best Bond that ever played the part.

reviewText: I finally watched this movie since the 2nd Daniel Craig 007 will be coming out soon and i want to be prepared. The ending was beyond absurd - AS IF M would only find out about Vesper's background in the last 5 minutes of the film! Please, don't insult me. However, Daniel Craig does save the film (considering the script he had) with his strong onscreen presence; perfect timing; and a new vulnerability that the other 007's never had. reviewText: A spine-tingling thrill ride that moves from the exotic poker tables of Montenegro, to the exotic hotel rooms of Montenegro, then back to the poker tables, then the rooms again, then a return visit to the poker table for a more extended stay, then a short rest and back to the poker table! And there's killing, too! And lot's of sweet lovin', if you're into that.Daniel Craig inhabits the role of James Bond, the dashing MI6 agent who holds a license to kill, as well a license to wax his chest and wear tiny, undignified swimming trunks. Eva Green is Vesper Lynd, (get it?) the hot-to-trot financier who administers the majority of Bond's lovin', with luscious Caterina Murino batting clean-up. And Danish actor Mads Mikkelsen stars as Le Chiffre, a sardine-faced villain and numbers genius (he can make change for a dollar without punching it into the cash register!)Joining Mike is Kevin Murphy. Both Mike and Kevin have a license to Riff.

reviewText: Back before Timothy Dalton took over from Roger Moore, and the persistent rumors about Pierce Brosnan were all over the tabloids, I was disappointed, but thought Dalton's Bond was different and I still enjoyed both of his turns in the British Secret Service.Then came Pierce.I thought this was casting GOLD.  And while the Brosnan Bond films all did well, and were (by and large) fun and exciting, the series as a whole really had been getting stale.  Initially the thought of firing Brosnan in favor of somebody new and fresh was an act of outright lunacy.  It seemed even more so when it was announced the new Bond would be blonde actor Daniel Craig.  Let me OFFICIALLY renounce my previous observations and accept Craig as hands down my favorite Bond from this point on.  The only thing now that will ruin the most successful movie franchise of all-time is a poorly written plot.From virtually the opening scene, you can immediately tell there is something quite different from Bond films of the past.  Gone are the smarmy, half-witted jokes that became standard starting with 'From Russia With Love'.  Daniel Craig just isn't the type to pull that off, which is one of the chief reasons why I believe most people counted him out as even being capable of playing the role.  Instead the writers chose to give us an entirely different Bond altogether.  On the surface this borders on sacrilege, but TRUST me, it has infused some much needed adrenaline into this aging character.  Erasing all previous Bond movies and starting from scratch seems to have been a great gamble on the part of the producers.  The opening scene of any Bond film has always been one of tremendous thrills and action sequences, and I have to give credit to Daniel and everyone involved for giving us quite possibly the greatest chase scene yet--and get this: it doesn't involve a car, truck or any motorized vehicle of any kind.  Strictly on foot.  It was absolutely flawless and breath-taking.  Simply incredible.  And the film only got better from there.High praise, huh?  Indeed it is, and yet I wonder if I have accurately portrayed the film as good as it actually is.  All I can say is this: if you once believed that nobody could replace Sean Connery (or Roger, or Pierce or...) you owe it to yourself to see how Daniel Craig has quite literally not just taken over, but he's done it with brutal force.  If you took every actor who has played Bond over the years and while in their prime placed them side-by-side, it would be impossible not to see that Craig is the best of the bunch physically.  And he more than proves it with the action sequences.  Bond is no longer a guy who can seemingly walk through a hailstorm of automatic gunfire without so much as a hair out of place...nope, THIS Bond is the real deal who isn't afraid to get down and dirty and he DOES get hurt along the way.  A much more human Bond.In short, I loved it, and can't wait for the next installment.
summary: We officially have a new leader in the role of Bond...

reviewText: This new James Bond is Harder, grittier and more careless than any other.  Why shouldn't he be, this is him at the beginning.  Daniel Craig is a perfect young James Bond before he's so sophisticated with his "shaken, not stirred" martini.  the action scenes in the movie are real for the most part with real stunt men and stunts. The fight on the top of a crane that is 250 feet in the air will have you holding on to the arm rests on your lazy boy.  I love the opening action scene which features the sport of jumping off stationary objects that are blowing up in the UK.  This Bond is rough around the edges but he's more romantic and "feeling" than the bond I grew up with.  You see at the end of this film why he becomes more disconnected to his emotions.  it's a step in the right direction for the 007 series and defiantly clears the pallet and reboots the franchise.  it's a good action movie with a great lead actor that knows how to hold the screen. This Bond is much like Ian Fleming intended, just like in his first book, raw and reckless.  It's a good contrast to what he becomes in the later years as an experienced 007.

reviewText: I have read all the Bond novels at least twice. I've seen all the movies several times. Craig is good. He looks tough. He looks cold and calculating. Even though, he is blonde, he looks convincing. I like the gimmick that he is starting his career. The first time he looks at himself in a fitted tux was pretty cool. The "Do I look like I care?" remark about the martini was good. The Aston Martin was a nice touch. The Walter PPK was left out.The plot was okay. They merged into the original novel territory about half way through. Some of the action sequences were awesome. The chase scene at the beginning was very exciting. The pursued was making Jackie Chan type stunts.The problems I have are two-fold. First, Craig is almost as bad as the terrorist he is trying to stop. How many people did he kill in the embassy? Maybe, they just got burn. He is reckless with other people lives and he lost some sympathy there. Second, the movie is too long. I know they are doing character development, but the plot is too long and the holes in the plot start appearing at the end. I don't want to spoil the ending, but one character makes stupid, contradictory choices. Furthermore, the whole building falling down scene was silly. It is like the car chase going down a tree in Jurassic Park. It is a director or the stunt coordinator trying to be impressive instead of in the moment of the picture.

reviewText: Having seen all the Bond films and, like the most of the galaxy, loving Sean Connery, I was skeptical of the remake. Does the world really another James Bond or another tired remake?Well, this isn't my old suave, testosterone-heady, gadget-wielding James Bond. This is the real deal. Classy, yes. But flawed, tough, riveting, and genuine.This is heart and guts and brains wrapped in sinew. This is the best Bond since Connery. No silly girls on his arm. These "bond women" are beautiful and smart and scintillate. Like Fred Astaire, Craig makes them a little sweeter, a little lighter, a little more alluring. With a swirl he holds them up to be appreciated and admired and steps back graciously- attending.Action galore. Intricate plot. Brutally evil bad guys. Excellent. Good show, old man!

reviewText: Review of Albert Broccoli's Eon Productions "Casino Royale:"As a dedicated fan of the entire James Bond franchise in my humble opinion Casino Royale is the finest Bond film made to date.  Daniel Craig's portrayal of Bond is fresh and realistic as shown through a gritty and hard facet.The storyline is not too complicated and again believable setting itself up for the sequel; in this case Quantum of Solace.  In the beginning of Casino Royale Bond's backstory is revealed as to how he attained his "00" status and reveals "flaws" in his character.  Bond's initial interaction with Vesper Lynd reveals even more of his background as an orphan,etc.Reminiscent of a young Connery in "Dr. No," Craig in Casino Royale delivers the goods.  Well done.  Five stars + with no hesitation or reservation.Jeffrey Peter Hauck

reviewText: I have enjoyed Bond movies, since my father and I used to watch them when I was a child.  My first Bond was Roger Moore in "Live and Let Die".  Roger used to be my favorite, until I was old enough to appreciate Sean Connery.  I was not sure what to expect with this new version of Casino Royale, as the first one was my least favorite Bond movie, if you can even call it that. The first Casino Royale was a spoof of spy movies, along the same line as the Goldmember movies.  I was very pleased with the new version of Casino Royale, and I especially like the "new" version of Bond.This new era of Bond, takes us to the beginning of James Bond, as he makes his seemless transition from agent to special agent "007".  Daniel Craig has such a presence on screen as the present day Bond.  Strong, athletic, powerful, and ruthless.  Craig has the charm and intelligence to match wits with the various Bond villains, women, and of course M, played by the always impressive Judi Dench.  Some reviewers are critical of Craig's performance, but I found him believable and dangerous in taking on the challenges of Le Chiffre(Mads Mikkelsen), and the new mysterious organization that is funding terrorist groups around the World.Bond's new romantic lead is British treasury official Vesper Lynd (Eva Green).  Eva has the beauty and quick wit to keep up with Bond throughout the film.  However, as the film plays, certain events transpire that may lead one to believe whose side Vesper is really on.Casino Royale takes us all over the world to exotic locations, something we come to expect from Bond films.  In Casino, we visit Uganda, Madagascar, the Bahamas, and Montenegro for a high stakes poker game, with a 10 million buy-in.  The cinematography is excellent.  And I especially enjoyed the scenes of the construction site brawl and the floating house on a canal.  Watching this movie on Blu-ray was visually stunning, and the audio was outstanding.Special Features on the DVD:*  "Becoming Bond" : Takes us from Ian Fleming's 1st spy novel, CasinoRoyale, and the transition to film.  Also, how Daniel Craig wascasted as the 6th Bond actor.*  "James Bond : For Real" : This segment showed how the various scenesand their stunts were filmed.  The stuntmen definitely earned theirkeep on this film, especially the driver who flipped 7 times duringthe Ashton crash scene.*  "Bond Girls Are Forever" : Ex-Bond girl Maryam D'Abo flies around theWorld to interview some of the more popular Bond girls from UrsulaAndress to Halle Berry and in between.*  "Chris Cornell Video" : featuring a video of the song played in theopening credits.*  "Previews" : Rocky Balboa, The Pursuit of Happiness, Stranger ThanFiction.Where is the trailer for the movie?  I am disappointed it is not on the DVD.Casino Royale is definitely a great film in the James Bond library.  Great fights, great women, great locales, and a new, ruthless James Bond in Daniel Craig.  This franchise is in good hands.

reviewText: What gives this film clear favor, in surprising conviction for me, is not the same told story by Ian Fleming, nor the fabulous environments, nor the beach bodies, nor anything that makes a bond film...well, a bond film. I can't give too much credit to the supporting cast, yet the bleeding eye guy still resounds on the creepy scale for me. What becomes outstanding is the calous, the damaged ego, the serious, deliberate, pure state in which Danial Craig seems to portray in what is a breath of fresh air that we can all celebrate about. I was seized onto his performance, his deeply absorbed expressions into the field of enjoyment I did not think possible considering the marketing of this film. It was my father, and friends who dragged me kicking and screaming into the theater to watch it. "no, not another mindless bond film. barely exhilerating!" I've read that every bond film gives its generation what it needs. The seriousness of this film, and the thought that perhaps the team involved with this film had to "earn it audiance" was a feeling that I wish many more studio films had today. A super spy killer film for us who live in a world of insecurity and constant threats, a little bond meant to shake our perceptions of who James Bond could be, not stirred as those, now jubilant fans, who once instantly branded the blond bond as impossible. Bond is more important now than the sum of his "products", which Q lavished onto him with an almost silly carelessness as to its use and expiration. Thus, as we are now learning for ourselves. We cannot allow our government, nor can we afford, the luxury of carelessness nor must we allow operations to be handled behind the scenes with only words of assuredness' to comfort our fears. Bond neither hides its operations, but curiously sheds its almost 'superhero' like prominence it once flatteringly demonstrated without regard to occurances (golden eye opening sequence...nuf said)
summary: Having entered the Bond flims since "golden eye", the best best of this era

reviewText: Casino Royale takes James Bond and turns him inside out...in a good way.  This is the movie Pierce Brosnan wanted to do as James Bond.  He begged and pleaded with the producers to make a movie that showed a Bond stripped down and dirty.  It's a shame too, because it's a great flick.This is by far one of the best Bond flicks ever.  Let me put this in perspective for you; I think Sean Connery is great, but I never knew him as 007.  I grew up on Roger Moore as James Bond.  For Your Eyes Only, The Spy Who Loved me...those were great.  Then came Timothy Dalton.  Dalton tried hard and I respect his effort, but the only two movies he did fell flat on their face.  Then came Brosnan, who I thought was superior to Dalton and Moore in all ways.  The first three movies he did as Bond were excellent.  Without a doubt they re-energized the franchise in the best ways.Then they made Die Another Day, and I felt really sorry for Brosnan.  In an effort to go back to campy stunts and overblown F/X in an attempt to celebrate the anniversary of Bond, they made it too over the top.  Now it seems someone with a brain has come in and made everyone take a few steps back and decided to show everyone why James Bond is who he is.Casino Royale starts with 007's second assignment.  It involves a kill, and as his victim finds out, it's much easier the second time.  Yes, considerably.  The chase sequence at the beginning through a construction zone in Madagascar will leave your jaw dropped.  Then as the movie moves on to the exotic locales like the Bahamas and Montengro (always stunning locations in Bond movies) we notice almost right away this is a different Bond.  Full of ego and confidence he's vicious and much more violent then what we're used to.  Tending to solve his problems with fists and bullets rather than brains and cunning.  M (brilliantly played again by Judi Dench) refers to him as a `Blunt Instrument' and his failure to see the `Big picture' causes issues with his own foreseen outcome in some situations.Now to the good part; Daniel Craig as James Bond, 007.  What were they thinking?  Putting a critically acclaimed actor in the role of one of the world's most beloved Spy characters?  Well someone what thinking clearly!  Craig is by far the most accomplished actor to take on the role  even though he doesn't quite fit the part with his blonde hair and...good GOD those EARS!  Nevertheless, he loses himself in the role so deeply that you finally feel like this is a real person, a real character.  Not a characture.  When ordering a Vodka Martini and asked, `Shaken or Stirred', we get a firm `Do I look like I give a damn' in accordance with the characters mood at the moment.  We are treated to a Bond who feels, gets angry, gets reckless and most of all, falls in love.  As his relationship with Vesper Lynn (Eva Green) builds, our affection for her does as well.  We find ourselves liking this woman as much as he does.  Again, this movie takes a step back and shows us why Bond is the way he is, and it's a near perfect execution.  It's just...those damn ears!As with any Bond movie there are women and tuxedos, cards and martinis and a villain with an unusual character trait.  But strangely, no Moneypenny.  No Q, no gadgets!  I was somewhat disappointed in this but didn't really miss it.  The character study shows us something we have finally never seen in James Bond, something Brosnan tried to get the producers to do a long time ago but for some reason, they wouldn't.  I think Pierce would have been great in this movie, he was my favorite Bond but I do think Craig could surpass him depending on the next installment.  But most importantly, Casino Royale jump starts the franchise once more, and gives them a place to start from all over again.
summary: Bond is back and no one does it better.

reviewText: Many moons ago, my parents let my sister and I watched "Diamonds are Forever" on TV. I'm sure my sister and I would have preferred a Disney movie at the time, but even at our age, it was pretty impressive when Sean Connery got his Mustang up on two wheels. Between that fateful starry night and now, I have ended up seeing almost every James Bond movie. To me, taking James Bond back to the basics--literally, back to square one--might have seemed a daunting task, as the 007 franchise had been waning in recent years (for a myriad of reasons) and the idea of a "prequel", if you will, may have been rather risky.Fortunately, this fined-tuned Bond is what a lot of fans have been clamoring for, and new addition Daniel Craig brings James into the 21st century with thuggish aplomb. Curt, compact and arrogant, he's a secret agent who isn't above making big mistakes; his own ego often times his worst enemy. James attempts to infiltrate a terrorist organization, and within the first ten minutes the film has globe-trotted so far across the map that you may be wondering who all these villains are and what their place in the story actually is (the movie opens curiously in black-and-white, with a confrontation and also with a flashback!). Judi Dench's "M" really lets James have it for 'needlessly' killing a bomber whom they hoped to interrogate, but she has a change of heart (indeed, quite a number of them) after Bond becomes involved in a high-stakes poker game in Montenegro with terrorist-operative Le Chiffre, a real poker-face (and asthmatic!) with a bloody tear duct. Watching him made me realize he was the weakest villain of all time. I heard the book was more interesting with an equally fantastic history of him. I also thought Mads Mikkelsen was miscast. Lambert Wilson probably would have been a much better choice."Casino Royale" is packed with thrills; it looks terrific and has many moments of action, romance, macho violence, and even beauty. The one thing it does lack is humor, but we may get more of that next round.
