reviewText: I never liked Bronson. I never liked him as an actor or as Bond. Though I did like his first three Bond films just never the actor. I didn't much care for his last Bond film either. But now we once again have a good film along with a good actor for the part - Daniel Craig in "Casino Royale"!I hate to say it, but Ian Fleming's novel "Casino Royale" was quite possibly his weakest Bond novel, but this film takes his novel and manages to be both faithful to it while also making it good. Apart from the beginning (which is great and action-packed), this film stays pretty close to the novel. The plot is pretty much the same except for a few miner details they HAD to change because of the times. The novel was written in the early 50s and this film is set in 2006. The James Bond character is much like Ian Fleming's Bond rather than the previous film versions that we've seen. And for the most part the film is action-packed and pretty exciting. And Bond once again has a meaningful relationship with the girl. The last time a Bond film tried that was in 1969's "On Her Majesty's Secret Service".The only thing that hated about this film was that Vesper's and Bond's relationship goes on for too damn long before anything actually happens. It would have been fine if they cut out the scene where Bond and Vesper were on the beach because that scene was unnecessary and boring. If they had just left that scene out, this would have been the best Bond film yet.Never the less this was still a great and action-packed film.Highly recommended!
summary: Finally a good actor for the part again!

reviewText: Sean Connery's James Bond films were, for the most part, classics.But Daniel Craig's portrayal is in a class all its own. Craig's Bond is edgier, reflecting a James Bond who is amoral, aloof, far removed from the values of the average person - which makes him well-suited for killing.Gone for the most part is the techno-wizardy of Q that provided so much of the fun of the Connery films. There's a bit of it: a Sony-Ericcson cell phone plays a small part as does a 1964 Aston-Martin with a surprising array of goodies in the glove compartment.Instead we have a relentless Bond who pursues his quarry without mercy. Bond's ruthlessness and coldness is demonstrated in the opening sequence. His subsequent exchanges with M, flawlessly performed by Judi Dench, hammer home that this Bond is still rough around the edges and his masters appreciate that: they want an automaton who doesn't worry about collateral damage.The requisite willing women fall for this Bond's charm as they have fallen for every Bond.The story is actually a bit of of a muddle, but there's so much action, no one cares.The villains, particulaly Le Chiffre, are as good as Daniel Craig.This is an old-fashioned film in many ways and all the more satisfying for that. No greys here, no nagging questions about morality. There is good - and his name is James Bond. And there is bad - everyone else. This new, edgier Bond is a tribute to all the classic adventures, thrillers and action movies of the past. It hold your attention from start to finish.In short, it's great.Jerry
summary: As good as the Sean Connery films: James Bond is reborn

reviewText: Danial Craig gives more of no non-sense James Bond then we're used to. I mean this Bond actually leaves a woman that wants him, to go follow a bad guy instead. He's a more serious James Bond and Craig and the director Martin Campbell make it clear that you don't want to cross this James Bond.Campbell's GoldenEye was the best Pierce Brosnan Bond film and it's nice to see him return. Casino Royale is a lot more serious than GoldenEye. I mean GoldenEye even has it's scenes of cartoonish violence. There's no sign of anything like that here. His pace is about as slow as if he's doing a 60's Jamees Bond film. Which is only bad when we get a little too many scenes with Bond playing cards. There's a lot of action in the beginning and then the film gets pretty slow. Craig is so good that it's still hard not to want to stick with the film though. Plus I can't say that I don't want Martin Campbell to come back for the next film. His direction and Craig's performance really are a good combination. All those people that said Craig was a really bad casting choice are gonna choke on those words after seeing how good he is here.

reviewText: The Bond films have always been about male wish fulfillment. All the guys wish they could drink, dress, drive, fight and f*ck like Bond. In "Casino Royale," Bond is still the ultimate man's man, but he's also something else: human.He makes mistakes. He has flaws. In this film, he learns and matures and develops as a person. Also, the women in his life are real, three-dimensional characters with distinct personalities and motivations. If you're not familiar with the Bond films, you're probably asking, "So what?" but those who know and love Bond will recognize this as a quantam leap forward.This gives the aging franchise a much-needed shot in the arm. I can now imagine 007 carrying on for another 40 years without seeming hopelessly dated.I hesitate to call it the best Bond film ever, but I think this is possibly the best Bond film in decades.

reviewText: There's a dirty secret when it comes to James Bond movies: they all suck. Every single one of them, and we're including the ones starring Sean Connery, who's made more out of less (his accent and bristly but cultured masculinity) than any actor I can think of.They all stank, like rot. Until this one.To begin with, it's not poorly lit, poorly shot, with lethargic "action" sequences involving cheap explosions and poorly choreographed fight scenes. The lovable institution of "Q" (always beware of "lovable institutions") has been dispatched entirely, as have cartoonish demonstrations of "cultured living" that would appeal only to those with no conception of what "cultured" and "high class" actually consist of. (Hint: it has nothing to do with ordering drinks shaken and not stirred, or enjoying Peruvian Blonde coffee from the first beans of the season.)James Bond movies have always appealed to a certain demographic. At least in the US, that was predominantly young, male, and incredibly dumb. Female characters--even the allegedly "strong" ones--were always soft in the head and punished for any semblance of mental fortitude with unapologetically mysogynistic names like Pussy Galore. (So much for "strong female characters", it's no wonder that being a "Bond Girl" is an insult to any serious working actor.)Daniel Craig is a wonder--physically compact and powerful, he's like watching a coiled spring move about the stage. Eva Green, however, is the real standout. Her Vesper Lynd falls for none of Bond's pat lines and surface charms, and is just as bright and quick as he is: his initial attempt to establish the alpha-male position in their relationship is quickly upended entirely, with a sharp riposte that set the tone for the rest of the movie.Given this latest turn in the franchise, and its rightful place as The Only Good Bond Movie Ever Made, I wait with no small anticipation for the latest release, Quantum Solace.
summary: Finally, a Bond movie that doesn't suck

reviewText: So many of us are utterly incapable of dissolving our image of the suave yet sophisticated British cavilier known as 007.  The tuxedo-wearing popinjay tantalized beautiful women with confident, yet refined displays of masculine charm, and impressed his male fans with his ownership of the entire gamut of scientific contraptions of every conceivable use.  The framework of this two pronged technique of charm and mechanical know-how was glued together with violence, and thrust into a land of spies, international intrigue, deception and surprise.With such an attractive combination of interest drawing elements, it is not at all shocking that some Bond aficionados are a bit thwarted that the most modern portrayal of the spy genre's most prolific icon has apparently departed from some of the more indispensible traits.The bond we are presented with in Casino Royale is not the same eloquent dandy that we have growned accustomed to.  To call him a brute, and to equate him with the likes of the slope-browed, ill-mannered icons of American 1980's era action, such as Arnold and Stallone, would constitute a full-blown hyperbole.  But the new Bond is suprisingly uncouth, and graceless when compared to his former self.His attitude is not the only change, he has done away with his impecable selection of duds, but has not totally replaced them with a formal dress code of clumsiness.  Though suit is used sporadically, he has not yet donned a pair of torn jeans with an oil stain.  If this is not the Bond you know, then imagine a Bond that has done away with at least half of his stunning staple of mechanical marvels.Before reading any further, I would beg readers to remember, however, that this is the Bond in his early days, before he fully accomplished his 00 status.  Refinement comes with age and experience.  A young Bond does not showcase all of the same character traits as the later edition, but he is Bond nonetheless.He has retained his extraordinary talent for womanizing, though his tactics are a bit different, every gallant nighthawk knows that the verbiage and attitude that attracts the fairer sex is constantly changing over the years.  Similarly, Bond's knack for action is enhanced by the proverbial rocket fuel of youth.  The tireless dynamo possessed every drop of energy that was necessary to revive the modern Bond epic, which has sagged recently.To those who say this is not Bond......A character that is not static, a personality that develops, a life that experiences change is certainly more interesting that a constant, suit donning old chap that churns out the same performances day in and day out.  James Bond, as spotless as he is perceived, was not born in a suit.In addition to the brilliant and gradual development of young Bond, the viewers are immediately treated to a brilliant chase scene, a staple of the Bond genre.  The stunts are well done and choreographed to near perfection throughout, and our protaganist shows a profoud and diverse sense of character.  Energetic, spontaneous, and aggressive, he demonstrates the youthful vigor that a young Bond surely possessed.  His measured violence and ruthlessness add colour to the film and the plot.The film would not be complete without the famous utterance "Bond, James Bond."  When it happens, it happens with the young agent clad in a sharp suit.  It acquires more meaning and signifies his gradual growth into the classic Bond.To those who allege that this is no Bond movie, my retort, is that it adds to Bond, it embellishes the legend, it is a peak into his development, it makes it stronger.  The action is enough for this film to stand on its own, but it does much more, it adds to a modern epic.
summary: Not the Bond we're used to, but entertaining nonetheless

reviewText: I love when the Bond movies break the traditional format and remain true to the Fleming novels. The Screen Writers did a great job of updating and adapting the Cold War based novel "Casino Royale" to the 21 century.Daniel Craig is a great Bond. Yes, he does not look like what would be considered a normal Bond but his acting makes up for that. He is much more intense than the previous actors who played the character. Some people thought he was not suave enough in this movie. However, these people must understand that EON has restarted the series. Craig is signed on for 3 movies and during these films he will develop more and more into the classic agent we all know. Already by the end of this film he was more Bond-like. Also, the Craig movies will all connect to each other and continue the storyline, unlike the previous Bond movies. EON says they will continue to develop Bond's complex personality.The rest of the cast was superb as well. Mads Mikkelsen played the villain, Le Chiffre. What I liked best about this villain is that he was not over-the-top evil. He was a more realistic "bad guy". Eva Green played the Bond girl Vesper Lynd. She is my favorite Bond girl of the 21 films. Her character was much more intriguing and complex than any previous Bond Girls. Craig and her had good chemistry. Judi Dench is M. This is her fifth appearance as M but this time she is not quite the same as in the Bronson films. In Goldeneye, she was the new one on the scene who felt that Bond was a relic of the Cold War. In this film, Bond is the new one on the scene and she is the relic of the Cold War. I liked Jeffrey Wright as Felix Leiter and I hope he is in the next movie.Casino Royale is the longest Bond film to date (Approx. 2 and a half hours) but it keeps a fast pace. The action scenes are some of the grittiest and intense of the 21 films. The stunt work is amazing. EON decided to back away from CGI and the crazy gadgets in favor of a more believable adventure. The director Martin Campbell (Goldeneye) did a great job and I hope he directs the next movie too.I am excited about the 2 disc set. The biggest reason is because the cast really did not promote the movie on the talk show circuit, so I am looking forward to hear what they have to say about the film.Conclusion:I highly recommend Casino Royale. If you thought Die Another Day was a major disappointment or if you have stopped watching Bond movies, you should give this one a chance.

reviewText: This film marks a major departure for the James Bond franchise. Although it is difficult to keep continuity in the series after all these decades, this film does not even try. In this one, Bond is freshly promoted to the ranks of the 00 secret agents and his on his first big case.He is trying to track international terrorism through a money man. This leads him to a high stakes poker game at Casino Royale in Albania.  All is not as it seems, however, there are plots within plots and it is difficult to know who to trust. This is a recurring problem for him.This Bond film does not rely on all of the techno gadgetry that most of the series do. Instead, it just relies on a hard charging agent who refuses to let the bad guys win. This Bond is not the polished operator one has come to expect from the series. He can be very rough around the edges and needs polishing. It fits in with the story line but I wonder how it will fit in with this Bond in other films, assuming there are more.Its an interesting film. Not the best and not the worst but worthwhile.There are a few "extra features" on a second disk. The first seems like just a promo for the new James Bond and details the casting process. The second was more interesting. It is called "Bond Girls are Forever" and documents the evolution of the Bond girls from simple cheesecake bimbos to the much more complex characters of later films. I found it interesting.

reviewText: I've been a 007 fan ever since DR. NO premiered as the bottom half of a double drive-in bill in Kansas City.  I loved Connery; thought Lazenby's OHMSS the best of the Bond bunch; suffered through the Moore era; loathedDalton's petrified agent; tolerated Brosnan's glossy but empty 007 - and woke up during the last two minutes of CASINO ROYALE to hail Daniel Craig as THE new Bond on the block.  Naturally I snatched up the original DVDrelease.So now here comes Sony with a new "collector's edition" (double-dipping, as they do so well).  There actually are some snippets that make this one worth having, notably the "deleted" which actually do add a little more to the film.  The extras are puff-pieces - but watchable.Only for Bond die-hards, or folks who believe Blue Ray will replace regular DVD.

reviewText: Director Martin Campbell has done a miraculous, most satisfying, reboot of the James Bond cinematic franchise in directing the stylish, captivating espionage thriller "Casino Royale", returning the character of James Bond back to the original character in the Ian Fleming novels, and having, in actor Daniel Craig, the best portrayal of MI 6 agent 007 James Bond since Sean Connery in the films "Dr. No", and especially, "From Russia with Love". Indeed, this splendid adaptation of "Casino Royale" - the third one, and while the others include a wacky 1967 spoof featuring Peter Sellars - it is this one which hews closest to the original text of Ian Fleming's novel, with some concessions to early 21st Century interest in combatting global terrorism. Craig is quite simply the best actor since Connery to play James Bond, offering a twisted, conflicted character who combines recklessness bordering on nearly suicidal behavior with unexpected sentimentality towards the woman he does fall eventually in love with; his portrayal isn't Connery's sophisticated, yet ruthless, espionage agent, or Roger Moore's debonair spy, but nonetheless Craig - a superb actor in his own right - offers a truly convincing, emotionally riveting portrayal of James Bond that suceeds in persuading fans that not only does he deserve this role, but he has also earned the right to continue acting as James Bond.Yet Craig's superb acting isn't the only reason to see "Casino Royale". Judi Dench is of course magnificient as a younger version of M, the stern director of MI 6, who finds herself questioning her decision to promote Bond to  00 status. French actress Eva Green is a brainy, beautiful foil to Craig's Bond as British treasury agent Vesper Lynd. Mads Mikkelsen offers an emotionally textured portrayal as the sinister banker - and chief Bond villain - Le Chiffre. Much to my surprise, Jeffrey Wright was also quite convincing as American CIA agent Felix Leiter. The same holds true for distinguished Italian actor Giancarlo Gianinni as Mathis, MI 6's field operative in Montenegro.  Hence "Casino Royale" deserves recognition as one of the best films of 2006, as well as of the James Bond franchise, simply due to the overall excellence of its cast."Casino Royale" introduces us to the character of James Bond, showing two riveting scenes filmed in black and white at the film's beginning, demonstrating how Bond earned his 00 status, or rather in plain English, his "licence to kill". The film's often breathtaking fast pace, takes us from Madagascar to the Bahamas and Florida, as Bond goes in hot pursuit of Le Chiffre's terrorist allies and agents, acting as a lone wolf in nearly complete independence from M and the rest of her senior MI 6 staff. Most of the film takes place in Montenegro, as Bond raises high financial stakes in a riveting Texas Fold-'Em poker match against Le Chiffre and several others, including CIA agent Felix Leiter. Before this thrilling rollercaster of an espionage film ride ends, we are treated to some unexpected scenes set in Venice, Italy, before the film ends on a riveting, dramatic note with Craig's Bond uttering, "The name is Bond. James Bond.".
summary: The Best James Bond film since "From Russia With Love"
Title: N/A

reviewText: Oh thank God.  The Bond series has been a sadistic parody of itself for decades, though thankfully, above average instances of parody have typically been followed by a complementary tendency towards seriousness.  Consider Casino Royale to be the restoring pendulum swing of the franchise' most ludricrous logical deviation to date, Die Another Day, a movie that had as much respect for the Bond character as it had for plot, plausibility or ... you get the idea.Very similarly to the films of the Timothy Dalton era, Casino Royale gives  a no-nonsense, uber serious portrayal of Bond, though its main advantage over the prior is that Casino Royale's use of character development permits the audience to understand WHY Bond behaves so darkly.  As a result, it no longer seems arbitrary.  At the same time, Daniel Craig plays the role brilliantly, making the audience really believe that Bond has a soul.  Though I realize this film is meant as a reboot, I could still very easily see the young, jacked, former-SAS Craig Bond evolve into the slighty more seasoned but still all around thug that was the Connery Bond.Most interestingly, however, about this movie, is the relationship that develops between Bond and Vesper Lynd, his liason to the Treasury, or something, which may very well comprise the prototype for all of Bond's future relationships with women.  (Ever wonder why he's so fond of but never dates Moneypenny?)  Lynd really is the perfect partner for Bond.  She's dark, just like him, she's calculated, just like him, and in a battle of misdirection and wit, there's no guarantee who would win.  And yet, on top of all that, she is slightly naive, which seems like a charming compliment to Craig's Bond.  Eva Green has been criticized a little for her portrayal but she acts in an interesting, slightly androgynous way, much like her character.  This unusual portrayal potentially reveals elements of the Bond character as well, though regretably, we'll most likely never know for sure.  Unfortunately, Fleming never wrote a prequel to Casino Royale.In summary, Casino Royale is a good leave-your-brain-slightly-on adventure.
summary: I think... I just... Crapped myself

reviewText: Finally - a Bond to make us forget the awful performances of Moore, Dalton, and Brosnan.  Craigs cold, introverted, ruthless presentation of 007 is truly something to behold.  The entire film has you clamoring for what's underneath his pokerfaced facade.  Gone are the goofy gadgets and gizmos, the silly puns and one liners (well, almost all of them), and the comic book villains.  Le Chiffre is truly evil and maniacal.  A few traditional Bond brands have, happily, been retained, such as Walther and Aston-Martin (and OMG what a car), although the Rolex has been replaced with an Omega. The action is edge-of-seat and original, and the extras disk is eye-opening with regard to the production and stunts - as much fun to watch as the feature.  There is a bit of a stall about 3/4 of the way through, and the end seems to taper off a bit, but, on a whole, this 007 feature is the star in the crown of the Fleming film franchise and bears repeated watching. Framed with a great opening number and a hot new rendition of the classic Bond theme for the end credits, this one is worth.."every penny of it". Even Connery's legendary performance is starting to fade a bit....

reviewText: This is a far more physical Bond than any we've seen before. Daniel Craig exudes strength, power and, indeed, a raw sexual allure. This Bond is also more tender, gentle, and fallible. It's also a Bond that spends quite a bit of time baring his skin. Good thing Mr. Craig is familiar with the inside of a gym.The plot of the film is simple enough. A rogue financier of rebellious factions, Le Chiffre (Mads Mikkelson), has gambled with the money entrusted to him and lost it all. He must regain it in a game of poker with an astonishing stake: $150 million. Bond has, as allies, Versper Lynd (Eva Green, Kingdom of Heaven), and Matthis (Giancarlo Giannini, Hanibal).For such a simple plot, this was highly entertaining. The action scenes are believable to the point of pain, and Daniel Craig stakes his claim as Bond more powerfully than anyone since Connery.The high-tech gadgets we've come to expect in every scene of a Bond film aren't as much in evidence here, but there are enough for the techno nerd in anyone.

reviewText: Casino Royale(2006) is a good James Bond film drected by Martin Campbell. It reboots the series and starts fresh with Daniel Craig as James Bond. The producers took Ian Fleming's 1952 novel Casino Royale and updated it to the post 9/11 era. There's no attempts to take over the world by bad guys. 007 has to stop enemy agent Le Chiffre from winning money at Casino Royale. There's no Q or Miss Moneypenny in the story. M and Felix Leiter do appear. Bond gets help from agents Mathis and Vesper Lynd. There is some fan service. Bond wins an Aston Martin DB5 in a card game and we hear Monty Norman's James Bond theme during the end credits. The film delivers parakour, gunplay, car chases, and explosions. The theme song by Chris Cornell is good. The music score by David Arnold is superb. Daniel Craig is good as a violent, sexy, macho, blonde haired, blue eyed version of James Bond. Craig acted in movies and TV shows such as Tomb Raider, Tales from the Crypt, A Kid in King Arthur's Court, and Layer Cake. Casino Royale is a great 007 movie!

reviewText: Deciding to start fresh with Casino Royale. Directed by Martin Campbell he did a better job with Golden Eye honestly. Daniel Craig plays James Bond now. I'm glad they brought Judi Dench back as M even though it's a reboot. Mads Mikkensen plays Le Chiffre, Eva Green as Vasper Lynd & Giancarlo Giannini as Mathis. Story is James Bond has recieeved 007 status & he's tracking down Le Chiffre who is a financer for the worlds terrorists. Bond has stopped Le Chiffre's plans to blow up a Skyfleetar so Le Chiffre sets up a high stakes poker game to recoup his losses. He also joins with Vasper Lynd from HM Tresury & he meets a contact in Monternago Mathis. Now don't get me wrong I think this is an ok movie it had it's moments it's better than Die Another Day. But the poker tornamet scenes are way too long it slows the movie down. Cause it should've focused more on building up this new Bond up & the action you get some decent fight scenes some good action. I love the scene were Le Chiffre's henchies find the body of this big guy that Bond killed it was pretty funny. I liked that Bond was given depth. But they did drag it out with 25 30 minute poker scenes. The torture scene where is well done they think Mathis is a insider but it turns out later that he isn't. I do like how they delt with Vasper she had no choice to betray Bond. Bond finds out who was behind it Mr. White which leads to our next movie which I like better. This was the 1st Bond film to feature Mathis. Daniel Craig was the 1st Bond to be younger that the film series. An origins story was planned after The Roger Moore series but Albert R Broccli rejected it cause he felt audiences weren't intrested in a younger Bond. Craig was Barbra Broccli's 1st choice. In some countries it was released in 2007 which was neat. This is the highest grossing movie in the franchise. Sean Connery was rumored to direct in early production. The Venice sinking sequence took 3 weeks to complete. In 04 while Brosnan was still James Bond he suggested Quintin Tarintino. Pirece Brosnan was considered too old to play Bond. Martin Campbell agreed to direct cause he had no other projects at the time. Longest Bond film so far. It would've costed $30 million to have Pierce Brosnan to return. 1st Bond movie to have Bond leave alone. Martin Campbell I don't know if his heart wasn't in it but he didn't have the same impact from Golden Eye. Daniel Craig gives an alright performance. Judi Dench gave a great perfomance. Eva Green wasn't bad. Mads Mikkenssen didn't get me as the villain. Giancarlo Ginnnini was good. Next Quantum Of Solace & I'll explain why I like it more.

reviewText: The Cold War is over, but that doesn't mean that there are not new treats to the world. For that reason, the Bond franchise gets a fresh start. The movie is now based on Ian Fleming's first book Casino Royale. This time Daniel Craig gets the role of one of the coolest characters in cinema, James Bond. He has presence on screen and the action is plenty, but the story could have been better.Story:James Bond (Daniel Craig) is the new kid on the block in the MI6 organization led by M (Judi Dench). He gained the 00 status after his two first kills. He is a cold-blooded, reckless and egomaniacal spy. Now as a 00 agent, he is after a villain Le Chiffre (Mads Mikkelsen) who funds terrorist groups around the world. One terrorist attack is stopped by Bond. To cripple his evil activities, Bond follows him to Montenegro where they will play an extravagant game of poker. As Bond travels, he meets his undercover partner, Vesper Lynd (Eva Green) who gets romantically involved with him. Will he be able to stop Le Chiffre? Will Bond break the spy code and fall for Vesper?Review:We all expect--if you are fan of Bond movies--to see cool gadgets, exotic cars, crazy stunts and plenty of beautiful women and you'll see most of those traditional icons in this new film. This time around the gadgets are almost gone to create a more mature, realistic and darker Bond--a beautiful Aston Martin is his car of choice. He is more reckless, egomaniac and careless that the previous 007 (Pierce Brosnan).We like the first half of the film--the classic Bond intro credits is one of the best ones. The photography is excellent and the stunts are probably one if the best we've seen this year--the airport action scene is priceless. Honestly, Daniel Craig was not my first choice as the next Bond--my pick was Clive Owen--but after watching his performance in this new film, he totally changed my mind. He is perfect for the role. He is very athletic, charismatic, but always keeping his cold-blooded and strong personality.Unfortunately the last half of the film is where most of the problems are. The main story becomes secondary, sillier, paper thin and stretched for a movie that is 144 minutes long. The plot is now more about Bond's ego and his game of poker. The editing could have been better--at this point, the movie drags--especially while playing poker. The game resembles a fancy version of the ESPN World Series of Poker TV show. As we are watching Bond playing poker, we realize how silly the whole scene is. How can you bring down someone that is funding terrorists just by taking his money in a game of poker? We ask ourselves. Also during the games, Bond and Vesper get romantic, but we don't feel the connecting between them. Their relationship feels a bit forced and awkward.After waiting for a great finale, we were surprised that the movie doesn't end in a conventional way because the story seems to "continue" for the next installment.The Verdict:Casino Royale--even though it has some low points--is much better than the previous movie from the Pierce Brosnan era. No more ridiculous gadgets. This reborn of the franchise feels more mature. We hope to see more of Daniel Craig in his new and exciting new role, but we also hope the next plot to be stronger than this one. For the filmmakers, please make the film a bit shorter next time.
summary: The Bond franchise gets a fresh start

reviewText: I have been a long time Bond fan since I can remember. I have read all the novels, seen all the films, and read about Ian Fleming and a lot of articles about the subject. After Ian Fleming's death other authors were hired to write Bond novels namely: Kingsley Amis, Christopher Wood, John Gardner and Raymond Benson.This is actually the second film entitled "Casino Royale." The first one was a James Bond spoof that starred David Niven.After all the hype, I must say that the second "Casino Royale" is an above average action film (but if you have to see only one action film this year you will be better off with "The Departed").Daniel Craig is a good actor. I have seen him in "Road to Perdition," "The Mother," and "Munich" among others. However, Craig's Bond is far from Ian Fleming's Bond in the novels and the early Sean Connery films which had Ian Fleming's seal of approval.What's good about Craig's Bond is that it was stripped off a lot of complicated and fantastic plots as well as unrealistic sets that plagued the last Pierce Brosnan film (Although I consider Pierce Brosnan as arguably the best Bond after Sean Connery). The sets of "Die Another Day" became too fantastic and distracting from the story and the character build-up. I think its a mistake to let technological advancement and elaborate sets to overcome a film's story and character.A lot of Bond fans complain that Daniel Craig doesn't look a bit like the 007 in the novels. This is accurate in the sense that Bond had dark hair..."with a comma of hair falling over his brow." In fact, Ian Fleming wrote in his novels "Casino Royale" and "Moonraker" that James Bond resembled musician-actor Hoagy Carmichael with a scar down one cheek.Also, Daniel Craig's recurring beefcake display was also distracting and unnecessary. As to the costume, the film focused more on Craig's muscle shirts than the traditional impeccable suits, jackets and shirts which traditional British Eaton and Oxford educated chaps, like Bond, normally wear. Ian Fleming was so precise as to write that Bond preferred fine Sea Island cotton for his shirts. Also, James Bond plays Baccarat NOT poker. The writers must have been overly influenced by the recent rash of Vegas style Texas Hold' em on television.Although Craig's acting in the the torture scene highlighted his ability, he lacked the tradmark Bond charm. There was no presence when he walked into the room. He could have been mistaken for the bad guy who get's killed in the first 15 minutes of a Bond flick. Also, Craig's Bond seemed to lack the distinct class and breeding the gentleman MI6 operative was known for. But this might be attributed to the fact that this was supposed to be James Bond's debut in both book and film.Speaking of MI6, the film's MI6 operatives seemed like blundering idiots who do not know what they were doing unlike those in the novel and the previous films. Looking back, the early Ian Fleming novels were written right after World War II & it is unlikely that MI6 would have chosen those types working for British Intelligence (CIA and KGB office and field operatives in "The Good Shepherd" were far more credible).Daniel Craig was able to emote the spy's calousness but lacked the depth of facial expression to tell you what was happening to him. I would have preferred Pierce Brosnan's portrayal in this area. He was still good for another Bond film. But if the producers wanted to replace him I would have preferred Clive Owen. But that's just my personal opinion. My opinion might be shaded by my belief in tradition especially when it comes to pop culture male role models. I believe that certain actors are fit to play certain roles which include looks as criteria as shallow as it may sound. Otherwise, I would agree that Daniel Craig will make a better "Superman" instead of newcomer Brandon Routh because the former is a better actor.Although, making Bond too hi-tech becomes distracting, this film had so little gadgets that it was not fun anymore (unless you consider Craig's too prominantly displayed Sony Viao as a "hi-tech" gadget. This is probably the commercial effect of Sony Pictures' getting this franchise. But much as I love Sony products their after sales service sucks! FYI). A miniature defibrilator in the glove compartment of the Aston Martin was the gadget highlight of the movie. Although, the novels do not emphasize the gadgets, I believe they had their share of secret weapons without going overboard like in "Moonraker" (the film not the book) and "Die Another Day." Noticeably, "Q" is missing.Characterwise, Bond isn't the type who would say "I love you." The only time I recall Bond saying those words was in "On Her Majesty's Secret Service" (book and film) to the only woman he ever married - Contessa Teresa "Tracy" Di Vicenzo played in the film by the unforgettable Diana Rigg ("The Avengers") to George Lazenby's Bond. I guess Daniel Craig had to say it to compensate for his inability to emote what the character would have felt at that particular scene. But it could also be that Bond becomes less emotionally attach as he gets older and more experinced. Eva Green, although very beautiful, looked too much like Bond Girl No. 99 Sophie Marceau ("The World is Not Enough") and unfortunately but understandably lacked the latter's acting experience which is not a whole lot to begin with.Overall, I was a bit disappointed. I heard people (especially women) say it's the best Bond film ever. I respectfully disagree. The novels speak for themselves. "Casino Royale" (the second film) although has its entertainment strengths, could not measure up to Sean Connery's "Dr. No," "From Russia with Love" and "Goldfinger" taking into consideration that most of these films were made in the 60's. Pierce Brosnan's first ("Goldeneye") was probably the best Bond film after them. Although good acting accolades also go to Timothy Dalton in "Living Daylights."Although "Casino Royale" was a fresh break from the last tech diluted "Die Another Day." I do not think I would like to see more of the same. Althought Craig's "The world will know you scratched my balls" dialogue was funny, I will always miss Sean Connery's more "intelligent" and "gentlemanly" quips. "...I think he got the point..." (Connery to Domino after shooting Vargas with a harpoon in "Thunderball").
Title: N/A

reviewText: With this film they decided to reboot the whole Bond franchise, which was probably a good idea given how lousy it got under Pierce Brosnan. But then for some reason they replaced all the actors except the actress Judi Dench as "M", which is slightly confusing.A lot of friends have told me they liked this film because it got back to the roots of James Bond as being a cold brutal killer.The James Bond franchise is similar to Batman in the sense that there is a subset of fans who are always complaining that the character isn't dark enough, and needs to return to his dark brooding roots and away from all his cartoonish gadgets. But, like Batman, the character can just as easily get ridiculous in either direction. As in: "you know he has a darkside, but you don't know it enough until you see this movie".I don't think Bond's cold side has ever really been neglected. In most of his films it shows up in some form or another.Even in films like "The World is not Enough" there was that scene where Bond remorselessly shot the woman he had slept with."Casino Royale" boarders on over-emphasizing Bond's psychopathic nature (I'm thinking primarily of the scenes in the beginning). But on the whole I think it walks the line pretty well, and does faithfully reproduce Ian Fleming's classic line: "The bitch is dead."The extended poker scenes also emphasize Bond's cunning side, and give the film a bit of high class Casion glitz. And the action scenes are well done, I'll give this film that.

reviewText: The Bond franchise starts over with this film, which stars fair-haired Daniel Craig as an inexperienced rookie earning his "00" status. The plot? To rid an African terrorist group of its funding, Bond takes on its evil banker in a high-stakes poker game at a Bahamas casino. Along the way he learns discipline, patience, and yes, how to judge a good martini.In fact, though the film has a definite modern feel, it contains many classic 007 touches. Though he starts off in a Ford, Bond soon finds himself driving a vintage Aston Martin, and later gets to wreck a brand-new one. When he tells his assistant (Eva Green) her secret identity, he jokes that "you are now known as 'Miss Stephanie Broadchest'" ("I am not!" she protests). And yes, guys, there's eye candy -- a bikini-clad babe once pops out of the sea, while another bounces down the beach as she rides a horse -- both for no apparent reason whatsoever.Trouble is, none of this is especially memorable. The girls are rarely seductive, and few and far between. The movie is based on Ian Fleming's 1953 novel, but the plot has been reworked to focus on the redial capability of cell phones, a mundane story device if there ever was one. The chase scenes are creative enough but offer little spectacular scenery. And though it's interrupted a couple of times, the poker game drags on for a full 32 minutes, with nary a bouncy babe in sight. In fact, the whole movie is way too long, especially the final third.Actually, my favorite part of the film is its gorgeous title sequence, which combines the art of  playing cards and roulette wheels with graphic silhouettes of Bond and his enemies. And I really like Judi Dench, reprising her role as the long-suffering M. Also good are two 25-minute bonus features. "Becoming Bond" recounts Craig's selection and preparation for the role with lots of behind the scenes footage, while "James Bond: For Real" shows how many of the stunts used a surprisingly little amount of CGI.In the end, this is a good popcorn movie, but it won't be a classic. Craig's youth and solid acting make him a fine choice for the new Bond, but he needs a better writer -- and editor -- to become the next Sean Connery.

reviewText: Movie Score: 4/5Just when it seemed the Bond franchise was getting stagnant, Casino Royale comes and serves as a much needed breath of fresh air into the series. Although I was a bit disappointed in the way that Pierce Brosnan was unceremoniously dumped, I have to say, it appears that Daniel Craig was certainly up to the task and has already proven himself a worthy successor.Although the story is a bit predictable and it does drag in a few places, the adaptation of the very first Bond novel is quite entertaining. There are some insightful moments that really let you delve a bit into Bond characters (such as why he tends to somewhat, umm, objectify women over the years) However, there are plenty of great Bond action sequences. There is an extraordinary chase scene early on in the movie that really helps it get off with a bang.It seems with this movie that the studio was initially going for a test run with Daniel Craig at the helm of Bond. However, what very well could have would up being a medicore movie wound up become a stellar one with solid performances given all around. Cheers to everyone involved in the making of this film.This film achieves all it sets out to as it will surely catapult Daniel Craig's name into the mainstream;s collective conscious and build high anticipation for future installments to come.Video: 4/5Audio: 4.5/5Video and audio are both superb. One of the best Blu-Ray releases I have seen so far from both a video and an audio standpoint. Highly reccomended. A great technical showpiece early in the Blu-Ray's life-cycle. The video was vibrant and certainly a noticeable upgrade from standard defintion. While there are a few blu-ray titles out there sporting better visuals, Casino Royale is by my no means lacking in this department. 1080p is, with the case of blu-ray, once again a given.The uncompressed 5.1 PCM sound track does a wonderful job of bringing every gunshot, grunt, and groan to our ears. The aural component of this film is very much a winner and will surely make you the envy of anyone whom you present this film to (especially if they know little about hi def video/audio)Extras: 2.5/5We all know that MGM knows how to make a film proper, so how about learning how to give a solid slate of extras along with the film. Is it really that much to ask for? The extras are sorely lacking and the absence of a commentary in this day and age is simply unexcusable. Hopefully, they'll learn to clean up their act.Final Verdict: Buy it.While a double dip of this film is imminent (see: every other re-hashed Bond film), if you can look past the sore lack of extras, this disk delivers everything else in spades. Strongly reccomended.
summary: Making it once again fashionable to say "shaken, not stirred"

reviewText: Have you ever wondered what events helped make James Bond into the man we have known for the last few decades?  Ever wanted to know how he achieved his `00' status or why he treats women the way that he does?  Well, if you do then you will no doubt want to watch the movie that is being called `the best Bond movie ever made'.  The movie I'm talking about of course is "007: Casino Royale".  After over 20 movies, the producers of the `James Bond' series felt it was time for a restart, a way to make Bond fresh for today's audiences.  So, what better way to do that than to begin this reboot of the franchise with the story that started it all, and let audiences everywhere discover just how James became Bond."007: Casino Royale" begins with a different kind of James Bond (Daniel Craig), as we are first introduced to him at a point in his career where he doesn't even have his `00' status as yet.  However, it doesn't take Bond long to achieve this level after he succeeds in assassinating two enemy agents in quick order, and the timing couldn't be better.  It turns out while James is becoming agent 007, a terrorist financier known as Le Chiffre is gambling heavily with his client's money.  It's a risky move for sure when playing with other people's money, especially when those people are terrorists, but it's a move that has paid off time and again with very lucrative profits.  But when Le Chiffre gambles his most recent client's money on the stock market and loses, he quickly realizes that in order to survive he will have to pay back the money in short order before the terrorists notice that their money is missing.  To accomplish this, Le Chiffre has organized a high-stakes poker tournament, and one he is confident that he will win.  That is until `M' (Judi Dench) the head of MI-6 assigns 007, who just so happens to be their best poker player, with the task of defeating Le Chiffre so that he will have no where to run except to the British government for sanctuary from the very terrorists that he used to work for.  To ensure that all goes smoothly, `M' has placed a Treasury agent named Vesper Lynd (Eva Green) to watch over James, but when they begin to fall for each other Le Chiffre sees this as an opportunity to stop Bond once and for all.After more than 20 movies have utilized the character of `007', and 5 actors had previously played the part, it's hard to believe that MGM would want to just start over as if all that had never happened.  Especially if they expect audiences to go along with them on this little endeavor, and I'm sure the fact that the previous `Bond' movie "007: Die Another Day" being the most successful `007' film to date didn't make the decision any easier.  But as difficult as it was to understand MGM's reasoning, and as much skepticism regarding the casting of the first blonde James Bond, after viewing the movie I have to say all my skepticism, along with everyone else's was all for naught, and that MGM had made a very good choice."007: Casino Royale" is by far one of the best `James Bond' movies ever to be made, if not the absolute best.  The story for the movie was the most realistic of any `Bond' movie, and also had so much ground to cover, that it's surprising the movie didn't feel cluttered with the amount of groundwork that was laid for the already established franchise, but the writers delivered brilliantly.  One terrific choice, and yet was also one that was panned in the beginning, was the lack of gadgets that were to be included in this `Bond' movie, opting to go with a more realistic approach, and this decision proved to elevate the movie above its predecessors.  Assisting in making this movie become so terrific was the directing by Martin Campbell ("The Mask of Zorro"), who delivers an even better, more polished movie than his last foray into the world of James Bond when he launched Pierce Brosnan's career as MI-6's most famous agent in "007: Goldeneye", and proving that he was the right man to bring James Bond back to reality.  As far as the actor chosen to portray agent 007, Daniel Craig was superb, though panned by fans and critics as not looking the part, after the movie was finished I believe almost everyone is in agreement that he is one of the best Bond's ever in the franchise's history.  Craig's performance shows audiences a much more gritty, battle-hardened agent who will do what it takes to get the job done, while at the same time he can show a vulnerability that hadn't been seen before in these movies as a Bond that makes mistakes and sometimes loses.  It was nice to see Judi Dench return as `M', though for continuity this doesn't work since she didn't become `M' until the Pierce Brosnan movies, but that is a fact that can easily be overlooked, much like the various actors playing the title role.  Rounding out the main cast of characters is Eva Green as Vesper Lynd, the newest Bond girl, who James falls in love with only to have his heart torn apart, delivering him his most valuable lesson:  Trust no one.Regardless of all the skepticism and nay-saying that surrounded this relaunch of Hollywood's most enduring franchise, in the end "007: Casino Royale" had the last word, proving to audiences and critics to never underestimate the man known as "Bond, James Bond"."007: Casino Royale" is rated PG-13 for violence and sensuality.

reviewText: MOVIE: The James Bond franchise is the most successful series of films in cinema history. So, when it was announced that Barbara Broccoli and Michael G. Wilson were looking to revamp the franchise there were some areas of concern. The biggest shocker to hit the film industry was that Pierce Brosnan was out and that it was time for a new Bond. Rumors began circling like crazy. Actors like Clive Owen, Hugh Jackman, and a dozen more were rumored to be the next actor to fill the role. When Daniel Craig was announced as the official Bond a roar of opposition came from fans all over. There was even a "Craig Is Not Bond" website that started a petition to get the producers to change their minds. It was a sad and humiliating exhibition on the part of the fans, to make judgements based solely on the actor's previous works and different looks from the other Bonds. I mean honestly, who thought Tobey McGuire was going to be Spider-Man, that Christian Bale was going to be the new Batman, and a bunch of other iconic roles. The fact here is that Daniel Craig makes an excellent Bond.Casino Royale was the first book written by Ian Fleming, and it introduced the world to James Bond. After a decade of inconsistent and so-so Bond films it was decided that character needed to return to his roots, back to the basics. Bond films started to become nothing but mere parodies of themselves. Die Another Day was the biggest sign that a few changes needed to be made. The last great Bond film was GoldenEye so it was logical to call back director Martin Campbell to direct Casino Royale. Another big thing to note about this film is that Paul Haggis was brought on board to do some rewrites, to solidify the script and fully develop the characters. Past Bond films had such laughably bad dialogue that the witty puns the series made famous became poorly executed and just shameful. The plots got so over the top even for Bond films. Die Another Day featured a giant laser, an ice palace, a bi-racial bad guy, and some thug with diamonds in his face. With Casino Royale we go back to the basics of Bond yet we still retain the class and themes that make Bond what he is.The film's opening sequence is the shortest of all the films (not counting Dr. No since it did not have one). We see that James Bond has just been promoted to double-0 status, we then cut directly into the amazing main titles. Chris Cornell delivers a very Bondesque song with David Arnold arranging the classy orchestral sound mixed in with Cornell's style. The title song is called "You Know My Name", and the titles are highly stylized animatics that use the poker theme of the film. The plot is simple, a terrorist banker decides to raise money to fund a terrorist cell by winning a high stakes poker game at the Casino Royale in Montenegro. Bond is assigned to win the game thus crippling Le Chiffre and the cell. Things go wrong mostly from the mistakes that Bond makes, which is brilliant. This is Bond as a beginner, so he makes plenty of bad choices. In the first action scene, a thrilling foot chase through a construction site, we see Bond stumbling and struggling to catch up with the fugitive. The scene is absolutely amazing and is really the most amazing foot chase I have ever seen on film. Other amazing action sequences include a rundown at the Miami Airport, a staircase fight with a machete wielding crime lord, a shootout in a collapsing building, and just as tense are the poker scenes. I was reluctant of the choice to drop the game of Baccarat and replace it with Texas Hold 'Em, but it was an appropriate choice considering that times have changed. Poker definitely worked and the games are incredibly tense.Another aspect of this installment is that it is notably more violent than the other Bond films. We also see more blood than we have scene in Bond films before this. In the novel there is a really graphic torture scene and I was wondering how they were going to handle it. They toned it down, but it still will make the men in the theater cringe and thanks to Paul Haggis' touchups he inserted the film's funniest line in the torture scene, which worked perfectly. The violence adds an intensity that really elevates the film and makes it a worthy adaptation since the novel itself was really dark.While the film has its questionable changes they are all for the better. For one, Judi Dench is M even though Bernard Lee plays the role in the original films up till GoldenEye. There is also talk of "post 9/11" even though the original films stay in their time period of when they were made. If the next Bond film attempts to continue the idea of this new Bond then it will be a big mistake. The next film has to return hitting the ground running as if it were the same old Bond. Even so, this is an incredible action film and an incredible Bond film. Casino Royale is an amazing and is equal to the quality of the Connery days. It is also one of the best action films ever made in my opinion.ACTING: Daniel Craig is a brilliant Bond and that is all there is to it. The character is quiet as he comes to terms with his environment, we feel that he is out of his element and is slowly molding into the James Bond that we have come to love and know over the past 45 years. Daniel Craig molds the perfect Bond to show guts and arrogance that end up teaching him lessons about how to handle the profession. James Bond doesn't become Bond until the very end of the film and that is enhanced by David Arnold's score. He uses the theme that was established in the main title song, but not once do we hear the James Bond theme. We only hear the theme at the very end when James becomes Bond. Any doubts that Craig was a poor choice should be thrown out, and people who doubted him before with such a passion should bite their tongue and take the shame of being horribly wrong. In terms of supporting roles we have Eva Green, Madds Mikkelson as the villain, and Jeffrey Wright as Felix. Eva Green is the perfect female lead in the film, and you really can't call her a "Bond Girl". She has a presence you can respect and she is not just there as eye candy and a toy for Bond. Madds Mikkelson makes the perfect Le Chiffre, a Bond villain that of course has a some sort of physical distinction like every Bond villain should have. The roles are well written and for the first time we see some real pathos in the Bond franchise.BOTTOM LINE: Casino Royale is genuinely thrilling and works on every level, truly a Bond film that stacks up with the best in the franchise. Daniel Craig will wow you as Bond and I guarantee you'll have a blast at the movies whether you've seen every Bond film before this or you are completely new to it.
summary: Casino Royale Is Genuinely Thrilling & Works On Every Level, Truly A Bond Film That Stacks Up With The Best In The Franchise

reviewText: This is the first Bond movie since "You Only Live Twice" (the last of Connery's "good" Bond movies) that didn't bore me witless - I basically threw in the towel after that one.  The producers and writers hit on exactly the right strategy here: showing Bond on the way up, still a bit raw, and displaying an edge of savagery that gives his choice of career some context.  Craig hits the right note bang on the nose: edgy, his cocky self-assurance actually a drawback rather than an asset to his job, still learning the ropes, and complicated.  And, despite performing the usual complement of nonsensical physical feats, he manages to remain human.  The difference between Craig's Bond and Connery's Bond is that Craig is playing an extraordinary man, while Connery was playing a ridiculously unreal one.  Connery, through sheer intelligence and physical magnetism, brought the unreal man to some sort of life; Craig brings the extraordinary man to life.  The Bonds in between don't count, and that includes Pierce Brosnan.  There are no other Sean Connerys - his was a unique persona in a unique physical package.  Trying to find another one was a pointless exercise.  Craig, by contrast, is not remotely handsome, but he's very hot, a product not of the arrangement of his features but of his controlled intensity, conveyed in the first black and white fight scenes of the movie.  Although there are plenty of Pretty People onscreen, it was a relief not to be hit over the head with an endless parade of also ridiculously unreal women falling into Bond's arms like clockwork.  The plot actually held some interest on its own, and the required action scenes were - well, just as they should be.The rest of the cast is also fine, including the Danish actor Mads Mikkelson as the villain. My one complaint is that the sound was a bit problematic.  I often lost the second halves of sentences.  This was particularly true of Eva Green, who appeared to be trying to pitch her voice to a very low and throaty timbre.  The result was that half the time I couldn't understand what she was saying.  This happened with the rest of the cast, too, but more often with her.The final frames of the film were delicious, as the old (that is to say the "future") Bond theme creeps into the score - a nicely done bit of foretelling.  I found myself grinning.  A terrific film and congratulations to all hands.
summary: The Right Man at the Right Time At Last . . .

reviewText: My grandfather is a gigantic James Bond fan, he has seen every film, knows which bonds fit the bond role and which ones don't. After 20 films and forcing me to watch them all for most of the beginning of my life he thinks Daniel Craig was a good pick to carry the Bond torch. I agree with my grandfather because Craig kills this role and makes a great first impression with his first Bond film. Casino Royale, which many may already know, was the first novel of the Bond series from the 007 creator Ian Fleming. It is also the first Bond film since The Living Daylights to take its name from a Flemming Novel.The film starts with a no license Bond and it's not his driver's license. James must kill 2 people before he can receive the double-0 and a license to kill. James sets out on his first mission as a 007 after completing 2 kills, which takes him to the world's terrorist banker Le Chiffre who is a very nasty man with a scarred face that has a huge addiction to gamble. In order to stop Chiffre James must beat him in a poker game, which certainly isn't cheap to stop the terrorists network. He is given some help from who else but his first Bond girl Vesper Lynd played by Eva Green but can she give him the help he really needs to stay alive.This film is very crisp; everything is perfect from the cinematography to the writing and pacing. A problem I always had with the James Bond films was that they seemed too long with prolonged over the top action scenes. On some occasions I might have had to watch a James Bond film twice to get everything that happened. I am surely not trying to knock the series cause the films were great but they also had flaws. I don't think that Daniel Craig is the best Bond though he was good but he lucked up by getting a great writing team and director that had fresh ideas and made significant changes.Having Martin Campbell directing was a great idea because he did a great job with GoldenEye but still brought some fresh ideas to this film. The action was perfect because it was very believable and Craig did well with his choreography and stunts. I feel that the film needed to focus a little more on the hand-to-hand fighting scenes than excessive mobile chases with gadgets going crazy blowing everything to bits.On the acting side of the film I think they did a good job casting. I wasn't a real big fan of Eva Green in Kingdom of Heaven but she did an ok job in this film. This was an overall great film because it was very realistic and believable. It took the good from all of the Bond movies before it and added more good to it than bad plus Daniel Craig is a good successor to Pierce Brosnan. He has set a high bar for himself and is expected to only get better in the upcoming Bond22 set to release in 2008.
summary: Who Knew It Would Be This Good

reviewText: As I was watching "Casino Royale," I kept saying to myself "This would make an interesting James Bond film."  I say this because the film did not seem like a James Bond film.  All the normal conventions were missing: no issue of the call from M, no Q, no Miss Moneypenny.  I'm not sure how they could even call this a Bond film.I think they were self-aware of the reboot, so they overcompensated by trying to too hard to make it a Bond film--the gunbarrel, the exquisite opening credits, retro swimsuit, the two Aston Martins, one a retro-Bond, the martini joke, the tux, and the self-aware Ms. Broadchest.  However, they merely depicted the external Bond. So what we saw were merely recycled props.  This is an action spy thriller, not Sotheby's.And then there's the plot.  Plot is usually defined as a story's meaningful series of events. We got the series of events, but there was no meaning to them. It seemed like splice job of well-choreographed actions and romance scenes.  The plot twists jerked in large clumps.  But I was not sure where I was going in the film--once again, this did not follow the pattern of the first 21 Bond films.And then there were the thick accents of the two leads. They sounded very romantic, but only Rupert Giles could understand them. Furthermore, you had the odd attempts at making Bond more human, with cockiness covering self doubt with a dash of angst--is this Bond or Bourne?. And mercy! to have Bond screaming under torture! After to years with the Chinese, Bauer kept his peace.  Sigh!As a consolation prize, I have seen that they have begun to reprint Fleming's clasics--albeit with rather racy covers.  Maybe I can find some good memories in the original sources.
summary: This would make an interesting James Bond film

reviewText: As a rule I loathe many of the Bond movies because they're so cartoonish.  This one was quite different, more in line with the true character in Fleming's novels than a well-dressed clown spouting one-liners to negate the comedic violence.  I know the producers chose this direction because they wanted to distance themselves from the goofy Austin Powers films which were nothing more than a parody of earlier Bond films... which had already become parodies of themselves!God, how I hated that.You see, the James Bond novels played a very large part in my growth and desire to be a writer.  My father introduced me to them when I was twelve years old and I devoured them.  I'm very picky, therefore, about my Bond actors and the movies themselves.  This one did not disappoint me.The producers of Casino Royale also had the good sense to realize the actor playing James Bond is only as good as the villain he faces.  Le Chiffre was a sadistic bastard in the novel and he's played that way here, too.  And anyone who's ever read the novel will be gripping throughout the movie because they know what's coming later in the film. Again, Royale doesn't disappoint, nor with the love interest between Bond and Vesper, (Bond's first and really only love until me met Tracy) along with its inevitable conclusion.The novel itself is somewhat famous for its last line.  Mickey Spillane copied something like it for his Mike Hammer novel, I, the Jury.) The line appears here in the film, though not at the very end which lessens its impact.  It's still powerful, however, played against the backdrop of a crumbling building as metaphor for Bond's life.All in all, a very good film. Bond is back, thank God, in a reincarnation that would make Fleming proud.Go see it.
summary: Bond as Fleming Wrote Him - and it's about time

reviewText: admit it, this Bond franchise needed some major changes after Pierce Brosnan and Timothy Dalton, who were fine in their own right but neither really measured up to Connery or the best of Moore. Talk about changes! Whoa, you got a blonde, blue-eyed James Bond going back to his roots earning his stripes as a 007 agent. When asked if he, wants his martini shaken or stirred? Bond replys, do I look like I care! This is of course right after he loses at poker to his target but he finds a way to get back in the game and get his man. This Bond has more depth, character and is a bit more raw then any Bond you know. I loved this film, it's a love story and action film brilliantly woven together to completely update the Bond series and give it new life. There are several scenes that just stay in my head, an intoxicating foot chase, a shower scene with clothes on that show more humanity then most Bond films, and the ending where you hear that famous line as the very last line of the movie. This is brilliant movie, Daniel Craig is Oscar worthy.

reviewText: I had been wondering for years when we'd get some sort of official treatment on "Casino Royale", discounting the first two lighthearted attempts.  I actually think Daniel Craig did a fine job as Bond.  At this point in the franchise, we have come to expect roles to change every so often.  I will let the other reviews stand on their own as far as that goes.  It all goes back to the original argument that there was no other Bond after Sean Connery.  That's subjective.  I was born & raised on Roger Moore, while my parents had Sean...and we all like Pierce Brosnan, so it's up to the viewer to decide if the actor is right or wrong.  Personally, I say it's the character we're here to see.The aspect I DON'T like about this adaptation of "Casino Royale" is we are led to believe this is pre-007 Bond, but we have modern cell phones, references to 9/11 and, the most annoying part of all, the current incarnation of "M".  The filmmakers readily admit they HAD to get someone younger to play Bond as this is supposed to be the beginning of the series....BUT in the same breath say there was no one else they could see playing "M" except Judi Dench who didn't assume the role until 1995!  Come on, now.  Judi does a fine job in the role as one would expect, but I cannot get past the fact that they didn't recast for this film.  This is why I am rating it a "3" instead of a "5".  Technically, the film, discs & packagaging are what we'd expect.It seems confusing to expect us to believe this is the originial story about Bond with so many liberties taken on continuity....BUT if we didn't suspend disbelief, we wouldn't love this franchise as much as we do!  Is this 1957 or 2006?  They seem to be wanting US to decide the timeline with regards to the other films/stories.  Having said that, this is an action-packed film that stands out from the rest of the series because it focuses more on the emotional development of James Bond, not his cache of gadgets.  There is a reason that aspect of the character wasn't included & "Casino Royale" manages to become a unique addition to the series.

reviewText: Everyone is gonna love the Bond they grew up with , both literally and figuratively, for some it will always be Connery or Moore. Each have their take on the role. But, rarely to you get the cold, hard and dangerous killer from the novels. The first Connery Dr. No, has Bond with no Q or gadgets, floating naked silhouettes and less wordplay than later films that better fit what we've come to expect from a movie Bond. When these 'Trademarks' are missing some purists become disgruntled. Royale does what could have been done when Brosnan took over, start over with the original novel and the first adventure with Bond. Overdue due to rights issues, one of the best, rawest 007 tales has never been done (seriously) to date (the '67 spoof and '54 American TV movie not considered canon). What better place to invent Bond, without reinventing him at all.Daniel Craig has the rugged look of a... dare I say it... a "Connery Bond", more man than model, although he took alot of grief over his hair color. But Craig is the who can utter all the original lines, even the icy closing line of the original novel (ck it out). Dame Judi Dench is so brilliant as M I'm not bothered by the continuity problems of her becoming her own predecessor. Another notable changes to the original, is that Casino Royale's game of choice is now Texas Hold 'em instead of Baccarat, which is cool considering the book was written in '53, swapping a current game the same way that Bond movies swapped post WW II for post Cold War.The story for the uninitiated is roughly the same, a newly upgraded British intelligence operative is assigned to track a band of international terrorist. The plan is to break up the band by breaking the Banker...Le Chiffre, who compulsively gambles with the groups funds. Bond, aided by hot Treasury agent Vesper Lynd, is to play and beat him at poker, forcing him to seek goverment protection from his understandably irrate ex-clients (in exchange for their secrets).In addition to Eva Green as the first "Bond Girl", we get to see Bond's first Tux, his first Aston Martin, but probably not his first Martini.As I said this one is raw, gritty and refreshingly free of the gimmicky gadgets and supervillian plots, away from the larger than life Bond pic of the past and more firmly set in the real world than ever before (sort of).This is a solid new direction for the Bond films I can't wait for more.
Title: N/A

reviewText: It isn't a short film but it goes by like the wind, and some of the movie's speed has to be credited to Mr On Again Off Again Martin Campbell, the director who has made some of the best action flicks ever, as well as some of the worst.  He must have wanted to put his best foot forward here and show Matthew Vaughan or whoever that there's life in the old dog yet.  But this baby races.  The long card game in Montenegro, that apparently lasts nearly 24 hours (with breaks for sex and murder), is briskly staged and comes studded with its own surprises, including the "reveal" about who Jeffrey Wright is supposed to be playing!  He seemed more than ordinarily interested in Daniel Craig from the beginning, but I thought he was supposed to be an aesthetic Hilton Als type, drawn to beauty like a moth drawn towarda a flame, and then you find out---(SPOILERS ENSUE)He's Felix Leiter, Bond's soon to be BFF!  Hats off to EON for casting such a great actor in what doesn't come to much here, but if he is kept will eventually bloom into a honey of a part.  It's like having Veruschka in the casino.  They don't have to make a great deal of it, they've got so much front line talent that great faces can just appear and disappear, alluring shadows.  What Eisenstein called the Cinema of Attractions.I thought it was a little over the top when Le Chiffre tore the entire cane seat out of the chair when it was time to torture Bond's underparts.  That was a huge hole and any other man would have fallen right through.  The hole ideally should have been somewhat less than the entire breadth of the chair seat?  And when Craig is strapped into it he seems to be perched as though there were no hole at all.  That's how great his body is, I assume.OK, should the producers have hired Eva Green when they had the chance to cast Angelina Jolie as Vesper Lynd?  Maybe Jolie was asking too much.  Or maybe the idea was that, everyone would know that Vesper had a dark side if you had AJ playing the part right from the start?  Maybe that's so, but it takes a while to get used to Eva Green and when Bond orders to look luscious for the casino scene, and she comes down in Morticia Addams' old hair and makeup, I knew right away she had sabotage in mind.{SPOILERS END.)All in all, a great shakeup for a beloved series.  Too bad it had to be PG-13 contractually, an R rated CASINO ROYALE would at least have ensured that Bond and Solange would have done the deed?

reviewText: Overall a great back to basics James Bond film.  In addition to Daniel Craig taking on the role of Bond, the film greatly limits computer generated special effects and we are presented with a slightly more mean spirited and almost humorless bond.Daniel Craig is a significant change to the Bond character.  In CASINO ROYALE he is more like Charles Bronson's character in THE MECHANIC or Clint Eastwood in PALE RIDER.  Missing are the largely humerous quips and self assured posturing at casino tables.  Craig's portrayal of Bond is probably closer to Sean Connery's original Bond in DOCTOR NO.  CASINO ROYALE'S bond freely uses his semi-automatic pistol.  Previous Bonds, following FROM RUSSIA WITH LOVE, always seemed to lose their pistols at the outset of a fight.  In all honesty it will probably take two or three films to get used to Daniel Craig as Bond.Gone too are the humorous foils with no sign of John Cleese or any reincarnation of "Q."  Judi Dench returns as "M."  Dench already established her character in prior Bond films as a no-nonsense administrator.  As such, there is very little difference in Dench's portrayal of "M" in CASINO ROYALE.In ROYALE we are treated to an alterante Bond universe in that the film is about Bond's first mission, set in the current era, as a double-O agent.  As such we find an arrogant and self-confident Bond whose foibles often lead to learning curve hubris.  He is not the automatic winner-takes-all at the gaming table and allows his emotions to lead him astray on several occasions.  In fact he initially comes off as the bad boy of the double-O's.The action sequences in this movie are more akin to Bruce Willis in the DIE HARD movies, albeit with additional stamina.  Yes, there are the trade mark fast cars, beaches, millionaire resorts and casinos that most of us can only dream about.  What would Bond be without jetsetting?The movie's only drawback is that it becomes unnecessarily complicated.  When I saw the film for the first time I felt as if I needed to have a line and block diagram to tie together all of the inserted characters, relationships and locations.  At the conclusion of the picture I was not sure what victory had been won for Queen and country.  Still, this is a good outing for a re-tooled Bond.  Hopefully future films will keep to this back to basics theme and stay away from stories with ice palaces, underground megaplexes, and gray-suited masterminds who have it all, but want more.

reviewText: I like James Bond as much as the next guy. I've read a couple of Ian Fleming's novels, have seen all the films (many in the theater), and have all the box set DVDs. I don't consider myself obsessive, however, Bond to me has always been a bit of a lark--adrenaline style entertainment. From the serious Bond to the cheesy Bond, there's always some action or outrageousness to admire. So I was mystified when so many people were absolutely indignant that Daniel Craig was signed for the role. I'm not saying I supported the ouster of Brosnan, I'm just saying I was pleased that a talented actor was taking his place. And the idea of rebooting the series wasn't controversial to me, but an ingenious way to reinvigorate the franchise.Now having seen "Casino Royale," I stand firm in my opinion that Craig makes an excellent 007 (even though he's blonde and not Clive Owen). He demonstrates a real brashness as the newly promoted Bond--defiant, cocky and tough as nails. But the character has many shadings which Craig pulls off effortlessly. The flirtatious womanizer, the tender romantic, the brutal killer, and the betrayed lover are all well played and believable. He inhabits Bond with a realness, a personality--it's more than the casual quip, there's something going on in his brain. But maybe Craig's strongest asset is his physicality. Not only has he given Bond emotional resonance, but his physical presence make his action scenes and tough guy performance much more realistic.The movie's plot is somewhat superfluous to me--it's a pretty standard setup. The film kicks off with a tremendously staged chase, however. The stunts and choreography are excellent--it's exciting when necessary and amusing where appropriate. You know instantly that you're in for a thrill ride. As we settle in for the main story, Bond meets with Vesper Lynd--played by Eva Green. Green is a good match for Craig, and her character is written well--their relationship can be surprisingly sweet. The major plot point revolves around a poker game which Bond must win. Within this card game, an interesting psychological contest is developed with the villain. I liked the blend of action and cunning gameplay.The third act for me, while necessary to the development of Bond's character, did play on a little long and held no real surprises. But that said, it was particularly well acted. Overall, I found the Bond reboot amazingly successful. Craig makes Bond human again and ruthless, too. Recommended as a solid action picture, and one of the stronger entries in the series!  KGHarris, 11/06.
summary: Bond Reinvigorated With Real Ruthlessness And Genuine Romance--Craig Disproves His Harshest Critics

reviewText: It's been awhile since the last Bond film was released, and I don't think I'm alone when I say that the Pierce Brosnan Bond films were poorly written, poorly acted, and all-around poor quality. Casino Royale is changing all that and reinvigorating what had become a flagging franchise. What we need is a Bond who is ruthless. We need a Bond who bleeds. We need a Bond who spends less time looking pretty and more time taking care of business. Enter Daniel Craig. Check. Check. And Check.With the introduction of Daniel Craig as Bond, we have entered  new era in the Bond franchise. These films have finally given us something to be afraid of--terrorism--and given us a hero who will not countenance our fear--he'll do something about it. A bomb maker is a bomb maker is a bomb maker to our new Bond and, rather than look at the big picture, he'll take them out one at a time. Then we'll take care of the big picture.This movie is visually stunning, entertaining, and gives me hope for the future of the Bond franchise. Whether this is your first or your fifteenth Bond film, you'll enjoy it and all it offers.
