reviewText: I've been a Bond fan all of my life. My dad and I read the books and saw all of the Roger Moore films together. Both of us hoped that one day the rights to Casino Royale could be bought and the book brought to the big screen. When Daniel Craig got the role I was horrified. I thought he was too short, too ugly and too blonde to pull it off. Well, I am delighted to say that I was wrong. After five minutes I forgot about the hair and remembered that Ian Flemming didn't describe Bond as being a handsome man but as a rugged looking one. Daniel Craig must have studied Sean Connery because he reminded me more of Connery than any of the latter Bonds. He's not soft like Brosnan, and he's not fooling around like Moore sometimes seemed to be, and he's not clearly overwhelmed like Dalton. He is extremely physical, tough looking and has that emotional coolness that Connery showed so well.The plot is tight and remarkably faithful with a few needed updates to the original book. The gadgets are still here of course but they don't dominate the story like they did in the Brosnan years (Remember the invisible car?). The most amazing piece of equipment is 007, himself.This is young Bond's first 00 mission and he makes mistakes and isn't bothered about being subtle. His relationship with Vesper was well done and the actress playing the part looks like the character is described in the book. I'm glad the producers decided to keep the torture scene pretty much as Flemming wrote it. Later instead of taking pills and leaving a sad little note Vesper gets a much more dramatic death in the movie and when Craig says the  big line, "the b---- is dead," you can really see his heart freezing over.The audience I saw the movie with oohed, awed, laughed and cheered at all the right moments. Casino Royale  was a fan's dream come true. Congrats to Craig. He pulled it off. He IS the best Bond since Connery.

reviewText: There have been a lot of great James Bond movies over the years, but this one raises the bar to a new level.  This is not the rather campy tongue-in-cheek 007 that has too often stolen the show in the Bond franchise; this is a truly ruthless Bond that is true to creator Ian Fleming's vision of the character and the world he lives in.  Daniel Craig steps right into some of the biggest shoes in the fictional world and makes the role his own from the first dead-on shot to the last.  Craig's lean, hungry look captures the essence of Fleming's master spy perfectly.  The dark, noir-ish prologue sets a dangerous tone that holds firm throug the remainder of the film, which delivers all the intrigue, action, romance and globe-trotting excitement that Bond films are famous for but with a decidedly sharper and deadlier edge.  There is no Q-branch here, with its plethora of fantastic gadgets, and while there is humor it's understated and flows naturally from the all-too-human characters and the plot itself.  The action scenes are physical and punishing, the love scenes intense but never gratuitous, the sets true-to-life and the direction from Martin Campbell precise and dextrous.  Mads Mikkelson is a perfect Le Chiffre, possibly even more menacing than the source novel's version, and Jeffrey Wright's new interpretation of Felix Leiter rings true. But it is Eva Green's stunning portrayal of the enigmatic Vesper Lynd that is perhaps the most haunting of the whole film.  Green's Vesper is beautiful, witty, and intelligent, but unreadable and somehow tainted with a hidden wound that makes her ultimately untouchable as well.  There hasn't been a Bond girl like this since Diana Rigg's immortal turn as Tracy from ON HER MAJESTY'S SECRET SERVICE way back when.  And Craig's last line is the perfect end-note for a breathtaking thrill-ride and brilliant re-imagining of one of cinema's most enduring yet frequently mishandled characters.  No doubt many long-time fans of the movie series, ignorant of the original source novels, were a little disappointed with this return to Bond's deadlier roots, but the result is one of the three best Bond films ever.  Only DR. NO and the aforementioned ON HER MAJESTY'S SECRET SERVICE, both likewise notable for their more realistic versions of 007 and his creator's vision, are comparable in any way to the new CASINO ROYALE.  Somewhere, I think Ian Fleming is smiling.

reviewerName: Konrei "Everything I need is right here"
reviewText: This third incarnation of CASINO ROYALE (Barry Nelson in 1954, Woody Allen in 1968, and now Daniel Craig in 2006) is as close to Ian Fleming's literary James Bond as we are likely to get. CASINO ROYALE catapults the Bond franchise all the way back to the gritty realism of 1963's FROM RUSSIA WITH LOVE, almost completely excising the many sedimentary layers of spoof, goof, and woof-woof laid on by Eon Productions over the years (Daniel Craig is known as the star of the cult classic LAYER CAKE, and here's another one, but perhaps not to everybody's taste).The now-habitual Bondian overreliance on gadgets is almost all gone, but so, sadly, are Samantha Bond as Moneypenny and John Cleese as Q. Dame Judi Dench reprises M. Monty Norman's electrifying "James Bond Theme" barely makes it into the film, and the theme song is utterly unmemorable. However, on the plus side, the forced dialogue that has passed for wit since the Roger Moore days is nonexistent; true Bond style has made a thoroughgoing comeback.Unfortunately, the first third of CASINO ROYALE consists of a very predictable set-piece high explosive battle that lacks any clear connection to the rest of the story, and is hard to follow, to boot. It's nothing we haven't seen before, and Daniel Craig lacks the dark solidity of Connery or Brosnan in carrying off the du jour action sequences.Truth to be told, I turned CASINO ROYALE off at just about the point where Bond reaches Casino Royale. Fortunately, I did turn it back on. I say "fortunately" because the second and third thirds of this movie are so vastly different from its beginning that CASINO ROYALE might as well be two different pictures. It's as though Eon elected to draw in the usual methamphetamine audience to feed them the usual tripe, but then said, "Oh, the hell with it," and decided to actually make a Bond FILM for the first time since who-knows-when...Bond is sent to destroy LeChiffre, financier to the world's terrorists, who has compulsively gambled away hundreds of millions of dirty dollars, and is trying to recoup his losses at the ultra-high-stakes poker table of the fabulous Casino Royale. Most of the action takes place around the green baize table, and is undeniably tense in its understatement. Better than an atomic bomb, the real fate of the world rests on a turn of the cards. In that sense, CASINO ROYALE is a true throwback of a film, eschewing the Jerry Bruckheimer Formulary of modern filmmaking. This is a story non plus ultra.Let us introduce James Bond, a spare, angular, wiry blond man who gets battered a lot by some really nasty villains and bleeds (profusely) on his ruffled tuxedo shirts. He suffers a horrific, if prosaic torture session at the hands of his adversary, more personal than any laser beam, and far more effective. Let us introduce James Bond, a man who has just received his "00" status and still has some qualms about killing (the bizarre torquing of "James Bond Universe Time" that occurs in the series by granting Bond his Double-O circa 2006 is disconcerting, but ultimately unimportant to the franchise). Let us introduce James Bond, a "blunt instrument" who must learn to hone himself rapier sharp in order to survive, is betrayed, drinks poison, falls in love, and rejoices over "the bit**'s" death, but without the omniscience usually granted by his cinematic stewards. This Bond has character development. In other words, let us introduce Ian Fleming's Bond of the novels finally brought to life onscreen.CASINO ROYALE walks quietly and confidently away from it's first hour to deliver a nuanced and intelligent spy movie. Viewers seeking the usual shopworn Bond formula WILL be disappointed. Even on its own terms, CASINO ROYALE has weak spots (mostly in places where the producers veered from Fleming's taut storyline), and Daniel Craig (though he does turn in a fine performance) is definitely not Everybody's James Bond. Still, I have to rate his interpretation of the Bond character below Connery's, but (surprisingly enough) better than almost anybody else's. Eva Green as Vesper Lynd is exotic and unattainable.In short, CASINO ROYALE is a very creditable THREE AND A HALF STAR EFFORT that suffers from its early adolescent angst, wanting to live down to the Bond Formula, but soon, and blessedly, maturing while we look on.
summary: "Shaken or stirred? I don't give a damn."

reviewText: Casino Royale is a welcome departure from the recent Pierce Brosnan films, which became so ludicrously over-the-top that they were annoying, culminating in the ridiculous invisible car and ice castle in the Halle Barry-starring last one. Thankfully, the producers have gotten back to the basics - emphasizing realistic (comparatively) action with bits of humor rather than humor with bits of realistic action. Daniel Craig, who benefits from a great script, plays the role with a intensity, capturing Bond's character weakness - his ego - while also showing his wounded, vulnerable side. The opening sequence, featuring an athlete known for his pioneering "free running" technique in England, is among the best of the Bond series, setting just the right tone for the film. Eva Green does OK, but I think she is a terrible actress overall. I'm excited to see the next film.
summary: Daniel Craig is an amazing Bond

reviewText: "Casino Royale" is brilliant! Daniel Craig is one of the best Bonds since Sean Connery. The directing by Martin Campbell (who, ironically directed Pierce Brosnan in his first run as Bond in "Goldeneye" (1995) is excellent! The screenplay, which is based on Ian Fleming's novel, from Neal Purvis, Robert Wade (both who wrote the screenplays to Bond films such as "Die Another Day" (2002) & "The World Is Not Enough" (1999) and both are working on another Bond film starring Craig), and Paul Haggis (who won the Oscar for his work on "Crash" (2005), and he also recently did "Flags Of Our Fathers" (2006) is brilliant! The music by David Arnold (who has been doing the score to the Bond films since "Tomorrow Never Dies" (1997) is brilliant! The cinematography by Phil Meheux (who has worked with Campbell on "The Legend Of Zorro" (2005), "Beyond Borders" (2003), "The Mask Of Zorro" (1998), "Goldeneye", "No Escape" (1994), "Defenseless" (1991), & "Criminal Law" (1988) is brilliant! The film editing by Stuart Baird (who recently film edited Campbell's "The Legend Of Zorro") is excellent. The casting by Stéphane Foenkinos & Debbie McWilliams (who has done the casting for Bond films since "For Your Eyes Only" (1981) is excellent! The production design by Peter Lamont (who was nominated for an Oscar for his work as an art director on "The Spy Who Loved Me" (1977) & 20 years later, won the Oscar for his work on "Titanic" (1997), he has been working on Bond films since "Thunderball" (1965) is brilliant! The art direction by Peter Francis (who was one of the art directors on "Batman Begins" (2005), James Hambidge (who was one of the art directors on "Die Another Day"), Steven Lawrence (who was one of the art directors on "The World Is Not Enough" & "Batman Begins"), & Dominic Masters (who was also, along with Lawrence & Francis, one of the art directors on "Batman Begins") is brilliant! The set decoration by Simon Wakefield (who has worked on Bond films since "The World Is Not Enough") is brilliant! The costume design by Lindy Hemming (who is working on the upcoming "Bond 22" (2008) & "The Dark Knight" (2008), also won an Oscar for her work on "Topsy-Turvy" (1999), she has also worked on "Batman Begins", "Lara Croft Tomb Raider: The Cradle Of Life" (2003), "Die Another Day", "Harry Potter And The Chamber Of Secrets" (2002), "Lara Croft: Tomb Raider" (2001), "The World Is Not Enough", "Tomorrow Never Dies", "Blood And Wine" (1996), & "Goldeneye") is brilliant! This is the best Bond film I have seen since the days of Sean Connery and this is one of the year's best! This is an brilliant, emotionally-charged action-packed thriller that keeps you entertained and wanting more. Yes, it is overlong, but, to me, I don't really care, once you get caught up in the movie. This is an action film to see again and again, as many times as you want.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Nothing like a dozen product placements every five minutes to remind you that SONY made this film. Talk about killing any feel of reality...which is ironic, as that's what this movie was going for: more reality and less spoofing.And at that, it does pretty well. Sadly, Bond's sense of humor has been all but excised, which makes him barely Bond, in my opinion. As a fan of the books first, Connery's Bond second, and all the other Bonds way down the list, I appreciated the emphasis on less gadgets but did miss the wryness that Fleming and Terence Young brought to the character. Young defined the cinematic Bond first and best, and while this movie aims to redefine him, it barely touches the elan, wit and smoothness that made the early Bonds, and Fleming's Bond, so special.I like Craig more here than in Quantum, but I still think he lacks the dry humor and stresslessness that makes Bond. I'd take him over Moore, Dalton, etc any day, though. The balls out scene shows some humor, but is so dark as to be ridiculous. Nice try, though.And sorry, but there are so many weak Hollywood moments here. For instance, when they have the first beefcake shot of Craig as he walks out of the sea, his hair is all washed back. In the next shot, after the girl swoons at the sight of him, he is still in the same spot...but his hair is now magically and strategically plastered over his forehead. That's a bad continuity man on set, and a bad editor after, and just bad filmmaking, period. Face it, he's going bald...give him a wig a la Connery, or just let him keep his laughable Tom Sawyer haircut and be done with it.Savile Row suits at two grand a pop...and a six dollar Supercuts hairdo? Come on.It's stuff like that, and the nonstop Sony logo on every product, that makes this film cheesy after a while...plus, it's 30 minutes too long, I didn't buy the romance (Bond swooning?), and the poker scenes are horrible. Any decent poker player has to laugh at how badly set up those hands are. Last guy goes all in with a non-nut flush on a paired board where the other three players are calling the turn? Not likely he'd last that long playing that badly. Etc. Terence Young would have cut that in two seconds.But, this Bond is more about selling Sony and a sense of "reality"...and in the end, that's what makes it real enough to be boring after 90 minutes. I've seen this a few times now and each time it seems to get looonger.But hey, I'm gonna go buy something Sony. Don't know why...I just...feel like it....
summary: James Bond: brought to you by SONY!

reviewText: If there were ever any doubts as to the suitability of the selection of Daniel Craig as the new James Bond then those doubts should vanish instantly after seeing Casino Royale. I like Craig. He LOOKS like a professional assassin and plays the part to the hilt. I think that he is the best Bond since Sean Connery.I won't rehash the entire plot of the movie, it has a pretty standard theme. That is: On behalf of Her Majesty's Government, James Bond fights a shadowy organization headed by an elusive, ruthless, sinister, and enigmatic boss out to control the world.You will find Casino Royale to be action-packed and immensely satisfying. Many of the stunts are breath-taking and often performed by the actors themselves. And though the story is 50 years old, the technology is modern. No need for the futuristic gadgets of the Connery years. The future is now! And the villains are no longer the Soviets and their lackeys, but instead are international terrorists and those who bankroll them. Of course, action takes place in many exotic locales, the most picturesque of which is Montenegro. Then there are the Bond women, beautiful and sultry as ever.In addition to Craig, I also enjoyed other the other main characters especially the mysterious Solange played by Italian actress Caterina Murino. The only question I had at the end was who Mr White was and where he fit in after Le Chiffre was eliminated. That is, besides the obvious fact that he was the one who ended up with the briefcase containing Her Majesty's Government's money.The action, the quality of the filming, the stunts, and the acting itself all combine to make Casino Royale a movie I'll watch many times. The only aspect of the package that annoys me is having to skip though the previews of other movies that precede the film. That annoyance is more than mitigated, though, by the bonus disc. The stories on how the new James Bond was chosen, the stunts and how they were done, and especially the piece on Bond Girls through the years add much value and make this special-edition package a real bargain.If you are a Bond fan and haven't seen this yet, get it. Its one of the best.

reviewText: I still remember my family driving to see "Mary Poppins" in the theater, the first time we went to see a movie off base, and passing another theater where they were showing "Goldfinger."  There across the marquee was the naked and gold painted body of Shirley Eaton as Jill Masterson.  I do not remember whether it was Sean Connery or the 007 logo that provided the proper coverage at the right point because that sort of detail is not important when seeing a naked woman covered in gold paint.  "Goldfinger" was the third film in the James Bond series and an important one because it was the first in the franchise to really emphasis all of those marvelous gadgets of Q and the beginning of the tongue-in-cheek approach to the character favored by director Guy Hamilton.  I never saw "Goldfinger" in the theater and I want to say that I saw "From Russia with Love" first, but it could have been "Thunderball."  I do know that from "Thunderball" on I saw all of the Bond movies in the theater through "For Your Eyes Only," after which I just waited for them to come out on DVD.  I did that with "Casino Royale," the 21st Bond film, but on the basis of what I see here I thin I will have to see the next offering in the theater.Whether you want to call this "retooling" or "rebooting" a character, what the producers did by casting Daniel Craig as the sixth James Bond and making him grittier and more realistic was a risky proposition.  I still think of Sean Connery as THE James Bond and while I greatly preferred Pierce Brosnan's comic take on the character to that of Roger Moore, the Bond that I thought was headed in the right direction after Connery was Timothy Dalton, who had the hard edge that was missing since the original.  In retrospect you can see Brosnan as being a combination of (or compromise between) Moore and Dalton, but with Craig they are really stripping down the character.  The opportunity was provided by the producers getting the rights back to "Casino Royale," the first of the James Bond novels which had been made into a television drama on CBS in 1954 and then a comic romp anticipating Austin Powers in 1967 with David Niven and Woody Allen.  But the idea that this is the "first" James Bond movie, because this is where he gets his double-oh status.The adaptation by the team of Neal Purvis and Robert Wade ("The World is Not Enough," "Die Another Die"), and Paul Haggis ("Million Dollar Baby," "Crash"), updates the novel but keeps to the main plot.  Originally Le Chiffre (Mads Mikkelsen) was a SMERSH agent running a baccarat game at a French casino to raise the money he lost in a failed attempt to establish a chain of brothels.  Bond is assigned to beat Le Chiffre because he is an expert baccarat player so that SMERSH will kill him.  Now the game is Texas hold 'em poker (which today everybody knows, whereas baccarat still confuses me), and the money was lost in a stock manipulation scheme thwarted by Bond.  They kept Judi Dench as M, which is a no-brainer as far as I am concerned because the tension between her and Bond is even stronger this time around, but we never see Q (the comic relief of John Cleese would not fit the film's tone) and M's assistant is now male (Tobias Menzies) instead of Miss Moneypenny.  There are still the sexual innuendos, but they come across now as serious attempts at seduction rather than as lines designed to get a laugh in the theater. Like the character, these bon mots now have an edge to them (e.g., the line about not giving a damn if his martini is shaken or stirred gets a laugh when you see the trailer, but not in the context of the film itself).Supposedly the decision to have the grittier Bond came before the casting of Craig, whose work in "Road to Perdition" and "Munich" made it clear he could do it (check out his work in "Infamous" as well).  This "Casino Royale" is an action film and this Bond does not waste a lot of time talking (the eyes have it), although the largest segment of the movie is spent playing high stakes poker.  That is sandwiched between the two key action sequences, which are the "free running" chase through a construction sight in the first act that ends up as a gun fight in a foreign embassy, and the big fight in a rapidly sinking building in Venice.  In between there is a nice minimalist knife fight, the attempt to stop a bomber and what is apparently a world record for clipping a car.I had to stop and think about what the action sequences were, because it is the fireworks between Bond and Vesper Lynd (Eva Green), the HM Treasury agent who is financing his seat at the poker table, that are most memorable (even if it takes an hour for her to show up).  When they first meet and she deflects his verbal sparring, he looks her up and down and reads her like a book.  But the fun part is when she does the same to him.  The idea is not so much to come up with the ideal woman for James Bond or for him to finally meet his match as it were, but rather to explain (if not justify) the character's infamous treatment of women.  I was pretty sure I knew where this relationship was headed, but they did go one twist father than I anticipated, which was a nice touch and another way in which this film succeeded in exceeding my heighten expectations.  I especially liked the torture scene because it played to my belief that if the torturer does not break you then they are the one that will end up dead for failing to break you.The extras are decent enough, although I was sort of expecting more given they are all on the second disc in the set.  "Becoming Bond" goes through the story of how Craig go the role, although after seeing the film you have to laugh at those who scoffed at his choice.  "James Bond: For Real" looks at decision to do all of the stunts "for real" as opposed to relying on super toys and computers.  Then there is "Bond Girls Are Forever: A Closer Look at Bond's Leading Ladies," hosted by Maryam d'Abo ("The Living Daylights"), which talks to most of the them and reminds us why Ursula Andress and Honor Blackman are still at the top of the list (bonus points for considering Dame Judi a Bond Girl too).
summary: Meet the new Bond.  Better than the old Bond.

reviewText: Very gritty and exciting, this is the best Bond since Sean Connery's Bond films. Unlike recent films in the series, "Casino Royale" bears some faint resemblance to the Ian Fleming book of the same name, and the characters are recognizable from the book as well. Highly recommended for fans of the book and of the film series.

reviewText: At a time when Pierce Brosnan's films had grossed well over 1 billion dollars it would have been very easy for Michael Wilson and Barbara Broccoli to just keep doing the same thing.  Fortunately, they didn't and the result is the best 007 film since the early Connery entries. Craig fits the part like a glove and Martin Campbell keeps everything moving at a pretty good clip.  Some have complained about the casino card game going on too long but I disagree.  Keeping the "ball-beater" scene from the book (though modified -- in the book LeChifre uses a carpet beater) gives it a kind of realism even the Sean Connery films never had.  Cubby Broccoli would not have made this film.  It's to the credit of his daughter and step-son that they DID. People who talk about how buff Craig was, take a good look at Connery as well without his shirt in Dr. No.  Personally, having made a start from scratch it wouldn't hurt to redo a couple of the older titles with Craig: THE MAN WITH THE GOLDEN GUN (Bond brainwashed to asassinate "M" and his final battle with the world's deadliest killer Pistols Scaramanga) & ON HER MAJESTY'S SECRET SERVICE.  That would be killer.  Won't happen but nice to imagine.  It wouldn't be too bad an idea to adapt Kingsley Amis' Bond novel COLONEL SUN.

reviewText: James Bond 007, really, are you serious ?Where are all the gadgets, Q, the Aston Martin WITH all kind of funny buttons, don't touch anything please !The only one is the heart attack thing in the glove box, really, yep that's it. reviewText: This is the 195th review of the "Widescreen Two-Disc Special Edition (2006)" of "Casino Royale."  I have just looked over the previous 194 reviews.  The great majority of them praise this movie to the skies.  Most adhere to one form or another of the "Best Since Connery" mantra.  Some wild-eyed radicals are even breaking through all the barricades to proclaim Daniel Craig the best Bond ever.I would guess that 180 or more reviewers approach this latest Bond feature entirely as a film in a series of films.  The underlying basis of their criticism, whether favorable to or revolted by the current "Casino Royale," rests on the joint creation of producer Albert R. (Cubby) Broccoli, directors such as Terrence Young and Guy Hamilton, and, of course, Sean Connery.  To these people, the long-ago contributions of an obscure individual named Fleming hover somewhere between invisible and irrelevant.The tiny remainder of reviewers trot out the memory of Fleming, but mostly to declare that "Casino Royale" is a faithful reproduction of his novel of the same name.  By "faithful," it is evident they mean on the one hand that the plot of the movie is  roughly congruent to that of the book and, on the other hand, they mean the new Bond is not decked out with all manner of gaudy, deadly toys, fripperies and gimcracks.  Only Mr. William R. Hancock, about a hundred reviews back, and one annotator amid the comments even further away, offer convincing evidence that they have read more than a couple of pages of Fleming's writings in all their lives.This new Bond, Daniel Craig, is very much a Bond for the Twenty-first Century.  He is the man of the people that many men of the people like to imagine themselves to be--one many women of the people would simply like to like: straightforward, tough, competent ... hard in any of several senses: a demotic Bond.Fleming's Bond was different.  Fleming's operative was no man of the Twenty-first Century, and barely one of the Twentieth.  His Bond was partly Sidney Reilly, who operated against the Germany of the Kaiser and the Russia of the Bolsheviks.  The greater part of Bond, though, was a romanticized, idealized ... Ian Fleming.Fleming was educated at Eton, Sandhurst, Munich University and the University of Geneva.  In 1939 he was recruited by the Director of Intelligence for the Royal Navy.  By the end of the war, he had risen to the rank of commander.  In 1941, American General William Donovan asked him to write a memo detailing the operations of an intelligence and operations service.  Parts of that memo were incorporated into the Charter of the OSS.  Fleming enjoyed telling an anecdote in which he stumbled upon an Axis paymaster gambling in some neutral location.  It had struck him that it would be a very useful thing to bankrupt the man at the tables, thus opening him up to control by British intelligence.  Even more,  he enjoyed admitting that he had gone broke in just three hands while trying to carry out his hare-brained scheme.After the war, he took up the time-honored profession of washed up, highly educated, gentleman spies.  He wrote potboilers for money.  He remembered the name of a fellow member of his London club, one Blofeld, just as he remembered that Axis paymaster at the gambling table.In his first novel, "Casino Royale," Fleming created an operative who held the rank of commander in the Royal Navy.  Commander Bond was a member of an exclusive London gentleman's club.  During the war years, while he had been busy assassinating Axis agents in New York and other exotic locales, he had stored away his beloved Bentley, which he now drove at excessive speed over English roads.  He was a gentleman, defined in his mind as a man who never harms anyone--unintentionally.  Commander Bond, like Fleming, was a frightful snob.  He had very specific, even finicky ideas on proper behavior, gamesmanship (not always legal ones), brand named merchandise, and the correct mixing of drinks.Now, compare Fleming's Bond with the Craig's demotic model.  That Bond's no commander in any man's navy.  If he has a military background, it's as an "other ranks" SAS man.  That Bond in a London club?  As a dishwasher, perhaps.  That Bond, a graduate of Eton, polished in foreign universities?  Hardly--a year at a red brick school, maybe, and a desultory go with the Open University, at most.Take the dinner jacket that Bond wears in the big gambling scene.  It's brand new and fits him perfectly.  Fleming, like his friend Noel Coward,  really wore the things on a regular basis.  They wore cuts slightly out of fashion and slightly but exquisitely baggy and threadbare.  They owned the things, you see, and took pains to preserve them, so as not to be taken for freshly-tailored, nouveau riche bounders.  Craig could pass for the bouncer at a slightly seedy gambling den."Casino Royale" is actually a pretty good movie.  It is true not so much to the book, but to the  500-word summary undoubtedly given to writers who had evidently never heard of it or read it.  The movie is noticeably less faithful to Fleming's written words than "Dr. No" and  "Goldfinger" but still more so than most of the films in the Bond series.  (Montenegro, Monte Carlo, who knows?  Who cares?  Baccarat, what's that?)  For all that, however, the heart and soul of this movie is not Fleming's novel but the recent success of "Batman Begins."  And at the climactic moment, Craig should not announce that he is "Bond ... James Bond," but, "Bourne ... James Bourne."DVD STUFF:I have noticed that people look askance at Amazon reviews that deal with the movies rather than their DVD releases.  Keeping that firmly in mind, I confidently report that "Casino Royale - Widescreen Two-Disc Special Edition (2006)" comes on a couple of pieces of plastic.  In a comment attached to the very first Amazon review of "Casino Royale," Mr. Todd Bradley reported what his coworker had told him that morning in the lunch room: "He said the special features are worthless crap."  Who am I to disagree with Mr. Browning's coworker--in the lunchroom or out of it?
Title: N/A

reviewText: "Casino Royale" is a good film.  The two DVD set is an excellent one.  I enjoyed learning about how Fleming's book had been tangled in legalities and was unable to be made until now.  I also enjoyed the clips of watching interviews with many of the women including Halle Berry and Maude Adams who have been "Bond girls."  "Casino Royale" was even nominated as Best Picture by Oklahoma Film Critics Circle Awards.  Five won Best Sound from the British Academy Awards for the film.Daniel Craig came onto my radar screen inLayer Cake (Widescreen Special Edition)as well as a smaller role inThe Jacket.  He played a doctor with Nicole Kidman in "The Invasion" and will star again with her in "The Golden Compass."  As James Bond, he brings an intelligence and intensity to the character.  The scene where he drinks a poison and must run to the car and avoid cardiac arrest was intense and gave a sense of reality, even to this Bond movie.  I felt like Craig's Bond established a relationship with Vesper that made the film's conclusion memorable.  The British Academy Awards honored Craig with a Best Actor nomination for this film.Eva Green who was in "The Kingdom of Heaven" and with Craig in "The Golden Compass" plays Vesper Lynd, a treasury official trying to manage the government's investment in the high stakes poker match.  She won the Orange Rising Star Award in 2006 from the British Academy Awards.  She passes well as the highly intelligent woman.  The plot does have her move into the damsel in distress role during several hacking scenes in the hotel.As the DVD explains, the scenes set in Madagascar were actually shot in the Bahamas.  Sebastien Foucan whose exploits as a free runner bounding over British rooftops plays Mollaka who initiates one of the first chases complete with sky high footraces on a construction crane.  Simon Abkarian plays the Bahamian poor loser Dimitrios who lasts all the way to Miami.  His girlfriend Solange is played well by Italian beauty Caterina Murino.  Mads Mikkelsen who was inKing Arthur - The Director's Cut (Widescreen Edition)plays the chief villain LeChiffre.  His cold ruthless calculation and the blood that drips from his eye make him a chilling villain.  The torture scene where a naked Bond is flogged by LeChiffre was extremely intense and well played by Craig.Judi Dench with her six Oscar nominations and her trophy as Best Supporting Actress from "Shakespeare in Love" in 1998 plays M with an intelligence and intensity that fits Craig well.  Giancarlo Giannini who was nominated for an Oscar back in 1977 for "Pasqualino Settebellezze" plays the double-dealing ally Mathis.  Jeffrey Wright who won both an Emmy and Golden Globe for "Angels in America" in 2003 plays the American CIA agent who is not so good at poker and stakes Bond when Vesper shies away.  Steven Obanno is a rebel leader who follows LeChiffre to the hotel.  He is played with an edgy performance by Ivory Coast actor Isaach De Bankole."Casino Royale" is an excellent Bond for the new century.  It's not as gadget happy and stands on its own as a strong spy film.  Along with the bonus DVD, this is an excellent package.  Enjoy!

reviewText: Casino Royale was quite a disappointment considering the long tradition of excellent Bond movies.The acting is pretty good (but nothing great), the plot is below average, while the dialogues/lines are way beyond "below average," and then there's the great locations/scenery...Daniel Craig disappoints in his role as 007; he is rough around the edges and is lacking that something the others had.  Sean Connery was suave, he was, *is*, James Bond.  Roger Moore was a gentleman with an amazing humor, while Pierce Brosnan was one handsome guy who carried himself well, and even Timothy Dalton had something about him that gave him dignity.  Daniel Craig has not shown any of those qualities.  There is nothing about him that screams "for Queen and country!"In addition, Eva Green, who was great in Kingdom of Heaven, is given weak lines and a bad role.  A shame, really...The dialogues-oh my- the dialogues are beyond words...M is simply pathetic; a highly hysterical and annoying elderly woman.Q is nowhere to be seen.Finally, the amount of brutality is unprecedented for a Bond film.  Kill away and smack around as much as your heart desires, but do not include the extreme type of torture scenes that this movie had.The positive aspect of the "movie" is the setting/location, with the scenery being great!So it's a weak plot, a great setting and a relatively good cast, which when put together fail to take off.

reviewText: Casino Royale (Two-Disc Widescreen Edition), I never had watched James Bond, until I meet my boyfriend he is a big fan of James Bond and has all of the movies , We also have the book Casino Royale Bond on Set [Hardcover] official movie tie-in. So we went to see this in the theater, and I was hooked right from the start, it is a great movie full of action, it keeps you locked in right from the start to the great ending, we couldn't wait to get this on dvd and add it to our collection , it is one movie you can watch over and over again never get tired of.The soundtrack is also great.Product DescriptionCasino Royale introduces James Bond before he holds his license to kill. But Bond is no less dangerous, and with two professional assassinations in quick succession, he is elevated to "00" status. "M" (Judi Dench), head of the British Secret Service, sends the newly-promoted 007 on his first mission that takes him to Madagascar, the Bahamas and eventually leads him to Montenegro to face Le Chiffre, a ruthless financier under threat from his terrorist clientele, who is attempting to restore his funds in a high-stakes poker game at the Casino Royale. "M" places Bond under the watchful eye of the Treasury official Vesper Lynd. At first skeptical of what value Vesper can provide, Bond's interest in her deepens as they brave danger together. Le Chiffre's cunning and cruelty come to bear on them both in a way Bond could never imagine, and he learns his most important lesson: Trust no one.Special FeaturesBecoming Bond: An intimate look at how Daniel Craig stepped into the role of the 6th James Bond.James Bond: For Real: Inside look at action and stunts of filmBond Girls Are Forever: Closer Look at Bond's Leading LadiesChris Cornell's Music Video, "You Know My Name"Product DetailsActors: Daniel Craig, Eva Green, Mads Mikkelsen, Judi Dench, Jeffrey WrightDirectors: Martin CampbellFormat: AC-3, Closed-captioned, Color, Dolby, Dubbed, Subtitled, Widescreen, NTSCLanguage: English (Dolby Digital 5.1), French (Dolby Digital 2.0)Subtitles: English, SpanishAspect Ratio: 2.40:1Number of discs: 2Rated: PG-13 (Parental Guidance Suggested)Studio: Sony Pictures Home EntertainmentDVD Release Date: March 13, 2007Run Time: 144 minutesCasino Royale (2-Disc Widescreen Edition)Casino Royale Bond on SetCasino Royale: Music From The Original Motion Picture Soundtrack

reviewText: I thought this film was a total disaster.  It contains none of the features that made the old James Bond films fun to watch.  No humour, no memorable supporting characters, no witty repartee, no exciting, wacky chases,no innuendos, no fiendishly elaborate but ineffectual attempts to dispose of Bond, nothing to delight the viewer. A distinct shortage of beautiful women for my husband to ogle (he was very discontented). And as for Bond himself, this one is entirely lacking in charm, character, and charisma.  I will say nothing about the plot, as I found it completely incomprehensible from beginning to end.I have always been a fan of the Roger Moore films myself, but this one made even Pierce Brosnan look good.

reviewText: This will be a movie that will either be disliked by James Bond fans or enjoyed by them. I enjoyed the movie, a different take on how Bond will be protrayed will always be welcome compared to the old formula that do get bit old. Daniel Craig proves to be a strange actor to played James Bond but if you are going to reboot the entire series, you might as well take a totally different formula, you might as well start with a totally different Bond. Blond, stocky and rugged looking, Daniel Craig will never passed for Connery, Moore or Bronson. He won't have the toys they had and he won't have the villians as well. Maybe Bond needed to be brought back to earth as Casino Royale have done. Maybe Bond needs to go after common bad guys like terrorists, mass murderers and others instead of folks seeking world control.I thought  Casino Royale was well made Bond film that cut down the high tech toys and worked on the story that appears to fit more closely to what Bond should be doing. While he may not be savig the world one more time, he does what secret service agents should be doing, going after bad guys that threatened safety and security of his nation.The DVD of Casino Royale turned out to be quite a treat. I am writing the review for the two disc special. I can say that the image from the DVD proves to be totally pristine and colors were vivid and clear. The sound proves to be aggressive, clear and well spread. There are a lot of extras attached to this set, most of it lies in the second disc and there are enough to entertained, educated and pondered for most folks who buy this DVD set.The movie will divide the Bond fans but in the end, it all matter of subjective taste. If you cannot adjust and adapt from the old Bond, this movie will not be for you. However, if you enjoyed the old but welcome the new, you will enjoy this movie.

reviewText: Bond's latest adventure begins, after a quick bathroom killing, with an unreal and elongated chase high among the beams in an African construction site. Acrophobics may be thrilled, but the unreality is overwhelming for most.Eventually the plot ends up in a enormously high-stakes card game as the villains attempt to regain the funds they lost shorting the market before Bond ruined their scheme. So its Bond behind cards, making high bets and relying on "tells," instead of flirting with Ms. Moneypenny and using the latest high-tech from Q Department to evade capture.Eventually his latest love turns out to be a "turncoat" and dies, and Bond finds himself on the beach in an attempt by the producers to set the stage for the next adventure.Bottom-Line: Confused and boring.

reviewText: It makes me sick to read the negative reviews stating Craig isn't Bond or that any true Bond fan wouldn't like this film because it's different from the rest of them. B.S. Everytime the actor changes Bond is different and not just in how the actor portrays the role. Lazanby was nothing like Connery. His Bond was very drab and laid back, lacking the intensity Connery had. Moore was more witty, sometimes to the point it could be more properly referred to as half-wit. He brought silliness to the Bond franchise that wasn't there before and hasn't been there since. Timothy Dalton was a major change of direction. His Bond was hard edged, much like craig is now, and ruthless. Consequently people that had been used to Moore's portrayal hated Dalton, many still do. Brosnan was like none of them and like all of them at the same time. He tried to hard sometimes to do it all and not be his own Bond at times. Craig is not as sophisticated as Bond of yore. But than again that's the point. this movie is about how he got to the point of sophistication he's at in the other films. To those who can't see beyond what's on screen the next Bond will help build that arch a little more. It's due November of '08.Every time a new actor took over this role a whole slew of people complain about the new actor not being Bond. Some people just can't get over change. I became a Bond fan when I saw GoldenEye. I had to go back and see the earlier films after seeing the Brosnan Bond. I saw Moonraker next and if any Bond film should be dissed on that one should. The sheer differences between those films didn't disuade me from viewing any other Moore Bond films nor of looking into Connery, Lazenby, and Dalton. I've enjoyed them all, some more than others (i.e. Moonraker) and I expect to continue enjoying these films no matter how much Craig is different from Brosnan.P.S. Anyone who writes that the movie is boring because it's not wall to wall action and explosions probably has ADD. Those scenes are not boring. At the most they are deliberately paced to establish suspense and intrigue. It's refreshing to see Bond have to figure things out instead of having things just fall into place right in front of him.
summary: The great change, Connery to Moore and so forth...

reviewText: Casino Royale is the Twenty-first James Bond film since Eon released Dr. No all the way back in 1962. In over forty years, the character has been played by just over five actors, including Sean Connery, George Lazenby, Roger Moore, Timothy Dalton, and most recently Pierce Brosnan. Each actor brought their abilities into the role and embodied Bond in a different fashion (for better or worse), but for Casino Royale, Brosnan has been replaced instead by Daniel Craig, who has appeared in action films such as Tomb Raider and dramas such as Road to Peredition. He is a younger Bond with a fiercer look, but a more vulnerable interior... and thankfully, that is precisely what is needed for the film.Rather than continuing on from previous films in the franchise, Casino Royale opts to reboot the series and bring Bond back to the beginning of his career... to the very moment he becomes Agent 007. With two assassinations in quick succession, Bond comes charging into the world, exercising his newfound license to kill with a raw, murderous candor... but hidden beneath the apathy is a small trace of humanity that has yet to die out. By the end of the film, that will change--he will be changed--and whatever remnants of his soul are left will perish.But before James Bond can truly become 007, he must first travel to Montenegro, Italy to take part in a high-stakes poker game hosted by the criminal financier Le Chiffre. His mission? To ensure Le Chiffre loses his money--to make him so desperate that he will sell out his clients to MI6 and shed light on a clandestine organization that poses a significant threat to Queen and empire.It is a dangerous game, since Le Chiffre is fully aware of who Bond is and why he is there (making Bond's usual stupidity of revealing his name to villains part of the plot), and the man tolerates him out of desperate straits and impending need to accept MI6's protection. The cards are dealt, the players stare each other down, and the game begins--but Bond soon realizes that Le Chiffre knows too much of his plays... someone is feeding him information, but the traitor lies just out of reach....M is once more played by Judi Dench (who took the role in Goldeneye), but new characters also appear, most notably Eva Green as Vesper Lynd and Giancarlo Giannini as Rene Mathis. Mathis is French Secret Service, but Vesper is merely a desk agent representing Her Majesty's Treasury... and despite her snark and spunk, is wholly unfamiliar with the brand of deadly field wet-work that Bond represents. In spite of the armor that he has built over himself, Bond is intrigued by her... he begins to lose himself in her (take the entendre as you will). This is the first time we have seen a woman in his life that means more to him than a fling or a cover. Bond is maturing--the advent of actual substance into "Bond Girls" has been long in the coming.Also matured is the plot in general--for the first time, characters and motivations actually make sense... you may have to dig for the connections, and some plot holes still linger, but at least these discrepancies are not as ostentatious as previous films. In recent years, the Jason Bourne movies have created different expectations in the spy genre--the romantic fallacy of the spy has worn away, and the relevancy of James Bond along with it. Thankfully, Casino Royale has learned from this development rather than simply ignore the shift in audience expectations.Bond is still a womanizer, but this time it is less a character flaw that impedes his mission, and more of a sharpened skill that he uses to get what he needs--Bond's sex appeal has been weaponized. Why torture and interrogate a man for information when you can seduce his wife and get the same info over pleasure?James Bond is no longer a hero--he never was, but this is the first time that the series has openly acknowledged and addressed what he really is: the Queen's hired gun. He is an assassin--a bully of Western imperialism sent out to police the world... and those he cannot coerce, he merely kills. There is no romance in that... and so, Casino Royale becomes self-aware, telling the story of a man losing his soul to a career that is (dare we say) almost inherently evil. Just because 007 has a license from the crown to kill people and get away with it doesn't erase its damning effects on his own humanity.Casino Royale breaks Bond down and reveals him--it doesn't celebrate in stylized murder and bloodshed like the comically superficial films of yore. Casino Royale isn't dumb, and it doesn't insult your intelligence by glorifying a film about a career-killer. For good or bad, the overplayed antics of Roger Moore are long over--this isn't a brainless action film anymore. The 21st Bond movie injects thematic depth into a formula series that has suffered too long under shallow pageantry.In short, Casino Royale is more than just a Bond film--it is a genuinely good movie. Pop culture has found substance without losing any of its "pop". Rather than James Bond portrayed as a distant, alienating figure--almost Homeric in his senseless elevation--Casino Royale brings him up close under the microscope and reveals who he really is. It is a character study with bouts of action and explosions lining the periphery. This is still a genre film, and it will never really be a piece of "high art" (no one wants that anyway)... but this film does give James Bond the depth and roundness that he has always deserved.
summary: The tale of Bond's origins... and of his soul... is finally told

reviewText: This was my favorite Bond film yet.  It was thrilling yet believable in the action scenes.  Daniel Craig pushes through with brute force and a grit that many past Bonds have lacked.  He can also play the debonair and smitten with equal verisimilitude.The script was well written with good dialogue.  Being a Bond movie, of course the bad guy has his distinctive idiosyncrasy, and there is the requisite femme fatale, but how could it not?All in all, this movie was a fun flick for times when you want some light entertainment watching gorgeous people and in exotic places crushing the bad guys with fists and intellect.

reviewText: Huge fan of James Bond movies, including weaker ones (like "On Her Majesty's Secret Service", Tomorrow never dies" or "Die another day"), I was from the beginning sceptical about the choice of Daniel Craig for this role - and once I finally forced myself to watch "Casino Royale" my worst fears were confirmed.I refuse to consider this film as part of James Bond franchise. For me it is a very average, although still watchable, action movie, but nothing more. It actually gets a little bit boring here and there and some fast forwarding was necessary, because this thing is LONG.The opening action scene is possibly the best thing in the film and the main villain, Le Chiffre, has a couple of good moments - but he cannot even stand next to most of previous James Bond enemies... The second action scene (on the airport) was not bad either - but that was the last really good moment in this film, even if M also had a couple of good lines.I found Eva Green pathetic as main James Bond girl and her character was half woden and half annoying. Also 007 fell in love only once before and it was with a girl played by Diana Rigg - and Eva Green is not even remotely as beautiful and neither does she have any charm or talent. The character of Felix Leiter is also pale.Towards the end I really wanted this film to end already, so I can start forgetting most of it. Three stars mostly for two good action scenes and also because the next two films were even less satisfying.I really hope we will finally get again a real 007 film, with a REAL James Bond (and not some street thug), really outlandish villains, hilarious gadgets, funny dialogs and especially really sexy James Bond girls (who will whisper "Oh, James" in critical moments)... For Queen and the country!
summary: A watchable action movie - but it is NOT James Bond

reviewText: This isn't just a great Bond movie, it's a great action movie. Period. Of course, great action movies need great leads, and Daniel Craig is just that. Despite playing a really, really tough guy, his performance is nuanced, even subtle at times. This Bond is a real guy, folks. A tough as nails, adrenaline charged tough guy of the sort we've probably met in lesser incarnations. If he needs to kill you, he will, and he's pretty good about rationalizing the whole business. Hey, it's a tough world, after all, and he's willing get his [...] ruptured to protect good people from bad guys that would like nothing more than to kill each and everyone one of us. We need this James Bond.Okay, the plot, at times, seems a bit Byzantine, but that's a good chunk of the pleasure. In addition, the story, the motivations, and the relationships are spot on, and the underlying premise plays out as completely convincing. The film is all about finding a way to make a mastermind terror financier talk. How better to do that than arrange for a way to put him on the short list of the devils he finances. That his own weaknesses are part of the set-up is all the more satisfying.Oh, and you want a bond girl? One that can actually act? One that isn't a cookie-cutter? One that you actually start caring about?  That's here, too.Eva Green is stunningly beautiful because of who she is, not how she looks in a low cut cocktail dress. Nice dress, though.I'd always suspected that Pierce Brosnan was behind those web sites that tried to derail this movie and Daniel Craig's turn as Bond. He had good reason to be worried.Pierce who?

reviewText: I had never heard of Daniel Craig when I first heard that he was to play Bond. But when I saw his picture in the paper, I was devestated. He was blonde. Blonde Bond? I wasn't buying it.I went into the movie holding my breath. I didn't know what to expect. I was pleasantly surprised to witness a tightly paced, action-packed Bond flick with- gasp -a very fine performance by Daniel Craig. The blonde hair was not an issue at all. In fact, looking back, I feel pretty foolish for thinking it would.Though some of the poker got old, I guess they had to have it in there in a movie called "Casino Royale". Though I was laughing to myself as they bet millions of dollars like it was nothing. But wait- Why were they playing Texas Hold 'Em? They're betting millions of dollars in a game of Texas Hold 'Em?!? Preposterous.Also, some of the sappy parts toward the end were just awful: "I have no armor left..." GAG!!! Oh well, even in those sequences Craig seemed to be giving it his all. And wow! He is ripped!!! He must have been training for this movie, because he was a beast! All in all, it was quite a good movie. I would recommend it. And I look forward to Daniel Craig in the James Bond movies to come.

reviewText: Daniel Craig has done a superb job of brining Ian Fleming's James Bond to life. This has more of the feel of the book than previous Bond films. Dame Judi Dench has been brought back as M to reprise her role, even though this is before her characters time. Who needs continuity when she plays the part so well? And she is a perfect counter balance to the new Bond. I had stopped watching Bond films once I saw the direction they were taking when Sean Connery. For having read all the books, I was always disappointed. But I decided to watch this new release. I enjoyed this film so much that I am actually looking forward to the next. And I do hope the go sequentially through the series and remake the old movies in the same mode as this one. A spy that actually has to work and gets hurt, like the books.In Casino Royale 007 mission takes him from Madagascar, Montenegro, London, the Bahamas, Miami and finally Venice. The scenery is great and so is the action. You can feel the energy from the action scenes as they take place. We follow Bond as he learns to become a 007 and still keeps his renegade ways. Don't worry there are still Bond girls in the film. Eva Green plays the Sexy Vesper Lynd and has Bonds attention. I was very pleased to see the iconic Astin-Martin in the film; and the new one was rather nice as well. And of course we have our villain Mads Mikkelsen as Le Chiffre, who weeps blood when under stress. From its violence to romance this is the Bond film that will bring back the franchise. A must see.

reviewText: This film is so weak and boring in so many ways, that it's a waste of time bothering to write a review. The only reason I am doing this is to prevent readers from investing in something based on the hype surrounding this film, and its bland leading man Daniel Craig.Now, I am sure Daniel Craig is a nice enough man, but he is woefully miscast in the role of Bond. He brings literally nothing to the role, and all his limpid blue eye-action cannot save this from the train wreck it actually is. Not that he is a bad-looking person, but this is one actor who has virtually no charisma and has very wooden body language, so much so that even during his so called erotic scenes, he seems bored and disinterested, more keen on forcing the camera to love him. No Daniel, this just does not work. This is by far the worst Bond ever, especially since Pierce Brosnan set such a high standard for anyone to live up to.I must say that Eva Green (the royal from "Kingdom of Heaven") is a sure find. She is beautiful in that most obscure way (such as Claire Forlani in "Meet Joe Black") that its impossible to hate her. In fact, if they had made a whole film about her instead, maybe this wouldn't have been such a terrible film. She isn't a talented actress per se, but is absolutely perfect as a Bond girl.Which brings us to the storyline, or lack of one. Of all the remakes, this is the worst, primarily due to Craig's constant expression of ongoing indigestion, coupled with a very weak backing cast. Judi Dench's allure and charisma are all flushed down the toilet, as she is portrayed her as an insecure and rather matronly mother-figure, with some of the worst one-liners. Should be seen to be believed. I cannot believe they reduced this amazing character to the bowl of mush we see before us today.Maybe its because I'm a guy, but I do not find Daniel Craig capable of acting to save his life, and the people I saw this with were as puzzled as I was. Why did they choose this obviously untalented abomination to play Bond? One will never know. All I can say is, if you're planning on buying this on DVD, please hold off of it. Don't even rent it, its that bad.A slow, tedious film, with no worth whatsoever. One star for Eva Green, and that's one star too many.
summary: The Weakest Bond film of All Time

reviewText: i think b/c we like the iconic Bond so much and it is so iconic, that even a mediocore Bond movie will be good. in other words, a Bond movie is never "bad." there's always something to outweigh something else. either the actor playing Bond is good, or the women are hot, or the action is good...but i'm not calling Casino Royale mediocre. it is good, but not great. i think all the acting is up to par, and there's good dialogue, yet positively, there's not too much dialogue, which makes movies boring. the dialogue is quick, sage, and has depth and meaning. it is concise. it isn't cheesy. yet i think the downfall is the script isn't up to par. it wasn't the actors fault. it's difficult to explain, but the story line wasn't engaging enough. but there's a lot of action. a lot of good action. that's where i give them an A. the 2nd opening scene has Daniel Craig chasing this guy with a backpack. they end up on those high beams in construction sites. whoa, those were some good stunts. it had me on the edge of my seat. and speaking of Mr. Craig, he gets an A+. and i'm not only talking about his rugged good looks, sexy voice, piercing diamond blue eyes, and sexy, manly body (damn he is HOTT!). i think his acting is A. this is Bond on his first assignment. Bond when he was just beginning. and like everyone else in an infantile stage, one is green, immature, believe you're invincible, and have a huge ego. that's exactly how Bond is in this movie, and i think Craig embodies those characteristics greatly. he effectively portrays Bond as naive, sensitive, but tough and cool. Craig has a good swagger for this "Pre-Bond." this is a different type of Bond and it was refreshing to see a different side. but Bond will transform into the ultra-cool, aloof, womanizing, confident, unflinching type, and Craig, after haven been betrayed by the woman he's madly in love with (eva green), and yet to discover that her betrayal was to save his life, shows the transition in just one scene, the ending scene. he is now the Bond we all know and love. he is now rough and tough, and wiser, and essentially will not get emotional in any aspect of his work. he almost has no feelings anymore. and mainly he will now regard women as just a hit and run.lol....the one big and very few peeve i had with the film, was Eva Green as the Bond girl. i think she was terribly miscast. it is only my opinion but i don't see much sexuality in her. she is very thin and i don't think she's sexy. i don't want to sound mean, but i'm just stating what i felt, and that is, her face is not that pretty or compelling either. she is very bland. i think ms. green would be excellent in a dramatic movie, and probably look great in it too. but she is not supposed to be in a Bond movie. it's like she's out of place. she doesn't look like an "action" girl. more like period movies. she would be great in them. Bond women are always, sexy, and curvy, and have this certain spark, and i just felt that ms. green did not possess that spark. i mainly look forward to seeing the Bond girl, and i felt very dissapointed watching her. the mistress of the villain should have been the Bond girl. you don't have to be terribly beautiful, but at least sexy and have a spark and she had it more... all in all i recommend this movie. come on, you can't miss a Bond movie!

reviewText: Meet the newest double 0 agent.  British intelligence agency MI6 assigns this designation to their premier agents who have made two kills in the line of duty.  And James Bond (Daniel Craig) has just made that designation.His first assignment is to find a bomb maker and use him to track the terrorists ultimately responsible.  While he wants the man alive, the situation turns deadly, and Bond is lucky to get out with his life.  He does manage to get one clue, the word "Ellipse" and the phone number the text message came from.  The trail leads him first to the Bahamas, then Miami.Behind the scenes is Le Chiffre (Mads Mikkelson).  He's a banker to terrorists the world over.  When Bond interferes with his original plan, Le Chiffre finds himself in major debt.  To earn the money to pay off his bills, he sets up a very high stakes poker game at the famous Casino Royale.  MI6 sends Bond to play.  Will poker be the end of Le Chiffre and his funding of terrorism?The movie starts well with a couple of clever action sequences that had me entertained.  I was hoping that the rest of the movie would be that good.  Then the second half hits, and the movie slows way down.  The poker scenes dragged, even for someone with an interest in poker.  And the action scenes the interrupt the poker are boring, too.  And the story slows to let us wonder if Bond will be okay.  Frankly, I just wanted to know how he'd be okay.But wait, we aren't done yet.  The movie keeps going after what appears to be the climax.  As each scene drew to a close, I thought the movie might be ending, but it just kept going.  And, in trying to add a twist or two, the story get almost impossible to follow.This is a shame since the movie has some good performances.  Daniel Craig is great as Bond.  And Judi Dench is funny as Bond's boss, "M."  Eva Green adds some laughs as an accountant assigned to work with Bond.  The two have some wonderful scenes together with easily the funniest lines of the movie.The movie is two and a half hours long.  Thirty minutes could have easily been cut to make this a much better movie.  Unless you are already a Bond fan, stir clear of this loser.
summary: This Could Have Been a Good Film if They'd Cut the Fat

reviewText: Daniel Craig reinvents the James Bond character in this film and the results are shockingly good. I didn't expect much given that Casino Royale (the source material) isn't a very good story to begin with. But they made the most of it.Craig is the first actor to play the role who actually has the physical presence to credibly pull it off. While others looked at home at parties but looked silly once the action started, Craig can do both. He also has the emotional detachment necessary to play the character in a convincing way.I would rather have seen Judi Dench not be in the film (a clean break) because she comes off as an abrasive mother rather than a tough boss. But thankfully John Cleese is gone this time as well as the old introduction of the gadgets to be used later scene which in my opinion never worked onscreen. The Felix Lighter (CIA) character was unnecessary and didn't really work. But he wasn't around much thankfully.In terms of plot, the flim pulls off a gradual build better than most bond films. We see bond tearing down a plot (and a man) one step at a time hopping all over the globe as he does it. He work his way logically through the case from beginning to end. Every location used as a backdrop is exotic but doesn't remain on screen so long that it gets boring.I expected the card game to be boring. But they found a way to make it work by putting breaks in that allowed for "the game" to progress in other ways.This was an amazing film in any number of ways. It took a character on its last legs and somehow reinvented it by going back to basics. It also took the action movie format itself and made it seem interesting for the first time in many years. Daniel Craig shows how to play a tough guy and others would do well to watch.

reviewText: Detractors of this film will harp on how it sullies the tradition of Bond, how it usurps the normal conventions and reinvents something that was already perfect to begin with.  Most of these people seem to be more in love with the formula than with movies that are memorable and well-done.  The Bond series, indeed, is a beloved institution, but this movie proves that it can be so much more.Whereas the films were once merely vehicles for every spy trope in the book (nifty gadgets, cool cars, easily-bedded babes, and villains with vatloads of henchmen), "Casino Royale" opts instead to embrace a story with vaguely realistic elements.  Bond himself was relegated long ago to the status of a mostly meaningless symbol.  He was less a human than he was a poorly concealed fantasy of slick, emotionless machismo.  Sure, throughout the years Bond has shown his share of fear, hate, and even love, but those feelings were always sublimated beneath the glossy veneer of a man who is never ruffled, never confused, and never orders anything other than the standard shaken martini."Casino Royale" opts to rip off that veneer.  Daniel Craig plays Bond with your typical bad-boy stubborness, but you can actually see what makes him human, restrained (just barely) beneath his laser-blue eyes and his awkwardly handsome smile.  He's a classy Bond, as always, but that class seems uncomfortably worn on him; he prefers to get straight to business, prefers to barge rather than sneak, and when the bartender asks him if he wants his martini shaken or stirred, he snaps back, "Do I look like I give a damn?"Oh, he gives a damn.  Just not about drinks.  This time around Bond is up against Le Chiffre (Mads Mikkelsen), illegitimate banker for the world's wealthiest terrorists.  His weakness (aside from an eye that occasionally weeps blood) is gambling, mostly with his clients' money.  Due to Bond's meddling, he's deep in the hole and facing some villains of his own.  To break even, he hosts a high-stakes poker game.  Of course, Bond is there, accompanied by Vesper Lynd (Eva Green), a British Treasury official, who is there to finance Bond's hand and make sure the agent doesn't lose millions of the Queen's hard-earned cash.  She is "Royale's" answer to the Bond girl, a frigidly beautiful woman whose guard is up as high as Bond's, and this time, when they clash, the sparks that fly are legitimate.  Previous Bonds were played like men who would slip into the sack at the slightest provocation, men of pleasure as much as anything else.  Craig's Bond certainly has that in him, but he is business before anything else, and so is Vesper.  It's no wonder they are both drawn to and repelled by each other.  They both think they've got the other's number, and they play their hands accordingly, but of course, nothing is quite that simple.  At one point, Bond says, "You don't play the cards.  You play the man holding the cards."  In this case, the man is a woman, and Bond has finally met his match.The poker game that forms the heart of this film is, thusly, all about taut and riveting psychology, and it mirrors the rest of the film, a movie that deigns to show a less-glossy and more-vulnerable man in the place of the Spy Who Always Gets Away.  "Royale" offers action, sexiness, intrigue, and plenty of explosions and wrecks, but its centerpiece is its dark, whirling mentality, the fact that, finally, the audience is allowed a glimpse into the heart and soul of a spy.  It may not be the prettiest view, but it sure is great to watch.

reviewText: Somewhere along the trail, and I don't remember exactly where, I simply tired of the predictability of Bond movies although I never stopped watching them probably out of some perverse personal obligation to say I had seen all of them regardless of whether or not I still enjoyed them. Fortunately, with Casino Royale and Daniel Craig, I sensed reinvigoration to the series and recognized I once again found the franchise thrilling.Craig's Bond is a refreshing diversion, more urban than urbane, confident and competent but falling short of cynical hubris of Connery, Moore or Brosnan. He is rugged rather than elegant and with this step back to the nascent persona much more introspective. While he is undoubtedly 007, he has not experienced so much that his compassion and passion has been misplaced.Casino Royale introduces a freshly credentialed 00 agent, with his spurs so to speak, earned early in the film. The gadgetry we have become so accustomed to is thankfully absent instead replaced by guile, wits, and in some instances, pure luck.  This is a Bond who lacks all the answers and more importantly, fails give the impression he has prior knowledge of all of the questions.  Both the antagonist, with a decidedly predominant of ideological rather than tyrannical bent and the requisite love interest are outside the stereotypical characterizations of the series' later films.This version of Bond may not care if the martini is shaken or stirred but if like me you've found the entire series most recently overly dry, this one might very well be the mix to suit your taste.

reviewText: It took fifty-three for Casino Royale to make its way to the big screen (not counting a 1954 TV film and 1967 spoof) and it now seems both fitting and ironic that the first, and arguably best, Bond novel should serve as the first Bond film of Daniel Craig. Even more ironic is the fact that one of the best Bond novels has lead to the best Bond film yet. That fact though, is just the icing on the cake for what looks to be the new beginning of 007.Daniel Craig's debut as Bond is nothing short of stunning. Many wondered if this blond actor better known for his more serious acting roles could be an action hero. The answer: a definite yes. Craig brings a physical magnetism to the part of Bond missing really since the early Sean Connery films and he is believable in all of the films action sequences. But what really sells Craig is his acting abilities. Craig brings a very serious approach to Bond. He is everything Bond should be: cold, ruthless, and capable of being a human being. And when it comes to humor, which a lot of fans were worried about, Craig is just as adept. Any doubts about Craig as Bond, they should be taken away at the very end of the film where Craig gets to say "The name's Bond James Bond" for the first time. Craig is the best Bond since Timothy Dalton and arguably he has even surpassed Dalton.Eva Green plays Vesper Lynd, the representative from the MI6 sent with Bond on his first major mission as a 00 agent. Green brings a considerable amount of acting ability to this role and she is far from your average Bond girl. While beautiful and truly stunning physically, Green is an actress and she gets to prove it more then really any other Bond girl. Green is truly an amazing Bond girl and a welcomed relief to the stereotypically cardboard Bond girls.Mads Mikkelsen, a relatively unknown Dannish actor, makes an impressive Le Chiffre. Bond villains generally lack either believability or acting ability, especially since in Die Another Day. But there we get arguably the best Bond villain of the series to date. Le Chiffre is a villain, he is after all the man who serves as financier to the world's terrorists. Yet there is a surprising amount of humanity in him. He deformed eye that weeps tears of blood and his sense of both menace and humor make him the most three-dimensional Bond villain and even at times sympathetic. Mikkelson is the new face of Bond villains.The supporting cast is also great. Judi Dench returns as M, the head of MI6. Her scenes with Craig have a sense of menace to them that surpasses similar scenes with Pierce Brosnan. Dench had more or less inhabited the role of M since Goldeneye but in this film she once again makes the role her own. Jeffrey Wright makes a brief, but welcomed appearance as CIA agent Felix Lieter and we can only hope we see more of him in future films. Caterina Murno seems to be little more then window dressing as Solange, a girlfriend of one of the villains, but she leaves one wishing we'd seen more of her in this film.The script is also perhaps the best to be written for a Bond film. Based on the novel by Fleming, the films plot is an update of the plot of Fleming's novel. The plot is realistic and the lack of gadgets doesn't hurt the film at all. The love story, the first in a while, is a nice addition to the film. The lines are well written and time is taken to actually develop the plot to its fullest and Fleming would be, in my opinion, proud of this film adaptation.The action sequences of this film are stunning. From the gritty black and white fight in the opening teaser sequence the to the running sequence in Madagascar to the attempted bombing of Miami international airport to the stairwell fight and the gunfight in the falling house in Venice at the end, the action sequences have a sense of realism missing from many of the Bond films.Campbell, who directed Brosnan's debut in Goldeneye, does another stunning job in this film. Working with cinematographer Phil Meheux (who also did Goldeneye) and editor Stuart Baird, Campbell created a visual style that brings a new sense of style to the series. From the excellently done black and white teaser detailing how Bond got his 00 number, to the shaky hand held sequence during which Bond is poisoned, and the darkness and shadows in the brilliantly done torture sequence, there is a sense of realism. The sets and costumes also help thanks to production designer Peter Lamont and costume designer Lindy Hemming.The music score by David Arnold is the icing on the cake. No longer having to adhere to the typical Bond score, Arnold creates his best Bond score yet and overall the best Bond score since John Barry's score for On Her Majesty's Secret Service. The score uses the Bond theme sparingly and when it comes back in full force at the end you welcome it back. The score makes good sue of a new love theme and sparingly uses electronics that had hampered the previous Arnold scores. The films theme song, You Know My Name by Chris Cornell, is a welcomed addition to the Bond theme songs and is a vast improvement over the last two or three Bond theme songs.With strong performances from the entire cast, one of the best scripts for any Bond film, strong direction from martin Campbell, terrific cinematography and a great score by David Arnold, Casino Royale delivers. This film was meant as a Bond reboot and it has more then done that. It the process of rebooting the series, the filmmakers have created the best Bond film yet.

reviewText: If the Star Wars prequels showed us anything its that going back to making a prequel to a old movie is a BAD idea, and this film is NO exception. This Bond is supposed to be set pre Dr. No, yet there are:1) cell phones, technology that did not exist then2) laptops, again that did not exist back then (especially not a Sony VAIO which was shamelessly marketed)3) Very elaborate tracking system, much more sophisticated than a radioisotope tracker used in Dr. No4) Modern weapons5) Texas Hold em, not BaccaratJust to mention a few. Sure the acting may be great in parts, like the torture scene, but the whole movie just feels drawn out like they couldn't stop. Kids and first time Bonders will probably like this, but for thoes of us who have seen every Bond movie from Dr. No to Die Another Day (including Never Say Never Again), it is a movie that should never have been made, which is why they made Dr. No first and not Casino Royale.

reviewText: Decades from now when people look back on the long-running cadre of Bond films this one will be among the top 5 all-time --- trust me. Daniel Craig gives a new spin to the tried and true 007 formula of non-stop action, beautiful women and international intrigue. His looks and laconic screen presence reminded me alot of Steve McQueen. It's almost as if Bond is being introduced for the first time because we get a real psychological insight into what makes this famous master spy tick. This is masterfully accomplished by action packed harrowing scenes including one torture scene that would make even Quentin Tarrantino blush. This is fitting since 'Casino Royale' was the book by Ian Fleming that first introduced the world to 007. The plot centers around a terrorist ring financed by a very deadly international financier called Le Chiffre. Bond must beat him in hold-em poker at a game where the buy-in is $10 million dollars and the prize is $150 million. Victory for Le Chiffre would mean money in the pockets of terrorists and as usual victory for Bond means saving the world. Of course, as with all Bond films, it's the 2 hours and 24 minutes of getting there that's all the fun --- 'Casino Royale' is licensed to thrill!!!
summary: Destined to be a "classic" in a long-running classic series!
