reviewerName: Meesha "I'm A Lonely Angel Stuck On The Slow ...
reviewText: Casino Royale is only the third Bond film I've ever seen. For many people, at least one of their favourite films will no doubt include a Bond film. I'd never really been bothered until recently, when I watched Living Daylights and Licence To Kill. Two older Bond films, with Mr Suave, Timothy Dalton. I must admit, when Daniel Craig was originally announced as the new Bond, I couldn't really see why, but out of others who were nominated to be Bond (Clive Owen for instance, no!), I could see he would be the best out of them. I'd only previously seen him in Layer Cake, which didn't impress me.Before seeing it, I was ordered to keep my back turned to the TV, and informed that I wasn't allowed to "moan, sigh, complain" and generally grumble about what I was about to watch. That normally means I'm in for a bad film.When the film started, it was in black and white. And then I spotted what looked suspiciously like Daniel Craig. OK, I knew what this was. (But I didn't complain.)And then the credits started, and they quite literally took my breath away. When by myself, I am notorious for fast forwarding through credits, unless they're short and sweet, or I'm looking for a name. But instead of the dancing girls, who have appeared in previous Bonds, this was stunning. Using the theme of cards (diamonds, hearts etc) it shows characters breaking into pieces upon being shot at with a diamond.Then the film started, and I was reminded of the finale of True Lies, where Eliza Dushku is on that crane thing, being chased by the bad guy, and waiting for Arnie to pop up. OK, I was reminded of it, but Casino Royale surpassed it every way imaginable. It's probably a thousand times higher, and involving (painfully) jumping from different sections of a construction site, it certainly starts the film with a bang and puts Daniel through his paces.There has been a lot of press & fuss about the scene where Daniel walks out of a beautiful ocean, in little blue trunks. I think I was the only woman in the world not to swoon at this shot. Everyone seems to rave about it, but you don't see anything! Stop letting your imaginations run wild, girls! For starters, you don't even see a full length shot. The scene I nearly swooned at (until I realised what was happening) was the naked torture scene. I didn't get what was happening, why exactly the seat of the chair was cut out, until I realised what exactly was getting whipped. Guys, you will cross your legs, and not let your girlfriend anywhere near the crown jewels after seeing this scene. Ouch. I think I went to cross my legs.What impressed me about Casino Royale, and ultimately, Daniel's performance, were the scenes opposite Eva Green. The scene in the shower, after she's witnessed him kill two men, where he sits beside her, made me go all gooey inside, and I actually felt a bit teary. It certainly showed a different side to Bond, a more romantic, softer side, which has only been briefly shown in On Her Majesty's Secret Service, when he gets married and loses his wife in a few hours. And then the stunning finale. WOW. Without ruining it, it shows the same side to Bond again, despite the fact he's been betrayed, and I nearly cried again, but I would have been embarrassed, so I managed to hold it back.Although I haven't seen many Bond films, this seems to surpass everything that was before it, including Pierce Brosnan (everyone will be saying "who?" after seeing Casino Royale). Daniel seems to be physically able to take part in the fights and he fills out a tux quite well. It helps he also quit smoking, and put on 20lbs of pure muscle to play Bond.I loved the poker scenes, but there's no way I could ever play it, I'd have on obvious tail! It's amazing how much money some players will throw at this game.My third Bond film - my favourite Bond movie. As soon as I got home, I raved about this film to my dad, to the point I probably revealed too much about the film when he hasn't seen it. I'm still not 100% about Daniel as Bond, with his ice blue eyes, and blonde hair (although it does look grey in some of the poker scenes!), but he gave it all and managed to come out and portray an excellent Bond, despite all the criticism in the press. All the reviews that just say bad things about Daniel not being a good Bond etc - ignore. He gives it his all as Bond, and showed me a different side to the action man. People are just missing Brosnan, or can't open their minds enough to see the director wanted a new, different Bond. They found him. For me, Daniel is the ultimate Bond. For some, they may argue Sean Connery or others are the definitive Bonds, but for me, Daniel played it magnificently, and will hopefully continue to play Bond. Introduce a new generation to Bond films. Like me.Now when's the next film?
summary: Judi Dench: The Ultimate Bond Girl

reviewText: I am a die-hard James Bond fan. I was absolutely devastated when I learned that Pierce Brosnan wouldn't be returning for a fifth installment as Bond and that blondie Daniel Craig was chosen as the replacement. I spent almost two years dreading "Casino Royale," convinced that it would be absolutely horrible and that Craig's performance would be a disgrace to the character. Well, all that worrying was a waste of time on my part. When I'm wrong, I say I'm wrong, and I was very wrong about this.Here's the bottom line: "Casino Royale" is the best Bond movie ever...hands-down.This film takes the series back to the very beginning, when Bond is first granted his double-0 status. Based on Ian Fleming's novel, "Casino Royale" opens with a gritty black and white sequence that depicts Bond's first government-sanctioned kills. The film soon seeps into full-color mode and features a fantastic 20-minute footchase between Bond and a sprinty African bombmaker. Bond soon finds himself hot on the tails of Le Chiffre (Mads Mikkelsen), a terrorist banker who weeps tears of blood and has a nasty gambling habit that's lost his clients a lot of money. Le Chiffre decides to participate in a high-stakes French poker game in hopes of recouping his losses. MI6 sends Bond there to play against Le Chiffre and prevent him from winning. M (Judi Dench) sends a government accountant, Vesper Lynd (Eva Green), to keep an eye on Bond, but 007 can't manage to take his eyes off HER. Eventually Bond and Vesper find themselves in grave danger at the hands of Le Chiffre. There is torture, bloodshed, and suspense, but I don't want to give away any more of the plot because it's so exciting and I don't want to spoil it for anyone!Overall, "Casino Royale" is brilliant. Craig captures the true essence of James Bond that is depicted in Fleming's novels: an unstoppable killing machine. Craig's performance is also incredibly physical. (He did most of his own stunts for the film.) I really enjoyed the way that the film took a few steps back and attempted explain WHY Bond is the way he is (sort of the way in which "Batman Begins" reshaped the Batman franchise). This isn't the same suave and unfeeling Bond we all know and love. Craig's James Bond is much more human. He's very introspective and allows himself to fall in love with Vesper very easily. Ultimately, their romance doesn't have a happy ending, which explains why James is the way he is with women. So many pieces of the puzzle from more than 40 years of Bond movies fall into place because of this film.Daniel Craig, if you're reading this review, I'm so sorry that I ever doubted you! Now that I've seen the film, there is no doubt in my mind that you are TRULY James Bond! I still don't understand why the director didn't give you a box of Nice 'n Easy to darken up your hair a bit, but I got over the blonde thing after about ten minutes.James Bond is back, and he's better than ever! "Casino Royale" surpassed all my expectations. I can't wait for Craig's next installment as James Bond!

Real-world technology has caught up to the old Bond fantasies and surpassed them, and so has real-world threat; this Bond operates in a recognizable world of terrorists, billionaires, internet connectivity, surveillance technology. reviewText: Before the 2006 film "Casino Royale" film was released in theaters, it caused a controversy among loyal James Bond fans because the actor chosen to play long-time spy James Bond, 007, was Daniel Craig, who is blond.  No other previous James Bond had been blond, but once people began to see the film, the trivial blond hair controversy quickly faded as the action-packed & far more realistic film caught everyone off guard.  Though there were several female characters in the film, there were no so-called "Bond-girls" to be found in this thriller.  Even gone were the silhouettes of naked women within the trademark opening credits of the film.  Thus, what director Martin Campbell (who directed the 1995 James Bond film "GoldenEye") and executive producers Callum McDougall (who produced the 2004 "Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban" and the 2002 "Die Another Day") and Anthony Waye (who also produced "Die Another Day" and "GoldenEye") wanted to portray in "Casino Royale" was a raw and very human James Bond, who was also athletically fit and strong-minded.Based upon Ian Fleming's (1908-1964) first-ever James Bond book entitled "Casino Royale", published in 1953, Bond battles an underworld figure known as Le Chiffre (which literally means "the cypher" and was played by Mads Mikkelsen) who is a financier to various terrorist organizations.  To bolster is dwindling finances, Le Chiffre organizes a high-stakes poker game (originally a baccarat game) in the famous European "Casino Royale".  However, things don't go as planned due to Bond's participation, with the assistance of British government representative Vesper Lynd (Eva Green).With stellar acting from Daniel Craig, Mads Mikkelsen and Judi Dench (who reprised her role as "M"), a brilliant story and lots of action, "Casino Royale" earns a well-deserved 5 out of 5 stars and quite possibly is the best James Bond film ever produced.  I look forward to any future James Bond films starring Daniel Craig as James Bond.As a side note, the 1967 comedic version of "Casino Royale" (that starred David Niven, Peter Sellers, Ursula Andress, Orson Wells and Woody Allen) was also based upon the original 1953 "Casino Royale" novel.  It includes the character Le Chiffre (Orson Wells) and retains the original game of baccarat and the organization known as SMERSH, but that organization (lead by Woody Allen's character, the James Bond's nephew) was quite different from the book and not included in the 2006 serious film version.
summary: Quite Possibly the Best James Bond Film of All Time

reviewText: (Spoilers)  The bad:  Does it bother anyone else that every bad guy in this movie, from the bomb maker to the drug lord, knows kung fu?  I mean, I was told this Bond was more real and had no gadgets.  Instead, I get a movie where Bond stops mid chase to get on a bull dozer to continue his pursuit, and somehow it helps him catch up with the guy?  You know what the guy could of done? Moved to the left or right.  And for a movie with no gadgets, it sure was convienent that Bond happens to have an EKG machine in the glove compartment in his car in case random heart attacking posions are ingested.  I have other gripes, like a bunch of Europeans playing texas hold 'em, and the multiple expositions of Le Chifre's "Tell" but will let them be.  I know, a bunch who read this are going to get mad at quibble, attacking the past bonds for their stupidity.  But that's not the point.  If the movie and critics call this a more real rebirth of the franchise (Babs Broccili said this specifically), then they should follow through with it. This just seemed to be more of the same to me.  Worse yet, I don't like that a rebirth movie has twenty plus in jokes for fans of the past movies. Let it be it's own movie and restart the franchise, or make it a sequel.  Don't do both.The Good:  Craig as a killer.  He has cold eyes and the action was incredible for the most part.  I like him working for the role as opposed to the usual costing other bonds have done...but this is his first movie.  Remember, he's not really Bond until the end of the movie, and even then I really wasn't convinced he was bond.  I guess we'll have to see in the next.  But I am interested.  I also very much enjoyed the last thrity minutes or so of the movie (But won't get into for those who should see it.Overall:  I think a majority of the problems I have were the films inability to choose if it was being a "real" movie, or a tribute to the past.  Probably due to the numerous rewrites, and script not being completed until after filming had begun.  I definitely think there is a ton of potential for the next one, and will be waiting.  I'd recomend seeing it to action fans, though I'm not sure how the majority of Bond fans will feel.
summary: Interested to see where it goes, but...

reviewText: There was never any doubt in my mind that  Daniel Craig would make a sterling James Bond as I have seen  most of his edgy, out of the box film roles in "Layer Cake," The Mother," Sylvia," "Munich," "Road to Perdition" to name several. Craig is and has always had weight, focus and importance on the screen. And as James Bond he brings all of these qualities to bear and "Casino Royale" is the better for it.Many actors were rumored to have been considered for the re-inventing of James Bond and Daniel Craig was not a popular choice but his interpretation here should put all the naysayers at bay for Craig more than re-invents...he makes this part his own.Martin Campbell ("Goldeneye," "Beyond Borders") stays clear of all the wham-bam, thank you M'am special effects of all the former James Bond films and concentrates on the things that make all films important: character, relationships and emotional commitment.The James Bond of "Casino Royale" (it was the first in Ian Fleming's series of books on Bond) has just been given the so-called honor of the "007" impranteur and, though he has been an operative for a time, he is still considered the odd man out, the dangerous one, the one who will stop at nothing to solves his cases. On the surface this would seem like the ideal government spy but the operative word here is "government," the biggest block of bureaucracy there ever is or was and as such "it" requires Bond to follow procedure as M (Judi Dench) reminds him time and again.The Bond of "Casino Royale"is physical, violent, without too much conscience, sexy, fit: more likely to kick you in the groin than serve you a glass of White Burgundy. But this Bond also has a heart and, though he has a couple of dalliances with women, he makes a real connection to one in particular, Eva Green as Vesper Lynd. Though I would have liked somone with a warmer, cushier screen presence than Green, this romance also sets up what is to become of Bond, romance-wise for the rest of the Bond series of novels and, I assume....films.The action sequences are personal and physical (the kind that you never saw Brosnan do) as well as excitingly staged and produced. "Casino Royale" marks a change of direction and focus of the Bond franchise and from the evidence on the screen, I would have to say it looks like the producers have a winner in Daniel Craig and a homerun in their first outing with him.

reviewText: I liked this film and it is nice that, like Batman Returns, the producers are taking the character in a whole new direction and breathing life into the franchise.  For once it was nice to see someone who can actually fight commando style fill the role.We finally see how Bond became Bond and the movie tells how Bond first me Felix Leiter.  This Bond is more ruthless than his predecessors, without the smugness of Moore or Brosnon.  Additionally, this Bond seems to bear his emotions, something we have never seen before and he seems to treat women on a more equal level.  I see this Bond as a lot closer to the Jason Bourne character played by Matt Damon then to any of the previous Bonds.Though I liked the Brosnon portrayals, his movies were predictable and difficult to differentiate between any of the prior movies.  This movie is fresh and makes you want to see this version of Bond in re-inventing some of the earlier Bond films in a fresh light too!

reviewText: Bond is back and Craig has got him!Here at last is the long anticipated film version of "Casino Royale". Based on the very first Bond book this fast paced high-octane thriller is something we have not seen in a 007 film since "Goldfinger". This is a movie, movie and by that I mean it exemplifies the ingredients you need to make a great film."Casino Royale" shines first in a very tight and brilliantly adult screenplay. This is by far the most interesting and complex of thrillers in a very long time. All the rather tired old comic strip aspects of previous Bond films have been swept away from outlandish plots to the old fashioned double entendre that used to pop on the screen like cartoon bubbles.This Bond is witty but with a finer more modern approach. He is truly sophisticated but with some rough edges that catch and tear at the ear with both humor and intelligence.Fine direction by Martin Campbell pushes the action, the actors and ultimately the audience to new heights of action and romance. He shows us in the most jaw dropping way that to kill someone is not easy; it is a messy hard and dirty job. And you can get bloody in the process. Bravo for putting the grit back into Bond.Then there is the cast, a stunning array of international talent and indeed some of the finest actors around today shine and sparkle forever like diamonds in this film.Eva Green as Vesper Lind is by far the best "Bond Girl" to date. She is an actress of great range and talent that brings Vesper to heart stopping life. Her talent combined with great writing and direction has amalgamated in this film to create what may be the only fully rounded and human "Bond Girl" ever seen.Mads Mikkelsen is astonishingly good as the villain Le Chiffre is a real delight to watch. This is no "Dr. Evil" but a cold desperate criminal who when cornered is liable to go nuts on you.Here Judi Dench is given her most complex "M" to date and carries if off with her very special gifts as an actress. She as always is a delight. And in this film you learn a few things about "M" that might surprise you.Then there is Daniel Craig who makes his debut as Bond. And boy's roll out the red carpet and put up the velvet ropes. This performance will bring him to the forefront of movie stars who are also exceptional actors. This is a man who can act, and yet never let you catch him at it. A talent that ranks with the top fine actors today such as Russell Crowe,He inhabits this very rough and dangerous Bond at the birth of the character and gives us a hot, hard, thug who though the course of the film is transformed by human design and circumstance into "Bond, James Bond". He is simply breathtaking to watch.The film has a brain and also tips it's hat to great thrillers of the past especially "North By Northwest" as exemplified by the very sexy and delightful train scene where Bond and Vesper meet for the first time. But the most surprising aspect of "Casino Royale" is how human it is and how heartbreakingly romantic it can be amid the very dirty business of international espionage.this spcial two disc blue-ray edition is stunning to behold with a perfect picture and window shattering sound. The extras are simply grand as well.This movie at last brings magic back to the movies and heart to the Bond franchise.

reviewText: I was really impressed by the story line presented in Casino Royale.  Special effects should never take away from a very good story line.  In Casino Royale, however, the producers/directors of the film have taken careful steps to ensure that the special effects compliment the story line.  "Casino Royale" was actually Ian Flemmings first James Bond novel.  The special features of the DVD suggest that the film is a very authentic rendition of the novel.  (I am not sure since I have not yet read the book).There are three highly compelling stunts that far surpass any that I've seen previously in a film.  The three stunts include a fight scene on the top of a building construction site; a scene in an airport in which a terrorist seeks to crash a heavy-duty truck towards a new airplane; and a case scene.This is an incredibly visually interesting film.

reviewText: My interest in James Bond died the day I saw Pierce Brosnan shoot a machinegun.  Gone were the careful headshots of a man who was an expert with his pistol.  Replacing that deadly accuracy was frenetic scenes, random gunfire, and Bond bending the laws of reality.  The Bond films had become a parody of themselves.Enter Casino Royale, which makes up for the shambling travesty that was the Casino Royale Bond spoof.  Daniel Craig takes on the role of Bond as a newbie, a newbie who is a ruthless killer.  Gone are the delicate acrobatics that were the trademark of other Bonds.  This Bond is a hulking brute, smashing through walls, ruthlessly shooting people, and otherwise achieving his missions through sheer brute force. It seems jarring at first, but this is the origin of Bond, from thug to international assassin.The plot, bound by the rules of the original novel, doesn't entirely make sense.  Why the entire world, including both the U.S. and British authorities, feel that beating a criminal at a card game is the best way to coerce him is beyond me.  But if you're willing to buy into that fact (a requisite, really, for the spy genre where nothing is ever so simple and direct) then the film has a certain cadence to it that really enthralls.Until the end.  The part where, we are led to believe, Bond is going to settle down with Vesper Lynd, a treasury agent, in Venice.  Yeah, right.About ten minutes could have been cut from this scene alone.  We get that Bond is enamored with Lynd, that he wants to give it all up for her, but after the torture, the shooting, the gambling, the chasing, the movie becomes something of a snore until it picks up again.  And then we're off to the beginning of another movie, with no resolution whatsoever.Casino Royale is a much improved film, but it's the foundation for the Bond mythology, and as such it breaks previous expectations and struggles to establish new ones. It's much better than the Bond films that went before it, but they set the bar pretty low.  As a book-end to Quantum of Solace, Casino Royale can't be really appreciated without seeing the two movies back-to-back.

reviewText: This is the best James Bond film in some time. The story is set at the very beginning of Bond's career (he's just been promoted to Double-Oh status) and Daniel Craig is a very believable rough-edged, not entirely self-assured agent who falls in love with a woman he's willing to resign his career for. But since I've seen all or most of the films in the series, beginning with "Dr. No" in 1962, continuity dictates that the beginning of Bond's career should logically have been set during the Cold War of the late 1950s -- not in the 21st century world of terrorism, cell phones, and Texas Hold'Em. (The original novel, of course, was set even earlier, in 1953.) It's as if the previous films in the franchise didn't exist. The stunts and the chase scenes are great and there's relatively little reliance on bizarre spy technology (except for a suspiciously convenient defibrilator in the gove compartment), and the relationships are key to the story for a change. And the parkour chase sequence in Madagascar was amazing, as was the the building-collapse scene in Venice. Even the open credit sequence was much more restrained than usual. Finally, the only really familiar face among the cast is Judi Dench as a very tough "M," which allows the story to take precedence over the actors. Mads Mikkelsen is especially creepy as Le Chiffre, and Eva Green (as Vesper Lynd) and Caterina Murino (as Solange) are sufficiently attractive without being Barbie Dolls. I rather miss "Q" and Miss Moneypenny, though. I understand a direct sequel to this one will be out soon (another Bond film first) and I shall be watching for it.
summary: Best Bond film in some time

reviewText: It's hard to give a movie a bad review when there are certain elements of it that you genuinely like and admire, but Casino Royale is just plain asking for it.  Yes, Daniel Craig does an excellent job portraying a darker, grittier, more cynical James Bond that we're used to.  And yes, the first half of the movie is entertaining (if you'll suspend your disbelief during the truly absurd chase scene at the beginning).  But then, things rapidly fall apart.How many movies have we seen now in which the hero's only recourse is to engage his arch-nemesis in a pulse-pounding... er, poker game?  And how many times are we going to be handed a villain who is supposed to be a poker-master, yet displays incredibly obvious "tells" (aka physical giveaways of the kind of hand he or she is holding)?And as for the last twenty minutes of this movie, to call them predictable would be, well, predictable.  The problem is that the movie-makers simply don't understand their own character.  Suddenly, they change gears and make Craig's raw, gritty, cynical Bond behave like a lovesick teenager.  Which ends exactly how you'd expect it to end.Oh, and one more thing...  I'm pretty sure Bond's cell phone should have been listed as a character in the movie, since an absurd amount of time is spent showing close-ups of who Bond is calling, who Bond is texting, etc.  I don't care if the hero is texting Jesus Christ or Satan; it's absolutely impossible for text-messaging to be dramatic!

reviewText: Finally, political correctness caught up with James Bond, something which was always sure to spell disaster for the whole Bond concept. Bond's long history of womanizing (although the 'manizing' of the many Bond girls is deemed acceptable in the hypocrisy of political correctness, Hollywood-style) was finally punished in this film, with amongst other things, a flogging on the genitals, to the delight of many it seems. Previous Bonds had broken every rule in the book of today's gender rules for films, especially the rule that a woman must always get the comeuppance over a man. If a man uses a woman, he must somehow be punished at the end of the film. If a woman uses a man, there must be a good reason for her doing it, and it's probably because he's a bastard. Bond broke this golden rule for nearly 4 decades, and now poor old Daniel Craig (who plays his role as well as could be done considering the script he had to accept) is paying for this with genital floggings and other humiliations no other Bond would have dreamed of accepting. This is NOT Bond. It's just the typical, routine modern action film, politically-corrected to match today's bogus gender ideology, and can only really be enjoyed by certain kinds of women and emasculated men, the type who've unconsciously accepted psychological castration. This would be perfectly OK if we also saw films of Charlie's Angels, for example, getting floggings on their genitals, as then men would know that Hollywood does promote real gender equality. But the fact that that is extremely unlikely to happen demonstrates just how ruinous bogus ideologies can be to film production, the creation of art in general, as well as relations of true equality between the genders.
summary: The castrated Bond for the modern emasculated man

reviewText: Casino Royale was the first James Bond novel Ian Fleming wrote and his worst.  The book had only two things going for it.  The fact that Fleming had knowledge of how a spy REALLY worked was one of those things.  The other was he was also able to make his main character, the brutal OO7, James Bond, as close to reality as he could.  Mr. Bond was NOT a nice character, even if he was fighting, or should I say killing, for the good guys.  Outside of those two points the rest of the book, from plot to the very flow of the scenes, pretty much sucked.  But it was his first book and his craft approved slightly with each new story.When the movies picked up the James Bond stories, mostly because JFK was reading them, they gave James Bond high-tech weapons, took away his rough and gritty soul, and gave him a sense of humor.  They also did what they did best - they made everything look great, from the fast cars to the glowing cities and sexy women James Bond would encounter, and use, on the way.  They also took his treatment of women and tuned it down a few levels.  They changed him into a spy totally removed from the reality of the Cold War or, at least, the Cold War of the books.Now they brought the James Bond from the books, they picked a story they could work on and approve BECAUSE it was so weak, and they tuned down the high-tech stuff.  They created, in my view, the best James Bond movie ever.  Daniel Craig is a ruthless Bond, Judi Dench is a cold and logical M, and even Eva Green plays a hard but also troubled Vesper.  From the opening black and white flashback to the closing, old fashion, theme song you CAN'T keep your eyes off the screen.The extras are nice, from behind the scene features to a special on James Bond Girls and even the Chris Cornell Music Video.  I can't wait for the next movie.  And they BETTER keep Daniel Craig as the agent OO7.
summary: The best movie from the not-so-good book...

reviewText: The plot of CASINO ROYALE is indecipherable but, hey, who cares? Just sit back and enjoy the action and Daniel Craig's new Bond. While I haven't seen all the Bond movies, long ago turned off my mindless gimmacry and adolescent sexuality, I will declare this the best Bond movie ever made. Mr. Craig, his rough-hewn face looking sculpted from too many times barroom fights, is a perfect Bond or at least is the Bond Sean Connery should have been: quiet, tough and no nonsense, all the clever Bondisms absent from the script, giving CASINO more of a sense of reality than previous Bond films. The long, opening foot-chase scene is stunningly choreographed. Hats off to director Martin Campbell for excellent production values and filming. Judi Dench is good as Bond's boss and Eva Green as his love interest. One hopes there will more Bond movies with Mr. Craig as the lead. There is one more new Bond movie fan.

reviewText: Two kills, and James Bond (Craig) has been elevated to double-O level.  M (Dench) feels that he is not ready, sends him on his first mission anyway.  His job is to find Le Chiffre (Mikkelsen), a supplier of terrorist money, and shut him down.  When Le Chiffre enters an exclusive poker tournament at Casino Royale in Montenegro, Bond enters as well to prevent him from winning.  Even with the help of Vesper Lynd (Green), a treasury agent, Bond may have his hands full, as Le Chiffre sets his eyes on removing Bond from the picture permanently."Casino Royale" is a successful reboot of the James Bond franchise.  As different as night and day from "Die Another Day", "Casino Royale" does almost everything right.  Daniel Craig is perfect as Bond, maybe even the best ever.  He is a rough around the edges "blunt instrument" that has a ways to go before he is the James Bond we know.  Grounded in reality, "Casino Royale" also does away with most of the gadgets one would expect from a Bond movie.  The supporting cast all do a good job in a movie that is all Daniel Craig.  This is not your father's Bond...this is better.

reviewText: I cannot understand anybody's reason for praising this movie. I've loved 007 films for years and I admit the last two that where made where CGI overkill and not a top film, but all it needed was a better director and scriptwriters.So they come up with the idea to jump on the Batman Begins wagon and re-invent something that wasn't broken?When I first saw the preview/trailer of this, and hearing about this as being a prequel, I saw an instant mistake when Judy Dench was shown as being M in the film. A prequel that ignores the fact that she wasn't the original M character, she took over as M in Goldeneye(or one of the Brosnon ones) because the Original M died or retired or something and she was next in line, or the wife or something, I dunno, but the point is she wasn't there in the beginning. And the excuse I heard was that this isn't a prequel, its a complete restart like Batman Begins. OK, I let that one slip by and ended up seeing the film.The start of the film bored the hell out of me, it was so slow, and dragged, and didn't even show how Bond became a double-0 agent, it's more like starting from his first day AS a 00. Then the rest of the film lagged and then action, then bore, then action, then lag, then bore then action, then what, then zzzzz, then "so that's it then is it?"As I said, being a Bond fan for over 20 movies, why try and fix what's not broken? This film is not a Bond film, it just has the character names, the 00 status and the theme music, and the theme music of the trademark guitar theme didn't even get played in the movie, it was just used in the closing credits.How can you call this a Bond film when you have Dr Who not fitting into the spot of a Bond type, men aren't my thing, but I cant imagine women seeing him as charming and sophisticated with a license to thrill them.Amongst everything else, no Q, no gadgets, no charm, not the right kind of smartarse replies expected from a Bond, no Money Penny, and he's gone from what we know Bond as to more of a dull egotistical and boring character that acts more depressing then anything else.I don't get it, I really don't understand how any fans of Bond could seriously see this as a decent Bond film? I'd probably think it was an average and forgetful film if it was titled something else and didn't use the Bond names and trademarks, but this will never be accepted by me as a Bond film.I honestly can't believe that only a small majority of reviewers have seen the movie the way I did. Either the world had gone mad, or there is only reviews being written by people who have never seen a Bond film before because all the ones who have are still in shock, puking in the car park or still at the ticket office demanding a refund.R.I.P James Bond (1962-2006)
summary: Why try to fix whats not broken?

reviewText: I must first say that I was "extremely reluctant" to accept Daniel Craig into my heart as the infamous, sexy and dangerous 007. I was very upset when they decided that Pierce Brosnan would not be back. A little history....I was a BIG Sean Connery fan, and could not stand Roger Moore or the other Bonds until Brosnan. He had most of the qualities that I feel Sean Connery has......he is suave, charming, handsome and a little mysterious/dangerous...and James Bond use to be Remington Steele.  So, needless to say I didn't want another 007, just when I got use to this one. So imagine my attitude when I went to see this movie.......Daniel Craig was going to be critiqued harshly. Now with all that in mind, I must say I was pleasantly pleased. Although Daniel Craig's was 007, his spin on the character was completely different. And although he was not as suave as Sean Connery, he is just as romantic (Vesper love story crucial to the story), more so because he only tried to get with two women, versus a ton (each critical to the story).  And more than anything, he was more believable than past Bonds. He would bleed, he got hurt, he was sensitive and completely human.This movie was great....the plot is well written, you love to hate the bad guy, you feel sorry for the hero, and I found myself beginning to embrace him as 007. I no longer view 007 as a "single" person, while for some reason in the past it seemed like writers wanted us to think of Connery, Moore, and Brosnan, as the same person.  But now, I have come to see the title of 007 as a classification, similar to the position of Inspector and Detective. And I really found myself appreciating the fact that this Bond was so human. Casino Royale is worth watching, and I would love to see Craig in the role again, in the near future.
summary: Daniel Craig made a believer out of me!

reviewText: I am a lifetime Bond fan.  I own all the films on DVD, view them on a reasonably frequent rotation, and in one way or another love them all.  I'll keep this brief -- no plot synopses, no detailed analyses: suffice to say that Daniel Craig IS James Bond, just as surely as Sean Connery was.  I have great respect for all the actors who have come in between over the last 3 decades, but this film, paired with this actor in particular, are the single greatest pairing in Bond history since Connery in "Goldfinger".  Kudos to everyone concerned -- Bond is back, he's better than he's been in decades, and he should be around for a long, long time to come.
summary: The BEST Bond since Connery -- the Bond we've been waiting for.

reviewText: As a Bond picture, this movie is nearly perfect. I was impressed right from the start. The well-done opening title sequence (interestingly, no nude women but you don't miss them) with it's somewhat retro artwork combined with the best theme song (by Chris Cornell - his voice sounding better than I've ever heard it sound - alternately warm and majestically screechy) since You Only Live Twice or Nobody Does It Better immediately hooks you.Next, I was completely impressed with Daniel Craig. Yes, at times his face does convey a certain unBondian goofyness. But you get over that right away after the stirring opening chase scene. Craig is no soft, pretty boy Roger Moore type*. He's athletic, built like a prize fighter, and viscious. For the first half of the movie, he's like Seattle Slew as a colt - inexperienced, cocky and naive - but you know he's going to win the Derby some day. And the Derby ends by the time the last scene plays - at which time I let out an audible "woo!" and "yeah, baby!" - even though I watched the DVD alone.This movie succeeds on so many levels. It convincingly portrays Bond before he became the icon. The action sequences and location shooting are top notch. The villian is as creepy and reptilian as any previous foe. The love story between Bond and Vesper progresses expertly and is quite moving (and unexpected). But Daniel Craig stole the show and by the time the movie ended, I was immediately thirsting for the next Craig-helmed Bond flick.At the end of the closing credits, the producers promise that "JAMES BOND WILL RETURN." Can't wait.* Don't get me wrong: I loved most of the somewhat campy but fun and exciting Moore-era Bond movies. I just sort of looked the other way during Roger's "fight" scenes.
summary: Arguably, one of the best Bond movies of all time! WOW!!!

reviewText: "Casino Royale" is the 21st movie in the James Bond franchise, and, for the first time since 1987's "The Living Daylights", it is based on one of Ian Fleming's novels. Loosely. The same book, the first of Fleming's Bond novels, inspired the 1967 spoof of the spy flick genre, also called "Casino Royale". I haven't seen that film, and it's been so long since I read Fleming's book that I barely remember it. But I can say that, in addition to moving the story beyond the Cold War and reinterpreting the Bond character, this film is more convoluted than the novel that inspired it. "Casino Royale" reinvents the James Bond franchise by moving away from the quasi-sci-fi, somewhat hokey technoterrorism of 2002's "Die Another Day" and toward a grittier world of death-defying hand-to-hand combat almost completely unaided by unusual gadgetry.Shortly after receiving his "00" status, or license to kill, British superspy James Bond (Daniel Craig) makes a spectacle of shooting up an embassy and an unarmed bombmaker in Madagascar. Annoyed by his politically embarrassing bravado and intent on cornering the banker to many of the world's terrorist organizations, a man called Le Chiffre, British spy chief "M" (Judi Dench) sets Bond lose to track down Le Chiffre's clients and create financial pressure that will force him to turn to MI6 for amnesty. This culminates in a high-stakes poker game in Montenegro, where Le Chiffre (Mads Mikkelsen) must recoup his recent losses in order to cover his clients' investments. The British government sets Bond up with a $10 million stake, watched over by sharp, curvaceous treasury agent Vesper Lynd (Eva Green), with orders to clean Le Chiffre out.We won't know for sure until a few more Bond films have been produced, but "Casino Royale" appears to be a major turning point in the franchise. It has jettisoned "Q", Miss Moneypenny, and gadgets-to-the-rescue. Moreover, Daniel Craig's James Bond is a huge departure from previous interpretations. Where Sean Connery's Bond was a smug playboy, Roger Moore's effete, and Pierce Brosnan's politically correct, this new Bond is a sociopathic automaton. I'm not sure what this says about today's ideals. Bond is reckless as always. But he has more contempt than desire for women. He's an unquestioning soldier, not a stylish individualist. He acts as if he's been programmed, a relentless and unfeeling machine with the odd lapse into cloying sentimentality. His detachment is perversely captivating, but if Bond is going to be this dark, I might have preferred Clive Owen in the role."Casino Royale" is an energetic and strangely seductive movie whose strength lies in its exoticism, immediacy, and careful pacing, not in Bond's charisma, action sequences, or Bond girls. The action sequences are the film's lows. A 9-minute chase goes past the point of dull and keeps on going. Adventures in Uganda, Madagascar, Nassau, and Miami that involve Le Chiffre's clients are tangential and cause the movie to run nearly 2 1/2 hours. They exist to provide eye candy and action at regular intervals. This works, but it complicates the plot to the extent that I must conclude that the plot does not matter. Le Chiffre seems to run a hedge fund for monied revolutionaries who manipulate stock prices with terrorist acts while he sells the stocks short. He is effectively an insider trader. Again, I'm not sure what this says about today's anxieties. "Casino Royale"'s plot, from its financial chicanery to its inscrutable and invisible villain "Mr. White", does not make sense. I can't excuse the sloppy writing, but "Casino Royale" is a pivotal Bond film with almost enough thrills and intrigue to entertain for its unprecedented 2 hour 24 minute running time.
Title: N/A

reviewText: An artful turn of phrase, an upturned eyebrow, and a casual air in the midst of a deadly situation means only one thing:  James Bond has returned.  Curiously absent on the big screen for the last half-decade, the famous, womanizing MI6 agent ignited the fires of controversy--off-screen for a change--when gossip-mongers discovered that the actor cast for the role would be, gasp, blond.  Luckily, the producers and directors of "Casino Royale" forged ahead regardless, giving actor Daniel Craig ("Layer Cake") a chance to prove his worth.  The short version of this review would be that he succeeded spectacularly; further, he was working with one of the best scripts the series has had in years.  The long version of this review, as befits this reviewer's compulsion, will continue below.By the mid-to-late 1980's, fans were beginning to view the franchise in a light similar to how nearly all Americans viewed "SNL" since the seventies--as a once-great thing long past its peak.  Then, "Goldeneye" was released, and new life entered the series as a new generation was indoctrinated into the cult of the Sultan of Suave.  Pierce Brosnan was the new captain, but even his brave leadership couldn't save future episodes ("Tomorrow Never Dies," "The World is Not Enough," and "Die Another Day") from being simply okay at best, and silly at worst.  Another idea floating around is the somewhat specious view that the "Austin Powers" franchise diminished Fleming's cinematic translations.  This is convenient in that blame is removed from the producers, writers, and directors of the Bond films, which was probably the entire reason for forwarding such as ridiculous idea in the first place.  Regardless, the series was far past the time for something new--director Martin Campbell ("Goldeneye," "Beyond Borders") proves far more than capable at injecting a little modernity into the aging series.  Ironically, he pulls this off by starting at the beginning:  the beginning of Bond's "00" career, of Fleming's novels, and of the agent's descent into total emotional detachment.  Campbell is not above resurrecting a few ideas and scenes from past "Bond" films--several of which may be lost of today's audience--but the overall effect still feels remarkably fresh.Everything chic and hip happens in Prague, so naturally that is exactly where Bond earns his "00" status.  He kills Dryden, a regional MI6 section chief who has been appropriating extra funds illegally.  After obtaining his promotion to "007" designation, we find James on surveillance duty in Madagascar.  His partner bungles his cover and is made by the target, prompting the movie's first chase sequence.  Chasing his acrobatic quarry through construction sites and city streets, James is finally able to corner him in an embassy.  Interested only in the target's bag, Bond kills the man and blows up most of the embassy in what must be the world's most elaborate distractionary gambit.  Finding a text message which says only "ellipsis," he begins on a journey to unravel a tangled web consisting of international crime syndicates, stock market manipulation, and Le Chiffre, (Mads Mikkelsen, "King Arthur") a banker who finances terror.  Along the pathway to illumination, James finds time to play perhaps the largest-stake Texas Hold `em game ever, win the heart of Vesper Lynd (Eva Green), hack into M's personal computer account, and seduce a vixen after first stripping her husband...of several thousand dollars, his pride, and his classic Aston Martin, that is.This film shows the filmmaker's desire to reinvent the franchise.  "Casino Royale" was Fleming's first novel, and this movie seeks to similarly begin a new Bond continuum, with no relation to prior films in the series.  As such, Craig's Bond is permitted to be shown as a flawed, vulnerable, and green agent who does not yet bear the scars of cumulative experiences.  He is recognizable as the agent we know--brash, arrogant, ruthless, and philandering--but seems to almost be the adolescent version of later manifestations.  The deep wound he sustains by the conclusion of "Casino Royale" may provide the viewer with a sense of why his later versions seemed so apathetic and aloof regarding--supposedly--key emotions like compassion, love, and honor.  Prior to this film, the character of Bond seemed axiomatic:  he simply was, and he was not a result of anything.  Perhaps the success of this movie over its predecessors is partially due to better audience identification with the main character--it's easier to root for someone that you identify as human.Forget the character, for this is a Bond movie, right?  That means blazing action sequences, smoldering women, hotter cars, technobabble, and cutting wisecracks garnished with the perfect martini to most fans.  Fans need not fear to the slightest degree.  Two of the chase sequences had my wife suspecting that I'd prefer a seat inside the screen, so riveted by the onscreen action was I.  I'll never view an airplane refueling truck the same way again.  Solange (Caterina Murino) heats up the screen with vibrant Mediterranean allure, probably causing most male viewers to miss the gist of several lines of dialogue.  However, Eva Green as Vesper succeeds in taking first prize in the sex appeal department--despite a rather mousy appearance--via simple combination:  presence, presence, and presence.  The unspoken suggestion present in every line of dialogue between her and James is hotter than even Solange's bikini-on-horseback scene.  Aston Martin brings several representative vehicles into the film--one car being most unfortunate, more's the pity.  Speaking of Bond's Aston Martin, it conveniently comes equipped with cardiac defibrillator, chemical blood analyzer, silenced pistol, and GPS locator, so technophiles everywhere should be assuaged their concerns.  Finally, James Bond--even as an agent just starting out--achieves a sum total of wit in one half sentence which most people aspire to in their entire lives.  He even manages to be witty without actually uttering an entire phrase--as an audience, we so easily accept his innate verve that we are willing to forgive him such extraneous matters as actually finishing the witty sentence.  In summary, 007 is supernaturally charming, capable, lucky, desirable, and macho, but this time, he's human, too.The movie had me chuckling from the moment Le Chiffre first took a puff from his silver inhaler to when Craig finally uttered the immortal introduction.  The tension was present from the bathroom brawl to the final confrontation in a doomed building.  The conspiracy runs deep and the movie may require several viewing before a viewer feels comfortable with the plot; however, the story does not end with the credits.  Fans of "Dr. No" will note a playfully inverted take on perhaps the most famous Bond girl introduction scene of all time.  "Casino Royale" is only the first movie of a planned trilogy, (the second film, "Quantum of Solace," was out last fall) so expect even more character development, as opposed to what you may be familiar with:  an indestructible, unaltered agent who operates in a vacuum, without memory or care of past events.  This movie is highly recommended for those interested in seeing both Bond's best film and Bond's best actor--and yes, I'm including Sean Connery amongst that list.
summary: The best Bond thus far:  two years on, people are still looking for blown-off socks

reviewText: Gone (for now at least) are the rediculous gadgets, cornball puns and outsized plots meant to disguise the fact that the series had little left to offer.  From the opening moments of "Casino Royale" when still rising British Agent James bond (Craig) earns his stripes with two calculated murders, it is clear  that the Bond franchise has rediscovered itself, going back to fundamentals and delivering the most exciting and engrossing Bond film since Sean Connery squared off against a certain deranged businessman with an affinity for gold.  Craig, a seasoned character actor with superstar charisma and animal magnetism to burn, is ideally suited for the restart.  His rough-hewn good looks and gruff demeanor perfectly accentuate this early Bond, who is still trying to channel his anger, aggression and recklessness into the suave charisma and ruthlessly lethal efficiency that a spy needs to survive.  But beyond the superficial, Craig's acting chops are formidable, and he rips into Bond with an intelligence and gusto not seen since Connery.  In fact, Craig may now have outdone Connery, but it will remain to be seen if Craig can muster Connery's consistency.However, the Bond series has been known to shoot itself in the foot with stiff, static writing and insipid direction (exibit A and B: "A View to a Kill" and "The World is not Enough," along with numerous others).  But, for "Royale," the franchise stewards Barbara Broccoli and Michael Wilson wooed back Director Martin Campbell from "Goldeneye" as well as screenwriter Paul Haggis (Crash) to spice up the script by Bond vets Neal Purvis and Robert Wade.  As a result, the writing is astronomically better than it has been in years, refreshingly devoid of cop-out puns and instead chock full of textured dialouge and biting back and forth banter (check the first interplay between Craig and Eva Green, the smartest and strongest Bond girl in years).  Haggis and co. also seem to have taken notes from Matt Damons' "Bourne" series, realizing that a touch of humanity and reality to the saga of a super-spy goes a long way in enriching character.  They allow Craig and Green to be vulnerable, terrified, and even a little bumbling in the face of the cool, demented and blood-stained eyes of Le Chiffe (Mads Mikkelson), a renegade finacier of terror who uses his clients assets to bankroll a high-rolling poker game and play the stock market, albeit with perfectly placed terrorist attacks of his own to push the market just the right way.  Director Campbell, whose work since "Goldeneye" has been spotty to say the least (Vertical Limit, Beyond Borders), is reenergized on "Royale," his style and confidence rekindled.  He, along with cinematographer Phil Meheaux (The Mask of Zorro) and editor Stuart Baird (A Richard Donner favorite), uncork their shared prowess and deliver a whirlwind of bone-crunching action scenes both small (the opening bathroom brawl between Bond and his first kill) to gigantic.  The foot chase up and down a construction site in Madagascar between Bond and a ridiculously athletic bomb-making terrorist is a show-stopper, as is the finale in a collapsing Venetian mansion.  What this adds up to is that "Casino Royale" ranks as one of the best Bond films of all time, but it also ranks as the best action film of the year.  Hell, it may end of being one of the best films of the year.
summary: Daniel Craig Shines in the Best Bond Since "Goldfinger"

reviewText: ....whether its his/her favorite Bond film or whether its his/her favorite Bond actor, there is bound to be disagreement.I will admit that this was the first Bond film I had ever seen. You're probably shaking your head at this point wondering why a self-proclaimed "movie-buff" hadn't seen a Bond film in her 28 years of life, but I just hadn't. I tend to avoid the big Hollywood Blockbuster movies (ie. Batman, Superman, Spiderman etc.) and am typically more into independent and/or "artsy" films, but I do enjoy good action/adventure as well. Not to say Bond films fall into the Hollywood Blockbuster category, however, the ones made in the last decade or so have been hyped up by Hollywood with much with so much pomp and circumstance, its actually kept me away from the theater.Regardless, I decided to "cave in" and rent Casino Royale when home for two weeks with pneumonia simply because I had exausted every other film in Blockbuster Video, and I was extremely surprised and impressed with the movie, so much so that I have now rented and seen most of the earlier Bond films. At this juncture, I feel I can finally submit my opinion that Daniel Craig IS the ultimate Bond! He was much more subtle than the other actors who played the coveted role, and defintiely much more manly, believeable and "cool" than Pierce Brosnsan who starred in the last few ones.The film was awesome (for lack of a better word): amazing special effects, quality acting, a great plot and twists and turns galore....pretty much a perfect movie (let alone a perfect "Bond movie").Despite being the first Bond film I've seen, its defintiely my favorite and I can't wait for Bond 22 (as yet untitled, I believe) to come out with Daniel Craig.I HIGHLY recommend owning this amazing film and adding it to your Bond collection- its worth every penny and then some!

reviewText: I have to say it was pretty odd seeing Bond being put under so much pressure and having to fight his way out of it to the extreme.Now the story is not the thing that is going to grab you in this movie but the action will.  The movie is unfortunately kind of a bore when there is no action going on but when it hits it is truly something special.  It starts out with a foot chase where Bond is trying to catch a man who he never should have started chasing.  This guy is doing some of the most dangerous jumps I have ever seen in a movie and he just flies through the air with such ease always knowing he will make a spectacularly easy landing.  If you have seen the French film 'District B-13' then prepare to be even more amazed!  Now the action itself in all of the scenes is absolutely brutal.  Definitely the messiest Bond movie and all the better for it.  This is not one of my favorite Bond movies ever, even from recent years, but Daniel Craig will certainly force you to recognize him.  I vote for Craig as the toughest Bond, by far.

reviewText: I had seen Daniel Craig inLayer Cake (Widescreen Special Edition), and was very impressed with him as an actor. The curiosity factor was high when I wandered off to see "Casino Royale".Was Craig as good as some of the other Bond actors? No, simply put. However, this was his first Bond movie, and I think an actor of his skill will quickly gain a feel for his own interpretation of the character. Craig brings a certain ruthlessness to the role, and a gritty earthiness. Without the vast array of nifty gadgets, Bond is finally relying on his wits. Breaking into M's home was a nice touch.Balanced with that is Bond's sensitive side. I do not ever recall Bond falling in love before. The vulnerability made for a deeper character, perhaps the deepest sinceOn Her Majesty's Secret Servicewith George Lazenby as Bond.The tension between M and Bond is plainly palpable, continuing one aspect from the previous movies with Brosnan. Another aspect of Bond that continues to develop is his sensivity and vulnerability. It is not emphasised, but it does poke through on the odd occassion.Bond spent a lot of time playing poker in this movie, and that was a bit of a drawback. However, the tension was maintained and well done. For anyone not familiar with poker, some of the game play may be a bit of a mystery. This section of the movie was nicely broken up with an awesome fight scene and some other elements of tension.Of particular note was the chase on foot between Bond and a bomb-maker in Madagascar. The agility and speed of the actor playing the bomb-maker was stupendous. The man could move like nothing I have ever seen. It was scenes and chases like this that made the movie truly great.Daniel Craig could be set to become a Bond actor of the highest calibre. If "Casino Royale" is anything to go on, I think we can expect some great things in the future.

reviewText: To tell you the truth, I was depressed when I first heard that Pierce Brosnan was replaced by Daniel Craig. But to my surprise, Daniel Craig is a really good James Bond who fits closely with the Ian Fleming description of Bond. Gone is the gentleman assassin associated with Roger Moore and Pierce Brosnan's depiction; here we have the early Sean Connery Bond, the ruthless, detached assassin-spy. Daniel Craig brings back the danger in 007; you believe that Craig could at any moment strangle you to death, put a knife into your belly, or shoot you without blinking an eye. (Timothy Dalton captures the danger in Bond really well in his 2 films "Living Daylights" and "Licence to Kill") Craig reminds me a lot of Steve McQueen and his Bond is more like Jason Bourne -- the action is fast and furious.We also see Craig as a human Bond; he makes mistakes, he is driven by his male ego, he gets bruised, he bleeds, he gets tortured, and he gets heartbroken. All this was reflected in the Bond described in the novel Casino Royale. Craig is a really good actor who helps the viewer see inside the character of the man, just as George Lazenby did in "On Her Majesty's Secret Service". It's nice to see Bond brought back down from being a comic book hero to being a real man with real emotions and issues. Great job, Daniel Craig!Eva Green does a commendable job as Vesper Lynd, Bond's love interest. Vesper is an intelligent and capable Treasury agent every bit as equal to Bond. It's always great to have a strong woman character in a Bond movie.There were some shortcomings in this movie: The chase sequence goes on too long where Bond chases the bombmaker. The title song and sequence weren't that great. The poker game drags on a bit too long, even though they put in bits of action in between. In fact, the whole movie could have been trimmed 25 minutes. Secondly, it is weird to hear M talk about 9-11 when this is the "Bond Begins" film; we have to forget 40 years of Bond films as though they didn't exist. Third, even though Judi Dench is a great actress, someone much younger should have been "M" for the chronology to make sense. Here Judi Dench looks older than "Die Another Day" when this is supposed to happen way before.Fourth, we know that Q doesn't show up until Dr. No, but it would have been great to have Bond have some gadgets either in his car or in his briefcase, not just the defibrillator. Also, it would have been great to have some good car chases, and have the Aston Martin do something.However, Martin Campbell does a great job of directing and introducing the 21st century Bond, just as he did in 1995 with Pierce Brosnan.I look forward to the next segment of Craig's Bond. I'm wondering if they could remake "Man with the Golden Gun", "A View to a Kill," and "Moonraker", 3 of the most forgettable in the film series.The special features in the 2 disc version are great:  There are 3 featurettes:  one which features how Daniel Craig got the role, another which details the incredible stunts, and the third, an updated version of "Bondgirls are Forever" hosted by Maryam D' Abo, the bondwoman in "The Living Daylights."  I enjoyed the "Bondgirls are Forever" featurette the most -- it featured insightful interviews with all the famous bondwomen- Ursula Andress (Dr. No), Luciana Paluzzi (villainess in Thunderball), Honor Blackman (Goldfinger), Cary Lowell (License to Kill), Halle Berry (Die Another Day), Michelle Yeoh (Tomorrow Never Dies), Judi Dench and Samantha Bond (all the Pierce Brosnan films), Rosamund Pike (Die Another Day), Jill St. John (Diamonds are Forever), and Maud Adams (Man with the Golden Gun, Octopussy).  It was very interesting to hear these actresses talk about how it feels to be a "bondgirl" and how it changed their lives.
summary: Craig reminds us of the early Connery 007

reviewText: **Beware - May Contain Spoilers**James Bond, the billion dollar movie character created by Ian Fleming makes his highly anticipated return to the screen in "Casino Royale".  After a long, drawn out search with the names of some of Hollywood's elite being tossed around as possible contenders to step into the infamous 007 shoes (and tux), British actor Daniel Craig was chosen."Casino Royale" starts off with the super agent making his second kill, a requirement in order to achieve his "double O" status.  Bond's next order of business puts him on the trail of a bomb maker in Madagascar.  After being admonished by M (Judi Dench) for the way things unraveled (and for breaking into her home), Bond follows the trail to the Bahamas where he meets Alex Dimitrios (Simon Abkarian) and his wife Solange (Caterina Murino).  He soon learns the scheme that Dimitrios is involved in:  to blow up one of the world's premiere jetliners in Miami.  Bond, however, has other plans and foils the plot.From there M informs 007 of the deadly Le Chiffre (Mads Mikkelsen), who lost a considerable amount of money when the jet's demise went awry.  Now desperate to get back the money, Le Chiffre plans an elaborate poker tournament.  With Bond as MI6"s best card player, they have no choice but to send him to Montenegro and back him in the tournament.  However, he doesn't go alone.  To make sure their initial investment of $10 million is secure, MI6 sends Vesper Lynd (Eva Green) to keep an eye on their assets.Once in Montenegro, the duo, who are supposed to pose as a couple madly in love, meet Mathis (Giancarlo Giannini), a field agent and later on, a CIA operative who is also in the poker tournament, Felix Leiter (Jeffrey Wright).  As the tournament intensifies, Bond and Vesper find themselves endangered when allies may not be who they appear to be.  Will Bond be able to stop Le Chiffre?  You'll have to watch "Casino Royale" to find out.With all of the press (some good and some bad) that's been surrounding not only the movie but also the announcement of a new Bond, this had to be one of the most anticipated movies of the year.  Film fans looking for an action packed 007 flick will not be disappointed.There were plenty of things that I liked about this one.  From the chase at the beginning of the movie to the scene where Le Chiffre is torturing Bond and even through the underwater sequences near the end, the movie is nothing short of intense.  But the film is not without its unique comedic timing particularly Bond's banter with M (when she threatens to have him killed if he reveals her true first name) and at other times with Vesper Lynd.  There are also a few funny moments with Mathis who seems to really enjoy his job!In "Casino Royale" we see a Bond that wasn't infallible.  Since Bond is new to the 007 gig, he does make mistakes and at times looses his cool.  We especially see this during the poker tournament when he, at one point, underestimates Le Chiffre.I also believe sometimes less is more.  The movie has almost no special effects and relies less on the gadgetry which were a bit detrimental to some of the previous Bond films.  This time around you're focused more on the story and what the people are up to on screen.The cast was also good and seemed to mesh well together.  Daniel Craig gives a good, solid performance as Bond as does Eva Green in the femme fatale role of Vesper Lynd.  It was also nice to see a little more screen time with Judi Dench as M.  A Bond film needs a truly memorable nemesis and Mads Mikkelsen as Le Chiffre delivers on this.There were a couple of things I would like to have seen in the movie.  There's only a brief introduction to Felix Leiter in the film so a little more screen time would have been nice, but probably not necessary in the scheme of things.  Also, at times, the poker tournament seemed to drag on a little.I questioned three other things about the movie.  Was Mathis really working for the enemy?  Where did Mr. White (Jesper Christensen) fit into all this?  "Casino Royale" never really answers this.  It could be assumed that these are cliffhangers that will be answered in the next Bond installment due out in 2008.My other question is (and this one is a major spoiler in case you want to stop reading here...), what were Vesper Lynd's true intentions/motivations?  One could argue that she really had feelings for James (who's about to leave MI6 for her) while another plausible view is that she schemed against him the entire time for the sake of her kidnapped boyfriend (who we're never told if he is released or murdered).  These are just minor things and do not detract from the overall movie.There's a lot to live up to with any 007 film.  "Casino Royale" delivers plenty of punch and helps to pave the way for the new direction that the Bond franchise is headed in with Daniel Craig."Casino Royale" runs 144 minutes and is rated PG-13 for intense sequences of violent action, scene of torture, sexual content and nudity.
summary: A New Bond, A New Direction

reviewText: The studio took a big risk with this film.They have basically abandoned the slap-stick comedy that has plagued Bond for 2 decades and created a very close and accurate portrayal of James Bond as written in the original novels from the 50s.These stories were dark, gritty and serious in tone.Of course it is safe to say that probably 95%+ of Bond fans only know James Bond from the movies, thus THEY may think this movie is off base for the character when it is actually the closest we have seen since 1962's "DR NO" when Sean Connery played a more serious Bond in the firt film.I know this is true because many critics of the film have attacked it for being very "un-Bond-like" when in fact it is almost dead on.Okay... the criticisms...1)Since this film is intended to explain how Bond earned his Double-0 license to kill, it theoretically of course pre-dates DR NO.This presents a problem for the nit-picky "Bond World Historians" since Bond's first boss "M" was a man.Also Daniel Craig appears a bit older than Sean Connery was in the first film.2) About Daniel Craig... His acting and dedication to playing this part wins you over out of respect.... BUT............. James Bond is supposed to have a "dark and cruel look".Okay.... with that stare, Craig has the cruel part down, but why couldn't they have darkened his hair a bit to at least visually match the Fleming description of Bond since they did everything else so accurately ?In the end, as I said above Daniel Craig earns your respect with his acting ability (I was NOT originally happy to hear he won the role.... I was hoping for somebody like the dark haired actor from SIN CITY---forgot his name right now).But Craig does capture the personality of the "Fleming Novel Version of Bond", even if the physical appearance is slightly off.Sidenote: I have always seen Craig as a villian for some reason, not a good guy..... but again I repeat..... he earned my respect to the point I accept him in the role.I hope they keep him on a serious side though, I don't want him to start throwing out one-liner comedy in the future.Since I am a Bond fan for over 30+ years, I for one was happy to see the studio scrap the silly humor, the "Bond Formula" that was being used in almost everyone of the last 10+ films, and the overemphasis on special effects and stunts simply for the sale of "eye candy".Finally we have a more gritty, dark and dangerous spy-vs-spy world with a tough Bond and not pretty boys grinning and smiling as they toss out one-liners like they know their lives are never in any real danger.I think the success of "24" on Fox and The Bourne Identity taught the studios a lesson..... people want the serious spy stories again and NOT the comical romps and frolics thru over-the-top CGI-land with bad guys that look like they came out of a Marvel Comic Book.Bond is Back !I hope the general viewing public is sharp enough to know or educate themselves on some Bond/Fleming history to appeciate this film for what it is.
summary: How many Bond fans have actually read Flemings' novels?

reviewText: Casino Royale is arguably one of the greatest 007 films of all time. Often placed #1 on lists and it's up there as well. Goldeneye was the last highly received film in the series and often regarded as Pierce Brosnan's only good movie (i personally enjoyed the next 2). Die Another Day was his last and was successful but bordering on sci-fi and fantasy at times, a lot of fans were disappointed. It was too much to take and didn't feel like a Bond film. Moonraker had a similar atmosphere which tend to go to far, after that they brought the series back to it's roots with For Your Eyes Only. Casino Royale brings the series back to it's roots and it was actually a remake of a '50s, made-for-TV movie staring Peter Lorre as Le Chiffre. The '50s movie is good and worth having in your collection but the 2006 version blows the original out of the water. Much closer to Ian Fleming's novel. Daniel Craig makes his debut as Bond here and he's easily the best Bond since Sean Connery. Vesper Lynd (played by Eva Green) is one of the better Bond girls and plays a strong lead character; Jeffrey Wright plays a good, believable role as Felix; Judi Dench continues as "M" (also in the Pierce Brosnan movies) in Casino Royale and plays a believable role as well.Casino Royale has a lot plot, action, emotion and character development which many Bonds lack. Opening scene is excellent as well, starting off in B&W; and changing to color during the theme with "You Know My Name" by Chris Cornell. A lot of people will say it's too far from Bond but the only closer adaptions are "From Russia With Love", "Dr. No" and "On Her Majesty's Secret Service". Roger Moore-era Bonds are a lot of fun to watch but nothing like Ian Fleming's Bond. Casino Royale ranks up there with the best Bonds and possibly the best action film of the '00s.

reviewText: The chase scene right at the beginning was enough to tell me this movie was not up the being a good Bond movie.  Die Another Day was pretty bad, but this...  Okay, I could accept Daniel Craig as James Bond.  He was not the problem here.  The problem was that this looked more like a 1970's Chuck Norris movie than a James Bond movie. (I loved Chuck Norris and his movies by the way).  This movie was about money.  No supervillains...Just money.  And can anyone really believe that the British government in a effort to thwart the bad guys would come up with a plan like this one?  Lets stake our best poker player to a few million and hope he wins.  No. Also, as I recall in earlier Bond films, (Goldfinger, I think) 007 was given him his Aston-Martin by Q.  He hadn't won it in a poker game.  Bond and action go together, but the climbing up the cranes and the jumping from crane to crane was way over the top.  Also, when Bond swerves his car to avoid hitting the girl in the road...Maybe the most ridiculous looking bit of fakery in recent big budget movie history. I did kind of like the collapsing building in Venice though I must admit. I gave this 2 stars only because it was James Bond and the closing theme was worth replaying.  James Bond needs to be more sauve...That's the appeal of the franchise.  Where was the wit?  Oh, I'm sorry, the line about that last hand almost killing me was it. I am willing to give Daniel Craig another chance.  Let's just hope they come up with a better script.  If they don't...Hey, Forced Vengeance with Chuck Norris is all the action I need...And he wears the suits well too.

reviewText: Plot Summary: A super-spy must stop terrorists from funding their activitiesReason for the Rating: Intense sequences of violent action, a scene of torture, sexual content and nudity.Bond...James Bond.How we love this spy who uses his suave personality and high-tech gadgets to catch his prey. If you like that Bond, and are hoping to see him again in Casino Royale, then you'll probably be surprised and possibly disappointed with this newest film in the franchise. But, if you have enjoyed the Mission Impossible and Bourne Identity movies, you'll love Daniel Craig as the new James Bond.This newest (oldest?) adventure of Bond is actually the first story in the series, explaining how he came to earn his 007 status, as well as some of the experiences that led to the smooth operator we've seen in previous movies. This Bond (Daniel Craig) is hard, arrogant, and brutal. He has no soul and has shut off all emotion, as he must do to be an effective killer - and this is at least one reason which explains his many sexual exploits without connection or personal meaning to the many "Bond girls" we've come to know through the past 20 movies.The plot of Casino Royale is a bit difficult to follow, as it jumps from bad guy to bad guy, until settling upon Le Chiffre (Mads Mikkleson), a banker who uses terrorist money to play the stock market. While Le Chiffre is creepy with a cloudy eye that weeps blood, he's not the evil villain we've seen in previous Bond movies. When James foils his plot to blow up an airplane, Le Chiffre loses $100 million and therefore, sets up a high stakes poker game to win back his losses and pay back his clients. Of course, Mr. Bond gets in on the action.This is one of the slowest parts of the movie, as it's hard to make a 2-day poker game exciting. Typically, we see this type of scene placed at the end of a movie, as the climax to the plot. In Casino Royale, the card game is in the middle of this 2 hour LONG movie. The story then moves on to Bond falling in love with the MI6 accountant, Vesper Lynd (Eva Green), only to jump back into the previous storyline (just when you think it's over, it starts all over again). While the love story is nice, it is really unnecessary and out of place. We are supposed to be convinced that this hard, cold killer is softened by this vulnerable woman and willing to quit the spy business altogether, all in the matter of two days. Unlikely.While Bond movies aren't supposed to be taken too seriously, the plot just doesn't hold up to scrutiny. Once Le Chiffre is found, why isn't he taken into custody? What was the purpose of playing the card game, just to arrest him at the end? Much of what Bond does, especially at the beginning, is unexplained, and his abilities are unbelievable. The characters lack depth, are predictable, and really aren't that likeable. Except, I must say, Daniel Craig does an excellent job of being a hard, mean, brutal killer. Most of the movie he sports numerous cuts on his hands and face, and many of the fight scenes and murders are ugly and graphic. He is focused and determined.Unlike previous Bond movies, Casino Royale does not employ the use of interesting gadgets. Q and Moneypenny are missing from the story as well, with the only other familiar character being M (Judi Dench). M isn't so impressed with Bond, calling him a "blunt instrument" at one point, as he lacks refinement and discretion. He's such a loose cannon, she has a tracking device inserted into the inside of his wrist and has someone watching over him the rest of his assignment. Not quite the James Bond you expect to see, but by the end of the movie he has begun to show some of the qualities we have come to know in James Bond.MOVIEBLOG RECOMMENDS:If you like action movies, you will undoubtedly enjoy this one, but don't go expecting to see what we've seen in Sean Connery, Roger Moore or Pierce Brosnan. This is a new James Bond, re-invented for a new, harder-edged audience.Additionally, it is unbelievable that the movie is rated PG-13, as it really should be R for the torture scene specifically. This movie is for adults and older teens.AFTER THE SHOW:* What did you like or dislike about the new James Bond? Is there anything from previous Bond movies you would like to have seen?* Bond is described as having no soul, meaning his lack of conscience and emotion. Do you think someone like this could be changed so dramatically, as portrayed in the movie? Explain.* In what areas has God changed you, softening and refining your rough edges?JW
