reviewText: PLOTIn this prequel-style instalment, a young James Bond is promoted to "00" status and deployed on various missions; some physical, some cerebral, some emotional.REVIEWTo me, there's the first three Connery films - more thrillers than action films - all of them deserving credit. Then there's all the dated and boring entries spanning the ensuing 30 years, with only the very occasional exception. And then there's Daniel Craig and his Casino Royale. The real James Bond has kindly stood up.There are at least two sequences that I will always remember from this film. The first precedes the opening credits, where Bond "earns his stripes"; the second is where he overcomes an attempt on his life whilst playing poker. I cannot go into these exquisite moments in any more detail because I'll ruin the film for those who haven't seen it.Of course, for the explosion fanatics, there are plenty of heavy-duty action scenes worthy of note, especially one taking place at Miami airport. For the torture scene, I was hoping for the thing that the Chinese do with water droplets, but I wasn't let down too badly...It's great to see they've trashed the "Q" and/or "R" characters, and Moneypenny, and that stupid character played by Robbie Coltrane, and given all such residual screen time to Judi Dench's "M" and the new Felix Leiter (played understatedly by Jeffery Wright).  They've also eased-up on the mindless "nightcap" affairs. Instead, one core emotional encounter comes slowly into focus, and we finally get a glimpse at why Bond became the way he is.SPECIAL MENTIONSDaniel Craig for Acting.

reviewText: I wasn't happy upon hearing about MGM's misfortunes and purchase by Sony.  I was especially unhappy upon hearing of a re-booting for James Bond as well, having grown somewhat fond of Pierce Brosnan in the role of agent 007, even though his films had grown stale over time, but little did I know just how good things would get.  Casino Royale is just the kick in the pants that the long running franchise has needed; inserting Daniel Craig (Layer Cake, Road to Perdition, Munich) as James Bond, as well as overhauling everything else.  This time around deals with Bond's origin as he sets off on his first mission as a double-O; getting involved in an ultra-high stakes poker game to nail a scarred, inhaler puffing terrorist financier (Mads Mikkelsen) who weeps blood.  Things get a little more complicated when Bond falls head over heals for treasury agent Vesper Lynd (Eva Green) as the twisty plot unfolds over the course of the film's running time; which also includes some spectacular action sequences, stunt work, violence which pushes the limits of the film's PG-13 rating, and a torture scene that really will make you wince.  Martin Campbell, who directed Brosnan's debut as Bond with Goldeneye, leaves a considerable mark with Casino Royale, providing nearly everything he did that made Goldeneye a memorable Bond film.  And as far as Craig goes as the new 007, well, he's great.  He has the right mix of charisma, style, and dark demeanor that it takes to be a great Bond, and he fits the mold like a well tailored suit.  Judi Dench returns as M, but don't expect any Q, John Cleese, or Moneypenny here.  Indeed, as said before, Casino Royale is the kick in the teeth that the James Bond franchise needed, and fresh air is breathed into the franchise from Craig, Campbell, and everyone else involved.  Undoubtadly the best Bond film in years, Casino Royale is a treat for Bond fans new and old alike.
summary: The best Bond movie in years

reviewText: "Casino Royale" blew me away. It is a fantastic movie in every way, and also the best Bond so far! I have always liked Pierce Brosnan (for some reason, other people didn't) in this prestigious role, and now that he has retired as a 00 agent, it is great to see someone even better replace him."Casino Royale" revisits the beginnings of the well-known British secret agent, and it does so in a very stylish manner. Every second of the movie is carefully thought out, and it really is perfect. James Bond is now played by Daniel Craig ("Elizabeth", "Sylvia", "Lara Croft: Tomb Raider"), who adds an interesting twist to this well-known character. Apparently, in the beginning, Bond couldn't care less if his martini was shaken or stirred, his first kill was pretty rough and not at all elegant, and he was also a little kinky. Of course, he has always been very cool, with the latest gadgets, fast cars and beautiful women.Speaking of women, "Casino Royale" doesn't disappoint. The latest Bond girl is Eva Green. As every good Bond girl should be, she is not both beautiful AND brainy, and is very believable in her role. Also, she is one of few 007 love interests to not be interested in Mr. Bond... until she is, of course.And of course, there is action involved, and lots of it. However, the movie is very smart - not all action consists of explosions, guns and foreign assassins (although, it's not like these elements aren't there!). In order for Bond to successfully accomplish his mission, this time he doesn't need to kill anybody... he needs to win a game of poker. Although this may sound like a major turn-off, it is magnificently executed - the scenes around the table are awesome, exciting and full of drama. Also, there is a sub-plot involved, because you don't just become 007: there is something for Bond, James Bond to do before he gains his title."Casino Royale" is one of the most satisfying movies to come out in 2006. It is everything a James Bond movie should be, and then some. Judi Dench is at her usual super-self, Eva Green is mesmerizing, and Daniel Craig... let's just say he might as well be the ultimate James Bond!

reviewText: This motion picture, directed by Martin Campbell (Goldeneye) created a dichotomy in my family and in my movie-going community: one side was utterly disappointed, even disgusted, and the other side surprisingly impressed. For once, I sided with the critics--many who extoled this latest of Bond films for its refreshing candor, dark edge and gritty realism. I say, for once, because, more often than not, I have taken the opposite side of the majority of critics (see my other reviews here and elsewhere), finding gems where others have found only rock. This time I have good company; except for my own family and friends, that is. It would seem that, although Casino Royale was highly regarded by the critics of the franchise, its long-standing viewing public was not equally impressed. Yes, this was a different Bond movie, which the Mandelbrot fractal designed title opening and title song hinted at: did you listen to the words of the title song?Of those in the negative camp there appear to be two major reasons for rejecting this lastest version of Bond. One is the Bond character himself (played with edgy grit by tautly coiled Daniel Craig) and how the other characters were portrayed (especially Bond Girl,Vesper Lynd, superbly played by Eva Green but with no revealing cleavage); the second is the lack of Bond clichés, such as the techno-gadgetry, non-stop action, womanizing and comic-book humour. Despite showcasing some of the most mouth-watering chase scenes (particularly the opening chase with parkour [free running] originator, Sebastién Foucan, and Craig doing most of the stunts himself), this Bond film was a more thoughtful one. It was also probably one of the most physically demanding Bond films to play by its lead character. David Edelstein of New York Magazine, describes the director's "awe for the poetry of human bodies doing things that, evolutionarily speaking, they haven't needed to do since the saber-toothed tiger died off."There are, I think, several reasons for this dichotomy between those of us who loved Casino Royale and those who remained diffident, disappointed or outright disliked it. One of which--and it is I think an important one--is that I have read the entire series, and long before a flashy movie was made using the title (often only using the title!). I grew up with Sean Connery as the quintessential Bond, a roughly handsome man with striking eyes and a cruel mouth.In the book version of Casino Royale, Vesper Lynd, after just meeting Bond, admits to Mathis: "He is very good looking...but there is something cold and ruthless in his [mouth]..." Ian Fleming's Bond is a somber misogynist who initially wants to bed Vesper as if to punish her for not falling for his charm:Her eyes were wide apart and deep blue and they gazed candidly back at Bond with a touch of ironical disinterest which, to his annoyance, he found he would like to shatter, roughly.I would not describe Campbell's Bond as a misogynist, despite tendencies for being a ruthless sociopath with a slightly sadistic sense of humour. After Casino Royale and his experience with one particular woman, he might have turned into one, though...Daniel Craig and those scintillating radioactive blue eyes brings us back to why we are ultimately fascinated with the character of James Bond. Think for a moment: this man is basically a sociopath, an assassin with a license to kill, dispense violence and torture to protect queen and country--a concept. Well, perhaps not quite a concept. Which brings us to M, Bond's pithy superior in MI-6 in the British Secret Service. Bond is like a child in many ways, emotionally certainly. David Edelstein of New York Magazine describes Craig's Bond as: "haunted, not yet housebroken, still figuring out his persona."The movie series--and this film in particular--explores this aspect of Bond through his complex relationship with M (played superbly by Dame Judi Dench). M is like a mother to him. His allegiance to queen and country, so prevalent in many of the Bond movies, appears a natural progression of this intuitive search to belong and connect, particularly in his reltionship with M. He breaks into her private house, not for a moment realizing--or capable of caring-- what this invasion of privacy means to her. M scolds Bond like he is a child and calls him a "blunt instrument". Says M: "Any thug can kill. I want you to take your ego out of the equation." Craig's Bond is the closest to the original character envisaged by Fleming, who describes Bond's features as "a taciturn mask, ironical, brutal, and cold." Carrie Rickey of the Philadelphia Inquirer describes Craig as "earthy and exotic, holding himself like a smoking gun."Thanks to excellent script writing by Neal Purvis, Robert Wade and Paul Haggis, it is Vesper Lynd in the movie who recognizes that Bond is an orphan, looking for home--though she doesn't call him on the latter. Bond is a man who doesn't recognize boundaries, who's closed off his emotions from the rest of him.The length to which he protects that inner vulnerable self is evident in his rakish and shallow relationships with women. After Vesper insists on separate rooms at the hotel, Bond says, "Don't worry. You're not my type." To which she tartly quips, "Smart?" And he responds, "Single." This is more elaborately described in the book:Bond saw luck as a woman, to be softly wooed or brutally ravaged, never pandered to or pursued...One day, and he accepted the fact, he would be brought to his knees by love or by luck. When that happened he knew that he too would be branded with the deadly question-mark he recognized so often in others, the promise to pay before you have lost; the acceptance of fallibility.It is so apt that Vesper Lynd is the one to shatter his cool and it is she (in the form of luck and love) who literally brings him to his knees by the last pages of the book with her tragic act of suicide.Despite a truly chilling villain in Le Chiffre (played by Mads Mikkelsen) and that frightening souless Mister White (keep an eye on him from the first scene; I think he will resurface in Bond 22), it is not the villains in Casino Royale who place equal footing with Bond; it is the two women in his life. I found atypical "Bond Girl" Vesper Lynd (his alluring and mysterious foil with dark depth) and M, his forthright boss, equally compelling and complex as Bond. They, better than the villains, help to define Bond and permit the film to rise from the shallows of its predecesors into the interesting arena of real art.This definitive Bond film, begins appropriately wtih a slick black and white prologue of Bond's pre `00' status (prior to achieving two kills). The heady and violent chiaroscuro creates a mood in keeping with the edgy grit of Craig's Bond, "whose cruel charisma rivals that of Sean Connery" (Ty Burr, Boston Globe). Every scene that follows defines Bond: his ruthless drive in the footchase; his sardonic humor when he's mistaken for a valet and "punishes" the customer by crashing his expensive car, marking Bond's disdain for the declassé rich (a trait that is further made apparent during Vesper's penetrating analysis of him in the train).Producer, Barbara Broccoli, successfully subverted the Bond trope to finally portray a "Bond Girl" as equal to Bond; someone equally complex, mysterious and interesting with her own compelling story, so much so that she draws the insular Bond into it. "The idea of a woman who is Bond's equal is unusual in the 007 series," says Jay Stone of the Times Colonist in his article entitled, "Bond Girl with Brains". Vesper is a compelling character, a real person; not just a mannequin for men to fantacize over. There have been other intelligent and strong-willed Bond Girls (e.g., Jinx in Die Another Day; Polly Goodhead in Moonraker; Natalya Simonova in Goldeneye), but none as engaging, none as vulnerable, contradictory and multi-layered as Vesper, who harbors a dark secret. It is partly Vesper's dark secret that unknowingly clinches Bond's interest. Vesper demonstrates right from her opening scene where she first meets Bond onboard a Euro fast train that she is not a typical Bond girl. First there is no gushy "Oh, she's gaspingly beautiful!" music to accompany her on-screen entrance; no highlighting of her physical attributes; no bikini to cue us in that she is the "Bond Girl".Instead, Vesper sweeps in like a summer storm and sits across from Bond, dressed in what he describes as "slightly masculine cut clothing" and flashes him with eyes that sparkle of taunting girlish impudence. As she takes her seat, she summarily announces "I'm the money," succinctly letting him know that she is in charge and what she thinks of him. Even his attempt at a rakish response, "Every penny of it," doesn't phase her and she launches into a sarcastic examination of the plan, further letting him know what she thinks of the whole plan of poker: "I suppose you've given some thought to the notion that if you lose, our government will have directly financed terrorism". So she'll be keeping her eye on their government's money and not on Bond's "perfectly formed" backside. To this Bond quips, "You noticed." Vesper has a quick come back: "Even accountants have imagination." To his suggestion of a plan, "Oh, there's a plan," she responds in a mocking tone. "I got the impression we were risking millions of dollars and hundreds of lives on a game of chance." Then she challenges him on his ability to bluff and read people (which provides the first in several installments of a subplot involving bluffing and "tells").Their verbal joust, which sizzles with sexual tension, escalates when Bond, priding himself in his ability to read people, demonstrates his skill as a poker player by arrogantly analyzing Vesper's personality and life from cues in their conversation. She turns the tables by doing an even more penetrating character sketch of him, calling him on his hubris and ego, and essentially outbluffing him:"By the cut of your suit you went to Oxford or wherever and actually think human beings dress like that. But you wear it with such disdain. My guess is you didn't come from money and your school friends never let you forget it, which means you were at that school by the grace of someone else's charity, hence the chip on your shoulder...and since your first thought about me ran to orphan, that's what I'd say you are..." Seeing his expression, she gloats, "Oh, you are! I like this poker thing. And it makes perfect sense. Since MI6 looks for maladjusted young men who give little thought to sacrificing others in order to protect queen and country. You know, former SAS types, with easy smiles and expensive watches..." She glances down at his. "Rolex?" Then dives in for the killing blow: "Now, having just met you, I wouldn't go as far as calling you a cold-hearted bastard...but it wouldn't be a stretch to imagine you think of women as disposable pleasures rather than meaningful pursuits."But more than outbluffing him, Vesper also proves herself to be a complex person on her own "hero's journey", a tortured character (we find out only later) with heavy matters to consider that involve more than the Bond girl's typical single question: "should I sleep with this guy or not?" The fullness and depth of her character as a "real" person is no better found than in the tender shower scene midway, where we are reminded that Vesper is a real person, an accountant unused to violence. Again, we find Bond about to enter their common bathroom to the sounds of a shower; I fully expected to see the typical playful scene between the Bond girl, nude in the shower, and Bond. But when he opens the door, she is revealed sitting under the shower, still fully clothed in her evening gown, shivering in shock. She'd just witnessed (and had even helped) a violent altercation in which Bond had to beat a man to death. For the first time in this series, we have a perfectly plausible reaction. Vesper is strong at first and assists Bond by helping to force the gun out of the assailant's hand, then breaks down after she's done what needs to be done and is alone. Bond surprises us by melting into a caring human being as he quietly and patiently comforts Vesper. And Broccoli tastefully does not let it dissolve into a sexual love scene. This scene is just one of several where the film takes a typical Bond cliché and brazenly turns it on its side--where we expect one thing and get quite another. An amusing example of this is when Bond playfully informs Vesper, as they are driving to their hotel, of her cover name ("Miss Stephanie Broadchest") to which she takes great exception.Vesper certainly has Bond sized up. "There are dinner jackets and there are dinner jackets," Vesper informs the bemused Bond in an earlier scene. She introduces him to the tailored tuxedo, in which he looks utterly splendid, by the way. The scene where he critically eyes himself in the mirror in his new tux provides us with a snapshot that is all Bond (and all Craig, I should add!): suave, sophisticated and mercurial, yet boyishly inviting, even awkward. Eva Green's "Vesper is teasing, angry, and vulnerable in madly unpredictable proportions" David Edelstein (New York Magazine) adds. A smart, self-possessed government accountant, Vesper "has the sensuality and extraordinary empathy to tenderize [Bond's] presence," said Scragow of the Baltimore Sun. Broccoli improved on Fleming's Vesper by making her a treasury accountant in charge of the money, and therefore of Bond.Keeping true to Fleming's first James Bond book, the film version of Casino Royale is, at its heart, a tragic love story. As Stax (IGN) says: "Bond falls in love, he changes; he cares for a woman rather than just lusts after her. They make love, laugh, quarrel but there is a friendship and tenderness between them. That makes the outcome of the story and Bond's infamous last line--`the bitch is dead'--all the more heartbreaking". Casino Royale is a story of how a scarred man found his humanity through love, only to loose both to the `game'. The irony of what Bond became, following Vesper's death, lies in her absolute mastery of him. Her power over his heart was elegantly shown as she both physically and metaphorically jumpstarted it. In fact, she saves his life twice. In the end she beats him with the ultimate bluff, beating him squarely at his own game. When she realizes that she will never escape SPECTRE, Vesper successfully hides her tortured decision to save Bond by ironically betraying him. In keeping with the book, Vesper's character is tormented by her genuine love for Bond and her conviction that he would hate her once he learned the truth about her--compelling her to end her life. The reason she succeeds so well in outbluffing him (and the audience) is because in matters of the heart she is tenderly sincere. As Bond himself declared to her, "Everyone has a `tell'...except you...that's why I love you." Blinded by their mutual love, he is totally sidewinded by her underhandedness. This explains why Bond later refuses to lower his armor and become vulnerable with any other woman; how can he trust his spy-sense when matters of the heart intersect and blur his cold judgement? He must, Bond concludes, keep them apart, tuck that humanity way inside, never let it get out again.While some of the movie-Bond tropes are there...they are few and well placed and just enough to remind us of how Bond uses off-colour humor to disarm or even to disturb. After a near-fatal interlude during the film's card game, he quips, "I'm sorry, that last hand nearly killed me."Another cliché which this film turned on its side is the classic figure emerging out of the sea--this time not the Bond Girl, but Bond himself. To those who lament the old clichés, Ty Burr of the Boston Globe offers this: "consider whether, after twenty-one Bond films and countless parodies, your response is simply Pavlovian." Grow up. Bond has.

reviewText: 3.5 stars.  Granted, I'm not a huge Bond fan.  The ones I've seen over the years late 80's on up have all had very forgettable storylines. Still I liked it better than the Bronson films.

reviewText: Critics gave the film a positive response, in particular Craig's performance and credibility. During production this had been subject to debate by the media and the public, as Craig did not appear to fit Ian Fleming's original portrait of the character as tall, dark, and suave. The Daily Telegraph compared the quality of Craig's characterization of Bond to Sean Connery's and praised the script as smartly written, noting how the film departed from the series' conventions. The Times compared the more assertive portrayal by Craig to Timothy Dalton, and praised the action as edgy,[64] with another reviewer citing in particular the action sequence involving the cranes in Madagascar.[65] Critics Paul Arendt of BBC Films,[66] Kim Newman of Empire[67] and Todd McCarthy of Variety[68] all described Craig as the first actor to truly embody Ian Fleming's James Bond from the original novel: ironic, brutal, and cold.The film was similarly well received in North America. MSNBC gave the movie a perfect 5 star rating.[69] The film was described as taking James Bond "back to his roots", similar to From Russia with Love,[70] where the focus was on character and plot rather than the high-tech gadgets and visual effects that were strongly criticised in Die Another Day.[68] Rotten Tomatoes gave the movie an aggregate rating of 94%, the highest rating for a wide-release of the year. It is the fifth-highest rating for a Bond film on the site behind Goldfinger which received a 95%, The Spy Who Loved Me and From Russia with Love which both received a 96%,[71][72] and Dr. No, with a 97% score.[73] Metacritic gave the movie a Metascore of 81, signifying "Universal Acclaim."[74] Entertainment Weekly named the film as the fifth best of the series,[75] and chose Vesper Lynd as the fourth best Bond girl in the series.[76] Some newspaper columnists and critics were impressed enough by Craig's performance to consider him a viable candidate for an Academy Award nomination.[77][78][79] Roger Ebert gave the film a four out of four star rating, the first for any of the James Bond films he reviewed. Ebert stated that Casino Royale answered many of the questions he had begun to ask himself about the 45-year-old series, like why no character seems to have any real emotions. Ebert also felt that this was the first Bond film that got him to care about Bond, and the rest of the characters.[80]However, the film met several mixed reactions. Though American radio personality Michael Medved gave the film three stars out of four, describing it as "intriguing, audacious and very original... more believable and less cartoonish, than previous 007 extravaganzas", he commented that the "sometimes sluggish pacing will frustrate some Bond fanatics."[81] Similarly, a reviewer for The Sun praised the film for its darkness and Craig's performance, but felt that "like the novel, it suffers from a lack of sharpness in the plot" and believed that it required additional editing, particularly the finale.[82] Commentators such as Emanuel Levy concurred, feeling the ending was too long, and that the film's terrorist villains lacked depth, although he praised Craig and gave the film a B+ overall.[83] Other reviewers responded negatively, including Tim Adams of The Observer who felt the film came off uncomfortably in an attempt to make the series grittier.[84]
summary: A NEW JAMES BOND WITH STEROIDS!

reviewText: First of all, anyone would love this movie if they like action.  Many Bond fans will hail Craig as the new and best bond, but thats just because hes new.  Everyone said that about Brosnan after Goldeneye, and I bet they said it almost every time a new Bond opened with a good first movie.So, let me start by saying, however, the film rocked. Really, I loved it. So why the three stars instead of 4 or 5?  Because it didn't feel like Bond to me.  It had some of the musical feel (not enough use of the original theme though), the same characters, but so many things were missing.  Q, Moneypenny, and an appropriate intro.  Yes, I hated the intro. Why? No girls. I'm not a pervert, but virtually every other Bond intro had girls dancing to the movie's theme. Not so in this film.  Instead we faced the polar opposite; guys getting shot and beaten up.  It was artistically done, and Bondworthy, if only there had been some lady silhouettes to balance it.This movie tries so hard to set itself apart from other Bond movies the way Batman Begins set itself apart from other Batman movies.  It worked for Batman Begins, but thats because the other Batman movies sucked for the most part.  There is nothing wrong with the rest of the Bond franchise as a whole (except for Lazenby).This new movie is also notably gritty and too realistic.  Other Bond movies had ridiculous plots, usually involving something in space (like the moon, or a satellite) or some distant island with a midget or maybe some lasers or advanced nuclear technology, and lets not forget Jaws Jackson or Oddjob.  This one had a less crazy plot about a private Banker stealing money from his clients and having some big Poker Tournament. Now less crazy isn't necessarily bad. At least it got rid of some of the camp in the Bond films.  But it still needs that element of Fantasy that makes it a modern spy movie.  There's no invisible car in this one, there's no remote control car either, and there's no laser guns or ethnic midgets.It feels unfulfilling to see everything that made Bond such a unique franchise go remiss in this newest installment.  So, don't get me wrong, the movie rocked. However, I still wish there was a little more Bond in this Bond film.  Daniel Craig, great job, director and script writer, bad bad bad.
summary: Great movie, but strays too far from Bond formula

reviewText: The first hour is filled with not credible, idiotic action sequences & ugly cinematography. For instance, Bond runs through a wall...really!? Sure, you can run through drywall, but not without knowing what's on the other side! What idiot would try to run through a wall? Bond.It takes about an hour before the film decides to read the book, but then the film turns Bond into a dufus who can't think for himself and has to have women think for him and dress him, which is NOT any Bond we've ever known, in film nor book.Bond used to be a man's man..now, he's a feminist's sex symbol..you know, the incompetent guy who is eye candy for the women, but is incapable of self reliance and has to be corrected by the nearest woman at every turn because he can't think for himself and if he tries, then he's wrong. Bond's male audience doesn't want to watch Bond walk out of the ocean ala Ursula Andress. Only the homosexual screenwriters/director and women. Yet, that's what this film does. Also, Bond can't save himself in this film, but has to have women save him.The James Bond Theme song is mostly absent, which destroys the Bond feel. Bond no longer cares if his martini is shaken or stirred. The point of this film is to deconstruct and destroy Bond with only a superficial connection to the book. Anything that Bond would do is mocked, anything that a man would do is mocked. Anything that a women used to do in the older films is now done by a man.They said it was because this film was a new beginning. For the next film they blamed its shortcomings on MGM's bankruptcy. For Skyfall (you know, that generic action film that's missing the heart, soul and spirit of ANY James Bond in film and book where they tried to push homosexuality into Bond), they put the normal opening at the end, once again stating that it's because of a new beginning. I'm tired of their pathetic excuses.Bond is dead. Those now in charge are trying to turn him into a generic action figure that is no longer a man's man, but a feminist/homosexual idol to please the desires of the screenwriters and bankrupt Hollywood. Bond is now a generic feminist with no relation to Ian Fleming's Bond nor the Bond film history.As usual with the Bond films, they ignore the book for the most part, so there's still potential to make a lot of Bond films that actually follow the books. Unfortunately, those now in charge of his legacy don't like Ian Fleming's Bond and are bent on destroying him to turn him into someone else.
summary: Ian Fleming's Bond and the classic Bond is Dead

reviewText: A simply excellent Bond continuing the legacy of Broccoli Productions that has left the world with the icon of intrigue and espionage.  This new release with Daniel Craig as the new Bond is simply a briliant comeback for a film franchise that, in terms of plots and iconic significance, was losing its appeal as the fossil of a cold war entertainment dinosaur.Here Casino Royale is revamped with a credible plot and a more dynamic Bond who is clearly a vulnerable human being rather than a superhero of the espionage world who never flinches.  Daniel Craig brings both vitality and vulnerability into the character of Bond and this brings a lot of tension into the story's plot.  Instead of just going through the motions of a predictable action-packed plot, Bond is filled with uncertainty as to the mission's players and ultimate success.  Judi Dench's cold beuraucratic and feminist "M" also adds a lot more tension into the plot than the franchise's previous stuffy and aristocratic "M" by virtue of her relationship to the still mysogenist Bond.  Mads Mikkelsen as Le Chiffre is excellent as Bond's cold-blooded nemesis who plays for keeps.A simply excellent beginning for this almost 50-year old franchise's 6th replacement for Bond.  Replacing Pierce Brosnan was no easy task and it is hard to fathom how they could have found someone better than Craig to replace him.  This is certainly one of the most memorable Bonds to have been produced and it is worthy of purchase.
Title: N/A

reviewText: 1. the writing is as tight as anything in the Bourne series: believable, taut, nerve wracking, heart racing and frightening2. the cinematography is breathtaking3. the music enhances the film as no Bond music has since John Barry gave up the franchise4. the acting is phenomenal, and it begins and ends with Craig. If you caught him in LAYER CAKE or MUNICH, you know he has an edge that is ruthless and sociopathic. The man looks and acts like a killer. This is the Bond that Fleming had in mind, and while Connery got close, even he wasn't this good. Forget everyone who followed, and to some extent that is a function of the writing as much as the acting. Not in this one, given the state of decline in the Bond series, it would all fall on Craig, and he delivers with deadly accuracy. If he does no more Bond films, he will have nonetheless rescued the franchise for the foreseeable future.But it isn't just him. Dench seems delighted to play a real woman in charge, and not someone doing walk-on ripostes witha cardboard actor. There is both palpable tension and sexual attraction to the interplay between M and Bond that teeters close to Oedipal undercurrents. Bond is a man with precious little conscience. This film goes a long way to explaining how and why. The villains are perfect: intelligent, duplicitous, treacherous thugs as ready to club and torture a victim as delight in the scheming and the betrayals. Who is really who eludes you throughout the film. The women are diabolical and intelligent. No bimbos. Each of the women is some projection of M, like a diamond turning and catching the light in its facets. Understandably, it isn't a direct line, but step back and consider when M appears in each scene and why, and there's as much going on here as there was in Silence of The Lambs. Except we have Vodka instead of Chianti.The movie is nearly free of product placement, and happily free of Cleese. He was never Q, and he should have been dropped a long time ago. Sony, Ford and Aston Martin make cameos, as does Bollinger, but all of them are less as prominent as they were with Brosnan, and never, ever get in the way. What happens to the Aston will break your heart, and maybe that's also the point. Everyone defined by their possessions is destroyed in this film.I don't want to say too much about it, other than you will read in some newspaper reviews that the card game seemed long. BS. It fairly flies and is so wrought with tension you'll find yourself holding your breath. The original book was based on the game of Baccarat and the financing of organized crime. This is poker and the financing of terrorism. Craig was determined "to keep it real." He did. In Spades. If you recall LAYER CAKE, about the last thing he says to the camera is "and I never told you my name....". Thus the theme song and the very final scene in this film resolve that.It is a long movie, but it has so much heart and soul, you won't want it to end. It's violent, no nonsense crime, spies and peril. The women are both sexual objects and radical challenges to his perception of himself. And if the producers know what's good for them, they will take the lessons of this film and carry them forward. When the James Bond Theme kicks in at the end of the film, everyone in the theatre applauded. Well done, Daniel.
summary: The best Bond movie ever for a number of reasons

reviewText: I wouldn't go as far as describing this movie as the "Best Bond Ever" but it is certainly one of my favourites. And I've seen them all.Daniel Craig had his doubters right from the minute it was announced that he was to take the role of 007, especially in the UK tabloid press. I personally couldn't work out what all the fuss was about (though one rumour suggested, completely ridiculously, that it was because he is blond and has blue eyes). I'd only ever seen him in one other role, in Steven Spielberg'sMunich (Widescreen Edition)and I thought he did a pretty decent job in that. I remember thinking at the time, let's give the dude a chance. Maybe he'll pull it off.Well, pull it off he did and while (sadly) there'll never be another Connery or Moore, or (thankfully), another Dalton or Brosnan, and while I accept that Craig might not have the smooth charm of any of his predecessors, he is edgier, grittier and much more believable than any of them as an agent in Her Majesty's secret spy service, MI6. This is definitely a 21st century Bond. He relies much more on his licence to kill than on smooth talking the ladies or on fancy gadgets (there's no Moneypenny or even a Q in this one) and when he does kill, he does it with a ruthless efficiency.This is an action packed thriller - the opening free running scenes with parkour supremo Sébastien Foucan alone are worth the price of the DVD - with most of the tension centred round a poker game played at the Casino that gives the movie its name. Judi Dench is her usual awesome self as M and I would say that Isaach De Bankole as the deadly Steven Obanno is also worth watching out for. The premise of this whole movie is that it takes place before Bond is ever given "00" status and I suppose that to make that premise authentic, the movie should've been based in the late 50s or early 60s or something but I'm not complaining. Period dramas never did it for me anyway. Purists may have anxieties about this new Bond, most especially about his raw brutality, but everything has to move on eventually.I say hats off to Daniel Craig for reinventing a role that was in danger of going stale. Bond may be a bit more politically correct (see his romance with Eva Green's Treasury Officer Vesper Lynd) but again, these are the times we live in.

reviewText: I have to admit that I have seen every James Bond movie. I used to watch the marathons on TBS during summer vacation when I was in elementary school. (Marathons also watched include...Elvis musicals and Frankie Avalon beach movies.) Casino Royale has changed the texture of the Bond genre. Gone are the tired cliches of the classic James bond movies, we now get to see a little bit into the mind of James Bond (He has a mind?) and begin to understand his motivations. I have to applaud the film makers in picking this particular book as a platform for the new James Bond, Daniel Craig, it allows Bond to start over in film and in person.I have read the book, and while the film is different, I didn't like it any less. Daniel Craig brings a realness to James Bond that hasn't been seen for a long time. It was great to see all of the cheesiness removed and a physically fit and young guy play the lead! I highly recommend this film to all Bond and non-Bond fans.

reviewText: It is appropriate that "Casino Royale", the first of the James Bond books (1953), would also be the first James Bond film to get a makeover. The original 1967 film was not just the black sheep of the series, but a bizarre departure from pretty much everything the franchise stood for. Which made it the best candidate for a remake which itself drastically breaks away from many Bond film conventions.The new "Casino Royale" represents a welcome invigoration of a series at a crossroads where it either had to reinvent itself or retire. As the least elaborate and most basic of Ian Fleming's series, the story adapts well to a gritty no-nonsense treatment. Basically it is the origin story of 007 and Daniel Craig, doing a reprise of his performance in "Layer Cake", steps in as the new (and the most like Fleming's original) Bond. He is more out-of-control dashing than suave and sophisticated.  While the young James Bond is immature and overconfident, he comes by these traits honestly being both a very competent and a very maladjusted young man. Which means a mean streak and a soft side unlike any Bond before him.Unlike the sound stage sets of the original "Casino Royale", the remake makes extensive use of exotic location shooting. The events in the films and the book center around a high stakes game (Texas hold-em poker here-baccarat in the others) as the villain Le Chiffre attempts to add funds to his agency's treasury at the gaming tables (the present day setting of the film requires the insertion of terrorist connections).For longtime fans of the franchise, Casino Royale offers some retro kicks. The film nicely blends virtuoso action sequences with sexy romance; and throws in a torture sequence more in the tradition of "The Ipcress Files" than "Goldfinger.This is serious stuff, not the self-parody and cartoonish antics which had begun to dominate the productions even before the Brosnan era. At first the new direction might seem a considerable gamble, but while there was no guarantee of success the producers had little to lose except production costs because the franchise was so close to fading away. Something rugged and unconventional was needed and that is exactly what the new "Casino Royale" delivers.  The gritty opening scenes (featuring desaturated images) flashback to Bond as he is earning his 007 designation with brutal assassinations in a public bathroom and office. No silly gadgets (at least not really silly) or "Man From UNCLE" quips. There is a gray Aston Martin and the best car chase in Bond film history.The new Le Chiffre is no Orsen Welles; and must rely on a bleeding non-functional eye for his creepiness. The interplay between Bond and Vesper Lynds (Eva Green) works quite well.The writing team of Neal Purvis, Robert Wade, and Paul Haggis provide a particularly nice script and it is fair to say that this version of "Casino Royale" ranks up there with the best of the series.Then again, what do I know? I'm only a child.
summary: A Nice Change of Pace for the Series

reviewText: Let me preface this review by saying I'm not much of an action film fan and I've never seen a 007 movie.  I rented this one because there was a lot of hype around the film and I heard it was different than most Bond films.  I wish I hadn't watsted my time.  This film is every action movie cliché wrapped into one.  I couldn't even finish this over the top borefest.  Of course this is full of action sequences like we've all seen before, ie., one secret agent taking on a small army, sexy babes and fast exotic cars.  The real turning point for me was the part after Bond sees a bikini clad sexy woman riding a white horse along the beach in front of her mansion, he then wins her husbands 1964 Aston Martin in a high stakes Texas Hold 'Em game.  I'm sure any guy out there who wants to see a testosterone filled, macho film will love this.  But I'll pass...

reviewText: Not really.Many things have been changed around, and although stylishly still valid, it is not truly what I wanted to see.I had hoped to see a true period piece taking a life of its own.After all, why not?Don't "Agatha Christie's Poirot" (starring David Suchet) adventures thrill and please audiences?And although the two characters don't resemble each other in scope, the settings in the mid thirties to late forties are still exciting.So I had hoped to see a lavishly produced fifties-style James Bond.Really set in the early-mid fifties.With the sport cars of the times, more glitzy than anything rolling out today, when women still were women to love and cherish and when the Cold War was real threat to anyone in this world, far more than terrorists nowadays.Or have we already forgotten the "duck and cover", stupid and totally ridiculous exercises, that kids had to perform in schools to protect themselves from an eventual nuclear attack?Those were the real days of adventure and thrills, but also of true elegance and splendor.What we have here, is another adaptation to modern days, with all the obvious technological advancements and gimmicks of the sort.Besides presenting a new Aston Martin, side by side with the legendary Sean Connery's DB II one, there is nothing really truly interesting to watch.Granted, 007 has become more human, with the face of Daniel Craig, and Q-branch has refrained from too much sci-fi stuff, but this is still the old-cliche Bond after all.It is far better than "The World is Not Enough" and the last "Die Another Day" one, but I still am convinced that now there should either be a split.What I mean is to produce two kinds of Bond movies, possibly side-by-side. One for newer generations, envisaginf always new adventures by renowned authors of the genre, like say, Tom Clancy, and another one, more classic in scope, reprising all Ian Fleming books as they were originally written and faithfully sticking to them.It would bring a whisk of fresh air into the franchise.The DVD containing the movie is well-made. The transfer is done with the competence and the quality one expect these days, as well as for its sound reproduction transfer, both in DTS and Dolby Digital 5.1 Surround sound.What concerns the second DVD, is not much, compared to the special offerings in the Ultimate Bond Collection Series.Still it is a very watchable movie and serves to complete the entire collection, if you, like me, have gathered them all.Enjoyable 007 flick.
summary: Casino Royale, as it was meant by Ian Fleming?

reviewText: I am admittedly not a James Bond fan. I have seen a few - not many - of the movies in this highly celebrated series and I have been relatively entertained. I think the more recent installments have been a little too much for me. I feel like James Bond is a role that needs to be overacted and cheesy, and I don't like it. With Casino Royale I was faced with an unpolished James Bond who still has an unabashed cockiness that gets him into trouble more often than it gets him out of it. That was the piece missing from the other James Bond movies. I really liked Casino Royale.I thought Daniel Craig did a fantastic job as James Bond, especially in the face of so much skepticism from the die-hard fanbase. He fit the mold of the unrefined hot shot very well. He was reckless and broke the rules. Maybe an imperfect James Bond is actually a more perfect James Bond. Think about it.The chase scene in Casino Royale can certainly rival that of most, if not all, other movies. At the beginning of the movie Bond must chase a man, but it is on foot rather than in cars. The pace of the chase coupled with the stunt work done for the scene were great.If you're a James Bond fan, I will assume you've already seen it. If you're not, like me, I think there is still plenty here if you like action/spy flicks.

reviewText: As just an action movie, I might have rated Casino Royale higher.  Casino Royale, however, isn't just an action movie, it's a Bond movie.  Therefore my expectations are much higher and my rating much lower.The Bond movie that I found Casino Royale most comparable to was On Her Majestry's Secret Service.  In both movies Bond fell in love and had his heart broken when the women he fell for died at the end.In this comparison, I'm almost tempted to give On Her Majestry's Secret Service the edge.  Casino Royale was arguably a better action movie but I feel that On Her Majestry's Secret Service had more of the key ingredients that make a Bond movie a Bond movie, in spite of Bond getting married in it.The ingredients that I felt were lacking in Casino Royale were Bond's charm, humor, gadgets and, to be blunt, scantly clad women.  All three were sorely missed, especially the scantly clad women during the opening credits.  I think the movie would have been helped by John Cleese's return as R to give the movie both more humor and more gadgets.I understand that Casino Royale called or an edgier Bond but I find it hard to believe that Bond had to lose his charm in the process.  I don't know whether that was because of the script, the directing or Daniel Craig's acting.  I suspect that it was a combination of the three.I think the Bond enterprise will benefit by turning to Hugh Jackman when they decide to bring Bond's charm back.  It won't be the first time an Aussie played Bond (George Lazenby in On Her Majestry's Secret Service) and I think Hugh Jackman will return to James Bond the much needed charm that Sean Connery, Roger Moore and Pierce Bronson brought to the role.  In Casino Royale, I felt that charm was sorely missing.
summary: Casino Royale Lacked Too Many Key Bond Ingredients

reviewText: To be frank, I never really had any desire to watch Casino Royale. Two years ago (2006), I was quite content with pretending the movie never existed and that James Bond had died when Pierce Brosnan was fired. Nevertheless, somewhere around November 2007, I picked up my Mom's recorded DVD of the film (she recorded it for me, as she too, had no desire of wanting to see it either), I fell victim to my curiosity and stayed up until 4:00am in the morning watching it. Then near the end of the year (December 13th, 2007) I grabbed the decently priced official copy of Casino Royale and watched it again.Sufficed to say, the movie isn't bad, but it's not excellent either. To put simply, this is not "Bond Begins" in the general sense that Casino Royale is an origins film. Its not. (That ideal was obviously scrapped with EON failed to find themselves a young actor, under 22, and stumbled upon the realization that an film-based-Origin Story on a British secret agent life before he gained the License to Kill would not blow over as well as a two-hour film devoted simply to the Origin of Bruce Wayne, via Batman Begins). As we already know this is an entirely different Universe in the James Bond franchise, Casino Royale, is simply the beginning of James Bond's career as a 00-Agent set in what people love to call the "Post-9/11 Era". (Why movies like this and War of the Worlds are defined by that era, are beyond me.)The film begins with James Bond (Craig) confronting the corrupt MI6 section chief, Dryden in his office in Prague. This sequence is frequently interrupted with flashbacks showcasing Bond trying to kill Dryden's "hit man" in a shady looking bathroom. Both sequences end with the Dryden and the Hit man's death. Fast forward to the present, James is sent to Madagascar by MI6 to apprehend an "international-bomb maker" named Mollaka, with another MI6, Carter, (Joseph Millson).However, Mollaka catches sight of Bond's partner and makes a run for it. Carter attempts to pursue, but fails in his endeavor. James follows after the bomb-maker in his stead. This in ensues in one of three of the longest action sequences in the style of free running by Mollaka, while Bond struggles to keep up with the spry man. Once Mollaka is apprehended though, Bond sees fit to kill him, and blow up the front of African Embassy (as he already has what he came for). After a tongue lashing from M (Judi Dench), Bond heads to Miami to chase the trail of Alex Dimitrios -- fellow bomb maker, I believe -- which ensues into second of three big action sequences, when Bond discovers that Dimitrios' henchman plans to destroy an airplane own by Skyfleet. The sequence ends with another dead hired hand and more loose ends for MI6 to clean up, courtesy of James.Determined to get the bottom of this mess, M, sends James to Montenegro, accompanied by Vesper Lynn (Eva Green), a liaison agent from the HM Treasury's Financial Action Task Force, to enter a Poker Tournament at the Casino Royale. While he is there, Bond encounters and confronts Le Chiffre (Mads Mikkelsen), a mathematical genius, [banker for terrorists] and the mastermind behind the events taking place in the film. Along the way, Bond allies himself with lone-wolf MI6 agent, René Mathis (Giancarlo Giannini) who aids him in his mission, and CIA Agent Felix Leiter (Jeffrey Wright) when he looses the game to Le Chiffre.Given, that I've never read Casino Royale, I can't say whether or not if the modernized film is true to most of the events of the novel (but, given that this a film-adaptation, I'll assume it really isn't all that faithful). That aside, the opening sequence (Vector-Art Style) is probably the weakest since Tomorrow Never Dies. Except, instead of shadowed women and computer chip textures, you get poker chips and silhouetted men duking it out. Chris Cornell's "You Know My Name" suffers from the same water-downed audio that Cheryl Crow's title song did in the aforementioned film.Royale's biggest weakness are the action sequences; The first two are so over-the top (and entertaining the first time `round) that what little storyline there is lost in the blood, smoke, and debris. Your so caught up in watching the action sequences unfold, you hardly busy yourself to remember what the movie is about (why Bond is chasing "Mollaka" or "Carlos") until its all over and your wracking your head, trying to pick up where the storyline and plot fell off the speeding Aston Martin. This is one major problem at the end of the film, during an action sequence concerning a sinking building in Venice, Italy. You actually forget the reason why Bond is perusing Vesper and the men who have apprehended her.The scenes concerning the Poker game are the slowest and most uninteresting part of the film and makes up about half of the second hour of the film. There's also the subplot concerning one of the characters turning out to be a Double Agent working for Le Chiffre that could`ve been written a little better. There's no warning or hint to suggest that the character is so, Le Chiffre just announces it and that's that. The torture sequence critical reviews and magazines seemed to describe as excellent, is gloriously, over-glorified and overrated. The entire sequence was overacted on Daniel Craig's part (especially the "scratch my balls" quote.); I was latterly laughing and hiding my face in shame. The only compelling moment in that scene was the skittish composure of Mads Mikkelsen's character, Le Chiffre.Another problem with the film are the characters; The majority of them, mainly the focal characters, lack in depth personality (mostly due on the actors and actresses part) with the exception of Jeffery Wright, who portrays a very interesting Felix Leiter (a character whom I never encountered, until now), the only riveting part of the Poker Game sequences. Mads Mikkelsen portrays Le Chiffre in a mild and sinister manner that is quite appreciated, but his character hardly chalks up to anything besides a right hand man. Le Chiffre is hardly and a compelling villain and ends up sharing fate identical to Elektra King (portrayed Sophie Marceau) in The World is not enough, near the semi-end of the film. Judi Dench as "M", gives the usual performance of the hardnosed and no-nonsense head of MI6; I cannot help but enjoy every moment when she gives Bond the tongue-lashing over what he did in Madagascar, like she was scolding a schoolboy (ha-ha!).Eva Green as Vesper Lynd falls between average or charming enough to make you smile. However, Green's dry and monotone voice and delivery of lines are probably the most irritating part of her character. However, there are moments, [particularly when discussing "Dinner Jackets" or "Financial Aid for James"], where personality inserts itself into Lynd. However, her romance with James Bond, in short, unbelievable. The chemistry between Green and Craig evaporates as soon as the two get together. Mostly, because, you know, James Bond will not be with her for long (thankfully).Of course, on the subject of Bond Girls in this film, it's nice to see that the film has decided to take the focus off the sexuality of the females and simply characterized them as people, even though they fall back into the position that they were meant for. Having sexual relations with James Bond (the sexual content in this film ironically is more PG-13 friendly than any of the previous films of Pierce Brosnan's Bond era).Daniel Craig as James Bond is all right at best. At times, he's charming (the scene when he drives around the hotel after inviting Solange to his "home" is an example), funny even. But, in all in all, Craig is not a very compelling actor for this role. For the most part, the majority of Daniel Craig's performance consists of going through the motions. Staring intensely at something or frowning in contemplation, or rattling his lines off in a monotone tone of voice like Eva Green. His James Bond is characterized like a true Thug or Hitman (obvious cues taken from movies like Munich and Layer Cake). Craig lacks the power of emotional range and that quirky personality that I loved from the previous Bonds (excluding Moore and Lazenby), continuity not withstanding here.Another irritating part of his character is the simple fact that he obviously acts before he thinks [hence the "blunt instrument" quote]; Bond made more mistakes than I've ever seen him make in one movie and his solution to the problem was a bullet from the gun or a dinner knife. He never thinks of the larger picture unless its to his benefit. EON's attempts to "humanize" the secret agent falls flat in places like the train scene where Vesper and James play tick-tat-toe with words to guess their character and upbringing or Bond's overly sappy speech that was featured in the theatrical trailer (*puke*) to Vesper. However, I think I do like him most when he attempts to comfort Vesper in the shower scene. When concerning his looks, Craig has never been the best looking or the most handsome man ever to grace the screens, so he makes up for it, with his acting. Overall, I like Daniel Craig as an actor, just not as James Bond. His demeanor just does not suit the character or the title.David Arnold has created a score for Casino Royale, which I have ended up loving. His previous endeavors for the James Bond films (1997-2002) were perfectly suited for the films, but as standalones, they were weak and uninspiring. Thankfully, this problem seems to be omitted and on its own, the score for Casino is an excellent listen. However, there are moments, where the more somber themes seemed forced, as they lacked a real emotional sound that failed to reach me.On one final note, the Second Disc containing all of the special features (which are about, three or four featurettes if memory serves) could've easily been slapped onto the Feature Film Disc. That said, aside from the featurette "Bond Girls Are Forever" (something I think I remember seeing on television or something), the other stuff is forgettable. Other than that, the Audio and Picture Quality of the DVD is standard "DVD Perfection" and clear on my television screen.Overall, Casino Royale is an entertaining Weekend Popcorn flick, but the fact that it takes itself too seriously and its atmosphere demands that you do as well, kills the enjoyment factor. In the end the movie's subplots and storylines never seem to come together to create a coherent story that works to the fullest and the characters could`ve been better developed in terms of personality. Factoids like "Realism" and "Gritty, More Realistic Bond" are instantly forgotten, because they have no presence in this film --- as Casino Royale is far from the quotations. Its just another Bond movie. ---- [3 out of 5]
summary: "They think I'm ugly but I'll have to live with that..." James Bond for the New Generation

reviewText: I was ready to be fully disappointed by "CR", specifically with Daniel Craig as the new James Bond. Ever since pretty boy Roger Moore left his bland tenure as Bond, Bond flicks had become enjoyable again, with Timothy Dalton and Pierce Brosnan bringing the franchise back to respectability again in movies with ACTUAL PLOTLINES, like "The Living Daylights", "Goldeneye" or "The World Is Not Enough". And now they were going to "reboot" the franchise with a new actor that just did NOT fit the mold as typically suave and debonair?? CHEZ INFAMIE!!However, "Casino Royale", and its followup, "Quantum of Solace", actually WORK!! In "Casino", based on the very first Bond novel by Ian Fleming, Bond earns his "double O" status within the first ten minutes of action in the teaser. He proceeds to track down a bomber somewhere in Uganda, offending "M" in the bargain, breaking into her apartment, hacking her computer and generally compromising her own little security capsule. Oddly enough, Judi Dench is held over as the head of MI6 in this film, even though she was Brosnan's "M", and we know that Bond had MALE "M's" before Brosnan. Oh, and here's another twist, for some reason, the gunsight intro doesn't take place until the movie ENDS in this one!Craig's Bond is a lot colder, a lot brasher....more along Timothy Dalton's line than either Moore, Brosnan OR Connery, but there IS the working class edge that Connery has....though I think, perhaps, Craig might have made a better Harry Palmer than ol' Jimmy Boy. There is a LOT of action in this movie and "Quantum".Oddly enough, the Palmer movies were produced by the very same people that produce the Bond films.Fancy that.

reviewText: "Casino Royale", very un-Bond like, somewhat disappointing.  This movie in the Bond series, although I found it disappointing, is by far the most believable in the true to life sense.  I suppose I found it disappointing as there were no gadgets from Q.This new actor, he's nice eye candy in his swimtrunks, but other than that, no fire.  His accent made the dialogue hard to understand at times.  There were awkward moments in the movie where there was no dialogue leaving the viewer with an empty feeling.Judy Dench however, delivered her usual spitfire performance.  But it seemed hard to believe that she would have a secret communications device next to her bed.  Did you notice the man?  Her husband?Another missing element was the "vodka martini, shaken not stirred".Scene shifts were not smooth, no explanation of transition.Felix Lighter, totally unexpected appearance.Out of 5 stars, 3 is my rating.

reviewText: I just finished watching the new James Bond Movie Casino Royale and I can say it was one of the best James Bond movies to come out in years. After watching the horrible Die Another Day I was a little afraid to watch Casino Royale. I took a risk and I'm glad I did because I really enjoyed this movie. This latest movie brings much needed life in to the James Bond Franchise which over the past few years had lost its edge. This is a new and improved Bond played by Daniel Craig. Daniel gives a great performance as 007, and his character actually has emotions and is not portrayed as this one dimensional robot like the previous films. The action scenes in this movie are great, and to see James Bond fall in love just adds to the drama of this movie.  I don't want to give the movie away so I will say no more. This movie has some slow moments in it, but for the most part it is a good, entertaining, action packed movie. The Blu-ray disc picture looks amazing in true 1080p HD, and the sound is top notch as well if you choose the linear PCM 5.1 soundtrack. This is another one of the best looking Blu-ray discs (along with Crank, The Departed, and Babel) to come out. Check out Casino Royale and discover how cool James Bond is once again!The Special Features:Becoming BondJames Bond: For RealBond Girls Are Forever (2006)Chris Cornell Music Video
summary: Casino Royale brings much needed life in to a franchise that had lost its edge

reviewText: Casino Royale is quite possibly the best Bond movie of all time and, with all due respect to Sean Connery's handling of the role, Daniel Craig deserves the same such praise for his portrayal of 007.  I would be all over pre-ordering this item if it were not for my noticing of the Regional Coding Enhancement (RCE) disclaimer in the Product Details.It may not seem like such a big deal in preventing discs from working on Region 0 or Multi-region players, I resent Sony's continued efforts in adding these extra levels of protection to its products.  This is the same company that not too long ago--in the name of digital rights managment--added malware onto its music CD's that actually damaged consumers' electronics equipment: most notably computers.While I will try to refrain from purchasing this particular product for as long as I can, this practice seems to have gone on for some time now with previous Sony DVD's and to little fanfare, so I suspect that I will eventually cave and get the Casino Royale DVD--it is that good of a movie--but I will certainly go out of my way to avoid Sony products with the rarest of exceptions.I really appreciate Amazon's efforts in informing its customers of some of their partners' practices.  If and when I decide to purchase this item, I will definitely do so through Amazon, unless I can find a bare bones version with just the single disc and sans the RCE from somewhere else.

reviewText: I think I'll make a film called "Mutiny on the Bounty." No, it won't be about Fletcher Christian and it won't take place on a sailing vessel. It will be about a housewife who finds that "Bounty" isn't the quickest picker-upper and then rebels out front of the local supermarket with a lot of other wives.That's what "Casino Royale" was to me. They took a famous title and hooked it to a famous film franchise; then they made it 21st Century film gritty and completely changed the character of Bond into Tom Cruise's Mission Impossible mirror image.Indeed Daniel Craig is a fine new actor and acts with fierce intensity. But this isn't Bond. This is a new character which someone should have been brave enough to rename and start a new franchise.At first I gave it 3 stars, but I then had to make it 2.
summary: Craig is great, but the film isn't anywhere near Fleming's Bond!

reviewText: Daniel Craig delivers surprisingly good interpretation on James Bond.  He is not afraid to create his own brand of Agent 007.  You will not see him impersonate any of the previous takes on the famous spy.  I like his looks.  He is well built bur not pretty; he is handsome in the acquired taste kind of way.  He cares not if his martini is shaken or stirred and we see him vulnerable both physically and emotionally for the first time.  Fighting and running scenes in the movie are frighteningly fast and scary while love scenes more passionate than any of the other Bond movies before.  One part of the film is supposedly set in Montenegro, but I am still confused if the scenes were actually shot in Montenegro, Czech Republic or Italy.  International group of actors brings the right kind of chemistry into this film.  Nothing too heavy and yet, very entertaining.
summary: A new and improved kind of James Bond
Title: N/A

reviewText: James Bond in both Casino Royale and Quantum of Solace is almost macabre in the way he is always covered in someone else's blood, the way blood often oozes from opened cuts on his face and his hands with his not caring in the least that it does. He's the right degree of handsome--or not--for the masses who are "anti" good-looking leading men.  But for me, Bond's greatest attributes are that he is vulnerable and that emotionally, he bleeds, in ways so subtle, they're almost subliminal.  His emotions surface  and then are  swallowed  up, lost, in the next frantic chase, fight or mind game.  But during their surfacing, they are so intense that they linger in the air like invisible tangibleness, and when the movie ends, you still remember a certain cold look, a distancing expression, or words, like a well-mixed drink, spoken with a shot of anger and a shot of the inability to mask the pain.I did miss the Bond gadgets, but the one liners were still in there, though not the deliberately funny ones like in previous Bond movies.  This Bond doesn't have a "tell" that gives away the fact he's about to say something funny. The line just comes out naturally, and sometimes, it takes the viewer a minute to realize the joke.  It's a new and difference approach, and I think it works well.As for the overall movie, some of the scenes in it just have to be watched over and over again. They are just that good. I don't mean only the action scenes. That shower scene rivals  The Age of Innocence on any given day.  And there are others. Each viewer will pick his or her own.  My recommendation is to watch this movie. Daniel Craig is so good in this picture. I read some of the Bond books, and like Ian Fleming's character, Craig's Bond is both a human being and an incredibly cold and dangerous machine, while not allowing one side of himself to detract or distract from the other.I gave the movie five stars because overall it was enjoyable. The only problem I had with it was what happened in the end with Vesper and why it happened.  The explanation given to justify it was just too muddy.
summary: This new Bond is worth the watch.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I recall that many a naysayer ranted and raved when Michael Keaton was hired to play Batman/Bruce Wayne in the first of the big-budgeted exploits of the Dark Knight. How could the actor, known to moviegoers as "Beetlejuice," possibly get away with playing the legendary superhero? However, Keaton excelled in the role and even returned in the first sequel.Well, the same crowd was probably upset with the hiring of Daniel Craig as the new 007. The guy is blond and more than likely is the shortest actor to assay the role. And Craig had never carried a film on his name alone.After seeing the film, I can attest that Craig should have no problems with being a headliner now. His interpretation of the role has brought life to a franchise that was becomingly increasingly far-fetched and somewhat boring. Pierce Bronson, Craig's immediate predecessor, had done well in the part but he was saddled with two good films ("Goldeneye" and "The World is Not Enough") and two mediocre ones ("Tomorrow Never Dies," and "Die Another Day").It was, indeed, time for a "changing of the guard."Craig's Bond is a combination of virility and vulnerability. He is appropriately strong yet shows weakness, especially when his superego gets the best of him. One can't imagine Connery ever losing a card game, as does Craig in this film.Craig obviously worked hard to buff himself up for the part, physically and mentally. His confident swagger as he enters a room is enough to make all heads turn.As far as the film is concerned, there are two extremely exciting chases: an unbelievable (and quite long) romp through a Madagascar city, filled with a jaw-dropping fight above on a construction crane and a fast-paced race along the runways of Miami International Airport.The stuntmen really earned their respective paychecks for both of these.Kudos must be given to director Martin Campbell for keeping the two-hour-plus film moving at a brisk pace.  And the screenplay co-authored by Robert Wade, Paul Haggis, and Neal Purvis brings new life to a character that has been around since the early days of "The Cold War," to borrow a line delivered by one of the key players.There is homage to earlier Bonds, direct and subtle. Craig wins a somewhat familiar '64 Aston Martin in a card game. And at the climactic game between LaChiffre (Mads Mikkelson) and Bond, there is an extremely large African-American player at the table. One might wonder if his presence is a tribute to the late Orson Welles who played LaChiffre in the earlier Woody Allen/David Niven Bond spoof.Even David Arnold, the composer of music for each of the Brosnan Bond films, seems to have intentionally constructed a score eerily similar to the classic ones composed by John Barry.As far as the other performers are concerned, Dame Judi Dench is again authoritative and impressive as "M," while Eva Green is captivating as "Vesper Lind," Bond's associate and eventual conquest. Hopefully, Jeffery Wright will be better used in the next film for his part is no more than a glorified cameo.This Bond is the film of which all its successors will be measured and Craig is, undeniably, the best actor to inhabit the role since Connery's departure.And I hate to say that 'cause I'm a big fan of Roger Moore!!!

reviewText: This isn't a 4 star review of the film...its a complaint with the second disc and the  special features which aren't very special.  When  compared to ALL the other BONDS which have endless bonus features the newest is thin and I suspect a 3 disc ULTIMATE edition is in the offing.  The making of ...is very much an extended press kit and fluff... under a half hour, the other featurette James Bond FOR REAL is a bit more interesting/enjoyable examination of the major stunts.  the biggest bonus feature "The Girls OF Bond" which they say is 2006 ...was available as a separate DVD by Best Buy with the release of Die Another Day...so its really just something MGM had laying around....to fatten up the "90 minutes of Extras" sticker.  Bottom line..you get about 50 minutes of NEW  Extras. reviewText: I have to admit up front that I have a strong bias about the way I think James Bond should be portrayed. I like the old Ian Fleming style of Bond who is true to the books. We are talking a very serious Bond who is macho, resourceful and more than a little bit vengeful when he feels like he has been wronged. At the same time, the classic Bond of the Ian Fleming novels that I look for also sets the ladies on fire and is soo unafraid of his enemies that he literally laughs at them even as they appear to have his life in their hands. This guy never loses his cool and is the epitome of the word. He used to go by Sean Connery when off-camera but I feel very comfortable now saying that he goes by Daniel Craig these days.In Casino Royale, we have a nice, modernized take on the very first of Flemings' Bond adventures. To summarize without giving away more than just basic plot devices for those who have not yet watched this movie, Bond is on a mission to smoke out a powerful money launderer who takes money and invests it for terrorist groups and other criminal organizations. Basically he demonstrates classic Bond wit by tricking his rival into losing all of his money in a game of chance which makes him a marked man by all the organizations he is a front for, rendering him an easy target for capture and use as an informant. Bond succeeds and in the process he manages to get into quite a few fights on the side. Despite being injured, again in classic-Bond style, he manages to get back to the table in no time flat and even clean up as if he never left his martini. The ladies fall for him and Bond himself, breaking one of his own rules to never fall for a lady, falls hard for his assistant, fellow MI6 agent Vesper Lynd. When she turns out to be a double-agent (not by her own choice), Bond goes on a rampage and is left scarred in the end. I should say more scarred as Bond is always a man who has a chip on his shoulder.Craig hits the ground running in this his first journey into the BondVerse. He pulls off the character with a nice showing of suave but also with a serious dedication to dark justice right out of the novels, a cross between Connery's smooth demeanor and the more violent Bond of the Timothy Dalton years. The atmosphere, the music, the story and the acting is amazing and all seem to fall into place right where they belong. This is instantly one of my favorite Bond adventures.The video and sound qualities are quite good, this being a recent hit release. I found no trouble here whatsoever- everything was crystal clear. I have read some reviews elsewhere of people having trouble watching this movie and others on certain players but on the PS3 it was just like at the theater as far as I was concerned.ConclusionIn short, buy this movie. If you like James Bond at all you will enjoy it. If you are like me and enjoy the more serious Bond of Connery and Dalton over the somewhat more comedic and slap-stick Roger Moore years, you will absolutely love it. I never knock anyone who played James Bond and for good reason- Double-O-7's shoes are very hard to fill. From a long-time fan's point of view though, this movie gets it right and is worth a look.
summary: A Nice, Modern Retooling Of A Classic Bond Adventure

reviewText: This review will be pushed to the back of the list for sure because i'm not among the rest of the crowd on this one.  Plus I'll get a big pile of "not helpful" votes, but I feel this has to be said: Casino Royale has a terrible screenplay, I've never read the book, but I cant possibly see how the storyline could be as bad as it is in the film. I sat through the lame 10 minute long opening credit sequence then the first 40 minutes of the movie and thought to myself, what has really happened so far?  People have come and gone, money has changed hands... and I really dont care about anybody in the movie.This movie could have easily be cut down to 1:20 and not the 2 hour marathon that it ends up as.  I found myself about an hour into it waiting for the credits to roll.  I didnt care about any character in the movie yet it kept carrying on and on.  The poker sequences could have been cut down 1/4 the length they are.  I understand Texas Hold'em is big all the sudden, but Bond was a Baccarat guy.  They waste a lot of time on poker in this movie trying to turn this into Rounders 2.  Hey I love Hold'em as much as the next guy, point of reference my reviews on many Hold'em related books, but this isnt the WPT or WSOP, its Bond.. I'm here for action and babes, not to watch a grind.They also have the lead Bond chick cast incorrectly.  The one that should be the main girl is the one that was the girlfriend of the first villan.  The main girl is cute and cleans up nice in the poker scene to do nothing more than hold up the bar in case it were to suddenly fall over, but seriously.. she's not all that.  The worst thing of all is Bond falls in freeekin love with her!  Come one, he's always been the king of "hit it and quit it".  Now he's Richie Cuddingham.I know everyone out there is comparing this to the Batman and Superman franchises saying this is the resurrection of Bond.  Honestly, I dont see anywhere near the presence in this Bond compared to our replacement Batman and Superman.  Its nice that they've dumped the slap stick humor, but they could have used a better lead.  Hugh Grant could have been a better Bond and I hate that guy's movies with the fire of a thousand suns.Possible SPOILER:  I was really getting bored when a never ending string of villans parade through the film with little in the way of character building and make an abrupt exit.  The last villan, who seems to be the most important has the least explained about him.  Things just got so predictable after a while.  The storyline is very shallow and I'm now interested in reading the book to see if it was really meant to be this dull.This movie left me looking for a comparison on how something could have turned out worse and I thought of one.  Terminator 4: Starring Andy Dick

reviewText: Running. Lots and lots of running. Craig spends much of the time throughout the film doing full-on windsprints across the screen chasing someone. As a standalone film, it was great. Good story, plot and all that. But not a classic Bond flick. No way. It lacked that bit of offbeat quirky Bond personality that we've seen in the past. No gizmo's and gadgets either. What happened to Q?. Craig is good.  Very athletic and limber and all that but really, too damn stiff and straight as a Bond.  No swagger.  His time with the babes (what there were of them) was almost uncomfortable to watch. Doesnt come across as a ladies man. I do admit that this film has one of the best footrrace chase scenes I've ever seen. Awesum!! This was more or less like watching another Mission Impossible sequel. Lots of action packed this and that,stuff blowing up and all but missing the true signiture of Bond. James Bond. They didn't even get his favorite martini right either. I think someone is trying (yet again) to rewrite, rework and rebuild the Bond we all grew up with. Leave it alone. Stop trying to make whats perfect "even better and more exciting". You'll only succeed by screwing up a legend. Another Bond film like Casino Royal will do it.  Hollywood always thinks its the expert. Not this time.
