reviewText: I imagine something along these lines happened in a nice boardroom in one of the office buildings on the Sony Pictures studio lot: It's June 2002, and audiences across the nation are being swept off their feet by a deadly government assassin with a serious case of the forgetfuls. There's a deadly agent that people are falling in love with, who has "J.B." as his initials, and it ain't James Bond. I imagine that didn't sit well with those suits in that boardroom, and it promptly urged them to begin their search for the next British actor to don the classic black tux and shaken, not stirred, martini. Fast-forward four years, to 2006, and we arrive at Casino Royale. After saying all of that, I still have to admit that Casino Royale is one hell of a remarkable film. Daniel Craig is exactly what I feel James Bond should be. It's funny that not many people had faith in him, until they saw the movie for themselves. I really wanted to see an actor put a new twist on the character, rather than copying the tried and true smooth-talking 'Bond, James Bond' from the older movies. I have to say, Daniel Craig did not disappoint me in the slightest. He radiates cool, and badassery, while managing to eliminate the main thing that I had problem with in older 007's. The over-the-top gadgets were the only thing that prevented me from loving earlier Bond films, as silly as that may sound. I just could never take them seriously in the contexts of the films.For instance, the car that could become invisible and the surf boards with weapon compartments in Die Another Day, and the wheelchair with a missle as a leg cast in GoldenEye, just to name a couple. I'm not very familiar with the oldest Bond movies, but I'm pretty sure they had even whackier gadgets than that. Anyway, the closer to realism, the better, in my opinion. At least for this particular property. I would not say that philosophy translates to every rebooted franchise out there, but I certainly think that mentality has worked wonders for this one. I thoroughly enjoyed the action sequences in Casino Royale, as well. They were very extreme, yet remained so believable. One of my favorite movie scenes of all time is the scene when Bond parkour chases the bomb maker in Madagascar. That scene was so mind-numbingly awesome that I immediately realized that something special was in out midst. Ironically, action is not this film's only strong point. I also love the tension, especially in the poker scenes. To this day, those moments make my heart rate increase slightly. No spoiler intended, but in one scene Bond's heart rate gets a bit of a boost as well. To further adress my inference that the Bourne series was an inspiration for this one to be rebooted the way it was, I want to add that I never got a Bourne vibe from this film. This movie more than stands on its own two feet, and did not copy Bourne in any way. I just credit the Bourne series for inspiring the producers and filmmakers to revamp this franchise the way they did.I so love the way this movie came from basically nowhere, to pretty much blew the minds of fans around the world. It reminds me of what Wb, Christopher Nolan, and Batman Begins did for the Batman franchise. All I can say is, thank God for Jason Bourne. If Bourne had not come along and set a new bar for secret agent/government assassin action thrillers, I seriously doubt that 007 would have been rebooted with such a vengence. And boy was it. Casino Royale actually surpasses all of its predecessors (at least the ones I have actually seen) and the Bourne series. In my humble opinion, it's a near perfect masterpiece. And the gorgeous Blu-ray transfer is nothing short of amazing as well. Reference quality audio and video. This Collectors Edition adds a plethora of special features for fans to dig into, greatly boosting the quality of the set as a whole. Highly Recommended!

reviewText: I have been a Bond fan for nearly 30 years now. I've seen many Bonds come and go and have appreciated what each actor has brought to the role.When I heard Daniel Craig had been cast as 007, I had my doubts. I had seen him in Layer Cake and Road to Perdition and felt that he really didn't LOOK the part. I know that looks can be deceiving. Case in point is Michael Keaton in 1989's Batman. I thought that was the worst casting decision in the history of film.....until I SAW the movie. Keaton ended up being PERFECT in the role.The same goes for Craig. Daniel Craig is masterful as James Bond. Many of the Daniel Criag detractors felt that Craig portrayed bond as an unrefined thug.That was the point of the whole film. Remember, Casino Royale is bringing the Bond franchise back to its roots. Bond has just become a "00" and isn't the seasoned agent that we've all come to know and love over the years.Yes, Craig's Bond is brutish. If you notice, in many scenes he doesn't wear a suit and tie (except for the casino scenes) and even goes around with his shirt untucked in some cases. He's certainly not the dapper British agent in all of the previous films.Also, when asked if he wanted his vodka martini shaken or stirred, he responds that he doesn't give a damn. What? Again, remember, he is unrefined and unseasoned, not a suave, sophisticated super-spy.Now. Fast forward to the end of the film when the villain behind it all asks him "Who are you?"We see Bond dressed to the nines in a fantastic suit and tie as he replies "Bond. James Bond."That sums it all up. Bond is seasoned now. He's been through a lot and knows that he's got to "tighten up" if he's going to survive as a "00".The next film, which I am greatly looking forward to, will most likely show a more sophisticated, cultured and refined Bond. He may still have some rough edges (he can't become a brute one day and a perfect gentleman the next; that proess should take a little time), but he should be closer to the traditional Bond we've all known since the '60s.One thing I REALLY appreciated was the story. Previous Bond films have been extremely outrageous (Die Another Day: a hotel sculpted out of ice, a villain with a "shock suit", an invisible BMW, an evil henchman named Mr. Kill.....puh-lease!) This story is better rooted in reality than some of the other Bond films which I think brings more credibility to the franchise. I think we're all getting a little tired of the "master villain wants to cause a nuclear war and dominate the world" theme. That type of story has been done to DEATH.As for the DVD itself, the extras are good but not great. It was nice, though, for Myram D'Abo (Kara from The Living Daylights) to interview the Bond girls through the ages; a very nice, nostalgic touch.The picture is excellent and the sound is very good although not top-notch. I found some of the dialogue difficult to hear, so I turned up the volume. When the action scenes came, I had to turn the volume back down because the movie then became way too loud.Overall, an excellent purchase and an excellent film. Even if you're not a James Bond fan, you will still enjoy this movie.

reviewText: In 2002, Paramount Pictures attempted to reinvent the film franchise based on Tom Clancy's series of Jack Ryan novels with the release of The Sum of All Fears.  Ben Affleck was cast as a young Jack Ryan beginning his CIA career as an analyst.  But a horrible script and lackluster performances from many of the film's cast members made The Sum of All Fears an abysmal failure.Fast forward to 2006, as MGM, Columbia Pictures and Eon Productions attempt to reinvent the James Bond franchise based on author Ian Fleming's 007 novels with the release of Casino Royale.  Daniel Craig was cast in the role of Bond, following in the footsteps of Sean Connery, George Lazenby, Roger Moore, Timothy Dalton and Pierce Brosnan, with actress Eva Green cast as Vesper Lynd.  Bond film veteran Judi Dench is the only 007 alum to return as she steps into the role of MI6 chief "M" once again.  Martin Campbell, who directed Brosnan's debut, GoldenEye, returns to the director's chair for the twenty-first Bond film.In Casino Royale, Daniel Craig portrays a younger, blonder James Bond early in his MI6 career.  The film opens with Bond obtaining his first two kills, an event that elevates him to double-0 status as he gains his license to kill.  The music score keeps the use of the traditional 007 theme to a minimum, but that's a good thing in this movie.  This film is the story of how Bond becomes Bond.Craig plays 007 with great confidence and proves himself a worthy successor to the role.  While Dalton brought acting credibility to the part, he never seemed fully comfortable in the role.  Roger Moore was Ian Fleming's original choice prior to Connery's landing the part.  But when Moore did assume the role, he came off more as parody than a regular Bond.  Brosnan was acceptable as 007, but his physique (or lack thereof) made it difficult for fans to believe that he was capable of engaging in the fights and other physical scenes constantly shown in Bond films.  Sean Connery has always been my favorite Bond, but Daniel Craig has already established himself as a very close second.For the first time since 1987's The Living Daylights, we have a Bond film that is actually based on one of Ian Fleming's books.  Mads Mikkelsen makes a great villain as Le Chiffre, a banker to many of the world's terrorist organizations.  "M" wants to put Le Chiffre under great financial pressure, forcing him to turn to MI6 for amnesty.  This leads to Montenegro where he hosts a high stakes poker tournament, seeking to recoup his recent losses to cover the investments of his clients.  Bond enters the tournament on a mission to clean out Le Chiffre.  007 having been set up with a $10 million stake by the British government.  Vesper Lynd is a British treasury agent assigned to watch over Bond and the government's money.Many elements of past Bond films are missing from Casino Royale--no "Q," no Miss Moneypenny--and many of the tongue-in-cheek one-liners are now gone as well.  This movie gets back to the beginning of Bond, as we see a reckless 007 who has not yet become confident in his skills and abilities.  The over-the-top action sequences of many previous Bond films have been replaced with a much darker tone.  And the tragic relationship between Bond and Vesper gives us insight into why he traditionally does not allow women to get close to him.This two-disc DVD set contains several bonus features of note, including two original featurettes:  "Becoming Bond," which examines how Daniel Craig became the sixth Bond; and "James Bond: For Real," which provides an inside look at the movie's action sequences and stunts.  Also included is an updated version of "Bond Girls are Forever," hosted by Maryam d'Abo (Kara Milovny in The Living Daylights) plus the obligatory music video for Chris Cornell's theme song "You Know My Name."With such superb work from the cast and crew of this movie, Casino Royale seems to have breathed new life into the James Bond franchise.  This could very well be the best 007 movie since 1965's Thunderball.  Daniel Craig has done an excellent job in his first outing as Bond, outshining four of his five predecessors.  Provided that the writing and direction continue to be this good, I look forward to watching Craig in future 007 films over the next few years.

reviewText: When I used to watch Pierce Brosnan as James Bond, first class secret agent for MI6, I couldn't help but laugh. The plots were so ridiculous, and the gadgets so amusing that the viewer couldn't help but think how unlikely anything like this could ever happen. Daniel Craig has reinvented the series as a rugged and ruthless Bond who fights most of his battles the old fashioned way and without any gadgets. In fact, the main conflict in Casino Royale is a poker game in which Bond must take down terrorist funder Le Chiffre, aided by Vesper Lynd (Eva Green).Daniel Craig plays a reflective and somber Bond, a man who trusts no one. Not to say that Craig's Bond doesn't have a taste for excitement. The action sequences and witty remarks are still there, but simply aren't as bombastic as the old days. Casino Royale keeps the plot moving, but also ensures that the film is interesting between action sequences and fight scenes. Daniel Craig carries the film as a suave and simple Bond, possibly the best Bond ever.

reviewText: This is unique as an extension of a pretty tired franchise.  Rather than a slick, corny, or ridiculous pastiche, Craig really tries to do something new and pulls it off.Bond is just promoted, and he is quite a raw talent, if fanatically devoted to his task.  He is far less assured and cool than Connery, engaging in really gritty fights in which he occasionally gets hurt.  There is also more on his background:  an orphan, gone to Oxbridge and wanting to fit into the elegance and style, which explains both his intensity to conform, his uniquely relentless aggression, and his pursuit of cool.  He is also more vulnerable than Connery, esp. to the love of the unbelievably lovely Eva Green.  The villains are also subtle, if sociopathically cold, and their game is not completely explained, which leaves the viewer hoping that the concept of Spectre will evolve in subsequent films from its simple bad guy/terrorist/extortion caricature.Best of all, Craig is so good that you can believe him, just as you could with Connery.  Warmly recommended.
summary: superb transformation of Bond, the best since Connery

reviewText: Vengeance is sweet.  Possibly no actor has received a more impassioned and negative response after being named the new James Bond than Daniel Craig.  He had few strong supporters in the general populace and most were pushing for a variety of other actors from Clive Owen (who would indeed have been quite good) to the recently deposed Pierce Brosnan.  Websites were set up to protest the choice of Craig.  Petitions were circulated denouncing his selection and demanding an alternative.  For once, in a huge way, the general public was proved wrong.  The producers really did know what they were doing and the selection of Daniel Craig as James Bond is certainly the most brilliant decision that they have made since the 007 first made his appearance onscreen nearly fifty years ago.Not just in the selection of Craig, but in a host of minor decisions, this Bond film signals not merely a return to form but a thorough going revamping.  It begins predictably enough, with a dramatic chase scene.  But this stands out as one of the finest openings of any film in the series, with Bond in chase of a bomber who possesses the acrobatic skills of Jackie Chan in his prime.  But some of the changes can be seen in the opening credits.  Instead of nubile women prancing around in profile, we see Bond himself with a design based upon the four card suits.  In fact, the film as a whole is considerably less sexist than most Bond films, though it can hardly be hailed a feminist classic.In a way, this film present almost an alternative reality Bond.  To make it work we all have to pretend that we've never heard of Bond, that he wasn't a creation of the Cold War, that we can imagine that in 2006 we are seeing Bond at the outset of his career.  In this alternative world we get almost instantly views of Bond that we had never seen before.  For one thing, this is not a psychologically normal human being.  Although Timothy Dalton had given us a self-conflicted Bond and in that sense more psychologically complex, Craig's Bond is a borderline sociopath, completely untroubled by the death of a woman he had near made love to the previous evening.  He also is the least quipping of the Bonds, the least apt to see humor in situations and provide a key funny line.  Facially he is not a terribly handsome man, with crude features.  He truly does seem--both mentally and physically--a bit of a brute.  Dressing him up in a tux truly is like putting dress clothing on a Neanderthal, albeit one with a high I.Q. and even quicker wits.  All in all, it is an amazing recreation.  All the previous Bonds had been essentially men of elegance who had learned violence; Craig's Bond is a thug who cleans up well.  And of all the Bonds, including Sean Connery, Craig is the one who most exudes menace and danger.The film as a whole is the least silly Bond film in quite some time.  The focus is away from elaborate gimmicks and massive props that take up an entire set and back to individuals fighting individuals.  The film recalls FROM RUSSIA WITH LOVE and GOLDFINGER more than any Bond films since.  And unlike most of the Bond films since those two, it features a story that truly is of interest.  There are twists that truly are twists and intrigue that is genuinely surprising.And for the first time that I can remember, I am actually looking forward to the next Bond film.  I know that there have been those who still cared about Bond, but I long ago ceased to be among them.  I would certainly watch each one as it came out, but now I am actually expectant.  On every level this is easily among the best Bond films ever.  Some even call this the best Bond movie ever and I would not argue very hard against them.  I personally would rate it slightly behind FROM RUSSIA WITH LOVE and GOLDFINGER, but certainly no lower than that.I would like to do a call out for one performer in a small role:  Christina Cole.  Many will know her from starring in the British supernatural series HEX.  She is one of the most natural beauties in the movies today and I heartily hope she gets bigger and better roles in the near future.  She appears here in a small role as the desk receptionist in the hotel in the Bahamas.  She should be starring in movies, not playing small bit roles.
summary: Easily the best Bond film in over forty years - no doubt about it, Bond is back

reviewText: I've never been too crazy about the James Bond movies because they always seem to slavishly adhere to a well-worn formula without never exploring the character of Bond and what drives him to do what he does. CASINO ROYALE finally allows us to glimpse into the dark soul of MI6's Agent 007 and in the process gives us the best Bond movie yet and the greatest screen incarnation of the iconic secret agent as played by Daniel Craig in what will become, as it did for every actor who has come before him, his signature role. CASINO ROYALE reboots the Bond series and updates it to post-9/11 modern times simultaneously. The result is a mature and gripping spy adventure that in its more quiter moments often invites comparison to the works of John Le Carre and Graham Greene with the same emphasis on interesting characters and their motivations. But that's not to say CASINO ROYALE skimps on the fireworks. There's plenty of great action sequences including two that might make your jaw drop: the opening action beat finds Bond chasing a scarred bombmaker on foot through Madagascar including an extended confrontation atop a high-steel construction site and makes wonderous use of the French free-running sport of Parkour; and a car chase where Bond's tricked-out spymobile does a few pretty frightening flips. The most suspenseful moments are the poker table duels between Bond and his blood-weeping adversary Le Chiffre (played by the great Danish actor Mads Mikkelsen with a subdued madness). Who would have ever thought Texas Hold 'Em could be so edge-of-the-seat thrilling? As 007's ice-cool boss M Dame Judi Dench is the only returning cast member from the previous Pierce Brosnan Bond flicks but she's given a real character to play this time around and her relationship with Craig's Bond carries genuine weight. Eve Green does some of her best acting to date as Vesper Lynd, the one woman capable of capturing Bond's elusive heart. Captain Kirk had Carol Marcus, Bond has Vesper. Jeffrey Wright and Giancarlo Gianni provide stand-out performances as two of Bond's unlikely colleagues. CASINO ROYALE is not only the best Bond movie yet but it's also one of the most ripping yarns cranked out by Hollywood in recent years. Let's hope they don't let the series to get out of hand....again.
summary: This is Bond shaken and stirred

reviewText: Anyone who has followed the James Bond series over the last four decades knows that the new Bond has changed... In "Casino Royale," 007 do not identify himself with the classic words, "Bond. James Bond," and instead of playing Chemin-de-Fer or Craps, he plays Poker and he doesn't care whether his vodka martinis are shaken or stirred nor he drinks a Smirnoff vodka, or a five-star Hennessey, or a Dom Pérignon'52... He never pauses to take a finger of Caviar... He never enjoys a good cigar and is less preoccupied with matters of sex...But he is a more trained Bond, a cold-hearted killer improvising, modifying, and overcoming, uttering to M in one decisive moment his most significant line, "So you want me to be half monk, half hit-man!"In taking the part, Daniel Craig completely inhabited the character of the super agent 007... There is something empathetic about him and something human...He so lets you in behind his blue eyes and into his emotional life...His opponent is the villain banker Le Chiffre (Mads Mikkelsen) who tries to get rich in supplying funds for terrorists... To continue doing so, Le Chiffre wants to win back his losses in a no-limit showdown Poker game with $115,000,000 in chips at Casino Royale in Montenegro...Ivana Milicevic plays Le Chiffre's Bosnian bodyguard who nearly eliminates our hero... Valenka is harmful but not pure evil as her boss...Simon Abkarian is the middleman Alex Dimitrios involved with Le Chiffre, who knew where to put his hands on weapons and people who could use them... He works with anyone who has money...The Italian actress Caterina Murino (Solange) reveals her sexy side as the frustrated woman so upset in her marriage...Jeffrey Wright plays the undercover CIA agent Felix Leiter 'bleeding chips at the poker tournament;' and Giancarlo Giannini plays the 'contact' Mathis...Eva Green is Bond's love interest Vesper Lynd... Green and Craig have electric chemistry on screen together... Vesper's character seems ambiguous, impudent and complicated... One night--slumped in the shower fully clothed, radiating inner beauty--her quiet look is capable to melt Bond's cold heart and free his doubtful mind... In another, she disconcerts him with her pretty 'Algerian love knot.'"Casino Royale" lacks the fundamental technology exhibition which plays an important part in any Bond films... The traditional "James Bond Gun Barrel Sequence" and the "James Bond Theme" disappeared... The only thin bit of continuity is Judi Dench's fifth return as the cool, scheming chief Lady M...Directed by Martin Campbell, the movie has it all: spectacular locations from Prague, London, Miami and Nassau-- and amazing actions involving the superb Aston Martin DB5 coupe in a high-speed mountain chase; a rush to stop a fuel tanker at Miami Airport; a combat with an Ugandan terrorist; a pursue in a four-wheel bulldozer; a breathless foot chase across highest cranes; and an unexpected climax in one of the buildings on the canals of Venice...
summary: "Do I look like I give a damn?"

reviewText: ****1/2The long-running James Bond franchise gets a much-needed  shot in the arm with "Casino Royale," a film which gives us, in the person of Daniel Craig, the least foppish, most rough-and-tumble 007 since the early days of Sean Connery.  Here's a Bond who's more at home in jeans and a polo shirt than in a perfectly tailored Giorgio Armani tuxedo (though he isn`t above wearing one, if the situation calls for it).  Gone, too, are many of the high-tech gadgets and preposterous, over-the-top villains that had begun to push the series increasingly into the realm of fantasy and camp and further away from reality.As conceived by writers Neal Purvis, Robert Wade and the seemingly ubiquitous Paul Haggis, Craig's Bond also has a noticeably darker side to his personality.  The authors have gone back to the source here, to Ian Fleming's first novel in the series, "Casino Royale."  This has allowed the writers to re-invent Bond almost from scratch as it were, and, indeed, the first scene of the movie - filmed in appropriately old-school black-and-white - shows us Bond literally gunning for his promotion to double O status (an agent can become an 00 only after he's successfully dispatched two victims).  Yet, despite this Bond's seeming indifference to human life, Craig brings a vulnerability and depth of character to the role that nicely counterbalance the dry cynicism, flippant tone and callous womanizing that are still crucial elements of the character`s mystique and makeup.  Yet, even in that latter category, this new Bond deviates from the old one by striking up a genuinely romantic relationship with the beautiful Vesper Lynd, nicely portrayed by Eva Green.The main plot - in which Bond finds himself on the Riviera playing in a high-stakes poker game against a notorious small-arms dealer - is secondary to the tense action scenes, wry humor and moral dilemmas that make "Casino Royale" a triumph for director Martin Campbell as well.After years of delivering one fine performance after another in a string of less high-profile but often very worthy films, it's gratifying to see Craig finally achieving the acclaim and stardom he so richly deserves with "Casino Royale."  With the help of his fellow filmmakers, he has nearly single-handedly resurrected this moribund franchise and reminded us of just how good a Bond picture can actually be.

reviewText: It's long and loud, and for much of the latter part of it, it's difficult to see just where "Casino Royale" is going, but it's still irresistible.  "Casino" has Bond out to stop a cold, calculating and compulsive gambler named Le Chiffre from bank-rolling hundreds of millions for terrorists.  The story occurs just as Bond has first received his "stripes" as a "double-o" agent for MI6 - a promotion he earns in a gritty pre-credits teaser by taking out a turncoat spy in Prague.  Sent to Madagascar to track a web of bomb-makers and their financiers, Bond instead assassinates the bomb-maker inside of a foreign embassy - an act of war unfortunately caught by closed circuit TV.  (Luckily for us, it also involves a dynamite foot-chase which has to be seen to be believed in and around a construction site.)  While M believes the mission a bust, Bond instead picks up the trail of the bomb-maker to Le Chiffre, figuring that the gambler's fortunes are tied to terrorism.  Hardly a believer in the causes he finances, Le Chiffre uses the millions of warlords to leverage his own schemes.  After Bond foils a spectacular scheme involving an airport and the maiden voyage of an airliner even bigger than the A-380, one that would have made millions for Le Chiffre, the terror-gambler is now stuck to earn his clients' money back.  For the West, it's a golden opportunity to catch Le Chiffre.  Unless he wins a multi-million dollar Poker Match in Montenegro, he'll have to surrender to Western intelligence or face the wrath of his ruthless clientele. (Bond's masters are betting on surrender.)That's about all I can say about "Casino" because it is definitely a plot-thin, attitude-thick movie.  Craig plays a Bond who seems new to the role of killing people, but looks to be anticipating the bruised soul that his new job will come with.  He bonds with Vesper Lynd, in ways that previous Bonds haven't pulled off with their women.  This Bond makes do without gadgets or even many funny catchphrases.  He gets bruised and beaten and he doesn't always have the steel resolve to insist on having his Martini shaken.  In other words, it's camp-free Bond - it's humorless but not without its share of wit.  It may not be your idea of a Bond movie, but it can't miss as a streamlined and efficient thriller.

reviewText: Yeah, I know what some of you are saying about the timeline of the James Bond saga.  But, I suppose that they want people to see every James Bond film as it's own unique project and not a series of stories that you would think that should play end to end.  Casino Royale is supposed to be the story that started it all.  All us original James Bond fans think of James Bond being about 40-ish back in 1962, so if that were the case, and if all these stories were to play end to end, shouldn't the Pierce Brosnan Bond be someone in his mid-80's?  Where's the appeal in that?  No, I believe every James Bond story is designed to be of the modern day of today.  The only thing that seems to link all the Bond films together is that we know James Bond married once, and she was then murdered.  This crucial part of the James Bond saga was done in a James Bond film by a guy who only did one Bond film, George Lazenby, in On Her Majesty's Secret Service. And in the beginning of For Your Eyes Only, you see James Bond (Roger Moore) in 1981 visiting his wife's grave (and the date of her birth and death is on the tombstone).Yes, having Judi Dench as "M" for the first time James Bond becomes licensed to kill does seem a little awkward when other Bond film's exist with her as "M".  Then in "Golden Eye", we have her describing herself as the new "M" meeting the "already employed" James Bond (with a long tracklist of past assignments in his file), and "Q" already established in the James Bond timeline as well.  But, we're not supposed to link these things together.  We're suppose to enjoy these stories as individual stories and not focus on a timeline.  So, yes it would be difficult to try and watch these stories in a probable fabricated order.  Like watching "Casino Royale" first, and then try "Dr. No" as the next story.  It doesn't work, does it?  James Bond has a 40 plus year history, however, he never ages, does he?  He's always about 40 to 45 years old.  But, who cares?And to close, in my opinion, I though Pierce Brosnan's "Die Another Day" was an excellent James Bond film.  I liked it better than "Golden Eye" which was once my first favorite Pierce Brosnan Bond film.  But, like most people, I think Sean Connery will always represent the perfect James Bond.  Perhaps because he was the first.  Roger Moore was a bit stiff and boorish to me compared to Connery.  But, the Roger Moore/James Bond era had some excellent stories for the James Bond saga.What was starting to bother me about some James Bond films, was that they were starting to get well-known established actresses to play the women that become Bond girls.  I like the Bond films better when they use some unknown beauty from other countries to represent the new Bond girl.  That gives the story a more personal charm when it may be the only film you will see of that particular actress.The James Bond saga may go on for another 40 years, and James Bond will never age.  He will just continue to look different when a new actor is needed to keep the James Bond saga alive.  Who knows, we might see a black James Bond someday, and in this "honest opinion condemning" politically correct world, we're not supposed to have anything negative to say about it.  So, we'll see.
summary: The James Bond timeline has gone askew, but don't let this bother you

reviewText: With the latest installment of the Bond saga, the entire series has been recreated in a new image that is more gritty, edgy and realistic. The facelift was beyond necessary as the series had become little more than a cheesy practice of stringing together enough bland action scenes and corny 1-liners to fill 2 hours of screen time.Daniel Craig's performance totally redefines Bond making him one tough customer but far less cartoony than prior incarnations. He's more interested in getting the job done and less concerned w/ being debonair. Another interesting note, he has character flaws, some of them major. At times his decisions are questionable or clouded by his ego. However he's clearly more of a man than any prior Bond that came before.There are enough other reviews to give you details about the story so I'll avoid that. I'll just end by saying the story is very good as is the action, the acting excellent all around and the combination of all of those things makes for the best Bond in many, many years. For those hi-def gurus out there, CR is about as perfect as it gets both for picture quality and audio. Altogether well done.
summary: Excellent Revamp That Was Desperately Needed

reviewText: My expectations were already lowered after the trailer as I don't know why in the world they would ever cast Daniel Craig as James Bond. Craig is better suited as a knight or warrior in a film set in the 11th century, but no, not as 007 - he doesn't fit that role at all.I don't know why Hollywood tries to package this film as a James Bond movie, because it certainly is not a Bond movie and Ian Fleming would revolve in his grave if he sees this mishap.Bond is all about style, a mystic, and flair and this movie is missing all of that. Given, as a no-name action flick I'll give it 3 1/2 stars, but as a Bond movie it's a disaster - this motion picture doesn't capture anything about James Bond. Yeah, the Aston Martin is there for a few seconds, and M is there, OK, well, but why I must ask? But I do know that I won't buy the DVD once it's released - I don't want to see this film ever again.The storyline is weak, the makeup kit was probably lost somewhere and a closeup of Craig's eyes gives you the rest. Yes, there's a high-stakes poker game, but any WPT episode on ESPN is more interesting than the one in Casino Royale - and by the way what a miss the title is. In our day and age with a mega budget somebody could do so much in a production, and then waste it on this film.All I'm expressing is my disappointment so that I will now watch the last Bond flick with Brosnan which was just absolutely phenomenal in comparison, and this Casino Royale I don't know why it is associated with the James Bond brand.
summary: Good Action Flick, but NO BOND and NO STYLE! ... maybe 3 1/2 stars

reviewText: I've been a fan of the Bond series since Sean Connery.  I've seen them all, and Casino Royale is one of my favorites.  This movie has it all with an interesting story, nice instrumental score, great action, intense drama, and heartfelt romantic scenes.  From the opening moments I was hooked.  I knew this was going to be a smart movie when they used the gun barrel introduction as part of the action.  Outstanding!Daniel Craig gives a good performance as Bond, and his range seems somewhat broader than some of the actors who've played Bond in the past.  Frankly, I would have a difficult time believing some of the previous incarnations would be capable of falling in love.  We also get to see the evolution of Bond from his heated and nieve beginning, to the complex and colder agent we all know.  I think Craig was a wise choice, and I look forward to his future roles.  I just hope the series continues to focus on story, and the more realistic elements of the Bond character.The extras are nice including: Becoming Bond, James Bond: For Real, Bond girls are forever, and the Chris Cornell Music Video.  If you're a fan of Bond, or just a great drama, pick up this DVD.
summary: One of the best Bond pictures

reviewText: Watching Daniel Craig reinvent James Bond in "Casino Royale" makes one wonder how fans ever tolerated the noble but graying Roger Moore in his later Bond films.  Craig's steel-blue eyes, clenched jaw, and massive shoulders remind us that Bond is first and foremost a killer.  Everything else - the women, the gadgets, the one-liners - are mere window dressing."CR" is the first James Bond novel written by Ian Fleming, and so the movie is essentially the prequel for the James Bond series of films.  The opening sequence shows Bond reaching "double-o" status.  His relationship with M (Judi Dench) is flinty.  And Bond is also naive about his new status.  After a bravura chase sequence in which Bond goes after a bomb-maker, one of those astounding urban acrobat types, Bond proves that he does not yet see the "big picture."  Bond's poor judgment forces M to put him on hiatus, and so Bond heads to the Bahamas.But Bond does not take anything lying down.  He knows that something is afoot with the bomb-maker he nailed in Uganda, and he needs to track down the guy who has hired the bomber.  Some clever detective work and opportunistic womanizing lead Bond to Le Chiffre (Mads Mikkelsen), a banker to the world's terrorists.  Le Chiffre is a bit reckless, however, and has some of his clients angry because he has lost their money.  All this leads to a huge poker game - no baccarat for Craig's Bond - where Bond, Le Chiffre, and the CIA's Felix Leiter (Jeffrey Wright) go head-to-head.In addition to being one of the most solid, well-crafted Bond movies ever, the delights in "CR" are found in how the movie plants the seeds of the James Bond legend.  We see how Bond forges his lifelong friendship with Felix.  We also see the birth of Bond's fondness for the vodka martini.  Perhaps most importantly, we get a little understanding about Bond's complex relationship with women after Vesper (Eva Green), a British banker, gets closer to him than any woman ever has.A beautiful film shot on gorgeous locations, "CR" knows that the Bond franchise needed a huge shot of adrenaline.  "CR" gives it that shot and then some.  Welcome back, Mr. Bond.
summary: Cold replaces suave as Daniel Craig takes over Bond

reviewText: Despite its box-office longevity, the James Bond franchise has been creatively bankrupt for years. Taking a page from the "Batman Begins" playbook, the 007 producers finally return to Ian Fleming's original creation - with an actor capable of redefining Bond while giving Sean Connery a run for his money. Thanks to Daniel Craig's masterful performance, a solid screenplay and Martin Campbell's bravura direction, "Casino Royale" emerges as the finest 007 effort since "On Her Majesty's Secret Service" (1969). Rarely has a Bond adventure contained so many terrific setpieces - accompanied by a strong emotional depth. When Craig's hard-edged 007 delivers the immortal closing line, we're revved up for the next installment.

reviewText: After forty years, twenty movies and five Bonds, it was reasonable to assume that the series had all the life ground out of it long ago -- how long, exactly, we could debate endlessly.  One thing, however, seemed certain: that Ian Fleming's original literary character had been washed away by a sea of cinematic silliness, giving only his name to a massive juggernaut of cheap thrills.Thank god we were wrong.  At last, at long, LONG last, we finally, finally, FINALLY have the first no-B.S. Bond since "From Russia With Love".  That's longer than I've been alive.What makes this version of Casino Royale -- the third one filmed, but the only one really worth watching -- so immensely satisfying is the fact that the writers have done essentially what Jeremy Brett did for Sherlock Holmes twenty years earlier: stripped away all of the extra elements added by the movie studios and returned to the origins of the character.  Gone are the flirtations with Moneypenny, the snippy banter with Q, the stupid gadgets, the white-cat-stroking megalomaniac master villains with their doomsday weapons controlled from underwater volcano fortresses filled with armies of jumpsuited technician, and (praise god for this above all else) the women with porn-star names and "Oh, James!" repertoires.  Bye-bye to all that nonsense, as enjoyable as it once was.Not to say that the action is lacking -- in fact, there are some terrific scenes in this movie, neatly combining cliffhanger thrills with down-to-earth locales.  An early chase scene involving dazzling free-running stunts is a particular standout.  But it never goes completely into fantasy land, a la Roger Moore's films.  Similarly, the plot, the villains, the violence, and even the gadgetry are well within the realm of possibility for a change.  Bond has access to the technology one might expect in the intelligence game: tracking devices, satellite uplinks and so on, but no lasers in the wristwatch or sport cars that turn into submarines.Best of all, Daniel Craig is Ian Fleming's Bond in a way that no other actor ever has been -- no, not even the venerable Sean Connery.  I realize it's widely considered somewhat blasphemous to suggest that Sean was anything less than perfect in the role, but I'm saying it here.  To his credit, this is mostly the fault of the writers and producers who quickly sacrificed the Hitchcockian suspense and characterizations of "From Russia With Love" for the comic-book goofiness of "Goldfinger" and all subsequent entries.  Connery himself has called "FRWL" his favorite, and it's easy to see why: it's about the last time he was given the chance to play the character AS a character.  George "love-him-or-hate-him" Lazenby touched on it, and the unjustly underrated Timothy Dalton tried valiantly to get back to that level of acting in the series, but he was swimming hopelessly against the tide at the time.  Roger Moore never really bothered, but relied instead on his own brand of screen presence to carry him through, and Pierce Brosnan was too busy keeping his head up in a series of increasingly over-the-top explosions.  But now, with this excellent reboot of the series, Craig has the opportunity to start fresh, applying himself to the reality of Bond, instead of living up to the massive, overwhelming screen-image of what has gone before.Critics of Craig's who claimed he was unfit or inappropriate for the role of James Bond have, I think, largely missed the point of the character.  He may well be the first Bond (except perhaps Connery) who was cast based on his skill as an actor rather than his potential as a matinee idol.  Certainly, he looks less like a pretty-boy movie star and more like a guy who can get the job done than most Bonds, and this is as it should be.  Bond himself, in one of the novels, resisted comparison to a movie star, claiming, "That's the worst insult you can pay a man."  Craig's Bond deftly avoids the mistake almost universally made by the previous movies: his James Bond, like Fleming's, is a very sexy figure, not because he's handsome or charming, but because he is cold, hard, and very dangerous.  This is a man who does the British government's dirty work, and wakes up each day knowing he may have to kill someone before he sleeps again.  He's a soldier with a polish-job, a la 'My Fair Lady', to let him wear the tux and pass among the beautiful people, but all the Cary Grant charm and the Hugh Hefner lifestyle aren't who he is inside; his true passion is the work, not the women.  Craig's Bond, like Fleming's, is a man who doesn't enjoy the killing, but takes pride in doing it well.And, at the end of the day, he is still: "Bond.  James Bond."
summary: At last, it's truly "Ian Fleming's" James Bond 007!

reviewText: No slam to Daniel Craig intended - I enjoyed him tremendously in Tomb Raider (particularly the shower scene? ;-)  That said, perhaps I just can't get past the inconsistencies in this film.  To name a few:1.  It is supposed to be Bond before/as he gets his 00 status.  Yet, Judi Dench is M.  Now, I think she is tremendous as M, but it doesn't fit the chronology.  I suspect she was used to pull in the fans as a familiar face in the franchise and while I understand the logic and love seeing her act whenever possible, it was not the best solution for this film.2.  The use of current technologies bugged me the whole time.  Like, how did Vesper Lynd get a Blackberry??  Cell phones everywhere??  No really cool gadgets, but technology that didn't belong.3.  WHERE IS Q??????????  Now sadly I am very well aware that Desmond Llewellyn couldn't play the role but the interaction between Bond and Q is a classic part of Bond lore that is sorely missing in this film.  They should have cast someone as the precursor to the Q we have known and loved through countless 007 films.I have every James Bond film and I fell asleep the first 4 times I watched this film.  I still don't really remember the end without having to really think about it.  The action was more like an Urban war movie, the gadgets - well, wrong.  I found the passion between Bond and Lynd unconvincing and just really didn't care one way or the other how it all came out I'm sorry to say.  As unpopular as it may be to say, I think the lions share of the blame lies with the script. I know from the special features that Cubby wanted to transform this book into film for decades but this implementation just didn't make it for me. I so very much hope that the next one recaptures the magic of James Bond.  Not just the unusual locales, the gadgets, Q and M, but the chemistry, witty dialog and sardonic humor that infects the most enjoyable of the franchise productions.  I just don't get the pure fun and enjoyment out of this one that I get watching other Bond films.

reviewText: I think Casino Royale was the best of them all.  Although it is hard to compare--this was made in a different time from the old ones.  The old ones were more friendly and had more of a warm, everything is okay feeling of fun.  But Casino Royale was gritty all the way through, and seriously dramatic and sad in the end.  There was never any real drama in any of the others.  If you pay attention, and watch it a couple times, at the end you can pick up the message the director and writers probably worked really hard to communicate: the movie showed how James Bond became what he was.  This movie covered the beginning of his career as a spy.  You notice at the beginning, the scene about him killing the first person whose life he'd ever taken--the guy he murdered in the men's room.  That means it was the beginning.After what happened in the movie at the end you then see how he would not care about any of the women he was with after Vespar and would be able to kill people indiscriminately.  I don't want to spoil it if someone hasn't seen it, but his heart was dead after what happened and he went from then on as a very hard man, like untouchable, using women and killing people.  Outstanding action, great story and acting, and a theme communicated effectively that took some real talent in the movie makers to show.

reviewText: Characters who have been around for a long time, basically crossing generational gaps, usually come to a point when they need a facelift to maintain their appeal for later generations.  Superman got one in the series, Smallville.  Batman got one in Batman Begins.  James Bond, which has been around for nearly fifty years on screen, was also badly in need of some reinvention.  After the Mission Impossible films and the Bourne films, it was clear that audiences are into much more serious characters than the tongue-in-cheek Bond.  In the last few Bond films, the wit was getting old, and people began to tire of the ridiculous, unrealistic stunts that Bond would pull off.  Jumping off a cliff on a motorcycle to climb into an airplane?!?Casino Royale puts Bond in a much more realistic light.  While he might have a couple of witty lines, he's very serious character who takes his job very seriously.  And while he might pull off some brilliant maneuvers, he's not performing stunts that are clearly outside the realm of possibility.  The audiences quickly responded to this new James Bond.  Sean Connery, Roger Moore, and Pierce Bronsan have each already christened Daniel Craig as THE new James Bond with high praise.Casino Royale takes us back to the very beginning of James Bond, before he's given his 007 status.  We get to see who Bond starts out and what events shape the man he will eventually become.  For example, you will be given a glimpse as to Bond's treatment of women.Bond is given his first assignment as a "00" agent.  He has to find a way to stop a man, LeChiffe, from funding terrorism by taking his money in a poker game.  Anyone who's watched the World Series of Poker will find the poker scenes to be crisp and suspenseful.  Bond is pegged as the best card player in the agency (no surprise there!), which is one of the reasons why he's chosen for this assignment.One good thing about this new Bond, is that he is not infallible; he makes mistakes, even being as good as he is, there are those who are even better.  The fun is watching how Bond finds ways to outsmart his opponents.  Gone are the times when things just happen to fall into place for Bond.  One mistake nearly costs him his life.Daniel Craig is a terrific James Bond.  Some people have already pegged him as their favorite Bond.  I still think it's hard to beat Sean Connery, but Daniel Craig comes awfully close.  Craig succeeds in making Bond his own character.  He isn't trying to mimick Connery, Brosnan, or anyone else.  His Bond is very serious, and many of the Bondisms are now gone.  For example during a scene at the bar, Bond asks for a martini.  The bartender asks, "Would you like that shaken or stirred?"  Bond growls back, "Do I look like I give a damn?"  I felt that Craig solidified his place as James Bond with this scene.  He told audiences then and there that he is not the James Bond that you're used to.  He's different Bond, and he should be.This movie is full of twists, suspense, and action.  Nothing is what it seems to be, and neither are the characters.  The movie will keep you on the edge of your seat, and right off the bat too with one of the greatest chase sequences to be filmed in recent years.  But best of all, Bond is now grounded in reality, and this reinvention helps to demonstrate why, for many people, James Bond is the quintessential hero.
summary: Re-Invention Gives Bond a Much Needed Facelift

reviewText: If you are going to introduce a new Bond, what better way to do it than go back to the beginning? This is exactly what Martin Cambell did in Daniel's Craig first movie as the beloved 007. We find a Bond at the start of his career, having recently attained the 00 status, and showing a personality that differs from what we are used to seeing from this character. I am not going to lie to you, Sean Connery still is, and probably will always be, my favorite Bond, but Craig comes pretty close to the Master. And he is undoubtedly better than the last couple of actors that attempted the feat of portraying one of the most charismatic secret agents ever.This time around, the plot takes us from Madagascar to the Bahamas. In the process we find bankers stealing money from Freedom Fighters, bomb-makers with clear and important targets in mind, a fair amount of poker playing, and of course, attractive women. The most interesting aspect of the movie is the differences in Bond's personality compared to the other movies. Here we can see how his attitude towards women changed and the reasons behind this. Also, there are many details that if you have watched the previous Bond productions you will not see in this one. Even though one of these shows up towards the end, you will miss several Bond traits that are always present. It is fun to go through the movie spotting these absences.The action scenes are exciting and even though they are unrealistic, as is usually the case with Bond movies, this aspect was toned down from the latest efforts. The high speed chase on foot in Madagascar is remarkable and very well filmed, and even though it runs for a fair amount of time, we do not get bored in the least. As I already mentioned, there is also quite a bit of poker playing. This is only natural, seeing the popularity this game has gained lately. The good news is that they managed to keep these scenes interesting and they fit well with the rest of the plot.Just when I was ready to accept that there will never be a James Bond that will make me want to see these movies again, I was pleasantly surprised by Craig. I am looking forward to his next effort and hope that we get many more at this level.
summary: "Quite the body count you are stacking up"

reviewText: This is one of the few movies that I bought prior to watching it. I've always enjoyed the early Bond movies with Sean Connery and some with Roger Moore but kind of lost interest in the late 80s. I picked this up for $21.89 in Feb 2012  which is not cheap considering all the great prices Amazon offers on many Blu-ray titles (now I see that it is currently not available directly from Amazon).The movie was OK. I was a little disappointed because I was expecting it to be a great movie reading all the positive reviews. Some action scenes were exaggerated  and contrived, especially the chase scene early in the movie. I don't want to give too many details if you have not seen it but that scene from start-to-finish was filled with excessive and unrealistic action sequences and ends up in way that contradicts Bond's character.As the plot thickens, the movie gets more interesting. Blu-ray transfer is really good as expected. If you are a fan of action movies and a casual fan of Bond franchise, you will probably enjoy this. But if you are cautious about the exagerrated action sequences and loyal to original Bond concept, you may find this not to your taste.

reviewText: Bond is back.Before he officially becomes 007, Agent James Bond (Daniel Craig, Layer Cake) is sent to spy on a terrorist cell in Madagascar and then to destroy the man, known as Le Chiffre (Mads Mikkelsen) who is bankrolling world terrorism in a high-stakes poker game in Montenegro.Absolutely brilliant. I loved this film. Signalling a real fresh start for the series, this film is far more serious and darker in tone than the cartoonish Die Another Day, and reminiscent of Christopher Nolan's "Batman Begins" in the sense of being a welcome reboot for the franchise.Daniel Craig is fantastic, he is not just a good Bond, he IS Bond, closer in tone to Timothy Dalton or Sean Connery, than Pierce Brosnan (with the exception of Die Another Day I really enjoyed Brosnan's films though) or Roger Moore, and has little in the way of quips. He is coldhearted, less suave and quite egocentric and rude, as he's learning the ropes of being an agent at this point before he is given his Licence to Kill by his boss "M" (Judi Dench), he's like a prototype Sean Connery.Some great action, an early fight on top of a crane reminded me of the climatic fight of 1995's excellent "Goldeneye" - perhaps the best Pierce Brosnan outing, no coincidence that film was also directed by Martin Campbell.I think the film is a wee bit long (145 minutes is quite long for an action film), and couldn't believe it was a UK 12A (cinema rating) as some stuff was definitely not for kids and quite brutal.I loved the humour in the film, there were some very funny moments that had me laughing out loud in places. I loved the part when the barman asks Bond if he takes his drink shaken or stirred, Craig growls "Does it look like I give a damn!" sending up a cliché of the series, or the part when he drove in a circle to get back to his "home"! What was especially good was how the film could be amsuing without resorting to the groanworthy puns of earlier films.I liked how the character of Bond could be vulnerable though and feel pain (something hinted at in Die Another Day). I think the hero is more realistic if he is not a Superman.I won't spoil the ending for you, but it certainly keeps you on tenderhooks for the next film.
summary: Daniel Craig is Bond. James Bond.

reviewText: Casino Royale is the 21st official James Bond movie and the first in the series to star Daniel Craig as James Bond. It's based off the Ian Fleming novel and essentially reboots the franchise with 007's first major case, to bring down the terrorist banker Le Chiffre (Mads Mikkelsen).Similar to what Batman Begins did for its franchise in 2005, Casino Royale takes a formulaic pop culture icon and makes him relevant and exciting again by bringing back the basics. I'm a huge Bond fan and I would've been happy with more Bond films in the vein of the Brosnan era, but this installment is like the breath of fresh air I didn't know I needed. Suddenly we have a James Bond that gets to develop as a real character, a beautiful love interest that really matters (Eva Green will go down among the best of the Bond girls), and action sequences that are intense and edgy without looking like they've been coated in the usual Hollywood gloss. This may be the 21st film in the franchise, but it stands on its own as a great movie and that's what makes Casino Royale work.The original 2-disc release was barren of any really relevant features, so while I usually avoid the double-dips, this was one Collector's Edition that was worth it. You get everything that was in the 2-disc set, plus a third disc loaded with deleted scenes and documentaries. Most interesting are a segment discussing the legal entanglements that kept EON Productions from making Casino Royale until now, and a documentary on the effects-heavy Venice finale.  Note the box lists a visual commentary by the producer/director, but the visual are only for the Blu-Ray edition.Blu-Ray or standard def, this edition of Casino Royale is worth owning.

reviewText: This is the best new James Bond film I've seen for a long time. The pre-credits sequence is very good, and its a shame they didn't maintain some of that style in the main film. This is Bonds last mission before he gets his double O status.Daniel Craig does bring something new to Bond. He is mean and ruthless, but underneath there is still a heart in there. The plot is simple, leading to a very high-stakes poker game at the Casino Royale, which was one of the best scenes in the film for me - quite mesmerising. Mads Mikkelsen as Le Chiffre made a worthy opponent to Craigs Bond, both at the Poker table and as a torturer. This latter sequence is extremly unpleasant and certainly not for youngsters. Judi Dench played M again and although it was only a small part she was, as always very good.The film isn't perfect though, their are a few sequences (such as at the airport and the sinking house at the end) which are typical Hollywood blockbuster stuff and unneccessary. The film is also a little to long. They could have chopped 10 or 15 minutes, ideally from the above scenes, and it would have been a much better film.Overall though this is well worth seeing. The extras on the two disc edition are well worth watching. They include an interesting documentary about the various Bond Girls throughout the history of James Bond films and a documentary about the making of the film.

reviewText: Have you ever seen the original full-length feature of Casino Royale made in 1967? It is unwatchable. For whatever reason, the 1967 version had multiple directors (Ken Hughes and John Huston) and they took Fleming's first Bond novel and turned it into a star-studded, comedian actor filled spy movie satire. In a confusing mess there is even more than one actor playing Bond (Peter Sellers and David Niven).Anyway, in 2006 along comes Martin Campbell (who also did GoldenEye in 1995) to direct and bring integrity back to the film adaptation of Casino Royale. Adding to the 2006 version's strength is a bold new 21st Century Bond.Big and small screen vet Daniel Craig takes over as 007, and he's terrific.Set in the present, Casino Royale shows you a brief look at how Bond attains "00" (two kills) status, first in a black and white (perhaps a salute Bond's true birthday in 1953) short scene, and then in a surreal pursuit that includes the human ability to fly...well almost...you know, like in those new Kung Fu movies?After these brief opening scenes I was a bit skeptic that the rest of the movie would follow suit in the unbelievable. But I was pleasantly surprised. Sure, there is no lack of the sensational, death defying feats that Bond commits throughout. But it was all done with...what was the word I used earlier?...Ah yes: Integrity.Hopefully there will be some more Bond movies with Craig (at least one is planned for 2008). And as long as the writers and directors can hold together what Campbell has certainly revitalized, the Bond franchise could be something to look forward to for years to come.Casino Royale was great. This is the version that I will point to as "the first" Bond movie...and perhaps the best.

reviewText: I was bored of Bond. Blam Blam. Sleep with disposable woman. Bond, James Bond. Martini, shaken, not stirred. Sleep with evil woman. Car chase. Find bad guy's lair. Blam Blam. Cheesy one-liner. Bad guy dies. Sleep with disposable woman. Roll credits.The formula is entertaining enough, but not even an iconic figure like Bond can stay one-dimensional and expect to continue to keep our interest forever. Bond seemed to be stuck in the 70's, where the sexual innuendo and bloodless violence actually pushed the envelope.I was glad to see that the newest Bond film attempted to show Bond as fallible, occasionally uncertain, and often hampered by the very arrogance and confidence that makes him distinctly Bond. This is a guy whose instincts just barely manage to keep him ahead of his own recklessness, a self-centered egomaniac who respects the law only slightly more than the villains he hunts, but also a man who can still make meaningful emotional attachments.Craig strikes a good figure as Bond, and Eva Green is enchanting as Vespar. All in all, the movie is closer to the Bourne series than it is to the earlier Bond films. You'll either love the transition or hate it, so try before you buy.
summary: Blond Bond - Includes Attitude and Bonus Emotions

reviewText: I think most people was caught up with the whole "Bond" thing, new actor, etc. and didn't notice some real big "faux pas". Although there has never been real dates set, and you can't just deal with the making of the first Bond movie (Dr. No), there were events that gave you an opportunity to know approximately what decade if nothing else you were in. This Bond, which is supposed to depict the "beginning" for James, has several references to things that happened more recently than the older Bond movies indicated but mostly, has M making the biggest mistake in her speech when she speaks of "9/11". Please, didn't anyone hear that?I don't usually notice mistakes on the part of the writers, wardrobe people, set designers or actors when I see a movie for the first time (unless it is sooooo bad)because I am intent on the movie and sometimes I never pick up anything unless it is pointed out to me, but this was so blatant that when I heard it my mouth dropped open. C'mon folks, don't tell me that you can actually put that reference in the beginning of the James Bond '007 saga?S from NY

reviewText: The James Bond series always seemed to me to have a bit more potential than it delivered.  The world's best secret agent going up against an array of colorful, dastardly evil-doers in exciting locations all over the world, beautiful women abounding as both allies and enemies, creative deathtraps, stunt-filled adventure on a massive scale...  But, although I haven't seen all the previous Bond movies (and maybe the only problem is that I've missed the really good ones and seen mostly the 'lesser' entries) it seems to me that there's always been one problem or another getting in the way.  A couple of the chapters where they attempted to make it more humorous, they missed the mark and ended up getting campy.  During a number of the movies, the Bond character himself seemed way too cold and arrogant, less the hero that I figured a 007-type character should be, than a guy who mows down whoever his government tells him to and doesn't really have feelings one way or the other about it.In "Casino Royale", ironically, it's not by launching Bond as a more heroic figure but by making him - at the start - colder, meaner and more emotionless than ever, that sets the film off on becoming the best of the series (based on the ten or so I've seen) and among the greatest action/espionage movies ever.  This prequel/remake, starting before James Bond even makes it to Britain's elite 007-status, depicts him in its early stages as a killer without conscience or emotional connections, lethally efficient and ice cold.  As it moves along "Casino Royale" neither ignores this seemingly non-heroic status or goes into a detailed backstory, but drops a few hints as to the origins of Bond's persona and what it is that really drives him, under the surface.  The plot of the show has Bond and the UK's intelligence service trailing a group of arms dealers who supply numerous dictators and terrorists worldwide, eventually leading to the world's premiere gambling event.  There, the central mastermind of the arms cartel is trying a last-ditch effort to gather the funds to cover a slew of deals gone bad because of Bond's interference, before his clients, disgruntled over not receiving their merchandise, come looking for him.The relationship that develops between Bond and the female government agent, Vesper Lynd (Eva Green), assigned to him, is totally atypical of the usual agent/girl pair-ups in the Bond series, and it's the story between Bond and Lynd as much as the spy thriller story that makes "Casino Royale".  It's done totally convincingly; so are the other aspects of the movie.  The action and stuntwork are fantastic and believable, and I doubt any other movie has ever devoted so much time to a black-tie poker tournament and managed to make it so riveting and entertaining.  Bond is a more nuts-and-bolts fighter here, tending to just beat the living daylights out of the bad guys with his fists instead of using remote-controlled cars with rocket launchers under the hoods.  Daniel Craig brings the character to life with a career-making performance."Casino Royale" starts James Bond off seeming to be little more than a cold assassin, develops the character, bringing out hidden aspects of him, and changing him into a more likable figure, then crashes him down to rock bottom psychologically before the final act.  It really remains to be seen which side of the fence he'll have ultimately landed on for future movies, but I hope they continue progressing Bond, and any other returning players, in the future movies rather than just letting "Casino Royale" be a stand-alone.  I also hope they'll return as many performers in their Casino roles (such as Judi Dench as M) as possible rather than doing a lot of recasting.  I think the future of the movies could see much more of a focus on a recurring or semi-recurring ensemble, with James Bond still at the center of course.  The best era for the 007 series may have only begun.
summary: 9 Out Of 10 - The Best Bond Movie I've Seen

reviewText: While Sean Connery still reigns supreme looks-, charisma-, and talent-wise as 007, Daniel Craig gives the classic Bond actor a run for his money in "Casino Royale," the high-octane, high-thrill film that rediscovers the secret agent's mojo.  This adventure, billed as a prequel to the Bond series, is really more of an adjustment, giving Bond both blond locks and a Gen-X history to bring him into the 21st century while distancing him from more recent outtings.  It also jettisons the paint-by-numbers approach of the Pierce Brosnan films, which capitalized on the actor's contemporary model looks and a formula that while comfortably familiar to some was wearing too thin for others.Here, Bond is raw and hungry, a headstrong, macho torpedo who has more in common with the Bond created by Connery than the one popularized by Brosnan.  Not long after brutally earning his 007 status, Bond is sent to capture a terrorist bomber, only to stumble upon a much bigger operation bankrolled by oily gambler Le Chiffre (with a terrifically understated performance by Mads Mikkelsen).  Along the way, he's aided by the charming Mathis (Giancarlo Giannini) and falls for Vesper (vixenish Eva Green), the lovely British agent sent to help him . . . or is she?Staying truer to the spirt of the Fleming novel than much of the film series that followed, "Casino Royale" still manages to inject stunning stunt and action sequences, orchestrated with the surprisingly steady hand of director Martin Campbell.  While the generally serious tone of the film (read:  it takes itself seriously) has much to do with its success, most of the credit belongs to Craig, who turns in a performance that somehow mates the deadly frank approach of Timothy Dalton to the confident masculinity of Connery.  The result is the best Bond since Sir Sean stepped down.Other highlights include Dame Judi Dench's meatiest performance as M, a decent, if derivative, score by David Arnold, and a script (polished by Paul Haggis) that gives Bond some smarts again.  Even the romance here works for the most part.  All that said, are there some problems?  Sure.  Good as he is, Craig is still rough around the edges, the film could have benefitted from about 10 minutes more of romance, and there are plot points that are, to put it kindly, murky.  But, hey, if "Casino Royale" is the blueprint for future Bond films, then these weaknesses can easily be overlooked.  After all, as someone put it, this is less a James Bond film than a film about James Bond.
summary: Good to have James Bond back after all these years

reviewText: XXXXXThis movie is based on the book "Casino Royale" (1953) by the late Ian Fleming.  It is the 21ST  "official" (meaning EON Productions) Bond movie with Daniel Craig being the 6TH actor to play James Bond.Before this movie came out, Bond movies covered a period of 40 years beginning with 1962's "Dr. No" and ending with 2002's "Die Another Day."This movie is about James Bond receiving his "double oh" status and completing his first mission as "007."The movie's strong points are that it has a lot of action and good special effects.  In fact, before explaining anything to the viewer, there is a long chase scene with death-defying leaps and bounds.  It is quite well done.  There is another long chase scene that follows this chase.  It, too, is quite well done.Unfortunately, the story is difficult to follow and is somewhat complicated.  In fact, I had to view this movie twice in order to completely understand it.It is after about 50 minutes (that's right, 50 minutes!!) into this long movie that you actually learn exactly who Bond was chasing both times and you learn the details of Bond's first assignment.You have to understand two things in order to understand Bond's first assignment: the basics of how stock options work and the basics of a poker game called "Texas Hold'Em" (a variation of the poker game called seven card stud).  This, personally, is why I'm amazed that this movie has received such high ratings from others--I don't believe that all people who view this movie know such things.  For the record, I know the basics of these things and, in fact, my interest increased at this point.For Bond's first assignment we're told what he has to do.  Oddly enough, we're not told why he has to do it.  I found this frustrating and had to guess why he was on this assignment.  It turns out I guessed right by reading some articles about this movie after I had viewed it.  The point is that you will have to do some guessing while watching this movie.You may need a brochure to figure out all the bad guys that pop in and out.  The main villain seems to be someone called Le Chiffre (Mads Mikkelsen), "private banker to the world's terrorists."  What I noticed is that this villain is not very villainous (except in his last few scenes).The Bond girl has the name of Vesper Lyn (Eva Green).  She's integral to the plot and especially to the movie's long, somewhat predictable, ending.  The ending reminded me of the 1969 Bond movie called "On Her Majesty's Secret Service."  Sean Connery who was playing Bond at the time wisely did not perform in this movie.When viewing this movie, don't expect to see the James Bond that you've seen in the last forty years.  There is no Miss Moneypenny, no gun barrel walk, no Q and, thus no gadgets.  (Apparently in the book, Q is not mentioned so there are no gadgets.  Actually, there is a gadget that Bond in this movie uses extensively--a cell phone.)In my mind's eye, I compared Daniel Craig to the other five Bond actors that came before him (namely Sean Connery, George Lazenby, Roger Moore, Timothy Dalton, and Pierce Brosnan).  In my opinion, he doesn't fit the mold of a James bond.  Sure, he's physically fit but there's more to Bond than just being fit!  (Actually, Craig does look like Bond in the last thirty seconds of the movie.)I also missed the Bond music.  The background music is good but does not compare to the distinctive music associated with James Bond movies. (Bond-type music is played when the end credits roll.)The thing I missed most is the James Bond witticisms and snappy dialogue.  For example, here is some dialogue from 1964's "Goldfinger" where Bond is tied down on a gold slab with a laser beam cutting the slab and slowly inching up threatening to cut Bond in half:Bond says to Goldfinger: "You don't expect me to talk, do you?"Goldfinger's priceless reply:  "No, Mr. Bond.  I expect you to DIE."Now, this movie is not entirely devoid of humor but it's not nearly as witty as expected.Filming for this movie took place in the Czech Republic, Bahamas, Italy, and England.Finally, the DVD (the one released March, 2007) I have is perfect in picture and sound quality.  There are several interesting extras included on a second disc.In conclusion, for those who are not James Bond fans and looking to see a good action movie, this is the film to see.  However, many true Bond fans may ask themselves the following:"Is this a James Bond movie or is this an action movie that happens to have somebody named James Bond in it?"(2006;  2 hr, 25 min;  wide screen;  2 discs;  28 scenes)<<Stephen Pletko or "Uncle Stevie," London, Ontario, Canada>>XXXXX
summary: Is this a James Bond movie or an action movie that has someone named James Bond??  You decide!!

reviewText: And trust me, I'm one of the ultimate James Bond fans.  I know the character, the books, and the films very well.  Does that make me an expert? No.  But I do feel I can comment on the film.  It was not one of the best Bond films, just average.  But it had potential to be one of the best.  Don't get me wrong.  I liked the film.  It had some awesome stunts that have been sorely missing since Goldeneye and before that.  The locations were excellent.  The action awesome.  The story brillant.  The villians very cool.  And the girls beautiful and smart.  All elements of an exellent Bond film.  But three elements held it back.1. The critics overhype Craig's performance.  They claim his Bond is closest to the novels.  Not so.  Timothy Dalton's performance was actually closets to the Bond of Ian Fleming.  He took the time to read all the books, to look into the character and to get a feel for how Bond operated.  Craig on the other hand just played the role as he felt Bond should be played.  I understand the producers wanting to break away from the traditional Bond.  But this Bond is actually more reckless than Ian Fleming's.  But Danial Craig does have potential to become great as the character.2. While I don't mind a breaking away from the formula of Bond and trying new territory, please don't mess with certain things that give it the feel of a Bond film.  The first is messing with the gun barrel logo.  This has been used at the very beginning of every Bond film.  To change it takes away from it feeling like a true Bond film.  Second, the gadgets.  They are essential to James Bond as a character on film.  I know it wasn't like this in the books, but we're talking about film.  These are what make it a Bond film.3. And finally, the movie was too long by 15 minutes.  This is what really made it miss it's target.  It was the longest Bond film ever made.  I guessed the ending of the movie long before it happened simply because scences in which ran too long also gave too much plot away.  Simply put they would have made great deleted scence for DVD.  And other certian scence just seemed out of sequence to the movie's pacing.  Case in point the shower scene.  Right after a major action scene, Bond sits back down at the poker table, but before anything happens, it cuts to him entering the room before the story resumes and then proceeds into a useless scene that really had no point to the story.  I could point out several more little things that could have gone, and made this a terrific Bond picture.  Main point: Too Long!
summary: Casino Royale a little bit overly-hyped by fans and critics

reviewText: I had a such a opportunity to see this film on Advanced screening presented by Sony last night. There have been very controversial and negative gossips and publicities about this upcoming film ever since Sony pictures announced Daniel  Craig for new James Bond.After the screening ended I felt very strange.Well, movie was great.  It has great physical actions, less explosions and CGI, and focusing on characters great plots, great lines with surprisingly great delivery.  It clearly portraits where James Bond was coming from.  So as sake of the criticism of the film, it was darn good film.  The movie was darker and more realistic than previous James Bond sequels, besides On her Majesty Secret Service (which is also great film)  but those elements made this film great.My cons on this film would be:  Daniel Craig's bodybuilders body.  I always except old-fashioned hero as James Bond with natural athlete's body.  Like Once Sean Connery possessed.  And he does not have cookie cutter elegance and charm of Bond.  It does not make him a terrible Bond just to be fair.  I just didn't like to see James Bond is transforming into something different.  Just because of movie got realistic and darker, it lost it's corniness and fantasy aspects of film which is the charm of the franchise, but I think it was inevitable to make this good film.For the best or worst, this franchise has evolved something different, and we all are gonna be judge of this updated Bond franchise..........
