reviewText: After enduring Pierce Brosnan through four films (Of which only one was fantastic), and with the series becoming too formulaic, it was time for 007 to undergo a slight re-invention. Enter "Casino Royale," the first Bond film to be based on an Ian Fleming novel since 1987's "The Living Daylights." Fan expectations were high, to say the least. My expectations were no exception. Would Daniel Craig do good? Could they change the format AND stick true to the Bond mythos?After seeing the film, I was happy! "Casino Royale" is one of the best films in the series, if not the best. The action sequences are fantastic, with very little use of CG effects. The plot and storytelling, missing from recent entries in the series, are both believable and exceptional. The many twists and turns will have you on the edge of your seat until it's exciting, emotional climax.Daniel Craig makes a fantastic Bond. Unlike recent actors in the role, his 007 is gritty and violent. You don't wanna make him mad. He won't just punch ya, he'll lay into you like a starving man on a Christmas ham. But Craig also manages to give Bond a more emotional edge, making his version of the character the most compelling yet.Eva Green is both smart, funny, and sexy as Vesper Lynd, one of the best Bond girls ever. Mads Mikkelsen is truly sinister as Le Chiffre, but also brings a bit of humanity to the role, making his villain one of the most compelling. Jeffrey Wright and Judy Dench give great performances as well.In conclusion, "Casino Royale" has helped resuscitate the Bond franchise, and created the best entry in the series in the last twenty years. Fans will not be disappointed, and non-fans may finally see what's up with Bond! I highly recommend it!Grade: A+
summary: JAMES BOND RETURNS IN A THRILLING ACTION EPIC!

reviewText: After having seen this new bond, Daniel Craig, and this new style of Bond film, I have to admit that my earlier doubts were for nothing as this film is probably the best in the entire franchise, even if Craig isn't my favorite Bond.  NOTE:  Keep checking the gross for this newest Bond film as it will easily become the most successful Bond film coming in at a cost of $150 million, but bringing in over $500 million.  Somebody must be liking Craig as much as I am.  We may be "shaken" up by a new Bond, but the producers are "stirred" in the right direction.  Sorry, I couldn't help the pun.  Now, let's take a moment here to review the Bonds of the past.Sean Connery will probably always be the definitive Bond for most of us as he originated the role and was the most successful at blending humor, sexiness, and ruthlessness in a character that is rather flat but ever engaging.  He himself got into a dispute with the Bond producers over money, the lack of character development, excessive use of special effects, and, in his words, "a tired formula."  The producers saw fit to replace him with the very forgettable George Lazenby who played Bond in only one film,On Her Majesty's Secret Service.  He damn near sank the franchise because he couldn't act worth a dime.  Connery was rehired to do one more Bond film which lacked some of the effects and grand scale of earlier Bond films in order to appease Connery who disliked that stuff, but ended up quitting the role anyhow after completing one "official" Bond film for him.Roger Moore succeeded Connery quite easily because he already had a following due to hisThe Saintseries; however, he was a bit too cartoonish in the role.  He joked far too much and never had that ruthlessness that Connery had and Bond needed, but Moore was, nevertheless, successful throughout most of his tenure as Bond.  An interesting side note here is that Sean Connery returned as admittedly aged Bond in 1983 outside of the normal Bond producers inNever Say Never Againand while Moore beat him at the box office back then, the producers where showing signs of restlessness with Moore as Bond; he ended up doing only one more Bond film.The producers began seek to reinvigorate the franchise in the mid-80's.  They wanted to heed Connery's warning about character development, but also wanted to return to his suave look and ruthless style again only laced with some trademark humor and not some of the silly punchlines Moore was attracted to during his tenure as Bond.  They tried to sign on Pierce Brosnan in 1987 after his popular seriesRemington Steelehad been canceled just as they had signed on Moore after his "Saint" series ended.  These two already had a following so-to-speak.  Brosnan was ready and willing, but the Remington Steele producers saw money to be made in all the hype over Brosnan playing Bond that they would not release him from his contract and restored the series to prime-time.  Brosnan then lost the part to Timothy Dalton and his Remington Steele series flopped in its final year and was axed mid-season anyhow.  Brosnan made a series of bad low-budget flicks for awhile before disappearing altogether for a few years.  He then did a cola ad playing a Bond-like character trying to get his drink and this made the studio remember him for later.Although Timothy Dalton never really caught on as Bond (hence he was let go after his two picture deal was completed), his films did well enough, but they were rather forgettable.  The studio wanted Brosnan from day one, but settled on Dalton when they couldn't get him.  Dalton was a departure for the Bond-type in that he was more serious and moody, less humorous, and definitely more ruthless and cold.  This pleased the studio as they wanted some change for Bond; however, the public never caught on to Dalton's Bond even though his versions did well enough at the box office and everyone, including Dalton, seemed happy when his contract was not renewed.  Dalton then all but disappeared from the silver screen.Now depending on how you look at it, this twist of events either helped restore Bond to the more traditional image with the firing of Dalton and the hiring of Brosnan, who Connery himself praised as Bond, or it convinced the studio to never tamper with a formula, tired or successful, again.  Brosnan was a suburb Bond and at a very young looking 54 he certainly had more Bond life left in him.  In addition, unlike Moore who was only a "passable actor", and Dalton who was over-the-top serious (come on this ain't Shakespeare), Brosnan was right in the middle, but became a much better actor as the years went on.Once again money and creative disputes caused a rift between the Bond player and the Bond producers and Brosnan was inexcusably fired in the most unprofessional manner, via a fax, after just starring in the most successful of all the Bond films; it raked in $400+ worldwide.  After the success ofBatman Begins, the studio decided to reinvent, to some degree, Bond.  Enter Daniel Craig.Craig's level of believability is more like Dalton's Bond who attempted to bring a moody dark side to the role.  Craig is not as good looking as previous Bonds, but he is a terrific actor and very athletic which is another throw back to Connery.  He may not be the best at blending the various elements of the role as Connery did and to some degree Brosnan too, but he is making the role his own.  He may never become my favorite Bond, but I can't fault his performance and, unlike Dalton's Bond, Craig will be remembered for the role even if it's his only entry into this franchise.  Although the entire franchise was mostly successful and the last Bond film with Brosnan was the highest grossing at the time, it was in need of something new.I will always love Connery's Bond, closely, very closely followed by Brosnan's Bond; however, Craig is an exceptional actor who brings much needed depth to a flat, stereotypical role and the script written by Paul Faggis ofMillion Dollar BabyandCrashfame raises the bar significantly for all future Bond films in that there really is a significant storyline here with surprising twists and turns for a "formula" film.  This series of films always lacked suspense because we knew the formula so well, but that is all changed with this entry and that is saying a lot.If this is Craig's only Bond turn, it will be a great loss for the series.  I'm sold on this guy in the role.  I still think Brosnan had several more good Bond films in him and I highly resent the way he was fired, but that shouldn't be taken out on Craig who had no real part in those decisions.  He is a worthy successor to Brosnan who should be on to better things now that he is free from "Bondage."  Check out his outstanding performance inThe Matadorlast year and see what a great actor he's become.  I think he's destined for a post-Bond career very much like Connery's.  He has proven to be a diverse actor beyond the Bond films.  You might wanted to also check him out inMrs. Doubtfire, andDante's Peakto see what I mean.
summary: Casino Royale was a Gamble Worth Taking

reviewText: I had SERIOUS doubts about Daniel Craig in this role, but my concerns are long since dead. The new character that Craig brought to Bond was unmistakable. My review of this movie is that you can't get much better than this. Mads Mikkelsen was TREMENDOUS in King Arthur, and excellent here too. Eva Green could not have been more beautiful (I really LOVE the way they didn't airbrush the birthmarks and freckles off this girl to make her look more "perfect"; she was plenty perfect on her own). Sadly, the second two movies after this did NOT match up to these standards whatsoever....  Casino Royale had: the BEST two Bond girls in a LONG time, EXCELLENT banter back and forth between Bond and Vesper Lynd, the right amount of violence and arrogance from Bond (a la Connery) and BY FAR the best script in a Bond movie since Goldeneye. Everything about this film was better than many before it, and certainly better than Quantum or Skyfall. Skyfall might has well have been any modern day violent thriller, nothing new about the script whatsoever. I was quite disappointed. Last but not least, the intro sequence with the incomparable Chris Cornell on vocals blows you away every time. Not only the music but the very creative intro piece with the hearts and spades and the villains was AWESOME... A far cry from the lackluster song by Adele on Skyfall. I really hope they can pull off the same entertainment and creativity again with a new Bond movie. They must have been really HUNGRY (all of them) to make a movie THIS GOOD..  hope they can do it again!

reviewText: This movie should definitely succeed at its goal of reviving the Bond series.  Updated for current times and starting anew from the beginning it works very well.  Although there will always be some cheesiness in a Bond movie this one keeps it to a minimum.  Bond is back to a more down to earth, gritty and even vulnerable human.The movie kicks off with intense action and then slows down to focus more on the plot.  The second portion is far from boring though.  The acting is very good, and the characters are believable for the most part.Very good movie and for once I am looking forward for the next one to come out.  Highly recommended.

reviewText: With all the hyperbole and commotion regarding the selection of Daniel Craig as James Bond, one would think this movie would rank low in the 20+ Bond movie catalogue.  Surprisingly, Casino Royale (2006) revising a franchise that appeared to be coasting on its laurels and becoming more extreme and foolish at every turn.Casino Royale returns us to the origins of James Bond.  Amazingly played with emotion and grit like no other Bond, Daniel Craig introduces us to a fresh new Bond character ready to fly into action.  The action sequences are amazing and adrenalized, and the story moves with an excellent pace (even though the movie is slightly longer than most Bonds).The Poker scenes are well shot, and the banter between M and Bond show once again why Judi Dench is a spy-diva's dream.  The movie is so satisfying that it leaves us wanting for more Bond, and soon.  Well done!
summary: Gritty and action packed Bond thriller returns to origins

reviewText: This James Bond thriller was such a refreshing take on a character that is one of the film industry's great icons. Unlike past films, in which Bond relies heavily on gadgetry and sexual prowess, "Casino Royale" demonstrates his skill as a highly trained, cold-blooded killer, pure and simple. Give the man a gun, and he'll get the job done. (Actually, the gadget guy "Q" doesn't even appear in this movie). Also missing from the movie are the tired, cliche megalomaniac heavies who are plotting to overthrow the world (actually, the best one in recent memory was "Dr. Evil" from the Austin Powers trilogy--Michael Myers completely deflated the pretensions of the power-hungry madman)."Casino Royale" shows Bond earning his "00" designation, that is, his famous license to kill at will, after performaing two assassinations. Without giving away too much of the plot, I can only commend the filmmakers for some of the best chase scenes ever put on film, particularly the foot chase that opens the movie.

reviewText: Casino Royale has finally completed a circle for me that was for far too long left in limbo. As as a child growing up in the 70's watching the Connery 007 films on weekend television I was enthralled. However, I was born into the Roger Moore era which didn't always impress me in comparison to Sean Connery's efforts. What was this ineffable 'je ne sais quoi' that the Roger Moore films lacked in comparison to the Sean Connery films? Well, I'll tell you - with the Connery Bond films there was always a dark edge of realism, something gritty and nasty cooking beneath the surface. Bond in the hands of Connery was certainly a darker character and not so politically correct showing clear signs of misogyny and at times out and out chauvinism. Connery played the character as Flemming had imagined him and while Bonds world is no joke he is a man with a black sense of humour.After being spoiled by the greatness of the Connery Bond films as a boy on TV I grew up seeing all the Roger Moore films on the big screen and yet always preferring the Sean Connery treatment. With the 1970's Bond turned more towards a character of largess, exaggeration and buffoonery. The jokes got hammy losing their dark poignancy and as the stunts got bigger the girls became more important than the plot! Under Roger Moore James Bond became a gigolo with a gun rather than an agent of the British Secret Service ... suffice it to say the more unreal and cartoon like the Bond series got the more I lost interest and longed for producers to get back on track with a more Connery like Bond series!It has been a VERY long wait indeed ... the rogues gallery of would be Bonds to follow Roger Moore were really no better with Timothy Dalton doing a passable job in his effort but hardly hitting the mark. Peirce Brosnan was a good choice in theory, if you merely wanted to continue the Roger Moore era of Bond as 'gigolo with gun' trajectory but who would believe Brosnan as a hard boiled and grave British agent like Flemmings creation indicates? Did anyone ever believe for a moment that Brosnan or any of the other pretenders would be able to seriously handle themselves in the kind of lethal close quarters/hand to hand combat witnessed in many of these films?For example, James Bond is the Jason Bourne par excellence and the grandfather of that type of brutal and nasty killing at close range ... Brosnan would be finished in about 3 seconds against experienced killers of the underworld he frequents. Looking at Connery with his build, stature, grave self confidence and bleak sense of humour he always exuded a rugged muscularity and element of mongrel that Bond requires in his line of work ... this is key to Bonds longevity when compared to other 00's! So finally when I heard that they were recasting the character of James Bond I threw my hands up in the air, rolled my eyes and wondered what new guy they might get who could further flog to death the great 007 that Sean Connery had created, YET AGAIN!When the name Daniel Craig was first announced I was indignant simply due to a knee jerk reaction to all others who came before - then I started reading the press and then I started to ignore the press and look at Craig as an actor - I started watching his interviews about the role of Bond and reading some articles. Hmmm, could this guy be the one I had been waiting for the put things right again and to finally carry the mantle of Bond in the Connery tradition? Nothing could be confirmed until I went and saw the film for myself but I usually let the latest Bond release pass by until it hit the DVD stores. What I began to see in the previews and trailers excited me for the first time since my youth and I started to feel like we might just have a worthy successor to Sean Connery finally!So I went and watched Casino Royale as soon as it was released ... the bottom line is that my suspicions were confirmed in the first minutes of the movie. Daniel Craig has completed the circle that Sean Connery left open and I can finally let out a sigh of relief when I say that James Bond has come home to this fan once again.I do not want to get into plot lines or areas of the story but suffice it to say that Daniel Craig brings us a dark, gritty, believable character with no less heart or humanity. He is a Bond with a steely gaze, a man who means business, a character with enough mongrel and rough edges to get the kind of jobs done that only men of that nature can. The buffoonery of previous Bonds is gone but the great action remains and nobody is more pleased than I to have this DVD in my Bond collection which only consists of the Sean Connery Bond Box sets and now this.For producers or movie makers with Bond in mind - take what you have done with Casino Royale and Daniel Craig and don't let it slip through your fingers.CASINO ROYALE is superb!
summary: A long awaited return to CLASSIC BOND!

reviewText: I loved the Bond franchise into my early 20's but it seemed like the plots/brushes with death/stunts became complete farce. Rather than Austin Powers spoofing Bond, it seems like later Bond films were spoofing earlier ones.Not so with Casino Royale. My wife described it best when she called Daniel Craig's incarnation of Bond, and the story itself, as "gritty." If a Bond movie could be described as "dark," Casino Royale would fit that description.Noticeably absent from this movie are the laughable escapes from confinement/death and the cliche one-liners. Craig's Bond is an amazing fighter and cold, hard killer, much like Jason Bourne (Bourne Identity & Supremacy) and relies little on gadgets. The only weapons I recall him using were a knife and a handgun w/a silencer. This movie was carried by the characters, not the machines (though there were some sweet cars in it.)Of course James is still a ladies' man. He wouldn't be Bond if he weren't. But there's an all-business, cold quality to his romantic encounters. Like the Bond girls in the previous movies, 007 uses sex first as a tool and second for pleasure.All in all, Casino Royale might be the best Bond movie of the last 30 years. It certainly is in the top 5 of the entire franchise.

reviewText: Were this a Moore or a Brosnan Bond film, the first chase scene would've had Bond matching the parkour freejumper move for acrobatic move.  He's a trained ninja diplomat assassin secret agent, you see; he's good at everything.  Freejumper vaults himself up and over a bit of drywall; certainly the best in Her Majesty's Secret Service can do the same.Instead, Craig bulldozes through the drywall.And, for an encore, the rest of the movie.Even the great Saint Connery was guilty of managing to kill at least one henchman with every single shot even at a dead run (I think that was /Dr. No/).  Craig?  Well, he shoots a lot but generally his only one-shot kills were either cheap shots (mook rounds a corner, hello gun, bang) or taking advantage of the environment (gas tanks, gas bags, anything explodey).Well, we -could- have the supergiant MI6 database of everyone's ever movements track down the bad guy... or Craig could just use people's cellphones in something approximating real spycraft.  Half-monk, half-hitman, all highly-trained thug who's been taught to stand up when ladies leave the table.  Everything a true Bond should be.

reviewText: "Casino Royale" was Ian Fleming's first James Bond novel. It was the only one to which the rights were not initially acquired by Cubby Broccoli, hence the previous send-up, starring David Niven, with music by Herb Alpert rather than John Barry. This has now been rectified.Like the more recent Bourne films, derived from books written when there still existed a Soviet Union and a Cold War (for which Judi Dench's wonderful M pines), the plot has to change to accommodate the new realities - and the new political correctness (the CIA's Felix Leiter is, er, darker). Nevertheless, the film is quite remarkably faithful to the book, including the book's (not the film's) last four words (which I won't repeat as it's a part-spoiler) and the book's refreshing absence of absurd gadgetry. Even the torture scene is the same (except for the rope in place of carpet beater (ouch!)).There are echoes of the earlier (in order of filming, not Bond chronology) films - he wins a vintage Aston Martin, although the Aston doesn't appear until "Goldfinger", and he makes a crack to the Treasury girl along the lines of Money Penny (who doesn't appear). It has added the standard current quota of high-adrenalin action, with the characters manifesting physical abilities, resilience and imperviousness to damage bordering on (and frequently transgressing into) the superhuman. But I wish someone would learn that, when you fire a bullet into a tank of inflammable liquid or pressurized gas, it does NOT burst into an instant fireball!And the new James Bond? Very good, but in a solid, "realistic" way. Somehow I can't imagine this one being a jolly cricket- and rugger-playing/public school/Oxbridge chap of the type beloved (still) by the British Establishment, the sort of spiffing chaps who ran the British Secret Service in Fleming's day. Moreover, he doesn't deliver the constant stream of glib one-liners (ditto the Bond of the books, of course).And herein perhaps lies the problem. The formula has been changed. The old Bond films, especially the Roger Moore ones, were really tongue-in-cheek, droll comedies masquerading slightly as action films. They thus differentiated themselves in the cinema marketplace. However, with this new style, they are really no different from the rest of the action/thriller pack, such as the Bourne films. Does this successful rejuvenation of a slightly jaded franchise actually represent its eventual demise? We can only wait and see.
summary: Good, but the end of the road for Bond?

reviewText: I love the entire James Bond franchise of movies and I was not disappointed when I saw "Casino Royale" at the theatres. Daniel Craig was born to play Bond. He has everything a James Bond should have: style, grace, elegance, sex appeal, wittiness, and so much more. "Casino Royale" also has evrything a James Bond film should have: great villins, sexy leading ladies, action packed sequences, good script, and a wonderful ending. It was also no surprise that "Casino Royale" became the biggest money-making Bond film, smashing boxoffice records worldwide. More than any other Bond film we really see the other side that was always lacking in most Bond portrayals in that we see a human side to Bond. This is evident when Bond deals with the death of one of his leading ladies. It is very heartbreaking and the audience becomes instantly warmed to Daniel's performance. I would say "Casino Royale" is the best Bond film ever. From a power-packed opening to an exciting finale, "Casino Royale" will please the most Bond enthusiasts. The DVD has many bonuses including interviews, trailers, and so much more. However, buy the DVD for the film itself: it outshines all other James Bond films. The filmakers should be proud!
summary: "Now This Is A Good James Bond Film"

reviewText: Daniel Craig takes the reins from Pierce Brosman in this classic Ian Fleming story.  Unlike previous Bond films, this story shows how Bond got his OO status and the trials he had to endure to learn the one important lesson: trust no one.Craig is dynamic as Bond and shows how the British assassin is suppose to be portrayed.  Sean Connery will always be the best but I can't think of a more worthy successor than Craig.  The only other actor who portrayed the British agent correctly was Timothy Dalton.  Brosman was okay and Moore portrayed Bond too much as a comedian.I love the way that Bond is portrayed as a vulnerable human being who is just as likely as anyone else to be fooled by love.  But he also shows that when all is said and done, he can be efficiently ruthless against his foes and will do just about anything to get the job done.  Now that is someone you want on your side (well, most of the time!).

reviewText: CASINO ROYALE is easily one of the best James Bond movies ever made.Not since Sean Connery has an actor boldly stepped into the role to put his personal stamp on it, bringing both charisma and brute force at the same time.  For all the Internet belly-aching about choosing Daniel Craig for 007, this has to be a major triumph for him.(Lazenby only did one.  Roger Moore took three films to establish himself.  Timothy Dalton never found Bond's sense of humor.  Pierce Brosnan also had an impressive debut...but then the stories ran dry after that).Everything worked in CASINO ROYALE for me and I've been a Bond fan for my entire life.I reread the original novel last week and appreciated how much of the story appeared in the film (for a change!), as well as the screenwriters' enhancements and developments.  An excellent job of adaption!Eva Green, who was so smokin' hot in THE DREAMERS, is much more than the usual eye candy.  The humor was restrained but pointed ("Your name is Stephanie Broadchest" is a great line) and the action close-quartered and tough.I plan on seeing it again and will definitely add it to my 007 DVD collection when it comes out.Bond blasts his way into the 21st Century!

reviewText: The Bond film world is made up of 20 or more movies and at least 6 different Bonds (including comic-actor Niven) 7 including the new Bond (Craig). Some people have a nerve to call Craig the greatest Bond, these people may not be fans of or may have missed the 22 previous films (yes I consider the original Casino Royale and NSNA as Bond films). Craig has been miscasted as Bond in my opinion. He doesn't fit or act the bill and the character has been reinvented in a negative less fantastic or cinematic fashion, even to say catering to a different crowd. This James Bond is even to say "americanized" and "overtly-mortalized" in some ways. I would conclude that if Albert Broccoli or Fleming were alive, they would not be happy with this portrayal of James Bond because it is too different in spirit, by comparison of all previous Bonds of old. Some claim that this film follows the Bond of the book more closely because it is more realistic or blunt. I say no it doesn't because it doesn't get the Bond, spirit or time period correct so what is the point. Bond has always been classy testosterone fueled romantic escapism. This Bond turns that idea of Bond on its head. I can easily say that this is the least entertaining Bond film. Not a bad movie by general movie standards, just a bad Bond movie by Bond movie standards laid down by the pioneers of series. Bond movies were what they were, many classic and entertaining films. All the previous actors who played Bond in the past fit the Bond mold well. Sadly I can't say the same about this, for Daniel Craig is the only one in my opinion who doesn't fit the character. How can someone say that Craig is the best James Bond in the franchises history? Well they must have a different idea for the character, Where Bond isn't great looking, debonair, suave, classy, witty etc.. Bond is now a guy who is just going through the motions and he doesn't seem like a happy guy, and is indeed very flawed. Is this the guy that everyman wishes he was and every woman wishes she was with. Sorry I'd rather be Brosnan, Moore, Connery, Dalton or even Lazenby over Craig any day. Craig's Bond isn't likable and he was seen driving a Ford here?? Beyond those flaws the movie lacks interesting story, villians and the action scenes are few and they concentrate more on the graphic "realistic" aspect of violence. Who ever watched a James Bond movie for the realistic aspect of violence? Then again this film was taking Q's more from action films like the Bourne series or police thrillers, not James Bond movies, because the total reivention of the character and movies is apparent. Speaking of Q, he is sadly missed, and its sad that they have thrown things like gadgets and moneypenny out the window. The comic and several other escapists elements of James Bond were one of its good enjoyable qualities. Bond is now just a miscasted and overtly serious drag. It should have never been reinvented as a DRAMA, it has turned pathetic. The worst Bond film ever hands down, depending on your taste and knowledge of the series. This reivention of the James Bond series is certainly an acquired taste which I will not choose to acquire.
summary: Not a terrible movie but not a good Bond movie.- Miscast Bond !

reviewText: Casino Royale hasn't got it. No silly villains, no stupid plot, or silliness that makes you cringe. No sappy dialogue, or poor fight scenes. No more Bond that girls have to drag guys to see.Forget those other guys. Daniel Craig IS James Bond. He's the guy Ian Fleming had in mind when he conceived the character. Craig is not pretty boy cute, and doesn't act like he's in a comedy. Craig takes control of Bond, and makes him HIS Bond. I pity anyone that assumes the character when Daniel Craig is done with him.The movie is well written and suspenseful. You won't want to hit pause before it's over. There's simply no slow parts good for breaks. The action is first rate. Of course there are women!

reviewText: This is how "Casino Royale" should have happened.(M and Bond are at Alex Dimitrios' beach villa after he prevented the plane bombing)M: Bond, thanks to you, you have prevented the bombing of the Skyfleet airliner and LeChiffre has lost all his money, including millions of dollars in terrorist funding. And now we know exactly where he is and when and where he's going to be.Bond: Great, let's go arrest him immediately then, shall we?M: Not yet. In order to recoup his clients' money, LeChiffre is staging a high stakes poker tournament at the Casino Royale in Montenegro. We need you to compete in the tournament and prevent LeChiffre from winning.Bond: So let me get this straight, you want me to play cards against this guy?M: Yes.Bond: Okay...is the tournament going to be rigged in our favor?M: No, you MUST win fair & square. And if he wins, then we'll have DIRECTLY financed international terrorism!Bond: I don't understand, we know he's guilty, do we not?M: Yes.Bond: Does the poker tournament make him more guilty or something?M: No, but if he loses, he'll be completely out of money and desperate for protection against his creditors and terrorist clients, and have no choice but to come to us and tell us everything he knows.Bond: But you just said the reason for LeChiffre's poker tournament is because he's completely out of money now. Is he not? I don't understand why we should do this if it proves nothing and could potentially give LeChiffre back his power if he wins.M: Listen to me, you'll going to Montenegro. We'll send Vesper along to help you, a woman who does not know how to defend herself and who also never had a thorough background check done on her. And while you're there, African warlords are going to try and kill you both. If you kill them, don't worry, because we'll stuff the dead bodies in someone's car and frame him for murder. And if LeChiffre tries to poison you, we'll have an expensive car waiting outside for you with a defibrillator. And after you win the tournament, you should try to avoid getting captured by LeChiffre, for he has a penchant for smashing his male victim's testicles. And hopefully no one will kill LeChiffre, because if he dies we'll be right to where we started...except for your testicles.Bond: Forgive me ma'am, but this sounds like a horrible idea.M: Fine! We'll do it the boring way.(Bond and a squad of MI-6 agents arrest LeChiffre and bring him back to England)LeChiffre: I'll never tell you anything! NEVER!Bond: Do you really want to go back out there and be sliced and diced by your clients?LeChiffre: Okay fine, here's what I know.By the way, the American, German, and British blu-rays are censored. The American release of "Casino Royale" censored a lot of violence throughout the film. The total cuts amount to a few frames per violent scene, adding up to about 30 seconds. Among the censored scenes are the bathroom fight between Bond and the contact and the stairwell fight between Bond and the African warlords. The UK version cut some of the torture scene and the German version cuts a scene where the plane bomber snaps a guy's neck. I recommend buying the Australian, Dutch, French, Hong Kong, Japanese, Russian, and Scandinavian Blu-rays and DVDs.*update: Apparently, there's been a British re-release of "Casino Royale" with a BBFC rating of 15 and it contains the uncut version of the film.

reviewText: Casino Royale is an excellent "rebirth" for the James Bond series, and fans won't be disappointed with the movie.  The movie kicks off with Bond acquiring his "OO" license in a great opening sequence filmed in black and white.  After chasing rogue bombmakers and preventing a terrorist attack at Miami-Dade Airport, Bond finds himself in Montenegro at Casino Royale for a high-stakes poker game organized by Le Chiffre, a financier for the world's terrorists.  Bond must win the game and stop Le Chiffre, or else MI6 will have directly funded terrorism.  Casino Royale serves as the perfect introduction for the new OO7, Daniel Craig.  The movie offers plenty of action, including the high-wire chase through a construction site  and Bond's fight to stop a bomb going off in the Miami airport among several others, but maybe most importantly, it is more realistic, more gritty.  The last few Brosnan Bonds used too many gadgets and CGI, but Casino Royale gets back to basics and overall it leads to a better movie.  Bond fans will not be disappointed, Casino Royale goes back to the tried and true formula that the early Connery films used, a secret agent who must rely on himself to get the job done, no gadgets or gimmicks.When Daniel Craig was announced as the next OO7, there was an uproar by many fans who disapproved of the selection.  But in his first role as Bond, Craig shines as the newly-appointed secret agent with a license to kill.  Since it is the "first" introduction to the character, Craig's Bond is allowed to grow as a character, and we see what he becomes in later movies.  All in all, Craig has done a great job giving Bond his tough edge back, and it will be interesting to see how he continues to develop in the next films.  Eva Green is a different breed of Bond girl as Vesper Lynd, the treasury reprsentative who loathes Bond at first but comes to warm to him as she learns more about him and what's he capable of.  Green is very good in the part and provides a perfect challenge for Bond.  Mads Mikkelsen is also good as Le Chiffre, a financier who takes care of terrorists' money and puts together the high-stakes game at Casino Royale.  Judi Dench returns as M, Bond's superior who is pushed to her limit by her agent's actions.  In a very cool but small part, Jeffrey Wright plays Felix Leiter, Bond's CIA equal who finds himself at the poker table.  Also, Giancarlo Giannini plays Mathis, Bond's contact in Montenegro who may or may not be on his side.  Overall, a great cast for Bond 21.The 2-disc DVD is a pretty good package for fans of the movie, but don't be surprised to see another edition released within the year.  It features a beautiful widescreen presentation on Disc 1 and saves all the special features for Disc 2.  "Becoming Bond" is a 26-minute featurette that shows the process Daniel Craig went through to become James Bond from the announcement all the way through filming.  "James Bond: For Real" details all the stunt work that went into making Casino Royale, and really makes you appreciate the stunts now that you've seen how they did them.  "Bond Girls are Forever" is a 47-minute documentary hosted by The Living Daylight's Maryam d'Abo about the history of the Bond girls that has interviews with several, including Ursulla Andress and Halle Berry.  Lastly there is Chris Cornell's music video for "You Know My Name," one of the best Bond songs that I can remember.  While the extras are good, it feels like a lot more could have been done, so maybe hold out for a future release.  With the movie and the features, this DVD is can't miss.  Check out Casino Royale!
summary: A rebirth for Bond, excellent 2-disc set

reviewText: I've never been a fan of James Bond. Probably, because I grew up with Pierce Brosnan as 007 and he sucked. I decide to give the series another shot, not because of Bond, but rather Daniel Craig. I have been a fan of Craig's for some time, having seen several of the films from overseas. I knew then that he would be a huge action star and now he's 007. As for my first Bond movie, it was pretty good. Craig was fantastic and avoided much of the cliché Bond moments that most of us have come to loath. The film was entertaining, but also pretty predictable and much longer than it needed to be. I was also very unimpressed by the bad guys. I thought Bond villains were supposed to be classic, but these guys were rather forgettable. I'm not in love with the Bond character, but this film did open my eyes a little bit and I probably will check out Quantum of Solace in the near future.

reviewText: CASINO ROYALE is a reboot in the finest sense of the word.  It picks up the slouching James Bond series and not only stands it up straight - it also works it out and beats it until it can do more pushups than Sylvester Stallone on steroids.  After the 20th James Bond screen adventure, DIE ANOTHER DAY, was released in 2002 (forty years after the first 007 thriller, DR. NO), it seemed as though the series could run for a while longer on pure popcorn entertainment, though the dwindling originality and the increasingly stereotypical nature of the films was becoming obvious.  Still, it wasn't clear just how near death the franchise was until CASINO ROYALE.A brief history lesson: in 1961, Ian Fleming, the author of the best-selling James Bond novels, sold the screen rights to his novels to producers Harry Saltzman and Albert R. Broccoli.  There was one novel that Saltzman and Broccoli couldn't get the rights to, however: CASINO ROYALE, the first James Bond novel.  Fleming had sold the rights to that novel years earlier when it was adapted as an episode of the American TV series CLIMAX! (starring Barry Nelson as James Bond, with Peter O'Toole as Le Chiffre!); it was also used as the basis for the insane 1967 spy spoof starring Peter Sellers, Woody Allen, and David Niven as James Bond (yes, all three played James Bond).Flash forward 38 years: Sony now owns the rights to CASINO ROYALE, while MGM owns the rights to all the other Bond books.  Flash forward a few years more: Sony buys MGM, thus giving current Bond producers Michael G. Wilson and Barbara Broccoli the chance to finally adapt the first ever James Bond adventure for the big screen.  Reacting to fan criticism over the more recent Bond adventures' over-the-top "world domination" storylines and ridiculous gadgetry, Wilson and Broccoli decided to take a page from BATMAN BEGINS' book and "reboot" the franchise.  They brought in Paul Haggis, the Academy Award-winning writer of CRASH and MILLION DOLLAR BABY, to co-write the screenplay, and in an extremely controversial move, they released Pierce Brosnan and hired Daniel Craig to play 007.The fan complaints were too numerous to list.  He's blonde!  He looks haggard!  He's not suave, he's just cold!  He's going to be the next George Lazenby!Then they saw the film.CASINO ROYALE isn't a prequel, as it's set in the present, but it is a new beginning for the forty-years-old-plus series.  In CASINO ROYALE, James Bond has just received his Double-O status; to become a Double-O, you must have had to kill two people in the line of duty, as explained in a pre-credits sequence stylishly filmed in black and white.  Bond makes a critical error chasing down a gun-for-hire, and is told by an enraged M. (Judi Dench, reprising her role from Pierce Brosnan's Bond adventures) to stick his head in the sand somewhere.  As we all know, though, James Bond never takes a vacation; instead, he travels to the Bahamas, where he follows the trail of the gun-for-hire - a trail which leads him to Le Chiffre (Mads Mikkelsen), a notorious banker for the world's terrorists.  Bond goes undercover to compete in a high-stakes poker tournament at the "Casino Royale".  His mission: bankrupt Le Chiffre.  If this were Sean Connery, George Lazenby, Roger Moore, Timothy Dalton, or Pierce Brosnan, you'd say "No problem!".  But Daniel Craig's Bond is a far more realistic and human Bond; nothing comes as easy to him as it did to the previous 007s.As a big fan of Ian Fleming's novels - CASINO ROYALE in particular - I had low expectations for this film.  Imagine my surprise when I walked out of the theater and realized that CASINO ROYALE wasn't simply the best Bond film in five years, ten years, twenty years even: it's the best Bond film ever made.  Daniel Craig surpasses even the god of 007 actors, Sean Connery, whom I previously thought was unsurpassable.  Craig has virtually nothing in common with any previous Bond actor, but he is precisely the 007 of Fleming's novels.  He exudes smoldering masculinity, but in a way less egotistic than the previous Bond actors.  His Bond makes errors, as established in a brilliant chase scene at the start of the film; he doesn't always win, and he lets his temper get the best of him far too often.  He's still a master of knockout one-liners, though, and as Le Chiffre remarks during one of the film's more unforgettable sequences, he has taken very good care of his body.Eva Green is the Bond girl, and what an unusual Bond girl she is; attractive in a classy sort of way, wise, and just as intriguing as Bond himself.  Mikkelsen's Le Chiffre is a despicable villain, with a damaged tear duct which frequently leaks blood.  He at first seems like the stereotypical over-the-top bad guy, but by the end of the film he becomes quite a menacing figure.  Giancarlo Giannini plays an amiable Rene Mathis, a character who featured prominently in a few of Fleming's books but makes his first screen appearance here, while Jeffrey Wright plays the first black Felix Leiter, Bond's best friend, who hasn't appeared in a Bond flick since 1987's THE LIVING DAYLIGHTS.  I was never riveted by Judi Dench's M in the Brosnan films, but she truly shines in CASINO ROYALE.Along with exemplary performances from the cast, there's a frankly epic screenplay by Paul Haggis with Neal Purvis & Robert Wade, who've written all the Bond films since THE WORLD IS NOT ENOUGH.  This script is very well-structured, and combines all the successful elements of previous Bond films while remaining down-to-earth; I'd imagine Haggis deserves most of the praise for this.  There's tender romance - yes, folks, real romance, not just your standard 007 sex scenes - laugh-out-loud comedy, and the most thoroughly riveting action sequences I've ever seen.  The script has little in common with the book on which it's based; however, if you've never read one of Fleming's Bond books and want to know what they're like, CASINO ROYALE is the closest thing we've ever seen to Ian Fleming's 007.  Some of the scenes and lines from that book are included, though, especially the infamous "torture scene", which - though considerably more tame in the film version - will still leave most men cringing as they exit the theater.The first time I began to have faith in this film during its controversy-heavy production was when I learned that Martin Campbell was directing it.  Campbell also directed Pierce Brosnan's debut as 007, GOLDENEYE, an utterly superb entry in the series that revitalized the franchise in much the same way that CASINO ROYALE does.  CASINO ROYALE is the stylish, thrilling Bond adventure that I've been dreaming of for years, and that's due in very large part to Campbell's directing.  He likes to use close camera angles, which work well in adding that "human" aspect to the the frequently superhuman character of 007; it feels like we're in the action with Bond, and adds an element of intensity and unpredictability.David Arnold's music is typically loud throughout most of the film.  I've always found the criticism of Arnold's Bond scores to be far too harsh; he mimicks the sound of John Barry's classic scores while adding a dash of his own style, and he does it well.  I'm not quite sure what to make of his music for CASINO ROYALE, though.  A large part of it is your stereotypical James Bond soundtrack - shrill, booming horns with the occasional techno line thrown in for good measure.  However, some of it - namely the love theme for James Bond and Vesper Lynd, Eva Green's character - is truly beautiful, and some of the finest music the series has ever had.  Audioslave's Chris Cornell contributes the film's theme, "You Know My Name".  The title's stupid, and the song's nearly as stupid; it's an odd alternative rock composition that just doesn't belong in the film.  It does work, however, in that it takes your mind off the absurd credits sequence.There's as much in CASINO ROYALE to enrage Bond purists as there is to please them.  For one thing, the film does NOT open with the trademark gunbarrel; instead, a music-less gunbarrel pops up moments before the main title sequence.  To make matters worse, the legendary "James Bond Theme" doesn't pop up until the end credits - because, of course, in this film James Bond is not the suave agent we know and love until that point.  He doesn't say "Bond ... James Bond" until well into the film, and when questioned as to whether he wants his martini shaked or stirred, the irritated new Double-O shoots back, "Does it look like I give a damn?"  And, as if that's not bad enough, neither Q nor Moneypenny are even mentioned.  That's right - no gunbarrel, no "Bond ... James Bond", no theme song, no shaken-not-stirred martinis, no Q, and no Moneypenny.  But you know what?  I couldn't be happier.  That's all perfectly fitting for what's chronologically the first James Bond adventure, and I wouldn't have it any other way.If you loved the intense realism of GOLDENEYE, if you loved the epic love story of ON HER MAJESTY'S SECRET SERVICE, if you loved the non-stop action of DIE ANOTHER DAY, if you loved the grit of LICENCE TO KILL, if you loved the suspense and thrills of FROM RUSSIA WITH LOVE - then this is the film you've been waiting for.  Not since FROM RUSSIA WITH LOVE or perhaps the seemingly ultimate Bond picture, GOLDFINGER, has the series been so grounded in realism, and never before has a Bond film been so intelligent, so fun, and so compellingly-structured.  Daniel Craig is here to stay, and if the producers can come near matching the quality of CASINO ROYALE on BOND 22, then James Bond will continue to return for years to come.

reviewText: "Casino Royale" is an exceptional reboot of the James Bond franchise.After 20 successful Bond films starring five actors in the title role, Daniel Craig takes over in a film that takes place at the very start of his career as a 00 agent. M, played by the masterful Judi Dench, hands him his promotion and his fabled "licence to kill" after a pre-credits mission to collar an MI6 turncoat; the action after the credits are apparently the new Bond's first adventure as 007.It begins with what must be one of the most amazing foot chases in movie history. By the end of that pulse-pounding scene, you'll be ready to acknowledge Craig as a fitting (and admirably fit) Bond. (For anyone who might confuse this film with the 1967 Bond spoof, they're similar in nothing but name.)Let's cut to the chase: Craig is Bond. But he's not reprising Connery, Brosnan or even Roger Moore; this Bond is entirely new, built from the ground up for a new generation of fans. He's edgier, more physical, without using gadgets and gimmickry as a crutch. This Bond is raw and unpolished, reinventing himself as a 00 agent as he goes, developing the character's notorious emotional detachment and ruthless sense of duty as we watch.And if you don't believe a card game can make for a tense movie experience, you haven't seen this film. But there's more than just cards: Casino Royale has its share of car wrecks, explosions, gun fights, seductions, exotic settings, chases and buildings collapsing into the Grand Canal. Just watch it and let this Bond win you over.by Tom Knapp, Rambles.(n e t) editor
summary: A powerful new Bond for the 21st century

reviewText: Movie - 5.0Growing up I was a casual Bond fan, maybe a little more than casual, but not quite die-hard. I appreciated the franchise for its style, sleek atmosphere, British charm, and sex appeal with all those girls. Somewhere down the line my tastes developed into something a little beyond the flash and pizazz that I started to grow weary of. And by the time Pierce Brosnan starred in his final film as Agent 007, I'm afraid to say I was starting to lose interest in the same old formula and presentation. Then came Bond 21, Casino Royale, starring a complete newcomer I'd never even heard of in Daniel Craig. Suffice it to say, Casino Royale is a much needed reboot of the classic character. Not only is there a new actor, but also a new tone that completely rejuvenates the franchise from square one. Here we see Craig portraying Bond as a rookie hotshot who's just earned his Double-O status. He's young, brash, full of energy, and borderline uncontrollable acting on impulse and emotion, though with just enough of that cool, collected debonair most of us are probably accustomed to seeing. However, as many young and overconfident hotshots often realize soon after, there needs to be a lesson of moderation learned. Enter Vesper Lynd who allows us to see a side of Bond that is so much more down-to-earth and actually humanized that one would never have thought possible. But with this being Bond, we certainly can't expect such a happy ending. Soon after their relationship really starts to blossom betrayal ensues and Bond is livid to conclude things the only way he knows best -- with cold, brutal efficiency. To be continued in Quantum of Solace. To really appreciate these movies for their writing I recommend you watch both, not as a movie and its sequel, but two parts of one long and personal narrative. I don't want to spoil the journey Bond makes between here and there, but read both reviews and you'll understand.Video - 4.5From the black and white flashback to the African Rundown to the lush and beautiful landscapes of the Bahamas, Italy, etc., every single frame is full of depth and color vibrancy. Skin textures are very fine and especially detailed with just enough film grain to give it that gritty, atmospheric feel reflected in the films' writing. Contrast and black levels are strong as well during the night and dimly-lit scenes. My favorite shots are from the poker game. Not only is there a great degree of sharpness to the face shots of the players, but the poker chips and various colors of tables, clothes, and drinks really stand out, only adding that Bond-level of material extravagance to the film's overall temperament. While not the most exciting reference scene I would recommend, it's certainly a very good part to watch, though you could easily use any of the overview shots of landscapes or grandiose action sequences as well. On the downside, I did notice a few minor instances of artifacts and debris, especially in the scene where Bond is talking to M in the Bahamas where this inexplicably large speck flashes on the screen, but other than that, everything else looks relatively flawless.Audio - 5.0To this date, Casino Royale remains atop my "loudest movies" list up there with Hellboy II, Fight Club, and The Bourne Ultimatum. The Dolby TrueHD 5.1 track here is as amazing as the video transfer. From the very get-go in the opening flashback scene we're surrounded in this pool of sound filled with tough, gut-thumping effects and immersed in a masterful soundtrack by David Arnold. I wanna' say that in addition to the very active sound field, I'm especially enamored with how well the music is separated and integrated evenly through each speaker. With that said, directionality and dynamics are exuberantly punctuated when the more hellish scenes with gunfire and crashing objects are on screen. LFEs, particularly through the music, will rock your room, if not your house. Explosions, crumbling environments, and all the sort have a great depth of bass. Dialogue (a large majority of the film) is crisp with no disparities at any point in the film, making for yet another title of reference quality. No-brainer demo material would be either the African Rundown at the beginning of the movie or the Collapsing Palazzo at the end.Extras - 5.0Owning the initial release from '07, I gladly double-dipped for this Collector's Edition when hearing there would be a separate BD containing many new special features. Of most interest were the vignettes talking about the history and stigma that were carried by this particular novel, how the rights remained in limbo for so long, and how it all came about in the first place up to where the idea of the movie was reconceived as the new starting point for the franchise. I have to say, I was amazed at just how complicated the entire ordeal turned out. In addition, there are also many, many other features that cover production design, shooting logistics, cast and crew interviews, and a somewhat brief look back on the iconography of Bond up to this newest installment. Time-wise, I'm pretty sure there are at least three plus hours of Extras between the new and old stuff from the previous release, of which most are in HD. Of course, most of this material is covered in the equally informative commentary if you don't mind watching the movie again. Big thanks to Sony for giving this fine film the set of extras it deserves.Overall - 5.0So yeah, Bond was starting to become stagnant around the end of the Brosnan era for me. And of all the novels to be filmed, the very first, albeit troubled, one in Casino Royale was picked. Not only did it revitalize the franchise by taking things back to basics and creating a darker, grittier atmosphere, but it did so in such stunning fashion thanks in huge part to the superb effort given by Daniel Craig and veteran Bond director Martin Campbell. A wonderfully written, photographed, and coordinated film, Casino Royale along with its direct sequel Quantum of Solace, which for all intents and purposes is just the third act of a very long film (again, read the review for my interpretation), are currently my top action/drama/spy/thriller titles of all-time. Presented with reference A/V specs by Sony and a long-awaited, very thorough, package of special features, this Collector's Edition is a must own piece of film-making for any Bond fan or movie aficionado alike.

reviewText: Albert Broccoli and Harry Saltzman first brought James Bond to the cinema in Dr. No (1962).  In the years that followed, with one exception, the two men adapted all of Ian Fleming's full length Bond novels into motion pictures.  Now over forty years later, that omission in addressed, as Daniel Craig makes his debut as Bond, the MI6 agent, licensed to kill in Casino Royale, based on Fleming's very first Bond novel, originally published in 1953.Each actor that assumes the role of Bond, is subjected to immense scrutiny and criticism.  Being fair haired, and looking nothing like past Bonds, is a superficial gripe against Craig.  What is hard to swallow is that someone as old as Craig (38), is supposed to be a newcomer to the double O classification.  Craig, comes to the role of Bond, looking tougher and more weathered, than Pierce Bronsnan did leaving it at age 49.  Craig being nervous about killing is a joke.  This Bond doesn't need any of Q Branch's gadgets, he will just shoot you dead, or snap your neck with his bare hands.In the film's first action sequence Bond engages in what is probably the most physically challenging, one on one, on foot pursuit in the history of the franchise.  The deadly serious pursuit of Mollaka (Stebastien Foucan), on and across the crane arms is so demanding, that no previous Bond would have been physically capable of attempting it.  Craig is overpoweringly masculine, and dominates the screen wherever the setting, be it Madagascar, the Bahamas, Montenegro, or Venice.The key element from Fleming's original story remains the same (except that the original game was baccarat), but how plausible is it that in 2006 an international criminal, and the British and American governments, would do battle at a poker table?  With the explosion in popularity of Texas hold 'em tournaments on television, watching the play here is pretty boring, regardless of how much the drama is forced.  Gambling aside, Casino Royale works well enough.  Head villain Le Chiffre (Mads Mikkelsen), goes through the movie with a sour expression, failing at every turn, and besides being a vicious ball slapper, doesn't really distinguish himself as a memorable villain.The Bond women are also the subject of scrutiny.  The exotically beautiful Caterina Murino makes a brief appearance in a sacrificial role.  The casting of Vesper Lynd is critical, as like the Contessa Teresa (Tracy) Di Vicenzo, in `On Her Majesty's Secret Service', this is a woman who captures Bond heart.  While Diana Rigg was an actress with considerable stature, it might be difficult to say the same for Eva Green (The Golden Compass), who apparently was a late selection to play Lynd.  While her performance is serviceable, whether she was the ideal choice is a very open question.  Some may not question what happens between Lynd and Bond, because the new Bond is such an unknown.The remake of Bond into a harder edged character, was an opportunity for the producers to take the character into the R rated category.  Surely teens have many others they relate to more than a middle aged, British spy, fighting the last war?  Instead Bond remains in the PG-13 cage.  The finale in a collapsing building in Venice is nicely done, and at the end of the mission, with M (Judi Dench) providing a little TLC, all the pieces have fallen in place, and Bond ends the film uttering his most famous line.  It has flaws, but Casino Royale is quite nicely done.The 2 disc version is an intermediate release, without the typically comprehensive Bondian special features.  Maryam d'Abo (The Living Daylights) has taken up being a `Bond Girl' as a cause, and an updated version of her documentary `Bond Girls Are Forever' (48 minutes) is included.  The somewhat curious selection does help pad the content, that also includes the featurettes 'Becoming Bond' (26 minutes), 'James Bond: For Real' (23 minutes), and Chris Cornell's music video for 'You Know My Name'.  The two disc version has since been surpassed by the upgraded blu-ray version, which has commentary tracks, and additional extras.
summary: the 'new' Bond . . . back to the blunt instrument days with Daniel Craig . . .

reviewText: As one of the only 12 people who was genuinely delighted at Daniel Craig's casting a year ago, I must admit I was more than a little worried about Casino Royale. Not the kind of paranoia that those newcomers who'd never experience the changing of the guard the series goes through every decade or the staggeringly venomous hate-mongering of the more fanatical Brosnan fans who felt compelled to start libellous hate-sites, though. After all those months of arguing that he was the perfect choice for the role (especially after some of the more moronic suggestions), was I setting myself up for a fall if he turned in a disappointing performance? Similarly there was the film itself. While the producers were making all the right noises about going back to basics, they'd done exactly the same with Licence To Kill and chickened out to deliver a sub-Roger Moore effort with Wayne Newton as a comedy relief villain, inept ninjas, pointless gadgets, laughable violence and monster truck stunts. Too often in the past the franchise had been over-reliant on the goodwill generated by the earlier films, rehashing earlier vehicles to decreasing returns secure in the knowledge that the audience would turn up anyway. Take away the Bond brand, and too many post-OHMSS entries simply wouldn't have stood up to scrutiny in the marketplace on their own merits: Bond had become a tradition, a ritual like going home for the holidays that you knew was never going to be as good as it was when you were a kid but which you still went through out of a mixture of hope and obligation.I needn't have worried. Not only is it the best Bond film in 37 years, it's as if the Roger Moore and Pierce Brosnan years never happened. After Brosnan's surprisingly lazy and slightly seedy turn in DAD, Craig delivers the most physical Bond since Lazenby, but this time matched by the acting chops to make the most of the best script the series has had in decades - at once plot and character led - as the rookie blunt instrument bulldozes his way through his mission until emotional awakening and betrayal starts to finesse him into the Bond we knew from the Connery days. Brosnan never could have delivered this kind of performance, either physically or emotionally, and, truth be told, neither could Connery in his prime: Craig is the first one to convince you that he's not a movie star or an actor but that he really IS James Bond.The updating of the plot from the Cold War era to a post 9/11 world works surprisingly well, with the first act managing to provide a convincing motive for the high stakes poker game centrepiece while also providing a couple of superb action scenes that don't become too absurd and serve the plot in a series where in the past the plot was too often an excuse for the action. The much-criticised change from baccarat to poker is a smart one too. Where Baccarat is purely a game of luck (as Fleming himself found out when he went bust in three hands trying out the novel's premise on a Nazi spy), poker actually involves both strategy and psychology, making for more satisfying drama and tension.There is, sadly, one concession to gadgetry that veers into the absurd - c'mon, who keeps a defibrillator in their glove compartment? - and is an unwelcome reminder of the days when old Roge would get out of a scrape with his buzz saw wristwatch or his projectile dart cufflinks thanks to lazy writing, but elsewhere it settles for using existing technology (most of it manufactured by Sony for some reason that escapes me) rather than veering into total fantasy. And it's good to see a Bond who needs hospitalisation after the villain goes Quasimodo on his nuts with a bell rope. The film's final sequence promises one helluva follow-up, and one can only hope the producers don't lose their nerve and throw it all away the way they did with Diamonds Are Forever. The real James Bond is indeed back.Extras-wise the 2-disc DVD is a disappointment by the standards of the previous EON entries, although there is reportedly a more elaborate special edition planned in the future.

reviewText: The film has already got positive reviews from many critics, most of which are more or less based on the film's new James Bond image. We must give due credit to Daniel Craig for reinventing Bond, making him a tougher and meaner super-spy. Of course some people just don't want re-inventing it, but even they would admit Bond series needed something refreshing. At least Martin Campbell did it successfully, but totally in a different way from in `GoldenEye.'Many reviewers have rightly pointed out the differences of the newer Bond. You will notice (and perhaps regret) the absence of gadgets (and Q or R) in the film, but actually the most notable one is that they set the plot in the post 9/11 era. The story is about the earliest days of 007, but the changed setting lends considerable power to the intense actions, some of which are more violent than you expect. And there is one torture scene.`Casino Royale' contains three big action sequences, and they are all really thrilling ones - the first one at the construction site includes lots of eye-popping stunts - but as I said, there is something dark and serious undertone in some of them. While watching Pierce Brosnan's Bond (which I like), I never took anything seriously. This cannot be said about `Casino Royale' where one long action sequence takes place at airport.Not that the film is free from escapism, In fact the main story involves a silly idea about the confrontation between a terrorist banker and a British agent at a card table, and the latter being backed up by the government's money! Eva Green plays Vesper who is in charge of the money, but in spite of the beauty of Ms Green Bond's romance with her is the least effective in the film.`Casino Royale' marks the successful return of James Bond with Daniel Craig in character, but not all fans would love it. But that happened many times before, and will in the future. It's destiny of popular series. The point is `Casino Royale' played for high stakes by creating a darker image of most famous spy. Probably whether or not the filmmakers will ultimately keep on doing that depends on the results at the box-office. But anyway I bought a ticket, and enjoyed the film pretty much.
summary: James Bond Reinvented: No Gadgets, More Actions, and Spy with a Dark Side

reviewText: There was a reason this film was made: Barb Broccoli & Michael Wilson knew that Die Another Day was the final straw for the series becoming too gimmicky & grandiose. The series had become too reliant on gadgetry, visual FX, and especially sex and it needed to stop. Perhaps worst of all, the character had become too much of an international, womanizing playboy, too jovial for what Ian Fleming had originally thought the character should be.Bond is therefore forced to rely more on his military training, his intelligence, investigative skills and his wits to complete his mission. He also has to rely on his competitive edge, especially during the lengthy poker match. Instead of relying on the legendary ability of the character to win in the end, Bond really has to work for his victory. That alone makes this film worth repeated viewings.Plus, there's still tons of incredible stunts, explosions, bullets, and Bond killing anyone who gets in his way. And just for the record, I believe, without a doubt, that this film has the absolute BEST finale of the entire series!
summary: A brilliant way to re-envision the series!! BRAVO!!!

reviewText: I admit that I wasn't quite sure what to expect when I first watched CASINO ROYALE. I had eagerly been looking forward to this James Bond movie because it was Ian Fleming's first novel starring Bond. The novel had been adapted to the screen before, but only as a comedy parody and a lukewarm made-for-television movie. This version of CASINO ROYALE was to be an "official" part of the James Bond cinematic canon. It was going to be the movie that explained the beginnings of James Bond's career as Britain's top secret agent. Production and filming began and then suddenly stopped. The studios decided that to keep the James Bond franchise viable they needed a new approach. So, they fired Pierce Brosnan. They fired some of the screenwriters and sent the script Paul Haggis for a rewrite because the film wasn't dark enough.Oh, and did I mention they fired Pierce Brosnan? Brosnan was the best actor to portray James Bond since Sean Connery originally played the character. In fact, not so long ago, Brosnan's portrayal of James Bond saved the franchise from total ruin and in doing so also prevented a certain film studio from going bankrupt. Brosnan was not only the right man for the role, he was the perfect man for the role. Had he not been fired and had he been willing (which he probably would have) he could have played James Bond for another two or three pictures. He should have played Bond for a few more movies. Instead, the filmmakers decided to start virtually from scratch. Pierce Brosnan was fired and Daniel Craig was eventually hired in his place.In the merrie ole land of England, when the news was released, James Bond fans in Britain went nuts. Protests were held and letters were written. Craig couldn't be Bond. Craig is average height, but traditionally Bond has been portrayed as being tall. Also, Craig has blond hair and Bond is supposed to have dark hair. The thing I found most interesting about the choice is that Craig is virtually an unknown actor in the United States. Outside of his performance in the artsy film LAYER CAKE no one in the U.S. had ever heard of Craig before he was announced as the next James Bond. Considering the tone of CASINO ROYALE, this is strange because CASINO ROYALE is the most Americanized of all James Bond pictures even though Bond is a very British character (for example, the high stakes game of gambling that is central to the film's plot revolves around Texas Hold `Em. You can't get any more Americanized than that). I guess the filmmakers felt they were offending their core audience enough the way it was and didn't want to turn them totally off by hiring someone like Brad Pitt or Matt Damon.In CASINO ROYALE, the audience witnesses James Bond's first two assassinations; the two killings that allow him the double zero and validate his license to kill. This opening sequence is followed by the usual opening credits song and like half the Bond movies that have ever been made, it was far too long. We next find Bond racing through the streets and leaping from buildings like Superman somewhere in Africa. The chase and the ensuing events which follow cause an international controversy and thanks to a camera-phone Bond finds himself on the cover of newspapers. He's taken off duty for a while and M (Judy Dench) tells him to take a vacation. He does, but uses the opportunity to do some spying on his spare time. He stalks a businessman who bleeds out of eyes and who seems to be supplementing his gun-running operation by playing in high stakes poker games. Bond is selected to play in the next high-stakes game that the villain, Le Chiffre (Mads Mikkelsen) is playing in. The game takes place in Monte Carlo and Bond is escorted to the event by the beautiful and intelligent Vesper Lynd (Eva Green) whom is being sent to insure that the millions of dollars in investment aren't wasted in vain. There is a connection between Lynd and Bond, but it doesn't begin romantically. It begins as business, turns to friendship, and then into love. James Bond in love? Sad, but true. I guess the point of this relationship is to illustrate why Bond never settles down and became a playboy and womanizer. Throw in a bit of Aston Martin driving scenes, some torture, and a couple of betrayals to make things complete.Overall, CASINO ROYALE turned out to be what I expected: a great action movie, a good spy film, and just a decent James Bond picture. Craig is better in the role than I expected him to be. He's a good actor and even though he is the "new, re-imagined" James Bond, he does a good job of staying true to the legacy bestowed to him while making it fresh and new. Eva Green is full of a feminine mystique that many Bond girls in the past have lacked. Her character, Vesper Lynd, isn't just beautiful and brainy; she's also independent, compassionate, and wise. Unlike the models and actresses who have played Bond girls before, Lynd comes off as being more of a girl-next-door than a supermodel. Judi Dench returns to her role as M and like many of the films she acts in, she steals every scene she is in. Mads Mikkelsen has played several oddballs and freaks in his career and fits well into the role of the eerie and sinister Le Chiffre. Finally, Jeffery Wright isn't on screen much, but he's great as Bond's American CIA counterpart Felix Leiter.Despite dragging in several parts, CASINO ROYALE has a lot of action. There's not quite as much as one would expect from a Bond picture, but this isn't a typical Bond picture. Also missing from the picture are any gadgets and the presence of inventor extraordinaire, Q. There are no gadgets in this movie.Overall, I enjoyed CASINO ROYALE. It felt very much like a typical American spy-thriller, which is what I found most interesting about the picture. As I mentioned before, Bond is a very British character, but in CASINO ROYALE he comes off as being more like a typical American anti-hero. The filmmakers set out to re-vamp the James Bond franchise. They have succeeded. I just hope that in the next film Bond gets back to his British roots.
summary: It's Bond, James Bond, But American Style

reviewText: Usually, when everybody else says the same thing about a movie, I'm going to agree.  Plus, they're right anyway.  :DHere's my problem:  No DTS audio.  This came as a surprise given how all the previous Bond films came out on DTS or were remastered in DTS and we all paid a pretty penny to purchase those.  Justifiably so, may I add.  They're great.  But I digress.The lack of DTS in this release means one of two things:1.  Only Blu-Ray discs will get such high treatment from now on.  Consider this a slap in the face to all of us who bought into DVD and DTS equipment, as both were sold as being high-end modern technology...2.  Another DVD "ultimate" set will come out with this movie in DTS, the way it ought to be...  this isn't an atypical ploy amongst movie companies to fleece every penny and more from their respective fanbases.I'm betting on #2 because, with yet another dual format duel with the high-def DVD standard, most people will refuse to upgrade until the whiny little dingdongs make up their minds and have one become THE standard.  Until then, all the movie companies will want to play games like this.So I say "Rent this movie until the full fledged 'Ultimate' edition comes out, which will have all the sound and visual enhancements and buy it then."There is no reason why a movie made so recently can't include a DTS sound track.  Especially a 2-disc set.Note to the Bond movie makers:  Keep Daniel Craig, keep the serious streak, you've done just about everything right with this movie and after 4 miserable, throwaway clunkers, it's really great to really have Bond back.  I may even buy the re-release with the DTS track and 28 hours of extra footage... but please have consideration; money doesn't stretch as far these days.
summary: Awesome movie; the lack of a DTS sound track means one of two things:
